however, neither party has fully confronted the harsh realities of the situation at hand.
there is a high probability of failure attributed to ecological factors.
from a political perspective, the chaco colonization may be viewed as a means to mitigate existing land disputes in the east, delay addressing issues related to population control, sustain a temporary façade of advancement and hope, and provide a significant national initiative to rally public backing.
the practical considerations regarding the region's carrying capacity may not hold much sway against the political benefits outlined above.
the components of a pragmatic approach for paraguay would likely align closely with those identified for ecuador.
in both scenarios, the basic estimation of carrying capacity has effectively highlighted the severity of the situation.
despite their simplicity and roughness, the deductions drawn from these calculations are robust, as a deliberate overestimation was adopted when assessing carrying capacity.
adding more sophisticated econometric models for policy purposes would offer little value beyond what is already evident.
what is fundamentally lacking is not greater precision in data but the political determination to acknowledge the ecological rationale behind historically low population densities, whether in the ecuadorian amazon or the paraguayan chaco, and to adjust human populations accordingly.
the variability of human carrying capacity does not negate the significant and conflicting challenges expected in both cases over the next generation.
additionally, the impracticality of a "hong kong solution" – involving importing food for a densely populated area by exporting manufactured goods and financial services – is evident for both the ecuadorian amazon and the paraguayan chaco, particularly due to their remote locations.
the intention is not to suggest that carrying capacity is exclusively pertinent to developing nations.
the united states of america, had it considered carrying capacity, might not have grown so perilously reliant on dwindling petroleum resources from foreign countries.
if the us struggles to implement a modest gasoline tax to curb unsustainable consumption, is it fair to assume that paraguay and ecuador can effectively manage their populations?
while these measures may seem implausible politically in the near term, neglecting them is unfeasible from a biophysical standpoint in the long term, even within a timeframe as short as twenty-five years.
it is important to acknowledge the limitations of using either total family income or family income per capita.
as highlighted by wood and carvalho, larger households typically have higher total incomes due to more earners, yet lower incomes per household member.
grouping households by income per capita reveals greater differentials in fertility and income inequality compared to grouping based on total household income.
both categories are distinct concepts, neither inherently biased.
it is crucial to understand their definitions and refrain from conflating them when making comparisons.
the initial disbelief that many nordestinos feel towards these figures might suggest a tendency to overlook the underlying social realities they represent rather than providing a basis to question their accuracy.
this was the perspective shared by certain individuals at the ibge in rio de janeiro, upon learning about the skepticism prevalent among my peers in ceara.
nevertheless, both supporters and skeptics alike should delve deeper into this topic, as it warrants further examination.
joao lyra madeira brought up a significant question a few years back, highlighting the apparent lack of attention given to the topic of fertility in brazilian demography and economics.
although the term "taboo" may now seem too extreme, there still exists a reluctance to delve into the socio-economic aspects of fertility.
when a subject is deemed taboo, it often points to an evident injustice that is too important for the status quo to openly confront.
this reluctance to address fertility issues in brazil is reminiscent of the segregated southern united states during my childhood.
the clear divide between the tasks and economic status of blacks and whites was apparent even to a child, with segregation laws enforcing and perpetuating these disparities.
implicit acknowledgment of such inequalities was tolerated as long as it was not overly scrutinized or discussed in depth.
the oligarchy finds it inconvenient as it reveals a different aspect of class exploitation.
while one might expect marxists to be keen on exposing such facts, they are reluctant to acknowledge any reasons for poverty besides the exclusive ownership of the means of production.
marxists particularly dislike neo-malthusian approaches as they suggest improvements can be made through individual efforts, undermining class unity and detracting from their primary solution to all problems, the class revolution.
as a result, this topic is often overlooked by them.
due to the lack of attention, the substantial fertility disparities in northeast brazil still lack a satisfactory explanation.
it is my belief that the root cause can be attributed to the societal class structure.
in my previous studies from 1970 and 1971, i posited that the essence of a proletariat is to have numerous offspring.
in ancient rome, the term "proletariat" denoted the poorest social class, characterized by having many children, who were exempt from taxes and primarily contributed to the nation by producing offspring.
this original connotation, later diminished in meaning by marx's era, tied poverty to rapid population growth.
marx redefined the term to refer to individuals who do not own the means of production and must sell their labor to capitalists for survival, effectively severing the historical link with prolific procreation.
marx's definition implicitly includes a theory of poverty, suggesting that poverty results from the control of production means by a small group and the resulting lack of ownership of these means by the majority.
although the two schools of thought conflict in attributing a singular cause and solution to poverty, there is no inherent contradiction between marxian and malthusian theories.
it is feasible for a group to control both production means and population limiting resources.
marx emphasizes that mere ownership of land and capital does not automatically make someone a landlord or a capitalist without the corresponding social context, such as proletarians dependent on selling their labor.
the rapid increase in such dependent individuals reinforces the unequal distribution of wealth in northeast brazil, a defining characteristic of its social structure.
by 1977, the disparity in life expectancy based on social class in the northeast had decreased to approximately 15 years.
the most significant change, a reduction of nearly 11 years, was observed between the income brackets of "half to one minimum wage" and "one to two minimum wages." conversely, the most notable shift in fertility rates during that period occurred between the preceding categories of "below half minimum wage" and "half to one minimum wage." interestingly, the decline in birth rates preceded that of the mortality rate as income levels rose, contradicting the notion that birth rates decline only in response to decreasing death rates.
while class-based mortality gaps were less stark than fertility variations and lacked a clear-cut threshold at a specific income level, they played a crucial role in painting a comprehensive picture of class distinctions in society.
in short, the demographics of class in northeast brazil highlighted nuanced interplays between mortality and fertility dynamics within different income strata.
additional backing for the second perspective can be derived from several official public statements.
in 1982, a research team from the escola superior de guerra released a concise publication titled "the brazilian demographic problem," embodying the official stance, as evidenced by the subsequent excerpts.
a nation as vast as brazil, boasting extraordinary natural riches, ample prosperity, and free of discrimination based on race, color, or faith, necessitates a populace capable of inhabiting and safeguarding its lands from external covetousness.
the conventional principles of free trade and comparative advantage used to strongly influence my thinking and were the hardest for me to reject.
it is not unexpected that some sympathetic readers disagree with me on the topic of free trade.
nonetheless, i am confident that the same reasons that led me to reevaluate these doctrines will also persuade others to do the same.
our uncritical embrace of all things global and cosmopolitan, while simultaneously devaluing national and local aspects, has been excessive.
in 1987-1988, during the collaborative work on our book "for the common good," john cobb jolted me from my entrenched beliefs on trade matters.
despite having taught the theory of comparative advantage for two decades, the issue had seemed settled until then.
john's prompting led me to reevaluate the entire topic, prompting a revisit to ricardo's theories.
much to my dismay, i realized how extensively i, along with the textbooks i used, had disregarded ricardo's crucial assumption of immobile capital between nations, which forms the crux of the comparative advantage principle.
in chapter ii of our book, we advocate against free trade, championing community, particularly the national community.
i admit, at first, i anticipated severe critiques and errors pointed out by fellow economists, yet over the past seven years, this has not materialized.
the significance of the limited range of occupational choices for a specific group is often overlooked as a welfare cost, though it holds crucial importance.
individual happiness is heavily influenced not just by how one earns a living but also by how they choose to spend their earnings.
take for instance a nation like uruguay, which has a distinct advantage in cattle and sheep farming.
in a scenario strictly following the specialization and trade principle, a resident might have the option of pursuing a career as a cowboy or a shepherd.
however, to maintain a thriving national community, uruguayans have found it essential to establish their own legal, financial, medical, insurance, and educational services in addition to basic agriculture and industry.
despite potentially reducing efficiency, such a diversity of occupations is vital for the unity and identity of the community.
from an individualistic standpoint, the expanded array of occupational choices must be viewed as a welfare improvement.
countries that have weakened their borders due to economic reasons find it challenging to implement domestic policies, including commitments made to support international environmental agreements they have ratified.
these agreements are a stride towards fostering a genuine global community.
however, their significance diminishes when nations relinquish their compliance ability by eroding their borders in favor of unrestricted trade.
transnational corporations have evaded their community obligations by operating on an international scale.
as there is no established global community, they have effectively sidestepped these responsibilities.
globalism, rather than fostering a sense of global community, promotes individualism on a vast scale.
the dilemma lies in whether to allow transnational capital to operate without constraints, establish an international governing body to regulate it, or opt to reassert control over capital by nationalizing it and reintegrating it into the national community.
personally, i advocate for the latter option.
while envisioning this change might be challenging presently, the same holds true for the other options.
the occurrence of an international market crash could potentially make it easier to envision and implement such a transformation.
as national borders become more permeable to the flow of goods, capital, and labor, a global labor market, capital market, and market for goods and services emerge.
consequently, each commodity will have a unified world price.
individual countries can no longer enforce unique wage, interest rate, full-cost pricing, or population control policies without global cooperation.
rather than various nations experimenting with different policies independently, there is now a singular global experiment.
this shift towards standardized competition risks failure due to the downward pressure on standards.
two instances illustrate the challenge of addressing national issues in the context of free trade.
firstly, attempting to transition u.s. citizens from welfare to sustainable employment becomes increasingly difficult when they are immediately exposed to competition from the less privileged global population.
pressing disadvantaged members of our community to transition directly from welfare to competing against abundant and inexpensive labor worldwide neglects our duty to support and stand in solidarity with them.
a similar challenge arises when attempting to transition our military production capacity to civilian uses, especially when facing strong foreign competition.
the inefficiency of our military sector is likened to that of centrally planned socialist economies, highlighting the need for a gradual introduction of competition.
rather than pursuing rapid global efficiency that could result in job losses and societal issues such as increased crime, drug abuse, and irresponsible behaviors, it is advocated to support domestic workers and companies making modest yet valuable contributions to our nation despite current global competitiveness levels.
the introduction of trade initially reduces environmental constraints compared to total economic self-sufficiency (autarky), giving the impression that increased trade will further alleviate these constraints.
however, the advantages of transitioning from no trade to some trade do not automatically imply that more trade is superior to less trade.
moreover, it is not feasible for all countries to solely rely on importing natural resources.
free trade amplifies the geographical distance between the advantages of production and the environmental drawbacks of growth in throughput.
this disparity makes it challenging to assess and more likely to exceed the ideal scale dictated by their equilibrium at the margin.
additionally, due to heightened connectivity from trade, nations will encounter increasingly stringent global environmental limitations concurrently rather than gradually on a national level.
this contrasts with a scenario of reduced trade and integration where countries would experience more sequential and localized environmental restrictions.
consequently, there will be fewer chances to experiment on a smaller scope and draw insights from other nations' past endeavors in managing throughput.
overall, through the simultaneous availability of resources and absorption capacities to meet demands globally, free trade is likely to boost throughput growth, consequently accelerating environmental degradation.
it may diminish the ability of local communities to manage their surroundings and sustain their means of living.
while neoclassical growth economics perceive the increase in throughput growth spurred by free trade as advantageous, sustainable or steady-state economics view any inclination of trade to drive growth above an optimal level as uneconomic.
however, proponents of free trade stress the significance of strengthening intellectual property rights and reducing the accessibility of knowledge as a common good.
they argue that without making new knowledge costly, there would be insufficient motivation to create more of it.
despite the persuasive nature of this argument, i am inclined to support the idea that the advantages of swiftly sharing existing knowledge outweigh the potential drawbacks of hindering the generation of new knowledge.
drawing from schumpeter's theories, one could posit that new knowledge initially holds a natural but temporary monopoly due to its novelty.
by disseminating knowledge, the loss of this exclusivity drives the pursuit of even newer knowledge.
the practical worth of fresh knowledge is attributed to the production factors that implement it, while its market value is driven down to zero through competition.
assessing welfare is complex and prone to numerous subjective considerations, underscoring the importance of avoiding broad generalizations.
nevertheless, it appears reasonable to suggest that there is scant empirical support for the notion that gross national product (gnp) growth has significantly enhanced welfare in the united states since 1947.
consequently, any potential welfare improvements resulting from free trade's role in bolstering gnp growth are likely to be minimal.
essentially, upon closer examination, the touted substantial benefits that supposedly necessitate sacrificing national cohesion and industrial harmony seem to be nonexistent.
ricardo demonstrated the concept of free trade being mutually beneficial even in cases where there were substantial one-sided differences in production costs between countries.
he used the example of england and portugal in the eighteenth century to illustrate this.
portugal was able to produce both wine and cloth at a lower cost compared to england.
however, england's efficiency in the cloth industry far surpassed that of portugal's, while portugal excelled in producing wine.
despite portugal's absolute advantage in both products, england had a comparative advantage in cloth production, while portugal had a comparative advantage in wine production.
ricardo argued that both countries would benefit by specializing in their respective comparative advantage products and engaging in trade.
this approach, rather than focusing on absolute advantages, would result in mutual benefits through free trade and competition within each country.
irrespective of what ricardo might argue if he were alive today, some contemporary neoclassical economists could still advocate for free trade based on absolute advantage rather than comparative advantage.
they may still demonstrate that overall global output would increase through specialization and trade under absolute advantage, though not guaranteeing that each country would necessarily benefit.
this was the crux of the matter.
classical economists, being nationalists, were primarily concerned with the benefit of their own nations and were not particularly keen on global integration or trade that did not directly favor their countries.
with the progression of global integration, the concept of "each nation" loses its economic significance.
nonetheless, neoclassical economists are not troubled by this shift as they prioritize individualism over nationalism.
apologies, aging union worker joe six-pack, but in today's interconnected global economy, companies like mine can outsource labor overseas for a fraction of the wages demanded by your union.
by avoiding higher environmental and social taxes, we can then market and sell our products competitively.
your severance package is being processed.
as for your mention of "bonds of national community," i must disagree.
the reality is that we now operate within a global economic framework, transcending the nationalistic sentiments that led to historic conflicts.
the movement of factors is crucial for attaining peak productivity, a vital aspect for staying viable amidst global competition.
while there may indeed be a trend towards the convergence of wages worldwide, it's imperative to recognize that profits will also harmonize.
consequently, wages may trend downwards while profits trend upwards, reflecting the equilibrium dictated by global supply and demand dynamics.
wouldn't you agree, joe, that striving for equality in wealth across all workers, be they chinese, mexican, or american, is the humane path forward?
let's not harbor any prejudiced views.
at this point in the conversation, there is a diminishing sense of community.
what is being observed is the nullification of a fundamental social contract between labor and capital regarding the equitable division of the value they collectively contribute to raw materials.
this accord hasn't been established on economic principles but rather through years of national discussions, voting, labor disputes, company shutdowns, legal judgments, and confrontations.
the rejection of this pact, crucial for national unity and industrial harmony, is now occurring in favor of worldwide integration.
this exchange, labeled as "free" trade, is deemed highly unfavorable.
the concept of free trade, when mistakenly expanded to include unrestricted capital flow, logically suggests that it should also extend to unrestricted labor movement, specifically through open immigration policies.
if we consider ourselves part of a global economy, why should there be limitations?
if both capital and the governments supporting it have no greater allegiance to their own citizens than to foreigners, then the freedom to migrate should be allowed.
the unrestricted movement of goods, capital, and labor is a direct outcome of global economic integration.
while this may not align with the original intentions of economists like ricardo or smith when discussing free trade, it now represents the implicit or explicit agenda of contemporary advocates of free trade.
however, this approach undermines national unity rather than fostering it and does not necessarily promote international cooperation either.
according to jim hightower, a former texas commissioner of agriculture, a potential solution could be to retain manufacturing facilities and job opportunities in the united states while relocating corporate headquarters to countries like mexico or korea to source cost-effective chief executives.
another proposition could involve liberalizing immigration policies to allow entry of affordable executive talent and labor force.
nevertheless, the reality may lean towards further marginalization of the working class, accentuated by corporate and academic elitism towards less educated and rural populations, with a corresponding increase in the emphasis on firearms as a defining element of identity among the former group.
the concept of free trade, specialization, and global integration has made it almost impossible for nations to opt out of trading.
however, the freedom to choose not to trade is important for ensuring that trade continues to be mutually advantageous.
emphasizing the idea that national production for the domestic market should take priority over international trade is crucial.
some free trade proponents advocate for intertwining the two so tightly that it could ultimately stifle domestic production in favor of a global approach.
this idealistic vision of a perfectly orchestrated international trade system might end up causing chaos and intense conflicts, both globally and within nations, rather than the intended harmonious outcome.
while there may be additional criteria for adjustment, these three typically encompass the majority of cases known as "adjustment lending." these loans are primarily used to fund changes in policies focusing on the rationalization of prices, addressing macroeconomic issues such as debt and deficits, and promoting the liberalization of international trade.
the rationale for a country resorting to borrowing money at interest to implement more sound national policies may not always be immediately apparent.
some view adjustment lending as a form of incentive, albeit for a noble cause.
the underlying belief is that the benefits of policy changes, akin to any investment, will outweigh the costs of loan interest, ultimately contributing more to national welfare in the long run.
certainly, if all trading nations were to reach a consensus on shared regulations for defining, assessing, and incorporating external costs, the stated concern would no longer be valid, thereby reestablishing the traditional arguments in favor of free trade within this new framework.
however, the likelihood of such collective agreement remains uncertain.
even the limited group of expert national income accountants cannot reach a consensus on the assessment of environmental costs within national accounts, let alone on the strategies for integrating these costs into firm-level pricing.
it is improbable that policymakers will fare any better in this regard.
some economists may oppose universal cost integration by pointing out that countries have varying preferences for environmental goods and services, which should justify profitable trade based on differential pricing.
undoubtedly, reaching a consensus on standardized principles and the degree of deviation permissible from these principles will present formidable challenges.
once capital can move freely, the concept of comparative advantage and its associated illustrations lose their significance.
the outcome of capital mobility mirrors that of international labor mobility, leading to a tendency to harmonize wages worldwide.
given the current issue of overpopulation and rapid demographic growth in developing countries, it is evident that this alignment will push wages downwards, as observed in the united states over the past decade.
consequently, under free trade and capital mobility, returns on capital are also expected to be leveled, albeit at a higher scale than now.
american capital stands to gain from inexpensive foreign labor, succeeded by low-cost domestic labor, at least until hindered by a demand crisis caused by insufficient purchasing power from reduced wages.
nevertheless, this can be prevented by efficiently redistributing resources to cater to the new spending patterns resulting from the growing income disparity.
the objective of sustainable development is to progress towards a future where development benefits all individuals across all generations through modifications in resource allocation, distribution, and magnitude.
however, achieving this goal requires more than just minor adjustments to the conventional growth model, which has largely contributed to the current stalemate.
libertarian economists often view homo economicus as an independent entity with unlimited mobility, comfortable in any environment.
however, actual individuals reside within communities, which are interconnected with other communities.
their unique identities are shaped by their connections within these communities.
treating community as a dispensable collection of temporarily proximate individuals, solely to benefit mobile capital, is problematic enough when capital remains within national borders.
the situation escalates when capital crosses international boundaries.
free trade does not eliminate carrying capacity limitations; rather, it ensures that countries will encounter these constraints more or less simultaneously instead of one after the other.
it consolidates various local limitations into a unified global constraint, thereby transforming a series of manageable issues into a single, overwhelming challenge.
the misconception surrounding this concept is evident when individuals, who are expected to possess better understanding, use the netherlands or hong kong as models that all nations should follow, claiming that every country could achieve the same high population density.
however, it remains unclear how all countries could achieve the status of being net exporters of goods while also being net importers of carrying capacity.
a subsystem is limited in its growth by the total system it belongs to.
if the total system offers services that the subsystem cannot provide independently, the subsystem should refrain from encroaching on the main system in a manner that could hinder its ability to deliver these services.
it is essential for the economy to operate within the bounds of the ecosystem's capacity to sustainably provide services like photosynthesis, pollination, air and water purification, climate maintenance, uv radiation filtration, waste recycling, and more.
prioritizing growth over sustainability has led us to exceed a viable scale.
in order to sustain the current population size and per capita consumption levels, we are depleting natural resources and categorizing it as income.
trying to alleviate poverty through continued expansion of resource consumption will ultimately backfire once the environmental costs exceed the production benefits.
it is highly probable that we have already surpassed this critical threshold, where further growth actually reduces wealth instead of increasing it.
an alternative approach involves halting the expansion of resource consumption and addressing poverty through redistribution and enhancing the efficiency of resource utilization rather than merely increasing the quantity of resources used.
by restricting resource consumption, efforts can be directed towards enhancing resource efficiency.
if technological advancements can substantially enhance efficiency, the transition may be relatively smooth.
however, if technological progress is limited, the process will be more challenging.
regardless, it is imperative to pursue this approach whether one is optimistic or pessimistic about technological advancements.
in an attempt to evade these truths, adherents of the adjustment paradigm have introduced another adjustment termed sustainable growth, adding to the confusion by wrongly equating it with sustainable development.
adhering to the correct definitions, "growth" pertains to a quantitative increase in physical size through the assimilation of materials, while "development" signifies qualitative change, realizing potential, or transitioning to a more enhanced state.
these two processes are distinct yet interconnected, as evident in examples like simultaneous growth and development in a child, mere growth without development as seen in a snowball or cancer, and development occurring without growth, like in the case of the planet earth.
economies often experience concurrent growth and development, though they can occur independently as well.
as the economy is a part of a limited and unexpanding ecosystem, its expansion causes it to encompass an increasingly larger portion of the entire system, making its operations resemble those of the full system, which entails development without further expansion.
the acknowledgment that continual growth becomes unattainable and increasingly burdensome is what underscores the importance of sustainable development.
this concept entails advancing without enlarging the economy beyond a threshold that remains within the carrying capacity of the biosphere.
many believe that the current scale exceeds the long-term carrying capacity, and to achieve sustainable growth, it may be necessary to experience a phase of negative growth initially.
even for those inclined towards technological optimism, who anticipate that productivity improvements in resource usage may outpace the reduction in resource volume, this notion remains quite radical.
the term "sustainable growth" is seen as an attempt to avoid this profound transformation and instead implies that growth is still the primary objective, albeit with a slightly improved environmental focus.
in contrast, sustainable development offers an alternative to the conventional growth paradigm and is fundamentally incompatible with it.
sustainable development, characterized by progress without growth, does not signify the demise of economics; if anything, it elevates the significance of economics.
this approach embodies a nuanced and intricate economic model centered on maintenance, enhancing quality, resource sharing, frugality, and adapting to natural constraints.
it advocates for a philosophy of "better, not bigger" economics.
the accumulation of physical assets acts as a support in enhancing our capacity to access energy income, provided they are protected from the effects of entropy.
however, the energy income itself cannot be significantly expanded nor conserved extensively.
preserving our stock of physical wealth against the impact of entropy necessitates a continuous supply of low-entropy "revenue." while nature has deposited energy in coal over vast geological timescales, we can only extract it.
soddy viewed the period of extravagant coal consumption as transient, with the limitations of depending on energy income becoming more apparent and undeniable once the coal reserves were depleted.
soddy seems to argue that if it is impractical for an entire community to subsist solely on interest, then it should similarly be discouraged for individuals based on principles of equity.
allowing unchecked individual accumulation of debt eventually leads to a scenario where debt holders exceed the future capacity of revenue producers to meet those obligations, resulting in conflicts such as debt defaults.
while debt, fueled by compound interest, can theoretically persist indefinitely, the physical constraints of wealth—subject to the realities of entropy—prevent limitless growth.
as debt compounds exponentially yet wealth growth is ultimately finite, a point of imbalance between the two is inevitable, requiring some form of debt repudiation or cancellation.
the subtitle of his later work, "the bearing of physical science upon state stewardship," is the only indication of the significant and innovative contribution he made to economics.
it is noteworthy that soddy foresaw the fundamental ideas of georgescu-roegen and boulding concerning the connection between economics and thermodynamics.
as a result, he should be acknowledged as a trailblazer in a school of thought that i predict will gain prominence in the future.
the initial question may seem logical, albeit extraneous, as soddy did not propose benefiting from compound interest without reinvesting some of the interest earned.
nevertheless, the latter portion of the inquiry indicates a misunderstanding between tangible and abstract quantities, leaving soddy potentially disheartened about bridging the gap with economists.
it is possible that when professor silverman used the term "approximately," he intended to convey "for a set duration." yet, this raises queries about the conclusion of this specified period and its duration.
georgescu-roegen's impact on the field of economics can be divided into the categories of normal science and revolutionary science, concepts popularized by philosopher thomas kuhn.
his normal science contributions encompass essential research in utility and consumer choice, measurability, expectations, production theory, input-output analysis, and economic development.
he was a trailblazer in mathematical economics, and although his work was groundbreaking at the time, it is now considered normal science as a result of the success of the revolution it sparked.
his revolutionary science contributions, particularly his pioneering work in the entropy law and the economic process, are still met with opposition from the prevailing paradigm, a paradigm georgescu himself played a role in establishing.
while some of his students may opt to focus on his earlier contributions to mainstream economics, i have chosen to highlight his groundbreaking contributions, which i believe hold greater significance and relevance to ecological economics.
it concerns me that, even decades after the publication of key works such as the entropy law and the economic process and the introductory essay to analytical economics, their impact is not evident in standard economics textbooks.
scholars in various disciplines outside of economics have recognized the value of georgescu's later work, prompting questions as to why economists have not embraced it more fully.
the lack of integration of these ideas cannot be attributed to their inability to withstand critique from within the field.
georgescu was not only a distinguished fellow of the american economic association but was also praised by paul samuelson in 1965.
in his preface to analytical economics, samuelson referred to georgescu as a "scholar's scholar" and an "economist's economist." this accolade was not limited to georgescu's established scientific work featured in analytical economics but also extended to the groundbreaking introductory essay that laid the foundation for his later pivotal work, the entropy law and the economic process.
samuelson challenged economists to reflect on this essay, stating, "i defy any informed economist to remain complacent after meditating over this essay." despite samuelson's endorsement, most economists remained indifferent.
surprisingly, even in samuelson's widely used textbook almost three decades later, there is no mention of the ideas presented in georgescu's essay.
naturally, an introductory text does not delve into complex themes, and it is not surprising that georgescu's intricate advancements in traditional economics are not referenced.
nevertheless, his groundbreaking perspectives on economics and entropy are quite straightforward due to their fundamental nature.
the comprehension of these basic concepts does not demand a technical explanation of the entropy law.
thus, these foundational ideas could feasibly be incorporated into an introductory text.
however, the challenge lies in the fact that their incorporation would necessitate substantial revisions across the text, given the far-reaching implications that challenge conventional perspectives.
the section focusing on national income accounting, along with its guidelines on evaluating the circular flow, could be enhanced by incorporating a quantified measure of the entropic flow, known as "gross national throughput." furthermore, this segment might address the peculiar imbalance evident in current national accounts.
while the depreciation of man-made assets is deducted from current production, there is no equivalent deduction for the depletion of natural assets.
this discrepancy allows for a situation where a nation could deplete its mines, destroy its forests, degrade its topsoil, and deplete its wildlife and fisheries to extinction, leading to a consistent rise in measured income despite the loss of these vital resources.
centering the analysis on the entropic flow underscores the importance of recognizing the natural capital assets responsible for generating this crucial flow.
it highlights the definition of income according to hicks, which refers to the highest level of consumption an individual or community can sustain over a period while maintaining the same level of well-being from the beginning to the end.
the preservation of capital now encompasses both natural and man-made resources in order to sustain the same level of well-being.
in our revised section on population, we would focus on reevaluating the notion of optimum population.
instead of merely considering the number of individuals, we would delve into contemplating the duration for which a certain population level is sustainable.
specifically, we aim to determine the ideal population size, longevity, and corresponding per capita resource consumption that would optimize the total duration of human existence, while ensuring a satisfactory quality of life for all individuals.
i conclude with a wish for my work to undergo thorough yet fair evaluation.
i firmly emphasize this request as i have had to contend with challenging misconceptions that are widely accepted as truth, which have become deeply ingrained for numerous individuals due to their livelihoods being tied, in part or in whole, to these beliefs.
renouncing these notions would thrust them into a circumstance similar to mine, where they would have to seek new opportunities at an advanced stage in life.
embracing sustainable development requires a profound shift in mindset, a genuine transformation of beliefs, and a sincere readiness for self-reflection.
these notions are rooted in religious language with a purpose - challenging us to reconsider our core values on a profound level that inherently leans towards the spiritual.
interestingly, within the academic world, there is often a reluctance to acknowledge this inherent religious undertone, as labeling an issue as religious can lead to its dismissal or marginalization.
the notion of repentance, once a powerful call to action, has been replaced by a more neutral and detached term - "change." this shift reflects a broader societal trend of avoiding overtly subjective terms like "progress" in favor of a more objective and value-free approach.
ultimately, the expectation is for individuals to adapt or at least not resist these changes, emphasizing a subtle shift from values-driven progress to a more passive acceptance of objective transformations.
the initial chapter of this section delves into the concept of limited inequality and asserts its solid biblical foundation.
while it may appear conventional to rely on biblical authority to uphold an ethical principle, as opposed to the contemporary academic trend favoring figures like john rawls, robert nozick, and amartya sen or concepts such as the social contract, historical evidence suggests that a significant portion of the moral principles embraced in the united states originated from the bible.
these principles were disseminated across the nation by churches and universities, many of which were originally established by protestant churches, although little evidence of this heritage remains in most modern universities.
for those who prefer to anchor ethical principles in culture and history, our culture and history predominantly offer various interpretations of the bible as foundations for ethical values.
hence, there is no need to justify basing a moral principle directly on the bible rather than indirectly through our diminishing cultural legacy.
advocating against enforced equality, no one is proposing an unwarranted scenario of equal distribution.
a tenfold difference in wealth could be deemed acceptable due to variations in work ethic and dedication, serving as motivation to encourage such qualities.
for a more cautious approach, one might argue for a twentyfold difference.
nonetheless, societal bonds start to fracture at or even before a hundredfold inequality.
the seeds of class warfare are already being sown.
the attachment of numerous individuals from rural and working-class backgrounds to their firearms, and the subsequent influence of the national rifle association, emanates from an implicit yet profound sentiment that "even though the government may view me as an uneducated, blue-collar individual, there are limits to how much they can oppress me if i possess firearms.
without them, there are no boundaries." while acknowledging the presence of political and religious extremity in these militia groups, they also signify a manifestation of class strife stemming from widening wealth gaps.
it is essential to establish a systematic approach that connects religious beliefs with economic principles.
this connection should be universal and foundational to bridge the gap between the agricultural economies of biblical palestine and the roman empire to today's advanced industrial economies.
in this chapter, i aim to interpret a particular and revolutionary economic principle rooted in the context of the old and new testaments.
the final chapter delves into a broader exploration of the religious context, proposing that the key aspects of sustainable development economics organically emerge from and are intrinsically supported by a religious worldview.
in today's agricultural practices, it seems unreasonable for farmers to refrain from harvesting the corners of their fields to accommodate travelers, strangers, widows, and orphans.
though this custom may be considered outdated, its underlying principle remains relevant: to provide for the less fortunate.
while traditional methods become obsolete, there is a need to identify more appropriate approaches.
furthermore, the demographics of those in need have shifted over time, with widows and orphans often being financially stable heirs.
it might be more apt to refer to the disadvantaged groups as "unmarried heads of households" in contemporary census terms, highlighting the changing face of poverty.
i suggest focusing on a fundamental biblical economic principle that, in my opinion, is straightforward to grasp and crucial for improved institutionalization in today's society.
this principle also aligns partially with the requirements for a sustainable economy.

next, i will propose a novel institution to effectively reintegrate this principle into the contemporary economy.

the concept of the "eleventh commandment" implies that private property and some level of inequality in its allocation are accepted.
however, it emphasizes that this inequality should have boundaries.
before delving into these boundaries, it is essential to briefly discuss the validity of private property, which is sometimes debated.
both christianity and judaism view individuals as autonomous beings capable of making decisions and facing the consequences.
private property is crucial as it expands the domain for personal freedom and accountability.
moreover, the eighth commandment, "thou shalt not steal," is sometimes interpreted as indirectly endorsing the idea of private property.
although total equality was not a reality or objective, the community could not tolerate extreme inequality.
there were defined limits on the extent of inequality.
firstly, land distribution among families was either equal or fair in a broader sense.
secondly, since property is essential for freedom and accountability, it is reasonable for everyone to possess some form of property or at least have the right to gather crops and utilize resources, a diluted form of ownership.
conversely, the traditional argument for private property stands as a safeguard to shield individuals from exploitation by others.
property owners have the autonomy to sustain themselves and are not compelled to agree to unfavorable employment terms.
if the legitimacy of property rests on these grounds, then it is evident that ownership should be widespread, if not universal.
according to the book of leviticus, the acceptable level of inequality was limited to what could amass over fifty years, starting with an equitable initial allocation, and adhering to principles of honesty, no interest, fallow sabbatical, protection of the impoverished, religious contributions, and similar guidelines.
the jubilee, marking the fiftieth year as a grand sabbath, was a time to revert to the original distribution.
the presence and prospect of the jubilee year tended to curb the rapid build-up of inequalities that it aimed to rectify.
as the jubilee year neared, the drive to amass wealth lessened, knowing that gains would need to be relinquished.
post-jubilee, with 49 years to enjoy the gains, the drive to accumulate peaked, aligning with a period of equal distribution.
it is essential to acknowledge that there is no universally defined limit to inequality that is of divine authority.
does this mean our efforts are futile?
just like how a democracy doesn't have a precise and absolute standard for determining the appropriate voting age, as it's subjective whether it should be set at eighteen or twenty-two.
the crucial point is that the specific age limit is somewhat arbitrary.
what truly matters is having a clearly defined and widely accepted minimum age, regardless of whether it is eighteen or twenty-two.
similarly, the precise boundaries of inequality are less significant compared to establishing limits that align with a reasonable, functional, and fair level of inequality.
the crucial question is: what constitutes this acceptable and functional range?
the baseline income would ideally cover basic needs such as food, shelter, clothing, health, and education, set at a culturally appropriate level.
the upper limit could be ten times higher than this minimum threshold.
while plato proposed a factor of four, i suggest ten as a suitable benchmark.
what is the precise extent of inequality and how is income distributed in reality?
economists rely on various tools like lorenz curves, gini coefficients, pareto distributions, and lognormal distributions to characterize income distribution.
yet, a particularly vivid and creative depiction was proposed by dutch economist jan pen, who illustrates this concept by organizing a procession of dwarfs and giants.
in this visual, all earners are either reduced or enlarged to reflect the size of their income.
they will then march past us in a parade, from shortest to tallest, spanning precisely one hour, providing an intriguing perspective for us, individuals of assumed average stature.
what would we see in this scenario?
initially, there are individuals with a negative height, possibly with their heads buried up to ten yards underground.
these individuals experienced financial losses that year; they are not necessarily destitute but may face financial struggles if losses persist.
following them are numerous gnomes, each roughly the size of a matchstick.
among them are part-time workers, students, and housewives who earn modest incomes, often contributing to a household's overall earnings, thus managing to stay somewhat financially afloat.
this procession of gnomes lasts for approximately five minutes.
subsequently, individuals of noticeably larger stature appear, standing at around three feet tall.
among them are elderly pensioners, divorced women without alimony, individuals with disabilities, and some artists.
this group takes an additional five minutes to pass by.
after fifteen minutes of the ongoing parade, individuals of short stature, standing at four feet tall and described as unskilled workers, start to appear.
among these individuals, many are women and most have dark skin.
the procession continues to showcase dwarfs for an extended period before transitioning to office workers, who although not dwarfs, are notably shorter from our viewpoint.
forty-eight minutes into the parade, twelve minutes before its conclusion, people of average height, representing the middle-income bracket, begin to be visible.
this group includes teachers, civil servants, insurance agents, farmers, and skilled workers.
six minutes later, individuals from the top ten percent, standing at around six feet and six inches tall, start to be seen.
these figures are mostly university graduates.
in the final moments of the parade, towering figures suddenly emerge.
among them are a lawyer, a doctor, and some accountants towering at about eighteen feet tall, followed by doctors, judges, and executives, standing at approximately sixty feet tall.
the procession culminates with the appearance of prince phillip and the director of shell oil, who stand at staggering heights of one hundred and eighty feet and more than double that, respectively.
the query arises as to whether restrictions on income or wealth should be imposed, or if a combination of a minimum income and maximum wealth, as suggested in scripture, would be more appropriate.
considering the options, it is evident that setting a minimum limit on wealth is not feasible since wealth can be spent, making it difficult to maintain year after year.
therefore, the minimum restriction should be placed on income.
the maximum constraint can be set on either income, wealth, or both.
placing a cap on wealth without limiting income could result in extravagant spending by individuals who have exceeded the wealth threshold, potentially escalating consumption inequalities once wealth inequalities are regulated.
this imbalance may contradict the principles of sustainability by promoting excessive consumption.
although setting a cap on income avoids this issue, it may be perceived as exacerbating wealth disparities.
however, upon closer examination, this symmetry proves to be flawed.
imposing restrictions on income will inevitably impact wealth in two significant ways.
firstly, wealth accumulation will slow down when income is restricted.
secondly, individuals whose income from other sources has hit the maximum limit will witness a devaluation of their existing wealth.
this would prompt them to either spend or liquidate their assets since they cannot retain the full benefits.
as a result, it is more effective to set direct limits, both for maximum and minimum levels, on income rather than wealth.
while exploring the feasibility of imposing a cap on wealth is also advisable, the most straightforward and practical approach to address inequality remains the implementation of maximum and minimum thresholds on income.
until now, the concept of limited inequality has been scrutinized within a specific timeframe.
however, should this principle not extend across time as well?
it is essential that the current generation does not amass excessive wealth at the expense of future generations being impoverished.
conversely, depriving the present generation in an attempt to secure disproportionate wealth for future generations should also be avoided.
amidst an era fixated on economic expansion, characterized by prioritizing investment over immediate consumption, there have been sporadic acknowledgments of the latter misstep.
suppose an economy adhered to the ten-to-one limits of inequality but experienced consistent growth in terms of population and per capita consumption.
while the limits to inequality were respected at all times, they would not be sustained over time due to the increasing scale of economic activity.
this growth trajectory could lead to either a significantly wealthier future or a substantial decline resulting from ecological collapse, possibly both in sequence.
the lack of mention of issues like overpopulation and ecological degradation in biblical times limits the specific guidance available in the judeo-christian religious tradition concerning these matters.
in antiquity, sustainability was generally assumed given the predominantly pastoral, agricultural, small-scale, and solar-based economy of ancient israel.
however, various laws promoting sustainable practices such as leaving land fallow, protecting nesting birds, and preserving trees during conflicts suggest that sustainability was not entirely automatic and was not taken for granted.
due to high death rates, the population did not grow rapidly, maintaining the economy at a nearly steady state necessary to revert back to the initial historical circumstances of the jubilee.
in these conditions, it was undeniable that imposing a maximum limit on individual income was necessary, as simply relying on overall prosperity without considering the rate at which the rich and poor became wealthier would be ineffective.
in a steady state scenario, if the wealthy accumulated more wealth, the less privileged would inevitably experience a decline in their financial standing, both relatively and absolutely.
when there is a cap on the overall wealth, it becomes vital to set a maximum limit on individual earnings.
moreover, if a minimum income is also established, generally, the higher the minimum threshold, the lower the maximum limit on income would need to be.
numerous individuals contend that the existence of a stable economy within the community was a fortunate outcome of historical events and not a result of divine intervention.
with the advancements in science and technology, the natural constraints that previously required the economy to remain steady, specifically the imposition of a maximum income, have been eliminated.
advocates propose retaining the minimum income but argue that once poverty is eradicated, concerns about inequality become less pressing.
moreover, some argue that an escalation in inequality may be essential to drive economic growth, subsequently enabling an increase in the minimum income level.
there are two key points to address in response.
firstly, the distance between the wealthy and the impoverished significantly impacts community cohesion.
excessive inequality undermines a sense of community, regardless of the well-being of the lowest economic strata.
even relative poverty fosters resentment, while wealth can isolate and desensitize individuals.
the bonds of conviviality, solidarity, and brotherhood diminish as economic disparities widen.
moreover, relative income often influences political power and must not become too concentrated in either a theocratic or democratic system, as this could pave the way for a plutocracy.
mistakes can occur in any of the three stages.
our religious understanding may be flawed, either lacking sensitivity or veering towards fanaticism.
while a fundamental religious understanding might be accurate, translating it into an ethical principle could still be skewed by historical biases or being overly one-sided.
there is a possibility of making errors in deriving particular economic strategies from a broad principle of ethical conduct.
even if our ethical foundation is solid, misconceptions about the functioning of the world can result in policies producing outcomes contrary to our intentions.
exponential growth, in a remarkably brief timespan, has rapidly transformed our once sparsely populated world into one teeming with people and their possessions.
this transformation, driven by economic progress, has led to a world bustling with human activity and material wealth, yet it has also come at the cost of depleting the natural resources and ecosystems that previously thrived.
this assimilation of nature into our human-made environment, now acknowledged as "natural capital" due to its intrinsic value and limited availability, has ushered in a new phase of growth paradoxically characterized by diminishing returns and escalating environmental degradation.
this detrimental trend, termed "antieconomic growth," results in a situation where the costs of expanding human activities outweigh the associated benefits, thereby exacerbating poverty and endangering the natural world.
despite the illusion of prosperity indicated by rising gross national product (gnp), the well-being of society is on a downward trajectory, underscoring the fallacy of equating material wealth with true prosperity and well-being.
this persistent confusion, perhaps rooted in misplaced priorities or blind allegiance, perpetuates a cycle in which tangible symbols of success are misconstrued as the genuine indicators of human flourishing.
nonreligious individuals may adopt this perspective due to its alignment with empirical knowledge.
conversely, the prevailing alternative viewpoint, endorsed in much of contemporary economic analysis, posits the economy as an all-encompassing system with limitless growth potential.
while acknowledging the finite nature of the environment, this view regards it merely as a component of the economy that can be replaced by other sectors without impeding overall growth significantly.
this perspective is rooted in the belief that humans are essentially creators rather than mere inhabitants of their surroundings.
it is worth noting that while these viewpoints are not explicitly tied to religion, they share a commonality with religious beliefs in that they establish foundational principles that resist straightforward disproof through critical analysis.
their influence over us stems partly from faith and dedication.
viewing the economy as a subsystem differs from the religious belief that the world is god's creation and we, along with our creations, are a part of it and constrained by its limits.
however, this economic perspective is more aligned with the religious insight than the idea of the human economy as the primary system, with nature being just a segment that could be replaced by various other sectors.
the contrasting implications of these preanalytic views are significant: regarding the economy as a subsystem prompts the pursuit of an optimal human niche scale, suggesting growth should halt beyond a certain point, while perceiving the economy as the total system encourages an endless pursuit of growth.
there is an inherent understanding of what constitutes a satisfactory life, although there may be differing opinions on this matter.
it is essential to delve deeper into this concept, as life can be negatively impacted by both poverty and excessive wealth.
establishing reasonable boundaries for inequality is a feasible expectation, despite opposition from economic experts questioning the validity of imposing personal preferences on others.
the argument suggesting that these values are merely subjective tastes and that perpetual growth is feasible is flawed, highlighting the superficiality of the current economic discussions.
however, without forests, a sawmill holds no value; without fish, fishing boats become worthless; without remaining petroleum deposits, refineries are of no value; and without rivers and adequate forest cover in catchment areas to prevent erosion and siltation, dams lose their value.
claims about intergenerational sustainable practices and the supposed efficiency of man-made versus natural capital are merely vague attempts to avoid addressing the underlying moral question.
i am convinced of the continuous existence of god, the creator, in the past, present, and future.
god is the origin of our responsibility towards creation, which includes all living beings, particularly those among us enduring suffering.
our actions that exploit the present, at the expense of future generations and other species, mirror the sinful act of favoring the wealthy over the impoverished.
it is undoubtedly a transgression to return the gift of creation to god in a deteriorated state, with reduced capacity to sustain life abundantly and for generations to come.
just as killing and stealing are considered sins, so too is the destruction of the earth's ability to support life in the present and for future inhabitants.
while it may be unavoidable at times to make choices that result in sacrifices for the future, trading the well-being of future generations for present comfort and luxury is a distinct moral failing.
the initial step in implementing this change involves recognizing, a concept discussed in chapter 2, the existence of three main economic challenges: allocation, distribution, and scale.
these challenges each serve as distinct objectives, and addressing one does not automatically resolve the others.
presently, the approach is to address these challenges in a comprehensive manner.
the first objective concerns allocation, which pertains to the distribution of resources across various commodity uses, such as determining the allocation for cars, bicycles, shoes, and beans.
a desirable allocation is one that efficiently meets people's preferences and purchasing abilities.
efficiency is achieved through the use of relative prices that reflect marginal opportunity costs.
the second objective focuses on distribution, involving allocating final products among different individuals, determining how many bicycles or beans are distributed to each person equitably and adequately.
an optimal distribution is one that maintains fairness and adequacy standards.
to achieve this, policy tools such as transfer payments and limitations on inequality are employed.
today, the issue of optimal scale cannot be disregarded any longer.
in the past, this matter was often overlooked due to the assumption that as long as the scale of operations remained small, economic growth could function as the primary guiding principle of society.
growth was prioritized with the belief that it would eradicate poverty through continuous accumulation facilitated by the miraculous effects of compound interest.
redistribution was considered unnecessary, as it was thought that premature redistribution could impede the momentum of growth.
the concept was that growth would naturally eliminate inefficiencies without the need for adjusting relative prices to encompass all social and environmental costs.
however, there are limits to scale.
there exists a maximum threshold, and well before this threshold, there is an optimal point at which further growth becomes more expensive than beneficial.
a mounting body of evidence suggests that we have already surpassed this optimum scale.
given that the earth is evolving without expanding, it implies that a part of the earth will eventually adapt to this mode of sustainable development, where growth is not the primary focus.
this transition may occur on any level below the earth's carrying capacity.
following ethical principles, the most suitable scale would be the one that maximizes the collective human experience over time, while ensuring a decent quality of life within the limits of available resources per individual.
currently, what is certain is that this ideal scale must be sustainable, avoiding any excessive strain on the ecosystem that could jeopardize future generations.
at this stage, the primary objective is to strive towards achieving a sustainable scale, deferring the question of determining the most optimal sustainable scale for a later time.
the challenges of achieving sustainability encompass both technical and economic aspects, which may not be overly complicated.
the true difficulty lies in breaking free from our addiction to constant growth as the primary means of harnessing our innovative abilities.
whether framed in religious contexts or not, there is a mistaken perception that our creative potential is self-reliant and boundless.
this misguided belief hinders the acknowledgment that combating poverty necessitates recognizing and respecting various constraints.
these include limitations on per capita resource consumption, population expansion, and the proliferation of inequality.
ignoring these natural boundaries results in unsustainable growth that surpasses the earth's capacity, precipitating widespread devastation.
this, in turn, leads to a decline in the overall quality of life, ultimately causing premature mortality among those currently lacking adequate resources.
however, critical academic relativists may highlight that distinct plimsoll lines are necessary for fresh and saltwater, and that the line is not solely a physical measurement but includes subjective evaluations of acceptable risk, further influenced by the ship's technical design.
despite these challenges, a practical line is drawn, offering significant advantages to seafarers over the years.
similarly, in economics, establishing a limit at any point holds greater significance than pinpointing the exact ideal location for the boundary.

in this context, there is a specific emphasis on analyzing these secondary practices and dynamics and viewing them as essential components of specific global scales, even if they are not commonly acknowledged as such.
an obstacle in pinpointing these processes and participants within globalization is that they are frequently perceived and defined in national terms.
consequently, there is a requirement to unravel and understand elements conventionally categorized as national.
studying the global involves not just concentrating on explicitly global phenomena, but also examining locally specific practices and conditions that are interconnected with global forces.
it also involves understanding the increase in cross-border connections among different localities, which are driven by shared conditions across various regions.
moreover, it requires acknowledging that many global dynamics, like the global capital market, are partially rooted in sub-national locations and transition between different organizational frameworks and practices.
for instance, the global capital market is shaped by both global electronic markets and locally influential factors such as financial centers with their encompassing infrastructures and trust systems.
exploring processes and dynamics of globalization at sub-national levels involves utilizing methods and theories that address not only global but also sub-national scales, challenging traditional scale hierarchies.
analyzing global phenomena manifested at local levels offers benefits over examining globally scaled dynamics but also introduces specific complexities.
this approach enables the application of established research techniques, encompassing both quantitative and qualitative methods, in the examination of globalization.
it provides a platform for leveraging various national and sub-national datasets and specialized fields like area studies.
nonetheless, these studies must be embedded in conceptual frameworks different from those initially used by the researchers who developed these methodologies and datasets, as their focus was largely unrelated to globalization.
another important example linked to the first one pertains to the impact of new interactive technologies in reshaping the concept of the local, prompting a deep analysis of our understanding of it.
these latest technologies have the power to transform a financial services firm into a microenvironment with a global reach.
similarly, resource-constrained organizations or households can also transcend boundaries and establish themselves as global microenvironments, such as activist groups.
by connecting these microenvironments to distant ones, the conventional association of the local with physical proximity and contextual limitations becomes unsettled.
this reevaluation of the local concept involves challenging the traditional belief that local levels are inherently part of a hierarchical scale system from local to regional, national, and international, proposing a shift towards a more intricate understanding of spatial dynamics.
another example involves the interplay between global dynamics and specific aspects of national states.
central to this concept is the idea of the global being partially integrated within the national realm, with the global city serving as a prime illustration of this phenomenon.
the primary thesis posited is that when particular configurations of the global take root in what conventionally constitutes national territory, it fosters a range of bargaining processes.
a contemporary consequence of this dynamic is the emergence of what i term as a nascent, exceptionally specialized, and partial deconstruction of certain elements of national states.
apart from a growing interest in geography scholarship, the social sciences have generally overlooked critically analyzing the concept of national scale from a historical perspective.
this oversight has led to the tendency of viewing the national scale as fixed and thereby making it absolute, while overlooking the complexities involved in scaling or reducing it to a mere hierarchy of size.
additionally, there exists an unexamined assumption that different scales, particularly national and global, are mutually exclusive.
however, a nuanced perspective allowing for some level of interconnectedness between scales can be observed when scaling is perceived as a nested hierarchy, albeit in a very limited sense.
the current landscape of influence is evolving beyond the national level due to a combination of initiatives by leading corporations, advancements in technology linked to information and communications, and certain aspects of governmental actions.
notably, subnational entities like global cities and supranational entities such as global markets are now pivotal in strategic decision-making.
this shift has disrupted traditional power structures and economic models.
previously, power dynamics and economic frameworks were determined by the scale of institutions and territorial boundaries, ranging from international to national, regional, urban, and local, with the national level acting as the primary mediator.
a significant portion of societal structures and institutions is historically shaped at the national level, with elements like authority, identity, territory, security, legal systems, and economic growth being primarily defined and aligned at this scale.
if obtaining these rights, choices, and capabilities requires a partial surrender of aspects of state power as it has been developed in the past century, we can suggest that this paves the way for a shift in the role of the state.
this also indicates that national states must actively participate in the globalizing process.
ultimately, it signifies the emergence of new power dynamics that challenge traditional national state boundaries.

these instances encompass various forms of global influence rooted in localized movements and individuals involved in transnational connections, extending to constructs like global cities, and even specific governmental initiatives designed to engage with global entities and their needs.

the involvement of rem sleep in synaptic consolidation is a crucial aspect to consider.
while the active system consolidation hypothesis clarifies the temporary strengthening and integration of freshly acquired memories with existing long-term memories through reactivation, it falls short in elucidating how sleep after learning reinforces memory retention and solidifies synaptic connections in the long run.
therefore, it is presumed that sleep plays a role in synaptic consolidation to stabilize memories, with rem sleep potentially serving this purpose.
the heightened activation during this phase could enhance local synaptic plasticity without being influenced by external stimuli, unlike in wakefulness.
the focused and isolated synaptic consolidation during this period could be the reason why rem sleep by itself does not enhance declarative memory consolidation.
this is because declarative memory consolidation depends on integrating various features from different memories stored in multiple memory systems and facilitating information transfer across different brain regions, which occurs during slow-wave sleep (sws)-dependent system consolidation.

moreover, modern youth gravitate towards digital and networked media.

two prominent characteristics are apparent in a basic model of corporate finance involving overly optimistic managers and efficient capital markets.
firstly, these optimistic managers have the belief that the market undervalues the risky securities of their firm and might reject profitable projects requiring external financing.
secondly, these managers tend to overestimate the value of their corporate projects and could be inclined to invest in projects with negative net present value, even when they prioritize shareholders' interests.
these findings illustrate a trade-off between underinvestment and overinvestment linked to free cash flow, without the need to consider asymmetric information or rational agency costs.
conversely, managerial optimism leads to consistently inflated cash flow projections and results in managers overestimating the value of the company's investment prospects.
managers who lack free cash flow may be reluctant to pursue projects with a negative net present value that they believe to be positive because they view the cost of external financing as prohibitive.
in such cases, free cash flow can be detrimental.
it eliminates the requirement for external financing and facilitates the pursuit of projects with negative net present value that are erroneously perceived as positive.
it is crucial to understand that optimistic managers will only make a limited number of poor decisions.
if the investment cost i surpasses the high cash flow state rh, optimistic managers will not pursue the project.
essentially, there exist projects of such low quality that not even highly optimistic managers will proceed with them, as their positive outlook on the likelihood of success cannot compensate for the fact that the project's returns will not sufficiently offset the initial investment.
nonetheless, optimistic managers may still consider a wide range of projects with negative net present value.

these observations aid in clarifying the concept of logical necessity.
despite the prevailing view held by many philosophers for an extended period, there is no requirement to actually draw out logical conclusions.
even if g follows logically from f, it is not mandatory to think of g immediately upon considering f.
however, what is essential is that if f is true, then g must also be true.
bringing about f inevitably results in bringing about g.
therefore, it is acceptable in reasoning that preserves truth to progress from f to g.
