one major benefit of fmri methodology is its ability to capture brain activity within a significantly smaller temporal window compared to pet scans.
this feature is particularly advantageous when studying brief cognitive processes, such as language processing which may occur within tens of milliseconds.
with pet scans, which operate at a slower pace, it becomes challenging to effectively measure such rapid cognitive activities.
unlike pet which generates a single average image over an extended period, fmri allows for the acquisition of multiple images across consecutive temporal windows, enabling the examination of moment-to-moment changes in brain activation.
functional magnetic resonance imaging (fmri) studies enable the recording of button-press data and response times, while other data collection techniques pose challenges.
obtaining vocalization responses, such as naming times and talk-aloud protocols, is more intricate.
despite advancements in noise-canceling technologies that aid in capturing voice responses in the loud scanning setting, data can still be compromised by head movements induced by jaw actions.
the typical scanning protocol also presents obstacles in gathering discourse recall data during a scanning session.
while these issues can be addressed with diligence, they have not been systematically resolved to date.
in brief, limitations of brain imaging methodologies impact the experimental design of discourse processing studies.
it is crucial to carefully structure passages to enhance the likelihood of understanding how intricate cortical networks operate during discourse comprehension.
each specific process needs to be linked to a precise moment in the text.
furthermore, this process should be consistently identifiable across most passages and for the majority of participants.
for instance, when investigating the creation of a bridging inference, this inference must occur at a consistent point within the text for various stimuli and readers for reliable measurement.
the restricted number of passages and participants hinders the ability to analyze a wide range of passages comprehensively.
despite limitations on experimental design, imaging remains advantageous for studying the overall functioning of neural networks.
this is particularly valuable when processes like inferencing do not occur at distinct temporal points.
therefore, imaging can reveal the cognitive effort needed for drawing inferences even if behavioral cues do not provide clear evidence of when or if an inference was made.
consequently, fmri can detect subtle processes that may not significantly impact behavioral outcomes, while also highlighting the qualitative nuances and simultaneous engagement of processes involved in discourse comprehension, aspects that may not be apparent through response time measurements.
the fmri results indicated that the left hemisphere overall showed no difference in response when reading paragraphs with or without titles, whereas the right hemisphere displayed significantly higher activity when processing untitled paragraphs.
specifically, the left middle and superior temporal sulci were more activated when reading titled paragraphs, whereas the right middle and superior temporal sulci showed increased activation during the task of processing untitled paragraphs.
these findings back the notion that the right hemisphere plays a role in mapping information into textual representation, as elaborated later.
furthermore, the results suggest that there are distinct processing functions carried out by each hemisphere.
the process of identifying the main idea and structuring the text is distinct from linking this information to the discourse structure, with both brain hemispheres collaborating interactively to construct a cohesive text representation.
additionally, the nature of the information in the text influences which brain areas are involved in constructing and preserving the text representation.
information at the propositional level might engage the left frontal and left temporal regions if adequate resources are allocated.
in contrast, processing situational model information involves the medial frontal cortex.
moreover, the specific cortical regions that come into play may vary depending on the type of input; for instance, emotional details concerning the protagonist could activate dorsal frontal areas more prominently.
frequently, the connections between events in a narrative are implied rather than directly stated, requiring the reader to make linking inferences and blend them with the provided information.
most texts rely on readers drawing upon a common understanding of the world.
the relationship between generating inferences and incorporating text is significant.
creating inferences is crucial for constructing precise text interpretations, just as having an accurate text representation is essential for inference generation.
in this chapter, we have outlined research aligning with diverse discourse processing theories.
the research discussed here has played a pivotal role in introducing innovative concepts, including the coarse coding theory of right hemisphere processing, the dynamic activation of cortical networks based on text constraints, the overflow of processing to other specialized networks due to capacity use, and the involvement of a theory of mind network in understanding discourse.
the next step is to explore how modern cortically driven viewpoints on discourse processing align with existing discourse processing theories.
the signal generated by active components in memory operates independently of coherence breaks or relevance and remains constant, self-sustained, and limitless.
any associated information prompted by this signal can be accessed regardless of its relevance.
whether outdated or current, information is equally susceptible to activation; when a reader comes across a specific sentence linked to outdated information, it can trigger the recall of that information, potentially disrupting comprehension despite the reactivation.
this presents us with the challenging task of suggesting that when a text contains high emotional content, prompts an elaborative inference, and presents a clear topic, we would expect to observe a distinct type of network engaged.
creating a multitude of networks that analyze discourse would be as diverse and numerous as the texts under scrutiny.
a more effective strategy would involve expanding on established discourse theories and demonstrating how data from brain regions align with elements of these different theories.
understanding the processing of discourse involves intricate high-level cognitive functions, engaging various aspects of cognition.
neuroimaging studies offer a unique advantage by allowing the exploration of a broad cortical network comprising specialized brain regions, adjusting the cognitive load.
this methodology is highly beneficial for enhancing our comprehension of discourse.
the range of research discussed in this chapter illustrates that we are at the initial stages of leveraging the power of neuroimaging to comprehend discourse more deeply.
each characteristic is individually examined in specific sections, but it is crucial to understand that they are interconnected.
they hold strong correlations not only with each other but also with indicators of comprehension performance.
the comprehension skill theories discussed in our review elaborate on these connections through distinct causal mechanisms.
to visually demonstrate how these theories allocate variance among the five reader characteristics, we feature figures in each section.
it is important to note that these figures do not encompass all possible relationships among the characteristics but rather highlight specific connections emphasized in explanations of variations in comprehension abilities.
in this chapter, figure 1 illustrates the five reader characteristics under discussion.
according to the verbal efficiency theory, three of these characteristics are highlighted: word-level ability, working memory (wm) capacity, and print exposure.
the figure demonstrates a direct correlation between word-level ability and both word-level processes and print exposure.
readers with strong word-identification skills tend to acquire more word knowledge compared to readers with weaker skills, consequently boosting their interest in reading.
regular readers tend to enhance their word-level ability, reinforcing their passion for reading.
additionally, figure 1 presents indirect effects of word-level ability on sentence-level and discourse-level processes through its influence on wm capacity.
inefficient word-level processes can deplete wm resources that could otherwise be utilized for higher-level interpretive tasks.
two primary assessments are frequently employed to evaluate working memory (wm) capacity: the reading-span task and the operation-span task.
during the reading-span task, individuals are required to orally read a series of unconnected sentences one by one and then remember the final word of each sentence after the full set is shown.
conversely, the operation-span task follows a similar pattern but involves solving basic arithmetic problems instead of reading aloud.
in both tasks, the span refers to the maximum number of words that the individual can accurately recall.
the rationale also extends to explaining why adept comprehenders are able to recall more details from text compared to struggling comprehenders.
proficient comprehenders possess effective strategies for storing intricate and cohesive units in memory.
these units are triggered when textual cues prompt their retrieval with incoming information.
conversely, individuals who struggle with comprehension encode information in fragments or disjointed clusters.
consequently, retrieval cues in short-term memory trigger retrieval of small, relatively incomplete, units from long-term memory storage.
there is significant variation among readers in their level of interest, the importance they place on reading, and the time they dedicate to this activity.
scholars have explored various aspects of how reading habits influence comprehension skills and the acquisition of broad knowledge.
a primary inquiry involves whether exposure to printed material enhances comprehension mainly through streamlining word recognition or if it additionally contributes to vocabulary enrichment, understanding of syntax, and the assimilation of cultural and specialized knowledge.
what causes poor comprehenders to struggle with high-level interpretive processes needed to form a coherent discourse model remains uncertain despite years of study.
differences exist between good and poor comprehenders, which significantly impact their comprehension abilities.
the relationship between performance on complex span tasks and comprehension remains a mystery.
is this correlation due to weaknesses in word-level skills?
additionally, are the disparities in the capabilities of good and poor comprehenders related to their skill in creating efficient retrieval structures and storing them in long-term working memory (ltwm)?
the focus of this chapter is to reexamine the ongoing discussions in psycholinguistics regarding the uniqueness of figurative language usage.
it is proposed that figurative language does not represent a singular category of linguistic elements comprehended through distinctive figurative processes.
however, the ambiguous nature of various facets of figurative expression, often overlooked in numerous psycholinguistic investigations, presents significant questions concerning the potential balance between reducing cognitive strain and enhancing cognitive impacts in the comprehension of figurative language.
strategies for empirically examining this balance are proposed, which could serve as a foundation for forthcoming psycholinguistic inquiries into figurative language.
various types of figurative meanings exist, such as metaphoric, idiomatic, metonymic, ironic, satirical, proverbial, hyperbolic, and oxymoronic.
in the academic realm, scholars commonly argue that figurative language comprehension involves contrasting processes like literal vs.
however, considering the diversity of meanings, one might wonder whether numerous linguistic processes are at play or potentially could be when processing language.
psycholinguists have overlooked this question because of their narrow focus on one form of figurative meaning in contrast to a simplistic perception of literal meaning.
previously, scholars have erroneously made theoretical assertions about rapid processing transitioning from slower and consciously constructed interpretations and appreciations.
furthermore, psycholinguists have frequently overlooked the thorough examination of cognitive impacts or the outcomes of grasping figurative language.
in our opinion, understanding the trade-off between cognitive effort and effects in figurative language comprehension hinges on identifying the influencing constraints.
this involves empirically investigating how various factors exert individual effects and likely interact in intricate, possibly nonlinear, ways.
the cognitive effort invested in producing and understanding figurative language is influenced by the aims and inclinations of both speakers and listeners, while the cognitive effects in linguistic communication are shaped by factors such as the prevailing perspective, evaluation methods, and the nature of the materials employed.
by acknowledging and appreciating these factors, we aim to enrich endeavors aimed at gaining a more comprehensive understanding of the interplay between cognitive effort and effects in the use of figurative language.
the aim of this chapter is to offer an introduction and overview of the rapidly expanding literature concerning eye movements and their role in processing spoken language, with a particular focus on applications related to spoken language comprehension.
section 2 concentrates on methodological considerations.
just like any new approach, the enthusiasm for innovative discoveries and new areas of exploration needs to be balanced with a critical assessment of the paradigm itself, which includes task-specific strategies and the assumptions that connect the observed behaviors to the theoretical hypothesized underlying mechanisms.
key topics encompass the rationale linking eye movements to spoken language processing, the methods for collecting and interpreting eye movement data, practical examples showcasing certain paradigms and their comparisons to eye movement reading studies, as well as the respective experimental rationale.
moreover, discussions extend to the challenges and restrictions involved in investigating language within a limited visual context.
to address these matters, we examine findings from various visual world studies.
over the years, researchers have long utilized eye movements in reading to delve into various issues related to lexical and sentence processing.
now, these same issues are under scrutiny through the examination of eye movements in spoken language.
while certain differences exist between reading and spoken language due to inherent differences in the two modes of communication, scholars in psycholinguistics exploring topics like syntactic ambiguity resolution and reference resolution through eye movements in reading and spoken language believe they are examining theoretical propositions about these processes that go beyond input modality.
consequently, the psycholinguistic community will increasingly grapple with how to merge findings from visual world studies with those from reading eye movement studies, sometimes having to address conflicting results.
most research studies that analyze reading patterns by tracking eye movements typically focus on using eye movements as a way to measure cognitive processing load.
the main metric used is fixation duration.
the underlying theory suggests that reading becomes more challenging as fixation durations increase.
on the other hand, a significant number of visual world studies utilize eye movements as a tool to gauge representation.
the key parameter examined is the timing and placement of fixations as language is spoken.
a comparison between reading studies on resolving lexical and syntactic ambiguities and visual world studies tackling similar questions can highlight these contrasting approaches.
timing in eye-tracking reading becomes more complex when fixations are segmented into multiple word regions.
the challenges in interpreting reading time data emerge from the fact that the order of fixations may not align with the linear arrangement of words in the text.
this discrepancy is particularly pronounced when discussions about timing hinge on delineating text regions and categorizing fixations in a manner that divorces the measure from the initial exposure to the information.
while one might interpret the limited action options as indicative of effective problem-solving skills rather than being influenced by the actions and affordances as proposed by chambers et al., the experiment revealed contrasting outcomes for tasks involving instructions with indefinite articles, such as "pick up the cube.
now put it in a can." in such cases, participants became perplexed when the cube could only fit into one specific can.
this comparison between linguistic influences and problem-solving techniques is essential in assessing the influence of task presentation and requirements on strategies used.
a key caution for researchers utilizing the visual world paradigm for both production and comprehension is the importance of recognizing that while visual stimuli can help infer the listener's understanding, they also shape the context of the spoken language itself.
it is essential to acknowledge that the information presented visually influences processing, much like how linguistic cues in prior discourse impact reference resolution.
some argue that the effectiveness of the visual world paradigm hinges on gaze patterns to potential referents remaining unaffected by other visual stimuli.
however, this stance is comparable to the belief that eye fixations during reading only provide insights into word recognition and reference resolution when they are independent of contextual factors surrounding the fixated word.
this chapter has presented an overview of the expanding body of literature on eye movements and their role in processing spoken language, particularly emphasizing their applications in spoken language comprehension.
foundational studies have been examined, alongside discussions on data analysis and interpretation, as well as the challenges encountered when comparing eye-movement reading studies to visual world studies.
additionally, significant research avenues utilizing this methodology have been explored, with a focus on areas within language comprehension such as spoken word recognition, the utilization of referential cues in parsing, interactive conversation dynamics, and the progression of language processing skills in children.
this review makes it evident that the visual world paradigm is extensively used across various traditional areas of study within psycholinguistics.
the utilization of the visual world approach in these areas is prompting psycholinguists to delve into novel theoretical and empirical inquiries.
particularly in the realm of spoken sentence comprehension, emphasis has been placed on reference issues, partly due to the capability of the visual world methodology to link real-time reference resolution research with pragmatic and conversational studies.
in the domain of spoken word recognition, the temporally precise nature of this method has enabled researchers to scrutinize phonemic, sub-phonemic, and prosodic influences on word recognition in speech at a level of intricacy previously unattainable through conventional means.
it is anticipated that eye-movement measures will continue to gain traction and find increased utility within the psycholinguistics community, driven by these and other compelling reasons.
though psycholinguistic studies have typically viewed language as a cognitive ability, language usage research has concentrated on the interactive aspects of dialogue, sometimes neglecting the cognitive underpinnings of both speaking and comprehension.
this has led to the formulation of theories rooted in descriptive criteria rather than explanatory mechanisms.
encouragingly, these two approaches are now beginning to converge, suggesting the emergence of a comprehensive language processing theory that is both explanatory and cognitively sound, while also reflecting real-world applicability.
this chapter provides an overview of studies that establish the foundation for such a theory.
the full constraint model takes a rigorous approach to incorporating common ground in language processing, positioning itself at the far end of the range of available theories.
according to this model, common ground influences all aspects of language production and comprehension, with unrestricted access across all levels.
in this framework, common ground serves as an instant, mandatory, and comprehensive restriction on each level's functioning.
consequently, the model suggests that information within the speaker's or listener's knowledge but outside their shared common ground would not influence language processing.
the matcher subsequently transitioned to a director role for a different participant matcher, where the process was reiterated.
subsequently, the new matcher assumed a director position with a fresh participant.
interestingly, despite the lack of interaction between any participants in this subsequent exchange and the confederate who initially set the precedent terms, those terms were more prominent in this conversation compared to the alternate terms.
this suggests that speakers may not always apply precedents in a partner-specific way.
listeners might have perceived a shared understanding between the two speakers because they both opted for the same terms to refer to an unfamiliar concept.
to explore this, barr and keysar undertook an additional study where a speaker departed from the established pattern instead of adhering to it.
if patterns are tailored to each partner, breaking away from them should result in more confusion when done by the same person who set them compared to a different speaker.
the research by barr and keysar showed that there was a similar level of confusion when the pattern was disrupted by a new or familiar speaker.
therefore, it seems that listeners rely on patterns during speech processing not because of mutual understanding with the speaker but because they are readily accessible in their cognitive processes.
the findings on language comprehension convincingly dismiss the full constraint model as effects of private knowledge on comprehension have been consistently demonstrated across multiple studies from various research groups employing different tasks.
the ordinary memory view also fails to account for most of the results, as comprehenders seem to differentiate between private and shared information.
the majority of reviewed evidence supports either perspective adjustment or partial constraint.
notably, the literature lacks discussions on a dual process model for comprehension, which could offer an alternative explanation for the findings.
further detailed process-level inquiries are necessary to differentiate between these competing models.
the primary objective of language use research is to construct a theory that elucidates how individuals adjust their language patterns in response to the information requirements of others.
achieving this objective necessitates overcoming the intricate nature of language use, which is influenced by its cultural, interactional, and cognitive components.
despite substantial progress in research over recent years, comprehending the collaborative dynamics of conversations is a long-term endeavor that demands sustained cooperation among researchers in the decades ahead.
the second explanation for task-specific sentence and structure-specific deficits is based on the observation that syntactic structure influences not only the basic semantic values such as thematic roles but also higher-level discourse representations like focus and presuppositions.
although these discourse-level representations are not directly necessary for the tasks at hand, which mainly involve considering thematic roles and co-indexation, they can impact performance.
this phenomenon is well-documented in various implicit processes and may have differing effects across tasks.
for instance, passive and cleft-object sentences highlight the theme in the discourse focus.
a patient struggling to formulate an action when the focused element is the theme, yet capable of matching a focused theme to depictions of thematic roles, would encounter difficulties only with passive and cleft-object sentences during enactment.
according to this account, task-specific deficits in sentence or structure comprehension arise from the challenge of aligning the combined discourse and propositional meanings with the tasks.
confirmatory factor analyses indicated a preference for one-factor solutions over two-factor solutions.
the patient and control factor analyses of rt data showed similar structures.
introducing a factor structure based on sentence type groupings reflecting the varied syntactic structures in the stimuli did not explain more variance than the unconstrained analysis.
rotated factors yielded more factors, yet none aligned with the sentence type groupings tied to the varied syntactic structures in the stimuli.
conducting factor analyses on the screening tasks and syntactic tasks performed by the patients yielded distinct results in the unrotated factor analysis.
this analysis generated multiple factors, each corresponding to the performance on specific tasks.
it is yet to be established whether the diverse types of information thought to be integrated during comprehension would aggregate onto a single factor, akin to the various structures explored in the comprehension tasks, or onto distinct factors, resembling the different tasks employed.
in conclusion, we explore various shared issues at both the lexical and sentential levels of processing.
these encompass cognitive factors affecting l2 processing, the impact of cross-language similarity, the direction of cross-language influences, and the broader implications of bilingualism research for theories on word recognition, lexical access, and sentence processing.
while our analysis mainly centers on behavioral findings from studies involving second language learners and skilled bilingual individuals, we also address the growing body of research on the neurological underpinnings of bilingualism.
the researchers postulated that if vocabulary in the second language (l2) relied on the first language (l1) for processing, then translating into the l2 would be faster than naming pictures because the translation could be readily accessed without the need for conceptual interpretation.
picture naming was expected to be slower as it would involve interpreting the meaning and name of the image in l1 before retrieving the l2 name based on its association with the l1 translation.
conversely, if words in the l2 directly accessed their meanings, then all else being equal, naming pictures and translating into the l2 would take approximately the same duration.
potter and colleagues' findings supported the predictions regarding concept mediation.
the variance in the results observed in l2 learners can be linked to their proficiency level.
in the study conducted by potter et al., the participants were high school students who were preparing to embark on a summer immersion program in france.
despite not being fully fluent in french, these students were considered to be highly motivated learners who had likely progressed beyond the initial stages of language acquisition.
sign languages used by deaf individuals are naturally developing forms of communication with a rich linguistic complexity comparable to spoken languages.
even though the study of sign language psycholinguistics is still in its early stages, many fundamental concepts shaping our comprehension of speech perception and production, such as lexicality, frequency effects, semantic and form-based priming, categorical perception, production errors, and tip-of-the-finger experiences, are well-documented in sign languages.
moreover, neurolinguistic research has pinpointed crucial brain areas essential for sign language and has observed cases of sign aphasia leading to the loss of sign language abilities.
recent advancements in neuroimaging have further deepened our insight into the intricate neural mechanisms that support sign language usage.
collectively, these investigations offer a unique perspective on comprehending the general cognitive limitations evident in language processing and the biological foundations of human language.
one type of inflection that indicates a high level of intensity or vigor is characterized by a decreased extension of the elbow and a faster movement speed.
another inflection related to time conveys a repeated occurrence of the action over time and involves a circular motion passing near the chin in a continuous manner.
inflections for agreement in grammatical number can involve a series of repeated linear movements aimed at two or three points spaced evenly apart.
lastly, inflections related to grammatical verb agreement influence the initiation and conclusion of the movement path, indicating the subject and object of the sentences correspondingly.
syntax pertains to a language form that governs the relationships among words within a sentence.
in-depth analyses of syntax unveil both universal and language-specific patterns and limitations that significantly aid in comprehending sentence meanings, particularly in terms of defining thematic roles.
psychological studies on syntactic processing aim to decipher how these structured patterns are utilized during real-time sentence comprehension and how they interact with word meanings to form a conceptual understanding of the intended message.
furthermore, the expanding field of cognitive neuroscience is increasingly exploring the similarities and distinctions in the neural mechanisms underlying spoken and signed languages.
although some subtle differences have been identified in how they are processed, the prevailing evidence indicates a significant degree of similarity in how speech and sign languages are represented in the brain.
these findings suggest that fundamental elements are fundamental to the neural mechanisms for language, irrespective of the specific form of communication used.
future research will likely delve deeper into both the shared and unique features of these language forms, aiming to enhance our understanding of the cognitive processes that are influenced by the modality of language expression.
through these efforts, we may gain insights into the combined influences of biology and environment on human language communication.
this concept is evident in recent intriguing research on infant speech perception, early vocabulary acquisition, and the development of efficiency in comprehending spoken language, all of which will be discussed in the upcoming sections.
the purpose of this concise overview is to highlight some of the recent studies on language acquisition in infancy that embody this probabilistic viewpoint.
our aim is not to present a comprehensive analysis of this field or claim that this perspective provides all the solutions.
rather, we aim to elucidate recent research on how infants initially focus on speech sound patterns in their first year and progress to discerning meaning in speech by their second year.
by examining how babies, right from the start, pay attention to various cues in deciphering spoken language, this approach underscores the link between current psycholinguistic theories on language use and the evolving developmental outlook on language acquisition.
this concise overview of studies exploring how infants start to understand speech sounds during the initial two years of life has emphasized the new approaches in the field.
the ability of human infants to combine various probabilistic cues is noticeable throughout all stages of development.
initially, infants recognize patterns in sounds without meaning, then progress to grasping words and their significances, and eventually, they form intricate meanings by comprehending and employing words in context.
linguists didn't realize the connection between various linguistic phenomena until they began to consider both positive and negative data.
nativists propose that language-learners, who do not have access to a broad range of language data, must have an edge over linguists because they understand linguistic constraints before encountering the limited primary linguistic data available to them.
these discoveries present a dilemma for the experience-dependent theory.
according to this theory, children could potentially learn the rules governing negative polarity items, such as "any," based on statistical patterns in the language they are exposed to.
however, it would require high proficiency for children to accurately identify the specific linguistic contexts that permit the use of such items to prevent using them incorrectly.
the difficulty in understanding the inconsistency in interpreting disjunction and the difference in the interpretation of the universal quantifier "every" in restrictor versus scope is even more complex.
this challenge is centered on interpretation rather than the distribution of specific words in language.
the principle of semantic subsets dictates an arrangement of values for specific parameters in a way that a sentence is deemed true for a certain subset of circumstances compared to being true for another value.
children are compelled by this principle to initially adopt the subset value of the parameter as their interpretation, only abandoning it based on positive evidence found within the local language.
opting for the superset value would result in children producing sentences that are not part of the local language, posing a challenge for learning.
without negative evidence, it is hard to envision how children would eliminate language-incorrect sentence structures from their grammars.
to mitigate this issue, the semantic subset principle organizes parameter values accordingly.
speech is represented acoustically through continuous waves of acoustic energy.
this energy is visualized on a spectrogram, showing the frequency of acoustic energy over time.
an essential finding is that the gaps or pauses between words, syllables, or sounds within syllables are not visibly evident.
our ability to discern individual words and elements within them is attributed to our cognitive and perceptual capabilities, rather than being an inherent feature of the actual sound signal.
therefore, the predictors in the causal model for word-level reading in third grade consisted of first-grade assessments of three phonological components, vocabulary, and word-level reading.
the inclusion of the autoregressor aimed to eliminate any potential artificial causes of spurious causal effects.
it is plausible that the primary causal factor influencing third-grade word-level reading is the performance in word-level reading from first grade.
put differently, if a student excels in reading in first grade, they are likely to maintain their lead over classmates due to their initial advantage.
excluding the autoregressor of first-grade reading from the model may result in any variable correlated with the omitted first-grade reading measure showing a misleading causal impact.

none of the groups can be considered to be in a preliminary, optional stage of development, as the adult grammar permits optional usage.
the notably restricted usage observed in children with specific language impairment (sli) appears even less explicable from an optional stage perspective.
while these children may demonstrate significant underutilization of aspect morphemes, it is not due to them holding an assumption about optionality that fundamentally differs from that of other children.
this correlation between knowledge and processing could also offer a feasible rationale for the prolonged duration of the optional period observed in sli.
in cases where the processing constraints of children with sli are notable, these individuals may continue to generate less advanced structures even after the restriction is no longer applicable.
essentially, nonfinite syntactic structures that have been consistently accessed over time may still have sufficient activation to rival finite structures, even when the initial reason for their retrieval is no longer relevant.
the outcomes from this study not only back the concept of priming effects associated with processing demands but also provide additional support for a fundamental assumption of optional use approaches.
it is crucial to note that if the children were striving to accurately replicate the finite prime sentences but unintentionally omitted the auxiliary form, their prime sentence outputs would still have utilized the same finite syntactic structure required for the target sentence.
by activating the syntactic structure, it should have facilitated the retrieval of the matching structure for producing the target sentence, thus conserving more cognitive resources for the final step of recalling the necessary auxiliary verb.
nonetheless, this favorable impact was solely observed when the finite prime sentence was articulated with the auxiliary form.
this implies that prime sentence repetitions without the auxiliary form could have been endeavors to form non-finite sentences.
another potential way in which knowledge and processing factors could interact is by considering that the developmental milestones attributed to children in linguistic knowledge theories may demand more input evidence than commonly recognized.
in this perspective, knowledge is viewed not simply as biologically determined principles with minimal input requirements, but as a gradual accumulation of evidence from the input.
due to processing constraints affecting the way children with specific language impairment (sli) analyze input examples, their progress may lag behind that of their typically developing peers.

initially, it was thought that the structure of dimers varied between cxc and cc chemokines, leading to the belief that they engage with receptors through different mechanisms.
further research revealed that the propensity to form dimers differs among chemokines, with certain ones like mcp-3 consistently existing as monomers.
dimerization occurs at substantially higher concentrations than needed for biological function.
it is now widely accepted that chemokines bind to their receptors in a one-to-one fashion.
a recent interesting study demonstrates frequent expression of cxcr4 and ccr7 in human breast cancer cell lines and breast tumor tissue.
the study reveals that the ligand for cxcr4, sdf-1, is predominantly produced in the lung, liver, and bone marrow, sites commonly associated with breast cancer metastasis.
in contrast, the ligand for ccr7, slc, is primarily found in lymph nodes, consistent with its role in lymphocyte homing.
the research also indicates that extracts from lung, liver, bone marrow, and lymph node tissues attract cells with cxcr4 receptors in laboratory settings, and that inhibiting cxcr4 significantly reduces metastasis in scid mice following the injection of breast cancer cell lines.
the findings on cxcr4 and sdf-1 suggest potential involvement of chemokines in tumor metastasis.
while it's unclear if ccr7 plays a similar role, it may attract tumor cells with this receptor to draining lymph nodes via slc and elc, which are present there.
the implications of ccr10, identified in malignant melanoma cell lines, remain speculative.
mastering the skill of effectively writing a coherent text is a challenging and extended process of cognitive advancement, markedly distinct from the acquisition of verbal communication.
typically, by the age of 5, oral language proficiency is well-established, encompassing a substantial vocabulary and the capacity to comprehend and construct grammatically correct sentences.
while the precise role of genetic predisposition in language acquisition remains uncertain, it is evident that speech development is an inherent aspect of early human growth.
conversely, literacy represents a purely cultural milestone, which individuals may not necessarily attain.
reading and writing involve the phonological speech mechanism to some extent, but also necessitate the acquisition of a distinct orthographic system.
the main objectives of this paper are twofold.
firstly, it aims to outline the developmental progression of writing skills across three distinct stages, from childhood through late adolescence to early adulthood.
the first two stages, namely knowledge-telling and knowledge-transforming, are extensively studied, while the third stage, knowledge crafting, though more hypothetical, holds significance in grasping advanced levels of writing proficiency.
secondly, the paper proposes that the primary obstacle in advancing through these stages lies in the limited capacity of the central executive in working memory.
this executive function needs to focus not only on language production but also on planning, reviewing, and coordinating ideas, all while juggling multiple text representations in working memory.
attaining the required cognitive control necessitates minimizing the central executive's workload.
finally, the paper will explore the implications of these insights for the field of writing education.
the process of demand reduction is believed to involve acquiring domain-specific knowledge which can be quickly accessed from long-term memory instead of relying on short-term working memory, and partially automating fundamental writing tasks.
these reductions can be most effectively accomplished through cognitive apprenticeship training methods, especially emphasizing deliberate practice.
additionally, there are two seemingly paradoxical phenomena to consider in older, professional writers: early literary prowess and a decline in working memory.
these aspects are examined before wrapping up the paper.
the purpose of the three stages depicted in figure 1 is to outline three broad phases of writing development.
the graph illustrates how writing proficiency improves steadily with practice, mirroring the progression seen in perceptual-motor and cognitive skills.
the specific incremental changes that facilitate the transition to the next developmental stage are not discussed in this article.
however, it is generally believed that fundamental writing processes such as planning, language generation, and reviewing, along with the mental frameworks required in working memory, undergo ongoing refinements through both natural maturation and educational experiences within specific writing contexts.
due to the influence of task-specific factors, a child might operate at a more advanced level in narrative writing, for example, if it is a more frequently practiced form compared to persuasive writing.
as depicted in figure 1, during the knowledge-telling stage, the author's representation takes precedence.
moving on to the knowledge-transforming stage, the text's representation becomes detailed and stable enough to sustain in working memory.
at this point, the reader's representation is not typically engaged in working memory until the knowledge-crafting stage, where it needs to be sufficiently developed and steady to be retained.
the availability of resources in working memory is essential to coordinate all three representations.
this emphasizes the significant strain on working memory due to the demands of planning, sentence construction, and reviewing processes.
these demands not only affect the coordination of fundamental cognitive processes but also impact the retention and utilization of the three diverse representations involved in the composition of expert writers.
among a group of 34 students, up to 50% provided feedback on modifications that enhanced coherence, included additional content, reduced redundancies, and enhanced overall quality.
however, it is posited that constraints in working memory, which involve retaining and manipulating the reader's understanding of the text while also handling the author's intent and text components, significantly hinder the writing proficiency of developing writers from childhood through young adulthood.
this limitation can elucidate why adolescent writers typically do not naturally and consistently engage in the intricate structural revisions commonly observed in proficient adult writers.
however, being conscious of a hypothetical reader when creating text differs from the ability to read the text from someone else's viewpoint as it is currently written.
while understanding the audience is crucial, it is only one part of the process needed to eventually interpret the author's text from the perspective of an imagined reader.
another critical factor is possessing a well-developed working memory system that can effectively manage the author, text, and reader representations simultaneously and effortlessly.
specifically, executive attention must be fully mature and efficiently utilized to juggle these representations as the writer drafts, refines, and assesses the evolving text.
in the art of crafting knowledge, the reader's understanding of the text influences how the author perceives the text and the intended message.
ultimately, knowledge-crafting involves a dynamic interplay among the representations housed in working memory.
a skilled and experienced writer working on refining their craft must possess the ability to juggle and manipulate various elements in their mind, such as the original author's concepts, the text itself, and the anticipated reader's understanding of the text.
the processes of both honing knowledge and the transitional phase of transforming knowledge require the skill of orchestrating intricate interactions that involve planning ideas, text creation, and reviewing both ideas and text.
the primary challenge in progressing from simply conveying information to crafting knowledge lies in the limitations of the central executive function of working memory.
while writers may possess substantial knowledge, effectively utilizing it necessitates the simultaneous retention of multiple representations in working memory and the skillful coordination of the writing process.
it is insufficient for a writer to only excel in planning or producing coherent sentences; they must also seamlessly blend planning and execution in a manner that mirrors established writers.
furthermore, these fundamental processes of composition must be adeptly managed.
considering the points discussed, two seemingly contradictory facts about the progression of writing skills over a lifetime emerge.
to illustrate this, it is beneficial to outline the key idea of the paper.
advancing writing abilities entail a gradual process of knowledge-telling, knowledge-transforming, and knowledge-crafting over several decades.
engaging in complex written composition tasks tests language, memory, and cognitive abilities simultaneously.
the pinnacle of expertise, typically reached at the professional level, necessitates the proficient handling of various representations in working memory and the harmonization of multiple writing processes.
both processes of transforming knowledge and, in particular, crafting knowledge require a significant amount of working memory resources.
specifically, executive attention is necessary for self-regulation, a process that likely depends on proper maturation, learning specific to a given domain, and sufficient training.
it is unreasonable to anticipate a 5-year-old to write at a college level since the development of the frontal lobes, which support executive functions, has not yet reached maturity.
additionally, considering that working memory tends to decrease as individuals age, one could also anticipate a decline in writing proficiency among older adults.
this book aims to present modern literary theory in a way that is clear and engaging for a broad audience.
since its first publication in 1983, it has been gratifying to observe that not only literary critics, but also lawyers, anthropologists, and cultural theorists have studied its content.
the book argues that there is no singular 'literary theory' that applies exclusively to literature, as the various approaches discussed, such as phenomenology, semiotics, structuralism, and psychoanalysis, originated from different fields in the humanities and extend well beyond literature.
this interdisciplinary nature may explain the book's appeal and the decision to release a new edition.
additionally, the author notes with surprise the interest shown by readers outside academic circles.
in contrast to typical academic works, this particular piece has transcended its scholarly boundaries to attract a wider readership, defying the perceived exclusivity often associated with literary theory.
despite its potentially complex and specialized language, it manages to captivate individuals outside traditional academic circles.
this indicates that even those unfamiliar with university settings are intrigued by its content.
consequently, those within academia who dismiss it as too obscure should reconsider their stance.
it is heartening to see that in a contemporary era that craves instant understanding of everything, there are individuals willing to invest effort in understanding new ways of discussing literature.
the notion within literary studies that certain works of literature can only be enjoyed by individuals with a specific cultural background is considered truly elitist.
some believe that there are individuals inherently possessing "literary values," while others are left in the outskirts.
the surge of literary theory since the 1960s stemmed from challenging this belief due to the influx of students from diverse cultural backgrounds entering higher education.
literary theory aimed to liberate literary works from a restricted "cultivated sensibility," making them accessible to a broader audience for analysis.
critiques about the complexity of literary theory are akin to not expecting immediate comprehension of biology or chemical engineering textbooks.
literature studies are often perceived differently as we anticipate literature to use a straightforward language accessible to everyone, reflecting a particular 'theory' of literature.
the transformation that has significantly impacted literary theory in the 21st century can be traced back to around 1917, marked by the publication of the influential essay 'art as device' by the young russian formalist viktor shklovsky.
since then, literary theory has undergone a remarkable expansion, particularly in the last two decades, leading to profound changes in the understanding of concepts like 'literature', 'reading', and 'criticism'.
however, much of this theoretical revolution remains confined to a niche audience of experts and avid supporters, yet to make a substantial impact on students of literature and the general readership.
the straightforward explanation here is that lacking any form of theory, even if it is unexamined and implied, we would be unable to understand the concept of a 'literary work' or comprehend how to interpret it.
displaying animosity towards theory typically signifies a resistance to theories proposed by others while disregarding one's own.
this book aims to dismantle such resistance and help us recollect and acknowledge the significance of theory.
gibbon believed he was depicting historical accuracy, similarly to the authors of genesis; however, some now interpret their works as either 'fact' or 'fiction'.
newman was convinced of the truthfulness of his theological reflections, which are now perceived by many as 'literature'.
furthermore, while 'literature' encompasses certain 'factual' texts, it excludes various fictional works like superman comics and mills and boon novels, which are not typically classified as literature or literature.
the question arises whether categorizing something as 'literature' suggests that disciplines such as history, philosophy, and natural science lack creativity and imagination.
the formalists initially viewed literary works as arbitrary collections of 'devices' before recognizing these devices as interconnected elements or 'functions' within a comprehensive textual framework.
these 'devices' encompassed sound, imagery, rhythm, syntax, meter, rhyme, narrative techniques, and other formal literary components.
the common denominator among these elements was their ability to create an 'estranging' or 'defamiliarizing' impact.
what set literary language apart and differentiated it from other forms of communication was its ability to distort ordinary language in various ways.
by subjecting ordinary language to the influence of literary devices, it was intensified, condensed, contorted, compressed, elongated, and inverted.
this manipulation rendered language 'strange,' leading to a sudden unfamiliarity in the everyday world.
everyday speech patterns tend to dull our perceptions and reactions to reality, a phenomenon the formalists described as becoming 'automatized.' through its ability to prompt a heightened awareness of language, literature challenges these ingrained responses, making objects more 'perceivable.' literary discourse may seem distant from everyday speech, yet it paradoxically immerses us more deeply into our experiences.
just as we often inhale air without awareness, language serves as an ever-present conduit.
however, when the air becomes dense or contaminated, we are compelled to focus on our breathing, heightening our bodily sensations.
similarly, we typically glance over a friend's hastily written note without dissecting its structure.
but if a narrative abruptly pauses, shifts between levels, and prolongs its climax, our awareness of its construction increases, intensifying our connection.
according to the formalists, such narratives employ hindrances to sustain interest, revealing the intricate artistry of literary language.
the formalists viewed literary language as a collection of deviations from a standard, a form of linguistic rebellion: literature represents a distinctive type of language, contrasting with the common language we typically use.
the ability to recognize a deviation necessitates the identification of the standard it diverges from.
while 'ordinary language' is admired by certain oxford philosophers, the everyday language spoken by oxford philosophers differs significantly from that of glaswegian dockers.
the language employed by these social groups when composing love letters is often distinct from their interactions with the local priest.
the belief in a singular 'normal' language, a universal form of communication shared uniformly among all members of society, is a misconception.
any real language comprises a diverse range of discourses, varying based on factors like class, region, gender, and status, and cannot be neatly enclosed within a single cohesive linguistic community.
what one person considers normal may be seen as a deviation by another: the use of 'ginnel' instead of 'alleyway' might be deemed poetic in brighton but commonplace in barnsley.
the russian formalists were aware of these dynamics.
they understood that norms and deviations could vary across different social or historical settings, highlighting that the concept of 'poetry' is relative to one's perspective.
they acknowledged that the quality of being 'estranging' in language was contextual, as it only appeared so in comparison to a specific linguistic standard.
if this standard changed, the written work might lose its literary essence.
the formalists believed that 'literariness' depended on the contrast between different types of discourse rather than being an inherent trait.
their focus was not on defining 'literature' but on 'literariness,' which encompassed unique uses of language present not only in literary works but also in various other contexts.
nonetheless, the formalists continued to believe that the core of literature lay in the concept of 'defamiliarization'.
they acknowledged this linguistic technique as a means of contrasting different forms of speech.
for instance, consider the phrase "this is aw fully squiggly handwriting!" overheard at a nearby pub table.
is this considered literary or non-literary language?
surprisingly, it falls within the realm of the literary, taken from knut hamsun's novel hunger.
however, what distinguishes it as literary?
notably, it does not draw explicit attention to itself as a linguistic performance.
the reasoning behind recognizing it as literary lies in its origins in hamsun's novel, a work classified as 'fiction', typically included in academic literature curricula.
a challenge within the concept of 'estrangement' lies in the fact that through clever interpretation, any form of writing can be viewed as unfamiliar.
take, for instance, a mundane and seemingly clear directive often spotted in the london underground stating: 'dogs must be carried on the escalator.' upon closer inspection, the statement's ambiguity surfaces: does it mean the obligation to carry a dog while using the escalator?
could one be prohibited from using the escalator without grasping a random dog during the ascent?
numerous seemingly straightforward notifications include similar uncertainties, such as 'refuse to be put in this basket,' or the british road marker 'way out' interpreted by a californian.
setting aside these perplexing ambiguities, it is evident that the underground sign could be appreciated as a form of literature.
one might be arrested by the abrupt, menacing rhythm of the initial weighty one-syllable words, allowing their mind to wander to the subtle connotations of 'carried' by the time it is mentioned, evoking imagery of aiding those in need.
they might even perceive in the cadence and emphasis of the term 'escalator' a reflection of the mechanical, oscillating motion of the apparatus itself.
while this pursuit may seem futile, it is no more so than interpreting the clash of swords in a poetic depiction of a duel and, importantly, it hints that 'literature' is as much about readers' interactions with the text as it is about the impact of the text on them.
he discusses women and love in a broader sense.
literature, unlike textbooks or daily notes, can be seen as a form of communication that doesn't have an immediate practical use but rather reflects a general understanding of things.
at times, it may use unique language to emphasize that it is discussing a concept of talking about women in general rather than specific individuals.
this emphasis on the language itself, rather than the actual subject matter, can suggest that literature is a form of self-referential language, where it discusses itself.
however, there are drawbacks to defining literature in this manner as well.
for instance, george orwell would likely have been surprised to discover that his essays were expected to be interpreted based on how he wrote about the subjects, rather than the subjects themselves.
in many works considered literature, the truthfulness and practical significance of the content are seen as crucial to the overall impact.
even if regarding discourse in a "non-pragmatic" manner is a component of what constitutes "literature," it implies that literature cannot be objectively defined.
this perspective suggests that how literature is defined depends on the reader's interpretation rather than the inherent nature of the text.
while certain forms of writing such as poems, plays, and novels are evidently crafted to be "non-pragmatic" in this sense, it does not assure that they will always be interpreted in that manner.
i might choose to read gibbon's account of the roman empire not because i expect it to provide accurate information about ancient rome but because i appreciate gibbon's writing style or am drawn to depictions of human corruption from any historical context.
on the other hand, i might be interested in reading robert burns's poem out of curiosity as a japanese horticulturalist, as i am unsure about whether the red rose thrived in eighteenth-century britain.
some may argue that this isn't a literary analysis, yet should i only consider reading orwell's essays as literature if i interpret his views on the spanish civil war to reflect profound truths about human existence?
while many works traditionally studied as literature in educational settings were deliberately crafted for literary consumption, numerous pieces evolved from historical or philosophical origins to become literary classics, or vice versa, appreciated for their historical significance.
in this context, literature is perceived not as an inherent quality or specific characteristics found in certain works ranging from beowulf to virginia woolf, but rather as a variety of ways individuals engage with writing.
identifying a constant set of inherent features in all that falls under the term 'literature' is challenging, similar to pinpointing a single shared characteristic among all games.
the concept of an 'essence' of literature does not exist.
any piece of writing can be approached in a 'non-pragmatic' manner, if that is the essence of reading a text as literature, just as any writing can be read 'poetically'.
for instance, when examining a railway timetable not to plan a journey but to trigger contemplation about the rapid pace and intricate nature of modern life, one could be said to be reading it as literature.
ellis suggests that the term 'literature' functions similarly to the word 'weed': weeds are not specific types of plants but rather any plant unwanted by a gardener.
he speculates that 'literature' could be understood as the opposite – any writing highly valued by someone for various reasons.
according to ellis, 'literature' and 'weed' are functional terms, not indicating fixed essences of things but rather how they are perceived and interact within a social context.
they describe the roles, relationships, behavior, and uses of texts or plants, and the human activities connected to them.
therefore, the definition of 'literature' is seen as purely formal and essentially empty.
even if seen as a non-pragmatic linguistic concept, defining 'literature' does not reveal its core essence, similarly to other language practices like jokes.
it is not clear-cut whether we can make a clear distinction between 'practical' and 'non-practical' ways of engaging with language.
while reading a novel for enjoyment is obviously distinct from reading a road sign for essential information, what about reading a biology textbook to enhance knowledge?
should this be considered a 'pragmatic' approach to language?
in various cultures, 'literature' has fulfilled practical roles, including religious ones; making a definitive separation between 'practical' and 'non-practical' may only be feasible in societies like ours, where literature has lost much of its practical value.
the definition we might be proposing for the 'literary' could actually be context-specific and tied to a particular historical period.
perhaps the simplest explanation is that the first three examples are considered instances of 'good writing', while the last three are not.
despite this being somewhat inaccurate in my opinion, it does hint that people generally label writing as 'literature' if they perceive it as high quality.
a valid counterargument is that if this were entirely true, the concept of 'bad literature' would not exist.
personally, i may find lamb and macaulay to be overrated, but that does not negate their classification as literature.
you might view raymond chandler as 'good within a specific genre', but not necessarily as literature.
conversely, if macaulay were an exceptionally poor writer with no grasp of grammar and a sole focus on white mice, his work might not be deemed literature at all, not even of a low quality.
value judgments play a significant role in determining what is considered literature and what is not.
it's not just about writing being exceptional to be classified as literary, but rather being the type that is perceived as exceptional; it could be a subpar instance of a commonly esteemed style.
while no one would label a bus ticket as inferior literature, it wouldn't be uncommon to critique the poetry of ernest dowson as such.
the term "fine writing" or belles lettres is ambiguous in this context, referring to writing that is typically held in high esteem without necessarily implying that a specific example of it is objectively "good".
the idea put forth by this reservation asserts that 'literature' is a highly revered form of writing, shedding light on the subject.
however, it brings about a significant consequence.
it suggests that the notion of 'literature' being 'objective' in a timeless and unchangeable way is erroneous.
essentially, anything has the potential to be considered literature, and even works that are traditionally seen as unquestionably literary, such as shakespeare, can lose their status as literature.
the belief that the study of literature involves exploring a fixed and clearly defined entity, akin to entomology's study of insects, is a misconception.
certain types of fiction qualify as literature while others do not; there is literature that is fictional and literature that is not; some literature is introspective in its language use, whereas some eloquent rhetoric does not fall under the category of literature.
therefore, the concept of literature as a collection of works with guaranteed and unchanging value, characterized by specific inherent qualities, is unfounded.
just as people may reinterpret a piece of work as philosophy in one era and as literature in the subsequent era, or vice versa, they are also prone to reconsidering the value they attribute to certain writings.
they might even reassess the criteria they apply in determining what is deemed valuable and what is not.
this shift in perspective, as hinted earlier, does not necessarily entail them categorically denying a work the status of literature if they now view it as subpar; they may still classify it as literature, signifying that it fits within the realm of writing they typically appreciate.
nonetheless, it does underscore the notion that the established 'literary canon', the revered 'great tradition' of 'national literature', ought to be acknowledged as a construct, devised by specific individuals for specific motives during a specific period.
there is no inherent value in a literary work or tradition independent of the context in which it is valued.
the concept of 'value' is subjective, determined by individuals, circumstances, specific criteria, and goals.
it is conceivable that a future society, shaped by significant historical changes, may no longer derive any meaning from shakespeare's writings.
his works could be perceived as incomprehensible, embodying perspectives and emotions irrelevant to such a society.
thus, shakespeare could lose his significance and be no more esteemed than contemporary graffiti.
while many might view this societal shift as a tragic loss, it would be narrow-minded not to consider that it could result from a broader human evolution.
karl marx delved into the perplexity of why ancient greek art maintained an enduring appeal, despite the societal circumstances that birthed it having long faded.
the uncertainty arises as history continues, and the final chapter remains unwritten.
suppose through meticulous archaeologi cal research, we uncovered more about the original intentions of ancient greek tragedy for its audiences.
upon realizing the vast disparity between their concerns and ours, we might approach the plays with fresh insight.
it is plausible that this newfound understanding could alter our appreciation, leading us to the realization that our past enjoyment stemmed from viewing them through our contemporary lens.
as this connection diminishes, the resonance of the drama may wane, failing to captivate us any longer.
the homer and shakespeare we associate with today are distinct from those of previous eras.
throughout history, different societies have interpreted and reinterpreted their works, assigning different values to various elements.
essentially, all literary pieces undergo a continual process of reinterpretation by the communities that engage with them, whether consciously or not.
therefore, any attempt to introduce a work to new audiences inevitably results in significant alterations, highlighting the fluid and evolving nature of literature and its appreciation.
i do not suggest that instability arises solely from the subjective nature of value judgments.
this perspective posits a clear distinction between objective facts, such as landmarks like grand central station, and subjective value judgments, like preferring bananas or perceiving the shift in tone from defensive assertiveness to grim resilience in a yeats poem.
while facts are deemed universally valid, values are seen as personal and discretionary.
it is understandable to differentiate between stating a fact, like "this cathedral was constructed in 1612," and expressing a value judgment, such as "this cathedral exemplifies magnificent baroque architecture." however, imagine if i were guiding a foreign visitor around england and constantly provided the first type of information, it might perplex her.
she may inquire why i emphasize the origins of these structures and question the focus on historical dates.
in her society, she may explain, buildings are categorized by their orientation towards specific cardinal directions without attaching significance to historical foundations.
in this context, it is impossible to make a completely unbiased statement.
for instance, disclosing the construction date of a cathedral is generally viewed as more impartial in our society than expressing an opinion about its design.
however, it is conceivable that there could be situations where the mention of the construction date is perceived as more influenced by personal beliefs compared to discussing the architecture.
the words 'baroque' and 'magnificent' may now be closely linked in meaning, while only a few of us maintain the importance of the founding date of a building.
therefore, my statement might be interpreted as subtly expressing this bias.
all our descriptive statements are influenced by underlying value judgments, and without such frameworks, we would struggle to communicate effectively with one another.
the preference for bananas can appear as a personal preference, yet its significance is debatable.
upon close examination of my food preferences, they may uncover strong connections to formative experiences in early childhood, relationships with family members, and various cultural influences as significant as societal norms.
this assertion is particularly valid concerning the foundational beliefs and values inherent in the society i am part of, such as the importance of maintaining good health, the biological roots of gender differences, and the inherent value of human life over animals like crocodiles.
while disagreements may arise, they stem from shared fundamental perspectives intertwined with our social environment that, if altered, would require a complete transformation of our way of life.
viewing literature merely as an 'objective' descriptive category is inadequate, just as it is insufficient to regard literature as a mere designation based on whims.
the value judgments regarding literature are not arbitrary but rooted in fundamental belief systems akin to the sturdy foundation of the empire state building.
therefore, it is evident that literature is not a tangible entity like insects, and the ever-changing value judgments shaping it are closely linked to societal ideologies.
ultimately, these judgments are not solely about personal preferences but are deeply intertwined with the power dynamics of different social groups.
to validate this assertion, one can examine the historical emergence of 'literature' in england.
in the 18th century in england, the notion of literature was not limited, as it sometimes is today, to just 'creative' or 'imaginative' writing.
it encompassed the entirety of esteemed writing in society, including philosophy, history, essays, letters, and poetry.
a text was considered 'literary' based not on whether it was fictional – as there was uncertainty during that era regarding whether novels were even literature – but on whether it adhered to specific standards of 'polite letters'.
essentially, the criteria for what constituted literature were openly ideological: writing that reflected the values and 'tastes' of a specific social class qualified as literature, while items like street ballads, popular romances, and even drama did not.
therefore, at that time in history, the inherent bias in the concept of literature was quite evident.
the distinction between 'factual' and 'imaginative' writing had been long acknowledged.
the term 'poetry' or 'poesy' historically denoted fiction, championed notably by philip sidney in his apology for poetry.
however, during the romantic era, literature started to be closely associated with the 'imaginative', where writing about non-existent entities took precedence over documenting factual realities such as birmingham or physiological processes.
the word 'imaginative' embodies a dual meaning reflective of this shift: while carrying connotations of 'imaginary' as in 'literally untrue', it also signifies an esteemed quality of being 'visionary' or 'inventive'.
as contemporary individuals influenced by the romantic era rather than positioned after it, we find it challenging to fully comprehend the distinctiveness of this historically specific notion.
most english writers of the time would likely have considered it strange that we now exalt their 'imaginative vision' while belittling those who focus on topics like the black death or the warsaw ghetto as merely 'prosaic'.
it was during the romantic era that the term 'prosaic' started to take on a negative connotation, implying something mundane, uninspiring, and lacking in poetic flare.
the preference for what is nonexistent over what actually exists, the elevation of poetry and imagination above prose and factual accounts, reflects a deeper societal characteristic of the romantic period.
however, the idealistic aspirations and vibrant energies unleashed by these revolutions, energies that breathe life into romantic literature, come into a potentially tragic conflict with the harsh realities of the emerging bourgeois governments.
in england, a crudely materialistic utilitarianism is swiftly gaining ground as the primary ideology of the industrial middle class, objectifying facts, simplifying human interactions to monetary transactions, and disregarding art as non-lucrative decoration.
the indifferent practices of early industrial capitalism displace entire communities, reduce human existence to labor-for-wage, impose a dissociating work process on the newly established working class, and fail to grasp anything that cannot be commodified in the marketplace.
in the face of formidable challenges, the emphasis placed by the romantics on the 'creative imagination' is not mere daydreaming but holds significant importance.
it suggests that 'literature' stands out as a rare refuge where the creative principles marginalized by industrial capitalism in english society can find appreciation and validation.
this notion of 'imaginative creation' offers a counterbalance to the alienated nature of labor imposed by capitalism; the intuitive and transcendent qualities of the poetic mind serve as a dynamic critique of rationalist and empiricist ideologies fixated solely on 'fact.' the literary work itself emerges as a mysterious and cohesive entity, in opposition to the fragmented individualism of the capitalist market - described as 'spontaneous' versus calculated, and creative instead of mechanical.
therefore, the term 'poetry' encompasses more than a writing technique; it carries profound social, political, and philosophical connotations that might provoke a drastic reaction from the ruling class.
the imaginative quality referred to as 'transcendental' not only posed a challenge to weak rationalism but also provided writers with a reassuringly absolute alternative to history itself.
this detachment from history was an accurate depiction of the situation experienced by romantic writers.
in a time where art was transitioning into a mere commodity and romantic artists were seen as little more than minor producers of goods, their claims to represent humanity and proclaim eternal truths felt increasingly detached from reality.
despite their fervent idealism, romantics found themselves on the fringes of a society that did not value their prophetic voices.
consequently, the impassioned ideals of the romantics took on a more philosophical, rather than pragmatic, nature.
without a significant role in the social changes needed to transform industrial capitalism into a fairer system, writers retreated into the solitude of their own creative minds.
the era under discussion witnessed the emergence of modern 'aesthetics', or the philosophy of art, through the works of influential figures like kant, hegel, schiller, coleridge, and others.
it is from this period that many contemporary concepts such as the 'symbol', 'aesthetic experience', 'aesthetic harmony', and the distinctiveness of art pieces originate.
in the past, people engaged in creating and interacting with artistic forms for various reasons; however, these practices were now being encompassed under a concept known as the 'aesthetic', giving rise to a new wave of aestheticians aiming to reveal its fundamental structures.
although questions regarding art had been posed earlier, they started to hold a renewed significance during this time.
the essence of social progress lay in nurturing the dynamic and spontaneous energies, yet tempering them with the limitations imposed by a structured social order to prevent chaotic outcomes.
representing a blend of motion and stability, chaos and order, and the interaction between the mind and the physical world, the symbol embodied an absolute spiritual truth.
this truth was not arrived at through analytical reasoning but was grasped intuitively.
the symbol conveyed truths in a way that demanded acceptance without room for questioning – it was either understood or not.
it stood as a central element of an irrational stance that forestalled logical analysis, a trend that has persisted in literary theory.
the unity of the symbol was sacrosanct, discouraging dissection or deconstruction akin to analyzing the holy trinity.
the growth of english studies in the later nineteenth century can be attributed, in part, to the decline of religion.
by the mid-victorian era, religion, a once powerful and steadfast ideological force, was losing its influence over the masses due to the challenges posed by scientific advancements and societal changes.
