consequently, readers are plunged into a boundless linguistic abyss by texts that become "unreadable." literary works possess a certain level of clarity when compared to other types of communication as they inherently recognize their rhetorical nature.
they acknowledge the distinction between their stated and actual intentions, operating through figurative language that adds ambiguity and open-endedness.
essentially, they exhibit an ironic quality.
while all forms of writing are equally figurative and open to interpretation, literary works do not pretend to provide absolute truths like other genres.
according to de man and his colleague hillis miller, literature is self-deconstructing and reflects on its own processes, making it inherently self-aware.
the yale critics' textual ambiguities are seen as distinct from the poetic ambivalences explored in new criticism.
rather than aiming to merge two specific interpretations, as the new critics did, the process of reading according to the yale critics involves navigating between two conflicting meanings that cannot be reconciled or dismissed.
this view transforms literary criticism into a somewhat ironic and unsettling endeavor, delving into the inherent emptiness of text, revealing the elusive nature of meaning, the futility of seeking truth, and the deceptive aspects of all forms of discourse.
however, this form of anglo-american deconstruction can be interpreted as a resurgence of traditional new critical formalism, but in a more intensified manner.
while the new critics believed that poetry could indirectly reflect elements of reality beyond the text, deconstructionists argue that literature serves to highlight the inherent limitations of language, suggesting that it can only reflect its own failures rather than convey any definitive truths.
literature is presented as a realm devoid of clear references, a graveyard for communication.
cautious individuals tend to avoid making decisions in unclear situations, which can impact their approach to social and political matters.
literature thrives on ambiguity, making it the perfect example of such uncertainties.
the new critical movement's focus on literary texts can simultaneously disconnect from the real world while attempting to analyze and deconstruct its meaning.
while past literary theories struggled with the complexities of experience, contemporary challenges revolve around the fluidity and complexity of language.
ultimately, despite the evolving terminology, the underlying perspectives on the world have remained largely consistent.
these texts are intentionally obscure as they lack substance, offering little opportunity for further analysis beyond appreciating the thoroughness with which any trace of textual significance has been erased.
this eradication of meaning is a fundamental aspect of deconstruction in academic circles.
if your critique of another critic's interpretation of a text retains even the slightest remnants of 'positive' meaning, then someone else will inevitably deconstruct your work as well.
this process of deconstruction is a strategic maneuver, akin to traditional academic rivalry but with a spiritual overtone where triumph lies in self-emptying.
the victor is the one who successfully discards all preconceived notions and judgements, standing metaphorically empty-handed.
however, like any narrative, the post-structuralist story has a contrasting viewpoint.
despite the american deconstructionists believing their textual pursuits aligned with jacques derrida's ethos, jacques derrida himself disagreed.
he observed that certain american applications of deconstruction contribute to reinforcing 'an institutional closure', favoring the dominant political and economic interests of american society.
derrida's intentions extended beyond creating new reading methods; for him, deconstruction is fundamentally a political endeavor, aiming to deconstruct the rationale that upholds a specific system of thought, and consequently, an entire framework of political and social institutions.
his goal is not to deny the existence of ascertainable truths, meanings, identities, intentions, or historical continuities; instead, he aims to view these concepts as byproducts of a broader and more profound history involving the unconscious, social institutions, and practices.
it cannot be denied that his own work has often been criticized for being historically inaccurate, politically avoidant, and showing a lack of consideration for language as 'discourse'.
it is important to note that there is no simple dichotomy between an 'authentic' derrida and the distorted interpretations of his followers.
while deconstruction is often perceived as rejecting the existence of anything beyond discourse or promoting a realm of absolute difference where meaning and identity disappear, this view misrepresents derrida's intentions and the valuable contributions inspired by his ideas.
even though the oppression of women involves concrete aspects like motherhood, household chores, workplace bias, and unequal pay, it transcends these elements.
it also delves into sexual ideologies, how men and women perceive themselves and each other in male-dominated societies, and a spectrum of behaviors ranging from explicit to subconscious.
any political ideology that disregarded these issues was bound to become obsolete.
sexism and gender norms impact the fundamental personal aspects of human life, so a politics that ignored human experiences was inherently flawed.
the transition from structuralism to post-structuralism partly emerged as a reaction to these political necessities.
it is untrue that the women's movement solely possesses a monopoly on 'experience,' as is occasionally suggested.
socialism too has been shaped by the aspirations and struggles of countless individuals across generations, who have devoted their lives, and sometimes even given their lives, in pursuit of ideals beyond mere economic or doctrinal considerations.
it is oversimplified to conflate the personal with the political: while it holds true that the personal is indeed political, it is equally important to recognize that there are distinct aspects to both realms.
political battles cannot be completely equated with personal experiences, and vice versa.
the women's movement correctly dismissed rigid organizational structures and overly comprehensive political theories.
however, in doing so, it frequently emphasized the personal, spontaneous, and experiential aspects as if they were sufficient for a political strategy, disregarded theoretical frameworks in a manner resembling common anti-intellectualism, and showed indifference to the sufferings of anyone other than women and their political solutions in certain sectors, much like certain marxists had appeared indifferent to the oppression of individuals beyond the working class.
the perpetuation of patriarchal structures was not solely due to the benefits men gained from it, but also stemmed from a complex interplay of fear, desire, aggression, masochism, and anxiety that demanded closer scrutiny.
feminism was not just a standalone issue or campaign but a fundamental aspect that critiqued all aspects of personal, social, and political existence.
the essence of the women's movement, as perceived by those not directly involved, extends beyond advocating for gender equality, to question the very nature of power dynamics and societal hierarchies.
it emphasizes not only the importance of gender inclusivity but also presents a philosophical viewpoint suggesting that without incorporating feminine perspectives into history, the world's survival may be at stake.
in the preceding chapters, i have indicated a correlation between advancements in modern literary theory and the tumultuous political and ideological landscape of the twentieth century.
however, such upheaval encompasses more than just wars, economic downturns, and revolutions; it deeply affects individuals on a personal level.
it signifies a crisis in interpersonal relationships and individual identities, in addition to being a societal upheaval.
it is not to suggest that feelings of anxiety, persecution, and inner turmoil are exclusive to the period spanning from matthew arnold to paul de man; these emotions have been present throughout history.
what distinguishes this era is the manner in which these experiences are formalized into a structured body of knowledge.
this body of knowledge is known as psychoanalysis, pioneered by sigmund freud in late nineteenth century vienna.
i will now briefly outline freud's doctrines.
humans are willing to tolerate repression as long as they perceive some benefit from it; however, excessive demands may lead to illness.
this illness, termed neurosis, occurs when individuals are subjected to too much repression.
since every individual experiences some level of repression, it is suggested that the human race can be considered a 'neurotic animal'.
it is crucial to recognize that neurosis is intertwined with both our creativity and the roots of our discontent.
one way we manage unfulfilled desires is by 'sublimating' them, a concept introduced by freud which involves channeling these desires towards socially acceptable pursuits.
for instance, unaddressed sexual frustrations may unconsciously manifest in endeavors such as bridge or cathedral construction.
marx analyzed the social implications, classes, and political structures resulting from the necessity of labor, while freud studied its effects on our psychological well-being.
the core contradiction in freud's work lies in the idea that our true selves are shaped through repressing elements of our past.
just like how individuals are often unaware of the societal forces influencing their lives according to marx, we are also oblivious to the desires we suppress into the unconscious, as per freud's theory.
a curious point to ponder is why humans, rather than creatures like snails or tortoises, are prone to neurosis.
the infant will nurse at its mother's breast out of biological necessity, but during this process, it also experiences pleasure.
according to freud, this pleasurable sensation marks the initial emergence of sexuality.
the baby's oral stimulation transforms its mouth into an 'erotogenic zone,' a concept later manifested in behaviors like thumb-sucking and kissing.
this intimate bond with the mother evolves into a new libidinal dimension, signifying the birth of sexuality.
initially intertwined with biological instincts, sexuality gradually evolves into an autonomous force, distinct from basic survival urges.
freud views sexuality as a deviation, moving away from inherent self-preservation instincts towards alternative objectives.
throughout infancy, various erotogenic zones are activated, with the oral phase, the first stage of sexual development, centered on the urge to assimilate external objects.
it is evident that in this state, the child cannot be seen as a potential productive citizen.
it exhibits traits such as anarchy, sadism, aggression, self-centeredness, and an unrelenting pursuit of pleasure, driven by freud's pleasure principle.
furthermore, it displays a lack of regard for gender distinctions, not yet embodying what can be described as a 'gendered subject,' as its libido is not differentiated between masculine and feminine.
to thrive, the child must be guided, a process famously described by freud as the oedipus complex.
the child transitioning from the pre-oedipal phases mentioned exhibits not only anarchic and sadistic behaviors but also displays incestuous tendencies.
the boy's intimate connection with his mother's body fosters an unconscious yearning for a sexual union with her, whereas the girl, who has also been closely linked with her mother and initially expresses homosexual desires, subsequently redirects her desires towards her father.
the initial bond, or 'dyadic' relationship, between the infant and mother has evolved into a triangular dynamic involving the child and both parents.
consequently, the parent of the same gender will be perceived as a rival by the child in terms of affection towards the parent of the opposite gender.
the reason the boy-child chooses to give up his forbidden desire for his mother is due to the father's threat of castration.
this threat may not always be explicitly stated, but the boy comprehends that the girl is figuratively 'castrated', leading him to fear a similar fate for himself.
consequently, he suppresses his incestuous feelings, aligns with the 'reality principle', acknowledges the father's authority, distances himself from the mother, and consoles himself with the subconscious idea that even though he cannot presently replace his father and have his mother, the father represents an achievable position he can take on in the future.
while not a patriarch now, he aspires to become one.
by reconciling with his father, identifying with him, the boy transitions into the symbolic role of manhood.
in the future, he will eventually step into the role of a father, contributing to society through the process of sexual reproduction.
his previous scattered sexual energy has now been channeled and organized through the oedipus complex, focusing primarily on genital sexuality.
failure to resolve the oedipus complex successfully may result in sexual difficulties.
he might prioritize his mother's image over other women, possibly leading to homosexuality, or he may struggle to form fulfilling sexual relationships with women due to deeply ingrained issues related to the perception of women as 'castrated'.
the depiction of the young girl's journey through the oedipus complex is far from simple.
it is important to acknowledge that freud, influenced by the male-centric norms of his time, struggled to understand female sexuality, which he referred to as the 'dark continent'.
his work reveals biased and demeaning views towards women, which taint his analysis of the girl's progression through the oedipal phase.
the girl, realizing her perceived inferiority due to being 'castrated', shifts from her mother to her father in a bid to fulfill her desires.
however, as this endeavor is futile, she reluctantly reverts to her mother, identifies with her, embraces her feminine role, and unknowingly replaces the coveted penis with a symbolic desire for a child from her father.
there is no clear reason for the girl to relinquish this desire, as she is already "castrated" and not susceptible to castration threats.
this raises questions on how her oedipus complex unravels since "castration," instead of deterring her incestuous longing like in boys, actually enables it to flourish initially.
additionally, for the girl to navigate the oedipus complex, she must shift her affection from the mother to the father.
this transition of love objects is a more intricate process compared to the boy who can continue loving the mother, presenting further complexities in female oedipal development.
everything seems to be in order to reinforce traditional gender roles, delay personal gratifications, conform to authority, and perpetuate family and societal norms.
however, amidst all this, the rebellious and disobedient unconscious mind has been overlooked.
as the child evolves, it forms an ego and establishes its individual identity within various relational and societal structures.
this process necessitates the suppression of shameful desires into the unconscious mind.
the individual resulting from the oedipal complex becomes divided between the conscious and unconscious realms, susceptible to the haunting return of repressed thoughts.
while colloquially 'subconscious' is often used instead of 'unconscious,' it undermines the profound distinctiveness of the unconscious by simplifying it as a readily accessible entity just beneath the surface.
in any case, dreams serve as a compelling illustration of how the unconscious mind exhibits remarkable creativity, likened to a laid-back and under-equipped chef who creatively combines a variety of ingredients to form a makeshift dish.
just like this chef improvises by replacing missing spices or using the available ingredients of the day, dreams opportunistically incorporate remnants of the day, blending daily occurrences or nighttime sensations with long-buried childhood memories.
dreams are a key gateway to the unconscious, yet not the sole one.
according to freud, "parapraxes," such as slips of the tongue, memory lapses, and misinterpretations, can also reveal unconscious wishes and intentions.
additionally, the unconscious can surface through jokes, reflecting libidinal, anxious, or aggressive tendencies.
the most detrimental impact of the unconscious is seen in psychological disturbances, where repressed desires attempt to manifest but are blocked by the ego defensively, resulting in neurosis.
patients may exhibit symptoms that reflect and conceal these unconscious desires, leading to a complex internal conflict.
a more challenging condition to manage is psychosis, where the ego becomes overwhelmed by unconscious desires, unlike in neurosis where such desires are partially suppressed.
in psychosis, the ego loses control to the unconscious mind, causing a rupture in the connection between the ego and the external world.
consequently, the unconscious constructs an alternate, delusional reality.
those experiencing psychosis, such as individuals with paranoia and schizophrenia, lose touch with reality in significant ways.
while a neurotic person may develop a paralyzed limb, someone in a psychotic state might believe their arm has transformed into an elephant's trunk.
paranoia involves a structured form of delusion encompassing persecutory, jealous, and grandiose delusions, according to freud.
he attributes the root cause of paranoia to an unconscious defense against homosexuality, where the mind transforms the object of affection into a rival or persecutor.
this systematic reinterpretation of reality confirms suspicions by altering perceptions and beliefs.
the patient may resist the analyst's attempts to access her unconscious through various familiar techniques.
however, if the transferential process proceeds successfully, it can lead to the resolution of her issues by bringing them into her consciousness.
by appropriately terminating the transference dynamic at the right moment, the analyst aims to alleviate the patient of her problems.
an alternative description of this process is that the patient can retrieve and acknowledge repressed memories from her past, enabling her to construct a new, more comprehensive narrative about herself that provides insight and understanding of her struggles.
referred to as the 'talking cure', this therapeutic method is expected to yield positive results.
freud's work in psychoanalysis can be succinctly captured by his own phrase: "where id was, there shall ego be." the idea is to replace the overwhelming influence of unconscious impulses with reason and self-control.
despite freud's belief in the supremacy of reason and experience, he did not underestimate the complexities of the human mind.
he recognized our inherent predisposition for pleasure seeking and avoidance of frustration.
in his later studies, he introduced the concept of a destructive death instinct that drives humanity towards self-destructive behaviors.
the ultimate aim, according to freud, is a return to a state of non-existence to evade harm to the ego.
freud's empathy towards the ego reflects his empathy towards humanity, struggling under the overwhelming expectations imposed by a civilization founded on desire suppression and delayed gratification.
while he dismissed utopian ideas to alter this situation and held conventional and authoritarian social beliefs, he still viewed positively efforts to dismantle or improve private property and national institutions.
this was rooted in his profound belief that contemporary society had grown oppressive due to its repressive nature.
freud's intricate and innovative theory naturally sparks intense debates and criticisms.
freudianism has faced numerous challenges and should not be viewed without scrutiny.
one major concern lies in how it validates its principles and supports its arguments; an example is when an american behaviorist psychologist commented that "freud's work lacks testability." the applicability of freud's concepts to contemporary scientific standards is questionable due to his reliance on outdated scientific views prevalent in the 19th century.
despite striving for impartiality and objectivity, freud's work is inevitably influenced by "counter-transference," colored by his unconscious desires and at times distorted by his conscious ideological convictions, as evidenced by the presence of sexist values within his theories.
equally significant is the criticism that psychoanalysis, when practiced as a medical treatment, can be perceived as a method of controlling society oppressively by assigning labels to individuals and pressuring them to conform to arbitrary standards of 'normalcy'.
this complaint is often directed not just at freudian psychoanalysis but at the field of psychiatric medicine in general.
however, when considering freud's own perspectives on what is considered 'normal', this criticism may not be entirely accurate.
contrary to common belief, freud's research shed light on how flexible and diverse human libido can be, challenging conventional notions of normal sexual behavior and highlighting that what is labeled as a sexual deviation could actually be part of a standard spectrum of human sexuality.
while it is true that freudian psychoanalysis often involves some concept of a sexual standard, it is crucial to recognize that such norms are not inherently determined by natural factors.
freud has faced familiar criticisms that are difficult to confirm.
one common critique questions the plausibility of a young girl desiring to have a baby with her father.
whether this assertion holds true is not determined by mere 'common sense.' it is vital to acknowledge the enigmatic nature of the unconscious as depicted in dreams, which differs significantly from the rationality of the conscious ego, before hastily discrediting freud based on intuition alone.
another prevalent objection is the notion that freud oversimplifies by attributing everything to sexuality, being labeled a 'pan-sexualist.' however, this view is overly simplistic as freud's thinking was fundamentally dualistic and not solely fixated on sexual aspects.
while freud did view sexuality as essential to human behavior, he balanced this perspective by acknowledging non-sexual drives such as self-preservation instincts.
therefore, while sexuality held a crucial place in freud's theories, it did not entail reducing all human activities to sexual motivations.
parental roles, child care practices, and the associated images and beliefs are all culturally influenced aspects that can significantly differ across societies and historical eras.
the concept of 'childhood' is a relatively recent construct, and the diverse historical family structures encompassed by the term 'family' render its utility limited.
despite variations, a common belief that appears pervasive in these institutions is the perceived inferiority of girls and women compared to boys and men, uniting societies worldwide.
this deep-seated prejudice, rooted in early familial and sexual development, has led to the recognition of the significance of psychoanalysis by some feminists.
feminists have turned to the french psychoanalyst jacques lacan, a freudian theorist, for insights, despite his unsupportive views towards the women's movement.
lacan's approach represents a distinctive effort to reframe freudian concepts in a manner relevant to those studying the human subject, its societal role, and particularly its relationship with language.
this focus on language also captivates literary theorists.
in his ecrits, lacan endeavors to reevaluate freud's principles through the lens of structuralist and post-structuralist discourses.
although this approach results in a complex and at times perplexing body of work, it is crucial to explore to comprehend the interconnectedness of post-structuralism and psychoanalysis.
i have discussed freud's perspective on the early stages of infant development where a clear distinction between subject and object, self and external world, is not yet present.
lacan refers to this stage as 'imaginary', describing it as a state where there is no distinct center of self, leading the self to blend with objects and vice versa in a constant interchange.
during the pre-oedipal phase, the child shares a 'symbiotic' connection with the mother's body, blurring the boundaries between them.
the child relies on the mother for survival, but one can also envision the child perceiving the external world as reliant on itself.
the young child, still grappling with physical coordination, encounters a unified reflection in the mirror that is both satisfying and slightly illusory.
the relationship with this mirrored image is at an early stage and falls into the realm of the 'imaginary'.
it represents a merging of self and reflection where the boundaries between subject and object are blurred.
this marks the initial steps towards developing a sense of self-awareness.
the self, portrayed through the mirror, has a predominantly narcissistic quality: it emerges through recognizing a reflection of oneself mirrored by an external entity.
this external entity is both a part of the self that the child identifies with and yet also distinct, almost foreign.
the mirror image perceived by the young child can be seen as 'alienated' in nature as the child gazes upon it with a sense of familiarity and yet a slight disconnect, finding a pleasing coherence that is not entirely mirrored in their own physical form.
lacan's concept of the imaginary pertains to the realm of images where identifications are formed, yet in this process, individuals often misperceive and misrecognize themselves.
during childhood and beyond, one continues to engage in such imaginary identifications with external objects, forming the basis of the ego.
lacan views the ego as a narcissistic mechanism through which a fabricated sense of unity is reinforced by seeking identification with external entities in the world.
in exploring the pre-oedipal or imaginary phase, we delve into a state where the essence is simplified into two entities: the child itself and the predominant other, often the mother, symbolizing the external world for the child.
however, as highlighted in our examination of the oedipus complex, this initial 'dyadic' structure undergoes a transition towards a 'triadic' one, as the father intercedes and disrupts this equilibrium.
the father embodies what lacan defines as the law, primarily manifested as the societal prohibition on incest.
this intrusion unsettles the child's intimate bond with the mother, prompting the child to acknowledge the father as a representation of a broader familial and societal framework in which it is a mere component.
not only does the child inhabit a role within this network, but this role is predetermined by the societal norms within which it is raised.
upon the father's arrival, the child becomes enveloped in post-structuralist unease.
now, it must comprehend saussure's argument that identities are formed through the distinction that one term or subject defines itself solely by excluding another.
notably, the child's initial encounter with sexual distinction coincides with its early exploration of language.
the infant's cry functions more as a signal than a true sign, conveying its needs such as hunger or discomfort.
as the young child begins delving into language, it subconsciously grasps that a sign holds significance by differing from other signs and recognizes that a sign implies the absence of the object it represents.
language serves as a substitute for objects: all language can be seen as inherently 'metaphorical', stepping in for a direct, non-verbal possession of the object in question.
the subject's identity is formed by its relationships of both difference and similarity with other subjects in its vicinity, a concept it begins to grasp.
this realization leads the child from the realm of imagination to what lacan identifies as the 'symbolic order': an established framework of societal and sexual roles and connections inherent in family and society.
in freudian theory, this marks the child's completion of the challenging journey through the oedipus complex.
nevertheless, not everything is in perfect harmony.
as illustrated in freud's work, the individual resulting from this development is essentially fragmented, with a sharp division between the conscious functioning of the ego and the buried desires of the unconscious mind.
the foundation of our being stems from this initial repression of desires.
a child must come to terms with the realization that direct connection with reality, particularly with the forbidden physical form of the mother, is unattainable.
it is ousted from the realm of complete, imaginative possession to the realm of abstract language.
language is considered 'empty' because it revolves around an ongoing cycle of distinctions and voids: rather than possessing things entirely, the child is compelled to navigate through a never-ending chain of linguistic symbols.
one symbol leads to another, and so forth infinitely, transitioning from the 'metaphorical' realm of reflection to the 'metonymic' realm of language.
lacan explains that desire is the perpetual shift from one symbol to another without definitive resolution.
desire originates from a sense of incompleteness, driving individuals to seek fulfillment.
human communication operates on this premise of absence; words derive significance from what they represent and what they exclude.
engaging with language exposes one to desire, as revealed by lacan's observation that language shapes yearnings.
language fragments and organizes the richness of the imagination, ensuring that there is no ultimate object or meaning to bring coherence to all aspects.
in embracing language, individuals are separated from what lacan terms the 'real,' a transcendent domain perpetually eluding definition and lying beyond established systems of representation.
notably, this separation extends to the maternal body: post-oedipus complex, the pursuit of this cherished entity continues incessantly despite its unattainability.
expressing the truth in a purely unfiltered manner is an unattainable feat.
lacan's perplexing literary style, reflective of the language of the unconscious, hints at the impossibility of conveying an untarnished meaning through speech or writing, debunking the pre-freudian notion.
while we may perceive ourselves as harmonious entities in our waking life, enabling our actions, this unity exists only on the surface level of the ego, just a fraction of our subconscious explored in psychoanalysis.
the ego serves as a facade for a subject that is in a perpetual state of dispersion, devoid of self-identity, interlaced within the discourses that shape it.
the profound disparity between these two layers of existence is strikingly brought to light when one refers to oneself in a sentence.
when i express the intention, "tomorrow i will mow the lawn," the exclamation mark i vocalize signifies a distinct and recognizable point of reference, contrasting with the complex inner workings of my self that is doing the speaking.
linguistic theory categorizes the former as the 'subject of the enunciation', which is the theme conveyed in my statement, and the latter as the 'subject of the enunciating', representing the individual who articulates the words.
while in speech and writing, these two identities may merge to a certain extent, this amalgam is essentially illusory.
the 'subject of the enunciating', the actual person speaking or writing, cannot wholly encapsulate themselves in their words; there is no single symbol that can encapsulate the entirety of one's identity.
thus, i can only allude to myself in language through the practical use of a pronoun, such as 'i'.
the strength of these texts resides in their concealment of their origins, or what can be referred to as their production methods.
this quality bears a striking similarity to the human ego's tendency to flourish by burying the acknowledgment of how it came into existence.
in contrast, numerous modernist literary pieces integrate the act of creation itself as a fundamental element of their content, exposing the process of their formation.
they do not function as barthes's "natural" signs but rather, following the formalists' ideology, they transparently reveal the mechanisms involved in their composition.
this approach is used to prevent being perceived as absolute truth, prompting readers to critically evaluate the limited and subjective ways reality is portrayed, and to acknowledge that events could have unfolded differently.
one prominent example of this type of literature is bertolt brecht's drama, although numerous other instances can be found in contemporary arts, notably in cinema.
for instance, contrast a typical hollywood film, where the camera merely acts as a passive observer, offering viewers a direct view of reality.
while immersed in such a film, it's easy to overlook that this depiction is not a straightforward representation of events but a carefully orchestrated creation involving numerous individuals' actions and interpretations.
consider envisioning a cinematic scene where the camera moves energetically and restlessly, shifting its focus rapidly from one object to another.
it meticulously explores each object from various angles before abruptly moving on to something else.
this approach, though not considered avant-garde, emphasizes how the camera's activity is highlighted compared to traditional filmmaking.
rather than passively observing the scene's unfolding, viewers are compelled to engage with the deliberate camerawork.
the essence of the sequence lies in its technical execution, not in a preexisting reality for the camera to capture.
the significance and meaning of the scene are derived from the cinematic techniques employed, establishing a unique relationship between what is shown and how it is presented.
the essay queries how individuals frequently conform to the prevailing ideologies in their societies, ideologies althusser deems crucial for upholding the ruling class's power.
it reflects on the mechanisms through which this compliance occurs.
althusser, often viewed as a 'structuralist' marxist, suggests that individuals are shaped by diverse societal factors, lacking inherent unity.
in analyzing human societies scientifically, individuals are considered merely as functions or outcomes of various social structures, positioned within a mode of production or a particular social class.
however, this analytical approach diverges from our subjective experiences of self.
in other words, althusser reconsiders the concept of ideology through the lens of lacan's 'imaginary'.
according to althusser's theory, the relationship between an individual and society resembles the connection between a young child and their mirror image in lacan's theory.
in both scenarios, individuals create a cohesive self-image by identifying with an object that reflects this image in a closed, self-absorbed loop.
however, this self-image involves a misperception as it idealizes the individual's actual circumstances.
the child is not as unified as its reflection may imply, similarly, in the ideological realm, the individual is not the independent, self-sufficient subject they perceive themselves to be, but rather a composite of various social influencers.
enamored by the idealized self-image they perceive, individuals willingly subject themselves to it, ultimately becoming a subject through this process of 'subjection.' many experts now find significant flaws in althusser's insightful essay.
it suggests that ideology primarily acts as an oppressive force that dominates individuals, overlooking the complexities of ideological struggle and containing misinterpretations of lacan.
however, the essay is an effort to demonstrate how lacanian theory extends beyond the confines of traditional psychoanalysis, highlighting its implications in various fields.
by reframing freudian ideas through the lens of language, which is fundamentally a social construct, lacan enables us to explore the intricate connections between the unconscious mind and human society.
his work emphasizes that the unconscious is not solely an internal, turbulent realm within individuals but a product of our interactions with others.
it can be viewed as existing outside or between individuals, akin to our interpersonal relationships.
just like our parents, the world is ready and waiting for us, and we can never fully control or manipulate it to serve our purposes, much like we can never completely break free from the influential role our parents have in shaping us.
in lacanian terms, language, the unconscious, parents, and the symbolic order are interconnected concepts.
while not interchangeable, lacan views them as closely related.
he refers to them as the 'other,' which, similar to language, predates us and remains beyond our full comprehension.
this 'other' is responsible for our formation as individuals but continues to elude our complete understanding.
according to lacan, our unconscious desires are directed towards this 'other,' seeking a fulfillment that remains unattainable.
furthermore, lacan notes that our desires are also influenced by this 'other' in some capacity.
in cases where the father, like walter morel, is burdened with particularly taxing and oppressive work, his role within the family tends to suffer.
morel's interactions with his children mainly revolve around practical household tasks due to his exhausting work schedule.
additionally, his limited education hinders his ability to effectively communicate his emotions, widening the gap between him and his family.
the demanding and regimented nature of his work leads to domestic tension and aggression, pushing his children closer to their mother while fueling her possessiveness.
to compensate for his lack of esteem at work, the father attempts to assert traditional male dominance at home, further alienating his children.
we can extend these considerations to the very structure of the novel, including how it presents and organizes its narrative, character development, and choice of narrative perspective.
the text predominantly aligns with and supports paul's perspective, as the story unfolds mainly through his viewpoint, limiting alternative sources of information.
as paul takes center stage, his father fades into the background.
the novel delves more deeply into mrs.
morel's inner world than into her husband's, emphasizing her character while downplaying his, a technique that strengthens the protagonist's viewpoints and emotions.
however, some elements of the novel appear to contradict this 'angled' portrayal.
daleski, lawrence criticizes morel heavily while also subtly expressing sympathy for him, and although mrs.
morel is initially celebrated, her harsh actions challenge this perception.
in line with lacanian theory, the novel conveys implicit meanings that differ from its explicit statements.
this ambiguity can be partly explained through psychoanalytical analysis, particularly in the complex oedipal relationship between the boy and his father.
the boy, torn between love and unconscious rivalry towards his father, instinctively shields him from his own inner aggression.
another reason for this ambiguity is that the novel acknowledges that while paul needs to distance himself from the narrow, aggressive world of the miners to embrace middle-class values, it also recognizes that this new consciousness is not without its flaws.
morel exemplifies both the controlling and life-suffocating aspects, along with the valuable ones.
the text suggests that walter morel has suppressed his true self, a point that is emphasized heavily by the author, yet it is arguable whether this overt narrative intervention truly adds significant value.
paradoxically, the novel simultaneously portrays elements contradicting this claim.
the passage illustrates how morel's presence continues to influence the narrative despite his physical absence.
the narrative gradually shifts focus from morel to his son, indicating how the story's structure plays a significant role in diminishing morel's character.
furthermore, the text suggests that morel's shortcomings are not solely his own fault but are primarily a result of being exploited by ruthless capitalism that values him only as a means of production.
although paul strives to distance himself from his father's influence, he, too, avoids acknowledging these harsh realities.
ultimately, the novel "sons and lovers" not only explores the working-class experience but also serves as lawrence's personal journey to break free from it.
when analyzing "sons and lovers" through these specific viewpoints, we are essentially crafting a 'sub-text' for the novel - an underlying narrative that exists within it, discernible at certain points of uncertainty, avoidance, or exaggeration.
as readers, we have the ability to elucidate this sub-text even if the novel itself does not explicitly do so.
every literary work harbors one or more such sub-texts, which could be regarded as the 'unconscious' element of the work.
the revelations of a work, like any form of writing, are intricately tied to its omissions: what remains unsaid, and the manner in which it remains so, can be just as significant as what is expressly stated; the seemingly lacking, peripheral, or ambiguous aspects can unlock crucial insights into its interpretations.
this does not imply a complete dismissal or reversal of 'what the novel conveys,' arguing, for instance, that morel is the true hero and his wife the antagonist.
paul's perspective is not inherently flawed: his mother does indeed evoke a far greater sense of empathy than his father.
there are generally four categories of psychoanalytical literary criticism, each focusing on different aspects.
these include analyzing the author, exploring the contents of the work, examining its formal structure, or studying the reader's perspective.
the majority of psychoanalytical criticism tends to concentrate on the first two aspects, which are considered to be somewhat restrictive and problematic.
interpreting the author's psyche is often seen as speculative and raises similar issues as debating the significance of an author's intentions.
meanwhile, examining the unconscious motivations of characters or the psychoanalytical importance of objects or events within the text, known as analyzing the 'content,' though somewhat valuable, can also be oversimplified, reminiscent of the search for symbolic meanings like the phallic symbol.
it is noted that freud's explorations into art and literature predominantly focused on these first two modes of analysis.
freud refers to the dream that arises from this labor as the 'manifest content', the dream we recall.
the dream is more than a mere reflection or replication of the unconscious; a process of 'production' or alteration occurs between the unconscious and the dream we experience.
for freud, the core of the dream lies not in its basic elements or 'latent content', but in the dream-work itself.
it is this 'process' that freud scrutinizes in his analysis.
the literary theories discussed in this book can be viewed as a type of 'secondary revision' of the literary text.
these theories aim to create 'harmony', 'coherence', 'deep structure', or 'essential meaning', by filling gaps, resolving contradictions, and smoothing over conflicts within the text.
the purpose is to make the text more accessible for readers, ensuring a seamless consumption experience without any unsettling irregularities.
many scholars strive to achieve this by neatly resolving ambiguities and presenting the text in a straightforward manner for readers to explore.
one common approach to this secondary revision is evident in the analysis of t.
many of the literary theories we have examined tend to perceive literary works as expressions or reflections of reality, portraying human experiences, conveying an author's intentions, or mirroring the structures of the human mind.
in contrast, freud's analysis of dreams allows us to consider literature not as a mere reflection but as a creative act.
similar to dreaming, language and other literary texts take perceptions of the world and transform them through specific techniques into a product.
these techniques, referred to as "literary form," are the tools used to shape this production.
as a literary text processes its raw materials, it typically refines them through a secondary revision process, striving to organize them into a coherent and engaging narrative, though success may vary as seen with works like sons and lovers.
in order to achieve this, the analysis focuses on particular elements within the dream-text, such as distortions, ambiguities, absences, and omissions, which are referred to as 'symptomatic' places.
these elements can offer valuable insights into the 'latent content' of the text, revealing the unconscious impulses that have influenced its creation.
similar to this approach, literary criticism, as demonstrated in lawrence's novel, can uncover hidden meanings by examining evasions, ambivalences, and moments of intense expression in the narrative.
by exploring unspoken words, repetitions, and shifts in language usage, critics can penetrate beyond the surface of the text and uncover its 'sub-text', which the work both hides and reveals.
in essence, literary analysis can focus not only on what the text communicates explicitly, but also on how it functions.
there are two distinctive american critics who draw inspiration from freud's theories.
kenneth burke creatively combines elements of freud, marx, and linguistics to develop his unique perspective, viewing literary work as a symbolic form of action.
on the other hand, harold bloom utilizes freud's concepts to introduce an innovative literary theory, fundamentally reinterpreting literary history through the lens of the oedipus complex.
in bloom's interpretation, poets are akin to sons feeling burdened by the influence of a 'strong' predecessor, echoing the oppression sons feel from their fathers.
each poem, according to bloom, serves as an endeavor to break free from this 'anxiety of influence' by reshaping prior works in a deliberate manner.
the poet, engaged in an intense oedipal rivalry with the dominant 'precursor', strives to neutralize its influence by immersing himself in it, creating a narrative that revises, displaces, and reinterprets the precursor poem.
consequently, all poems can be interpreted as reinterpretations of existing works, often perceived as 'misreadings' or 'misprisions', as efforts to resist their overpowering impact and make room for the poet's own distinct creative expression.
each poet finds themselves positioned as 'belated', a figure at the end of a literary lineage; the adept poet confronts this belatedness with bravery, working to subvert the authority of the precursor.
essentially, every poem becomes an act of subversion, deploying various techniques that function both as rhetorical devices and psychological defense mechanisms, in order to dismantle and surpass the original poem.
thus, the essence of a poem lies within another poem.
a form of humanism presented here challenges the 'serene linguistic nihilism' prevalent in american deconstruction, moving beyond the constant deconstruction of specific meanings towards a perspective of poetry as an expression of human will and affirmation.
the intense and confrontational nature observed in much of bloom's work, characterized by the intricate use of arcane terminology, reflects the effort and urgency of this endeavor.
bloom's critique vividly highlights the predicament faced by modern liberal or romantic humanists - the impossibility of returning to a tranquil, optimistic human belief post-marx, freud, and post-structuralism, while also acknowledging that any humanism influenced by such rigorous theories, as in bloom's case, is inevitably tainted by them.
bloom's dramatic portrayals of poetic figures still exude the grandeur of a time before freud, yet they have shed their innocence, becoming more about internal conflicts and emotional complexities such as guilt, envy, anxiety, and aggression.
any humanistic literary theory that disregarded such realities could not be genuinely considered 'modern'; however, a theory that acknowledges them is likely to become sober and cynical, leading to a relentless determination to affirm itself.
bloom navigates through american deconstruction enough to return to a heroic human perspective but does so through a nietzschean invocation of the 'will to power' and 'will to persuasion' of individual imagination, which may be perceived as arbitrary and symbolic.
within this male-dominated realm of fathers and sons, the focus intensifies on power, conflict, and strength of will, with criticism being viewed by bloom as a poetic form akin to poems serving as inherent literary critiques.
ultimately, the success of a critical interpretation, for bloom, depends less on its accuracy and more on the rhetorical potency of the critic.
experiencing this loss can be both distressing and invigorating: desire often thrives on what remains slightly out of reach, providing a key source of satisfaction in storytelling.
without the hope of eventual possession, the intensity of our longing could turn unbearable, giving way to dissatisfaction.
it is crucial for us to believe that the desired object will ultimately be restored to us; whether it is tom jones returning to paradise hall or hercule poirot solving the mystery.
this assurance allows us to find satisfaction as our anticipation is relieved, and the twists and turns in the narrative serve to heighten our enjoyment by keeping us engaged until the resolution.
our ability to endure the object's absence is supported by the underlying certainty that it will be reunited with us eventually.
ultimately, meaning is derived from the connection between loss and recovery.
certainly, the reverse holds true as well.
once integrated into the symbolic order, we are unable to perceive or own any object without subconsciously considering its potential absence, acknowledging that its existence is somewhat arbitrary and temporary.
if the mother departs, it is seen as a temporary measure leading up to her eventual return.
however, even upon her reunion with us, we cannot dismiss the notion that she could vanish at any moment, possibly never to return.
traditional realist narratives tend to soothe our fears of absence by emphasizing presence, acting as a 'conservative' force.
in contrast, many modernist works by authors like brecht and beckett prompt us to contemplate that what we observe may have unfolded differently or not at all.
in the realm of imagination, death does not exist because the world's survival relies on my existence just as much as my existence relies on it.
it is only when we delve into the symbolic order that we are confronted with the reality of mortality, as the world does not actually hinge on us.
while we are immersed in an imaginary state of existence, we mistakenly perceive our identities as fixed and reality as unchangeable.
according to althusser, we are ensnared by ideology, accepting social norms as 'natural' without examining how they and our identities were constructed and could potentially be altered.
this rhythmic pattern can be interpreted as a type of language, even though it lacks meaning at present.
in order for recognisable language to emerge, this diverse flow needs to be segmented and structured into consistent terms.
by assimilating into the symbolic realm, this initial 'semiotic' process becomes repressed.
however, this repression is not absolute, as traces of the semiotic can still be observed as an impulsive force within language itself.
these traces manifest through tone, rhythm, the physical and tangible aspects of language, as well as through contradiction, lack of meaning, interruption, quietness, and void.
the semiotic represents the contrasting element of language that is deeply intertwined with it.
originating from the pre-oedipal stage, the semiotic is linked to the child's connection with the mother's physical form, while the symbolic, as previously discussed, relates to the paternal law.
therefore, the semiotic is closely associated with femininity, yet it is not a language exclusive to women, as it originates from a pre-oedipal phase that does not recognise gender distinctions.
james joyce represents kristeva's theories in a remarkable manner in the english language.
however, shades of these theories can also be found in the works of virginia woolf.
woolf's writing style, characterized by its fluidity, expansiveness, and sensuality, resists the traditional male-dominated metaphysical world epitomized by the philosopher mr.
ramsay in "to the lighthouse." ramsay's worldview operates on abstract truths, clear-cut distinctions, and fixed essences, reflecting a patriarchal society where the phallus symbolizes absolute and unchallenged truth.
our contemporary society, as described by post-structuralists, is 'phallocentric' and 'logocentric,' believing in immediate access to ultimate truth through language.
jacques derrida combines these notions, forming 'phallogocentric,' or 'cocksure,' implying an unwavering confidence in those in power.
woolf's 'semiotic' fiction can be interpreted as a critique of this unwarranted certainty that allows individuals with social and sexual dominance to maintain control.
in feminist literary theory, a debated question is whether there exists a distinct feminine mode of writing.
kristeva's concept of the 'semiotic' is not inherently feminine, as most of the writers she deems 'revolutionary' are male.
however, due to its close connection to the mother's body and the belief that women maintain a stronger bond to this body for psychoanalytic reasons, one might anticipate that such writing could be more prevalent among women.
some feminists have rejected this idea, concerned that it may perpetuate an essentialized and non-cultural notion of femininity.
they also suspect that it might resemble the sexist stereotype of women as merely chattering.
it's crucial to understand that kristeva's theory does not necessarily entail these beliefs.
the semiotic is not a replacement for the symbolic order or an alternative language to 'normal' discourse.
instead, it is a process within conventional sign-systems that challenges them.
the female identity is intricately woven within the societal norms, much like any other gender, and yet she is often positioned on the outskirts, deemed inferior to masculine authority.
women exist within the realm of male dominance, both as an admired figure within it, and as a marginalized outsider.
they can be perceived as a force that maintains order in a man's world or as a symbol of disruption and disorder.
this duality challenges the clear boundaries set by such a system.
despite being represented through the lens of a male-driven society, women contain elements that defy easy categorization, remaining elusive and resistant to complete representation within that framework.
according to this perspective, femininity, considered as a mode of existence and communication distinct from women, represents a societal force that challenges it.
this notion directly influences the political landscape, particularly through the feminist movement.
in connection with kristeva's concept of a semiotic force that disrupts established meanings and institutions, the logical political alignment would seem to lean towards some form of anarchism.
while a constant dismantling of fixed structures may not be a sufficient reaction in politics, similarly in theory, assuming that a literary work that destabilizes meaning is automatically 'revolutionary' is flawed.
a text can achieve this subversion in the service of right-wing irrationalism or without any clear purpose.
kristeva's argument can be criticized as overly formalistic and easily caricatured: can reading mallarme really bring about the downfall of the bourgeois state?
while she does not claim that it will happen, she overlooks the political essence of a text, the historical context in which it challenges established meanings, and how these aspects are interpreted and utilized.
simply deconstructing the unified self is not inherently revolutionary.
kristeva is accurate in recognizing that bourgeois individualism thrives on this concept, but her analysis tends to stop once the self is shattered and left contradictory.
in contrast, brecht believes that breaking down societal norms through art is integral to creating a new type of individual, one that embraces not just internal disarray but also social unity.
this new individual would seek not only the pleasures of language but also strive for social justice.
in conclusion, it is essential to highlight a significant and straightforward connection between psychoanalysis and literature.
freudian theory suggests that the underlying drive behind human behavior is the pursuit of pleasure and avoidance of pain, fundamentally rooted in hedonism.
this can be seen as a key link between the two fields.
a vast majority of individuals engage with poems, novels, and plays because they derive pleasure from them.
surprisingly, this seemingly obvious connection is often overlooked in academic settings such as universities.
despite the challenges posed by academic literature programs that sometimes dampen the enjoyment of literary works, those who manage to sustain their pleasure in reading after years of study are arguably either heroic or perhaps considered out of the norm.
in the earlier sections of this book, it was noted that the inherent pleasure derived from reading literature presented a significant challenge for the early advocates who sought to legitimize it as an academic discipline.
there was a need to imbue the subject with a certain level of gravitas to establish "english" as a respected counterpart to classics.
concurrently, in the realms of thrillers and historical fiction, readers continued to voraciously consume romantic novels, largely unaware of the academic world's concerns and anxieties.
the current situation is marked by an interesting observation that the term 'pleasure' is perceived with trivial implications, appearing less weighty compared to 'serious'.
describing a poem as extremely pleasurable can seem less valid critically than asserting it to be morally profound.
there is a notion that comedy is shallower than tragedy.
the contrast between the morally serious nature of cambridge scholars and the oxford scholars who appreciate george eliot for being 'amusing' leaves little room for a comprehensive theory of pleasure.
however, psychoanalysis, among other things, delves into this exact dilemma: its sophisticated arsenal of intellect aims to explore fundamental aspects such as what brings individuals satisfaction or despair and how they can alleviate unhappiness to achieve greater happiness.
if freudianism is viewed as a science focused on impartially analyzing psychological forces, it is a science dedicated to liberating individuals from obstacles hindering their fulfillment and well-being.
it is not implied that psychoanalysis is the sole solution for understanding issues related to literary significance and enjoyment.
our preferences toward language are shaped not only by the unconscious forces they trigger in us but also by our conscious beliefs and inclinations.
the interaction between these aspects is intricate and should be elucidated through a thorough analysis of a specific literary work.
the challenges associated with literary value and enjoyment appear to be located at the intersection of psychoanalysis, linguistics, and ideology, an area that is yet to be extensively explored.
we have some knowledge suggesting that it is indeed possible to articulate the reasons why individuals appreciate certain word arrangements to a greater extent than traditional literary criticism has acknowledged.
a deeper comprehension of the joys and sorrows that readers derive from literature could potentially shed light on more critical issues of happiness and unhappiness.
a significant aspect arising from freud's writings is a unique political-psychoanalytical approach that delves into the concept of happiness within entire societies, distinct from lacan's concerns.
this approach, epitomized by german psychoanalyst wilhelm reich and scholars like herbert marcuse from the frankfurt school, analyzes how societies grapple with the pursuit of instant gratification juxtaposed with deferred fulfillment.
the social, economic, and cultural realms are painted as "eroticized," inundated with enticing products and alluring visuals, while intimate relationships encounter turmoil and disorder.
literary theory is not just a subject of study by itself but rather a unique lens through which we can deepen our understanding of contemporary history.
it is not surprising that any theoretical framework exploring human meaning, values, language, emotions, and experiences necessarily involves addressing broader philosophical questions about individuals, societies, power dynamics, sexuality, historical interpretations, current realities, and future aspirations.
rather than lamenting or criticizing literary theory for delving into these inquiries, we should acknowledge that there is no such thing as a completely detached or pure literary theory unaffected by these considerations.
the concept of a pristine, untainted literary theory is a fallacy of academic discourse, as evidenced by some theories that strive to detach themselves from historical and political contexts but inadvertently reveal their ideological underpinnings.
however, biases are not always covert or unconscious.
in some cases, like matthew arnold's, they are overt, while in others, like t.
eliot's, they are covert but not unconscious.
the issue with literary theory is not just its political nature or its tendency to overlook it, but rather the specific politics it embodies.
in essence, the critique lies in how most of the literary theories discussed in this book have upheld rather than questioned the fundamental assumptions of the existing power structure, as evidenced by its current implications.
this is not to suggest that matthew arnold endorsed nuclear weapons or that there aren't literary theorists who would oppose a system where some profit from arms sales while others suffer poverty.
literature, according to popular belief, is deeply entwined with the real experiences of individuals: it is focused on the tangible rather than the theoretical, showcasing life in all its diverse richness, and shunning unproductive abstract analysis in favor of capturing the essence of existence.
ironically, the evolution of modern literary theory narrates a shift away from these realities towards a seemingly boundless array of alternatives: the poem itself, the ideal society, timeless truths, the human imagination, the workings of the mind, myth, language, and more.
this departure from concrete history can be partly attributed to a response against nineteenth-century historical criticism's overly scholarly and reductive approach; however, the radical nature of this shift remains quite noticeable.
the extremity of literary theory, its stubborn, unconventional, and endlessly imaginative refusal to acknowledge social and historical truths, stands out to anyone studying its texts, even though 'extremism' is a term typically associated with those who emphasize literature's impact on real life.
despite attempting to distance itself from modern ideologies, literary theory often unconsciously aligns with them, exposing its elitist, sexist, or individualistic tendencies through the seemingly 'aesthetic' or 'unpolitical' language used to discuss literary texts.
it operates on the assumption that the contemplative individual self, absorbed in reading and seeking connections with experience, truth, reality, history, or tradition, is at the core of the world.
while acknowledging the importance of interpersonal relationships and the complexities of human existence, literary theory frequently elevates individual consciousness within its narrow circle of interactions as the ultimate measure of significance.
as we stray from the profound introspection of personal life, epitomized by literature, existence can feel increasingly mundane, mechanized, and devoid of personal connection.
any attempt to define literary theory based on a distinct method is bound to falter.
literary theory aims to ponder the essence of literature and literary critique.
consider the myriad methods employed in literary criticism - from delving into a poet's childhood struggles to analyzing their unique syntax, to interpreting sounds evoked by specific words, exploring the experience of reading, contextualizing works within societal conflicts, or even gauging commercial success.
these methods vary significantly and share no fundamental similarities.
in essence, they align more with diverse academic fields like linguistics, history, and sociology than with each other.
therefore, from a methodological perspective, literary criticism emerges as a multidimensional field.
if literary theory is viewed as a form of metacriticism, a critical analysis of critique itself, then it naturally assumes the status of an expansive, multifaceted domain.
it may be seen as fortunate that this approach has yet to influence fields like medicine or aeronautical engineering.
however, one should not dismiss this method entirely as the inklings and hunches one possesses stem from deeply ingrained assumptions that can be just as persistent as those of a structuralist.
interestingly, this kind of 'intuitive' criticism relies on 'intelligent sensitivity' rather than a strict 'method', and it does not always identify ideological implications in literature.
despite this, there is no inherent reason why it could not.
certain traditional critics differentiate themselves by claiming to engage with literature directly, without subscribing to theories.
they maintain that no theoretical or ideological biases stand between them and the text: for instance, labeling george eliot's later works as exuding 'mature resignation' is not considered ideological, whereas suggesting they reflect avoidance and compromise is.
engaging in debates with critics who hold strong ideological beliefs can be challenging, as their conviction in the righteousness of their interpretations is profound.
they often believe their readings are completely unbiased.
leavis was deemed 'doctrinal' for critiquing milton, not c.
similarly, feminist critics are perceived to blur the lines between literature and politics by analyzing gender representations in fiction while traditional critics are viewed as politicizing by claiming clarissa in richardson's work is partly to blame for her own assault.
northrop frye and the new critics believed they had successfully combined these two approaches, yet the question remains: how many contemporary literature students engage with their work?
liberal humanism is now viewed as the feeble moral compass of middle-class society, characterized by its mild, delicate, and powerless nature, while structuralism has all but disappeared into the archive of literary history.
the ineffectiveness of liberal humanism highlights its conflicting relationship with modern capitalism.
while it is a part of the sanctioned ideology of society, the actual social structure of capitalism tends to undervalue its principles.
concern for individual uniqueness, enduring human truths, and rich human experiences is not a priority in entities like the foreign office or the boardrooms of corporations like standard oil.
the capitalist system often hypocritically appreciates the arts, mainly as a profitable investment rather than genuine admiration.
despite this, capitalist governments allocate funds to humanities departments in academia.
these departments, typically the first targeted for budget cuts during economic crises, receive this support not only out of hypocrisy or to mask philistine tendencies but possibly due to deeper motivations.
liberal humanism, while being viewed as somewhat ineffective, is considered the most dominant ideology in contemporary bourgeois society.
it prioritizes the notion of the 'individual,' particularly in defending the rights of business entrepreneurs to generate profit at the expense of workers.
this emphasis on individualism also extends to matters such as the right to choose, which often leans towards consumerism, like affording private education for one's child over essentials like school meals.
the enduring aspects of the human experience, such as freedom and democracy, are fundamental to our way of life.
this concept of existence is grounded more in practical instincts, biased judgments, and traditional beliefs rather than abstract theoretical principles.
despite its critics, there is still a place for the arts and humanities in society, even in the face of opposition from those in power who benefit from our democratic freedoms.
furthermore, by giving numerous young individuals the opportunity to indulge in reading books and engaging in discussions for an extended period, it is conceivable that, under specific broader historical contexts, they might not just challenge the values passed down to them but also scrutinize the authority through which these values are imparted.
it is completely acceptable for students to question the values they are taught; in fact, this critical thinking is fundamental to higher education.
the ability to think independently, express dissent, and engage in reasoned debate are essential components of a comprehensive education.
as i mentioned previously, no one expects your essay on chaucer or baudelaire to lead to predetermined conclusions – the emphasis is on effectively employing language in an appropriate manner.
achieving certification from the state as proficient in literary studies relies on the ability to communicate and write effectively in particular ways.
the focus lies on teaching, testing, and certifying these skills, rather than on personal opinions and beliefs, which may be influenced by linguistic constraints.
while individuals are free to think and believe as they wish, proficiency in a specific language is crucial.
the content of what is expressed is less of a concern than the ability to articulate within the parameters of a defined discourse.
varied stances, from extreme to moderate, are acceptable as long as they align with and are communicable within the established discourse framework.
literary studies revolve around the signifier, emphasizing form over content.
instructors assessing proficiency in this discourse will prioritize your ability to speak it correctly over the specifics of what was said.
some staunch defenders of the literary canon have, at times, illustrated how literary discourse can be applied to non-literary writing.
this poses a dilemma for literary criticism, which traditionally focuses on literature as its primary subject, despite comprising techniques that can be used beyond literary texts.
for instance, one could attempt a literary critical analysis of social events like parties, discussing their styles, genres, nuances, and sign-systems.
such an exercise can yield insights as profound as analyzing canonical works like shakespeare's.
therefore, literary criticism must confront whether it is equally adept at interpreting parties as it is at interpreting classic literature, risking losing its distinctiveness if it broadens its scope, or recognize that non-literary subjects can be analyzed under different methodologies such as ethnomethodology or hermeneutical phenomenology.
its primary focus is on literature due to its higher value and significance compared to other types of texts subject to critical analysis.
however, this assertion is flawed as it overlooks the potential worth of numerous films and philosophical works that surpass many pieces included in the literary canon.
the exclusion of these works from scholarly examination is not due to their inability to be scrutinized but rather stems from the arbitrary power of the literary establishment.
one more justification why literary criticism cannot simply restrict itself to specific works based on their 'value' is that criticism plays a crucial role in the literary establishment that deems these works as valuable in the first place.
it is not only individuals or elements that are transformed into significant literary entities through particular treatment, but also shakespeare himself.
shakespeare did not start out as exceptional literature waiting to be recognized by the literary institution; rather, he is viewed as remarkable literature because the institution establishes him as such.
this does not imply that he is not genuinely exceptional literature and that it is solely a matter of subjective opinions because literature does not exist in a vacuum as being 'truly' exceptional or 'truly' anything without being influenced by the ways it is perceived within specific social and institutional contexts.
there are countless ways to analyze shakespeare, but not all approaches qualify as literary criticism.
while i have previously mentioned that critical discourse lacks a fixed meaning, it does, in fact, have specific parameters that exclude certain ways of discussing literature.
it also disqualifies various discursive techniques as inappropriate, unauthorized, non-critical, or nonsensical.
its apparent openness regarding meanings is only equaled by its narrow-mindedness regarding expressions.
essentially, different variations of the discourse are recognized and sometimes accepted, but diverging too far risks being seen as speaking an entirely different language.
such deviation highlights that critical discourse holds power.
being entrenched in the discourse blinds one to this power, as it feels natural and non-coercive to express oneself in familiar terms.
critical discourse operates on various levels, demonstrating the power to regulate language by determining which statements are deemed acceptable or not.
it also influences how writing is categorized into literary and non-literary, separating enduring works from passing trends.
the hierarchy within this discourse establishes authority and power dynamics between those who control and shape it and those who are permitted access.
moreover, it evaluates and validates individuals based on their proficiency in engaging with the discourse.
ultimately, the relationship between the academic literary sphere, where these dynamics unfold, and the societal power structures that benefit from maintaining and expanding this discourse, highlights the intricate interplay between intellectual institutions and broader ideological interests.
in my opinion, the most appropriate course of action for it is to acknowledge that literary theory, like literature itself, is essentially an illusion.
while figures like northrop frye and f.
leavis were real individuals, literary theory ultimately reveals itself to be a construct intertwined with social ideologies.
this illusion is underscored by the lack of a distinct identity setting it apart from disciplines like philosophy, linguistics, psychology, and sociology.
additionally, the notion that literary theory can differentiate itself through a focus on literature is misguided.
therefore, this book can be seen not as an introduction, but as a final tribute, signaling the burial of the very subject it sought to uncover.
in essence, my aim is not to oppose the literary theories i have critically evaluated in this book with a literary theory of my own that purports to be more politically correct.
for readers anticipating a marxist theory, it is clear they may not have been fully engaged with the content of this book.
while there are valuable marxist and feminist literary theories that i acknowledge and recommend for further reading in the bibliography, my focus is not to introduce a new theory.
rather, i question whether it is feasible to discuss 'literary theory' without reinforcing the belief that literature is a separate, defined entity of knowledge.
instead, i suggest considering the practical implications of recognizing that literary theory can analyze the works of bob dylan with the same level of competence as those of john milton.
however, does this not risk expanding literary theory to a degree where specificity is compromised?
wouldn't a 'discourse theory' encounter similar methodological and subject study issues as seen in literary studies?
indeed, there exist numerous discourses and approaches to analyzing them.
what distinguishes the study i propose is its focus on discerning the impacts generated by discourses and how they come to be.
while reading a zoology textbook for information on giraffes pertains to zoology studies, delving into its discourse's structure, organization, and evaluating the effects these elements have on specific readers in practical settings constitutes a distinct endeavor.
this approach could be considered one of the earliest forms of 'literary criticism', often referred to as rhetoric.
rhetoric, a prevalent form of critical analysis from ancient times to the eighteenth century, focused on deconstructing discourses to understand how they are structured to achieve specific impacts.
it was inclusive of various forms of communication, such as speaking, writing, poetry, philosophy, fiction, and historiography, aiming to explore the broader spectrum of societal discursive practices.
central to its approach was the recognition of these practices as mechanisms of power and performance.
despite this emphasis, rhetoric did not disregard the truthfulness of the discourses under scrutiny, as this aspect often influenced their effectiveness on audiences.
it differed from being a 'humanism' driven by an intuitive understanding of language experience or a 'formalism' concentrated solely on linguistic analysis during its principal phase.
as with the most effective radical viewpoints, my stance is deeply rooted in tradition.
i aim to steer literary criticism away from current trendy and modern perspectives that have overly focused on literature as a uniquely privileged entity, or on separating the 'aesthetic' from social influences.
instead, i advocate re-embracing the long-abandoned ancient principles of literary critique.
although my approach may seem conservative, i am not suggesting a complete revival of archaic rhetorical terminology to replace modern critical language.
we do not have to undertake this task as the literary theories explored in this book offer a sufficient array of concepts to help us get started.
rhetoric, also known as discourse theory, explores the formal aspects of language, much like formalism, structuralism, and semiotics.
however, similar to reception theory, it also delves into how these aspects influence communication at the point of reception.
its focus on discourse as a tool of power and desire can benefit from insights from deconstruction and psychoanalytical theory.
