for instance, if one exchanges fish caught in the summer for furs to be worn in the winter, the fish gains value as it can be consumed promptly, while the furs lose value due to potential damage or devaluation during the waiting period.
conversely, the fish's value decreases as it won't remain fresh, whereas the furs' value increases as they will still be usable later on.
to serve as a suitable form of currency, an item must possess these qualities that enhance its value.
it might seem contradictory, but the stronger the desire to possess something or establish a relationship, the more intense and passionate the enjoyment derived from it becomes.
the level of anticipated enjoyment plays a crucial role in determining the intensity of our desires.
surprisingly, this dynamic actually favors the less interested participant, as it is common for the party benefiting less to receive some concessions from the other.
this principle is observable even in the most intricate and close relationships.
in every romantic relationship, the individual displaying less emotional investment holds an advantage because the other party willingly refrains from any form of exploitation from the outset, is more willing to make compromises, and expresses a higher degree of devotion in return for the greater satisfaction they experience.
money possesses a paradoxical quality where its association with lack of character actually highlights its positive aspects.
someone deemed to have a weak character is often swayed more by external forces rather than internal values.
money, being abstract and solely quantifiable, tends to attract individuals solely driven by monetary gain, thereby appearing devoid of inherent character.
this trait is an inevitable consequence of the advantages and emphasis placed on financial wealth over qualitative values.
a distinctive feature of money's power lies in how it motivates sellers more fervently than buyers.
a key aspect of our overall perspective on objects is at play here: when comparing two contrasting sets of values as a whole, the first set may be clearly superior to the second set, even though individual objects or representatives from the second set may excel those from the first.
presented with a choice between all material possessions and all ideal values, we would likely opt for the former since relinquishing it would mean denying life, along with all its ideal aspects.
however, we may readily sacrifice any singular material possession for an ideal one.
in our interactions with others, we acknowledge that one relationship is far more valuable and essential than another when considering the entirety; nevertheless, on specific occasions and in specific contexts, the less valuable relationship may be more enjoyable and appealing.
this gives rise to a broader phenomenon that could be described as the additional value of wealth, akin to the unearned rent from land ownership.
the affluent individual enjoys benefits that go beyond just what his money can purchase.
the merchant serves him with greater reliability and at lower cost than he does for less wealthy individuals.
everyone he encounters, regardless of whether they stand to gain from his wealth, treats him with more deference.
he operates within an environment of unquestioned privilege.
one can see various small perks being bestowed upon those who buy expensive items or travel first-class; privileges that are as unrelated to actual value as the friendly demeanor of a merchant is to the price of the goods being sold.
these perks are an extra, undeserved add-on, and one of the most troubling aspects might be that those purchasing cheaper goods, who are not granted these privileges, have no grounds to complain of being shortchanged.
this can be best exemplified by a minute scenario.
in certain cities, streetcars have two distinct classes with varying prices.
interestingly, the higher-priced class does not necessarily provide any additional physical comfort.
essentially, when a traveler purchases a first-class ticket, they are essentially securing the privilege of mingling with a more elite group of passengers who are willing to pay extra to separate themselves from the second-class passengers.
this means that affluent individuals can gain an advantage by simply spending more money, even if they do not receive any tangible benefits in return for their expenditure.
they project an image of an ambiguous influence that is not limited to attaining a specific outcome, and this impression gets even more robust when the possessions are more fluid and readily available for any purpose.
in other words, the greater the share of money or its convertibility, and the more distinctly money functions as a tool and a conduit devoid of any inherent purpose.
the intrinsic potential of money as a resource is refined into a broad perception of authority and importance that translates into tangible power and significance for the money holder.
it resembles the allure of an artwork, which is not only shaped by its content and connected emotional responses but also by all the incidental, personal, and indirect emotional layers that it enables.
the cumulative sum of these emotions encapsulates the total value and significance of an artwork.
if this explanation of the unearned increase in wealth holds true, then the increase will be more significant when the owner's circumstances offer better opportunities and more freedom to utilize it.
a person with limited resources has the fewest options as their income only covers essential needs, providing minimal flexibility in decision-making.
this flexibility grows as income rises, with each additional earning being more valuable as it can be used beyond fulfilling basic requirements.
consequently, a higher income includes a larger share of unearned increment until a certain income threshold is reached.
at that point, the phenomenon under scrutiny can be viewed within a specific frame, which i find particularly insightful.
nevertheless, instead of invalidating the other relationship, it serves to highlight money's intrinsic characteristics: by distancing itself from specific definitions, money can adeptly navigate the complexities of both internal and external aspects, acting as a pivotal cultural and representational tool for each.
this highlights the unparalleled importance of money in the progression of practical thinking; it successfully minimizes the distinctive traits and narrow focus of various tangible forms.
the downfall in human conceptualizing lies in the higher concept's struggle to encompass a wider range of details, resulting in a gradual loss of specificity.
in ancient athens, during the emergence of monetary transactions in the fourth century, the wealthiest banker, pasion, began his career as a slave.
in turkey, armenians, a marginalized and often persecuted group, commonly engage in trade and money lending, akin to the moors in spain under similar circumstances.
in india, a comparable scenario unfolds where the socially oppressed yet striving parsees predominantly work as money changers or bankers, while in certain regions of southern india, the chetty, a mixed caste facing low status due to imperfect caste distinctions, control financial affairs and wealth.
likewise, the huguenots in france and the quakers in england diligently pursued wealth accumulation due to their vulnerable social positions.
it is nearly impossible to categorically exclude individuals from money pursuits as various avenues inevitably lead to it.
once the quakers had achieved full political equality, they chose to abstain from certain activities that conflicted with their beliefs.
they refrained from taking oaths, which barred them from holding public office.
they also rejected worldly pursuits like adornment, sports, and farming to avoid paying tithes.
consequently, to maintain some semblance of engagement with the external world, they concentrated on financial matters as their primary interest.
similarly, critiques have noted a lack of interest in the sciences, arts, and socializing among members of the herrenhuter community.
apart from religious matters, their main driving force seemed to be a drive for material acquisition.
in the herrenhuter and pietist groups, the emphasis on industry and avarice was seen as a reflection not of hypocrisy but of a declining cultural landscape, waning spiritual pursuits, and a focus on values associated with the material aspects of the world rather than higher ideals.
money is considered merely a tool on an absolute scale, lacking specific attributes derived from actual determinations.
it serves as the unconditional starting and ending point for all transactions.
thus, there are instances where certain groups are not excluded from the pursuit of goals, leading to a universal teleological structure applicable to the entire group.
historical records suggest that the spartans, who prohibited the pursuit of economic gains, exhibited signs of great avarice.
this illustrates how the desire for possessions can surface under circumstances where ownership lacks clarity and restrictions are less enforceable, as exemplified by the impractical distribution of wealth in the lycian system.
reports also indicate that in sparta, there was little disparity in the practical enjoyment of possessions between the rich and the poor over an extended period, with both groups living similarly without significant distinction in their lifestyles.
personal belongings prove more pragmatic to handle, but variations exist: for example, in medieval england, wool was notably practical as a form of currency utilized by parliament for tax allocations to the king and by the king to extract funds from merchants.
money represents the pinnacle of this spectrum.
the distinct attribute of money being void of specific determinacy, which rendered it the most favorable and least resistible revenue source for the marginalized jews, also made it the most straightforward and potent tool for exploiting them.
in relation to the medieval pogroms, instances where persecution targeted affluent jews in some cities and impoverished jews in others do not contradict, but rather underpin the increasing dominance of money.
this paragraph reflects on the significance of fashion, especially when it is imported, as a valued and influential form of social interaction.
just like how our eyes focus best on a distant point, social elements seem to converge effectively when not too close.
the stranger is particularly drawn to money for similar reasons that make it crucial for socially disadvantaged individuals – it offers opportunities not easily accessible to fully entitled persons or indigenous people through specific channels and personal relationships.
the depiction of strangers throwing money to native girls in front of the babylonian temple, leading them to prostitution, underscores this point.
additionally, there is a link between the sociological importance of strangers and money, where the primary interest in money manifests through trade rather than purely monetary transactions.
the prevalence of jews in the profession is underscored by the significant number of those from the diaspora who pursued this trade.
displaced communities, confined within distinct cultural boundaries, struggle to establish solid roots or secure independent roles in manufacturing.
consequently, they rely on intermediary commerce, which offers greater flexibility than primary production.
this is because the realm of trade can be expanded extensively through formal arrangements and can integrate individuals not directly affiliated with the group.
the stranger demands a higher risk premium for his business ventures and loans.
this concept applies not only to the jewish community but is ingrained in the fabric of commerce and finance, playing a crucial role in various aspects.
in this context, i will focus on examples from modern times.
cities like lyons and antwerp, home to major stock exchanges in the 16th century, owed their unique character to the presence of foreign traders who benefited from extensive trading freedoms.
these freedoms were closely tied to the financial transactions that defined these locations: a monetary economy and liberal trade policies share a profound connection, despite occasional historical disruptions and governmental errors.
the involvement of strangers in financial dealings serves as a clear illustration of this interconnectedness.
notably, the financial prominence of certain florentine families during the medici era stemmed from their exile or loss of political power at the hands of the medici ruling family.
to regain strength and significance, they relied on financial transactions as they were unable to engage in alternative businesses away from their homeland.
a closer examination shows how seemingly contradictory but concurrent events demonstrate this interconnectedness.
during the sixteenth century when antwerp was the prominent hub of global trade, its prominence was sustained by the presence of foreigners, including italians, spaniards, portuguese, british, and germans, who settled there and conducted trade.
the local populace of antwerp had a limited involvement in commerce, primarily serving as agents and bankers in financial transactions.
in this international community driven by global trade interests, the natives filled a role typically occupied by outsiders.
the key factor lies in the sociological dynamic between a large group and marginalized individuals.
due to their lack of direct ties to concrete interests, the latter gravitated towards financial dealings.
in the sixteenth century, the initial significant transactions made by modern bankers occurred overseas, regardless of the personal motivations of individual strangers in a group who opted for trading, particularly financial deals.
money transcended local limitations of most purposeful sequences, acting as the intermediary between any starting and ending points.
just as every facet of historical existence seeks an avenue to showcase its distinct qualities and strengths in the purest form, the early substantial modern capital, akin to the ambitious drive of young spirits, sought investments that best exemplified its comprehensive influence, utility, and impartiality.
in the analysis above, we have assumed a particular aspect of the sense of value that may easily obscure its importance to us.
money holds value for us because it enables us to acquire what we value, but it could also be argued that it is merely a means to an end.
it is not logically necessary for the value attributed to the ultimate goals of our actions to be transferred to the means themselves, which, devoid of any teleological context, would be detached from value.
this transfer of value through external associations manifests as a common feature of our thought processes, known as the psychological expansion of qualities.
when a series of objects, forces, or events contains a link that triggers specific subjective reactions in us, for example.
in essence, in any group of people and objects that are linked in some way, the inherent value of one element can influence and spread to the others that might not evoke the same sentiments individually.
since value is not dependent on the physical structure of items, but rather transcends it into a realm of its own, the process of valuation is not restricted by logical boundaries.
instead, it can freely expand beyond the objectively justified relationships between things.
alternatively, an object holds relative value when its perceived worth is influenced by achieving an absolute value.
the fluctuation in its value is evident when a better or more accessible alternative is found for the same purpose, resulting in a loss of value.
this distinction between absolute and relative value is not synonymous with the differentiation between objective and subjective value, as both can manifest in either form.
in this discussion, the terms "value" and "purpose" are used interchangeably, indicating they are facets of the same phenomenon.
the theoretical significance of an idea as a value aligns with its practical implication as a purpose from a volitional perspective.
the establishment of a goal is influenced by the character, mood, and interest of a person, whereas the path towards achieving it is determined by external circumstances.
the idea that we have freedom in deciding the initial step but are restricted in the subsequent actions is particularly evident in the realm of goal-setting.
however, this contrast, which reveals the complex interplay between our internal motivations and external realities, does not prevent a particular objective from transitioning between these two states.
the inherent spontaneity in defining the ultimate aim, coupled with the understanding that the methods used are mentally linked to the significance of the destination, allows these methods to gain a distinct independent value in our consciousness.
moreover, if this framework is accurate, it implies that addressing teleological progressions solely necessitates the existence of the initial energy unit, representing the original purpose.
the potent energy force endures in subsequent actions, driven throughout by the purpose right from the beginning, irrespective of the diminishing awareness of the purpose within the practical series.
the premature establishment of the ultimate goal, in its most extensive and fundamental aspect, is evidently not observed in everyday life occurrences but predominantly in the context of money.
nowhere else has an entity, deriving its value purely from its functionality as a medium and its capability to be transmuted into quantifiable values, captured such a profound and overwhelming psychological significance, evolving into an all-encompassing final objective steering our pragmatic awareness.
the insatiable pursuit of money intensifies as money acquires characteristics of a sheer instrument.
this signifies that the array of items attainable with money proliferates continuously, with objects becoming increasingly vulnerable to the authority of money, thereby rendering money intrinsically less valuable but more potent in comparison to the value of commodities.
the rising significance of money is contingent on its purification from all non-functional elements, consequently averting clashes with the distinct traits of objects.
the degree to which money assumes a paramount role in the perception of value hinges on the significant shift in economic focus from traditional production to industrial endeavors.
the disparity in viewpoints on money between contemporary individuals and ancient greeks arises mainly from its historical function primarily in consumption versus its contemporary pivotal role in production.
this discrepancy is crucial in understanding the overarching purpose of money as a key indicator of the entire economy.
in the past, the prevailing economic interest leaned heavily towards consumption rather than production; agrarian activities predominated, relying on straightforward and customary techniques that didn't demand heightened economic awareness like the evolving industrial sector.
consequently, attention was predominantly fixed on consumption rather than production in the economic landscape.
similarly, the evolution of labor practices mirrors this trend.
indigenous communities predominantly engaged in immediate consumption-driven work rather than accumulating possessions, which symbolize a progression towards further acquisition.
the formation of life encompasses a complex interplay of internal and external factors, making it challenging to pinpoint one as the sole fundamental aspect.
the nature of an agrarian economy is shaped by both its dependability, modest number of intermediary stages, and focus on consumption over production, as well as an orientation towards the essence of goods and a distaste for unpredictability and dynamism.
these attributes are like fragmented reflections of a shared historical foundation seen through diverse perspectives.
they are not easily identifiable or categorizable as they are part of a system where prioritization may not apply, rooted in interconnectedness and cyclical patterns essential despite lacking in comprehensive understanding.
the significance of money is paramount when considering the psychological aspect of how we strive towards achieving our goals.
it becomes evident when we closely examine the relationship between the means we employ and the ends we aim to achieve.
at times, we may deceive ourselves about the true motivations behind our actions, leading our desires to be directed towards objectives different from what we assume.
this prompts us to question whether there are underlying purposes that transcend our conscious awareness.
thus, we ponder where the boundaries of our quest for purpose lie.
if our pursuit of goals does not culminate in the last link we are consciously aware of, could this not suggest an endless continuation of this teleological sequence?
consequently, it seems imperative to remain discontent with any identified purpose that our actions are based on and to seek further rationale in a purpose that extends beyond the known one.
furthermore, no acquisition or achievement provides us with the ultimate fulfillment that is inherently connected to the notion of a definitive purpose.
in essence, the ultimate purpose seems to exist beyond the teleological progression, but it still maintains a connection to the end goal like earthly pathways that continually point towards it.
interestingly, no matter how far one wanders, the ultimate purpose never appears closer than it did initially.
the key issue is not about reaching this ultimate purpose but more about attributing any substance to its conceptualization.
the teleological progressions, aimed at achieving realizable objectives in the world, often halt not upon accomplishment but due to their inherent design.
rather than adhering to a fixed point representing their ultimate purpose, the proposal only puts forth a heuristic regulative principle suggesting that one ought not regard any singularly desired goal as conclusive, but rather keep open the potential for transitioning to a higher aim.
essentially, the ultimate purpose is more of a function or a suggestion.
seen abstractly, it is simply the compression of the idea that initially seemed to negate: that the course of human endeavor and assessment leads endlessly, and that any attained milestones along that journey must inevitably be seen as mere stepping stones in hindsight, no matter the apparent definitiveness prior to attainment.
thus, the promotion of means to the status of an ultimate purpose emerges as a less irrational concept.
while irrationality may persist in specific instances, the essence of the collective teleological progressions contrasts with that of confined phases.
justifying the notion of means becoming ends stems from the perspective that ultimately, ends themselves are merely means.
from the myriad of potential desires, self-directed actions, and gratifications, we arbitrarily designate a particular instance as the ultimate objective, rendering everything leading up to it simply instrumental.
even as we assign paramount importance to a specific endpoint, an impartial observer, and perhaps even we ourselves in hindsight, are compelled to introduce new, truly impactful objectives for the future, susceptible to a similar shift in significance.
amidst this intense interplay between the relative nature of our pursuits and the absolute notion of a final goal, the concept of money regains importance and is further elaborated upon.
acting as a representation and measure of the value of goods, while simultaneously serving as a mere tool and a neutral intermediary phase, money embodies the reality that the values we cherish and pursue are ultimately transient and instrumental in nature.
when money becomes the primary focus for an individual beyond what is considered acceptable in their social and economic environment, it can lead to the emergence of greed and avarice.
it is important to note that the perception of these traits depends on the prevailing economic conditions.
the level of importance placed on acquiring and hoarding money may vary across different contexts, being considered normal in one setting but excessive in another.
in advanced economies, the threshold for being labeled as greedy tends to be higher due to the dynamic nature of money circulation, whereas in less developed economies, this threshold is lower.
conversely, what may be seen as frugal behavior in a less monetized environment could be viewed as avaricious in a context where money flows more freely.
moreover, altruism can also manifest in one's devotion to god, where obeying his commandments stems from a deep love and surrender of the heart, akin to how we strive to fulfill the desires of a beloved individual out of genuine care for their happiness.
additionally, one may find motivation in upholding a world order that reflects a continuous alignment with the will of a supreme principle, where the relationship between god and humanity necessitates obedience as a genuine expression or inherent outcome, irrespective of personal consequences or the reciprocation of joy from god.
often, the awareness of purpose may not entirely align with objective reality and does not simply derive worth from psychological or epistemological interpretations of this impersonal drive.
this psychological truth interacts with various personal intentions and objectives in multifaceted ways.
the dedicated collector carefully hoards his treasures away from others, not deriving pleasure from them himself but vigilantly guarding them, thereby infusing his selfishness with a touch of transcendent appreciation.
normally, possessions are meant to be enjoyed, contrasting with items appreciated without a desire for ownership, such as the stars, or those valued for their inherent beauty, order, or significance, like the universe, which retain worth regardless of personal response.
for possessive individuals, a complex dynamic exists where ownership is crucial, yet its typical personal joys are eschewed in favor of perceiving it as a valuable and meaningful objective in itself.
ownership of land holds a distinct level of honor that sets it apart from other forms of possession, regardless of whether their practical benefits are equal or even greater for the owner.
this uniqueness explains why it has often been safeguarded through sacrifices that are typically reserved for ideals of utmost importance.
embedded within the concept of landed property is an intrinsic value that goes beyond mere utility; historically, being a landowner was considered inherently valuable, beyond just practical terms.
the attachment to land may carry spiritual significance, as seen during the peak of greek civilization.
during this era, selling land was deemed not only a betrayal to future generations but also disrespectful to ancestors, disrupting the family's continuity.
due to the limited supply of land, its symbolic representation of familial unity that transcends individuals and holds a sacred status was greatly valued.
the transformation of goods into a greater purpose that goes beyond mere enjoyment is most prominently illustrated in avarice and greed, aberrations within the pursuit of wealth that increasingly influence similar behaviors.
money, when elevated to an ultimate objective, undermines the intrinsic worth of even non-economic goods.
it vies not to coexist as one of life's ultimate objectives with wisdom, art, personal fulfilment, beauty, and love, but seeks supremacy, subjugating other pursuits as mere tools.
this shift in priorities is especially notable within the realm of economic goods.
insisting on regarding items as invaluable when they can be easily bought back with money may seem senseless.
the precise quantifiability of their monetary worth has stripped them of their unique individual importance and their relevance beyond the purely utilitarian economy.
the abstract nature of money, its detachment from specific personal gratification, fosters an objective fascination with money, appreciating its value that surpasses personal enjoyment.
for those consumed by avarice, money becomes not just a means to an end like other tools, but a final end in itself.
however, it is not even an end in terms of enjoyment.
the miser views money with a reverent distance, keeping it separate from their personal life as an object of almost fearful veneration.
the miser's affection for money is akin to the adoration one feels towards a cherished individual whose mere presence brings joy and contentment.
the miser values money not for any specific pleasure it can bring but for the possession and association with it.
by deliberately resisting using money for personal indulgence, the miser maintains a separation between himself and the money, yet constantly tries to bridge this gap by acknowledging his ownership of it.
the assurance of contentment is further reinforced by the unique connection between desire and achievement that money embodies, unlike other objects of our interest.
the personal outcomes of attaining a wish do not always perfectly mirror the initial sense of lacking that birthed the wish.
the acquisition of an item doesn't simply plug a gap left by desire, leaving everything unchanged.
this perspective is championed by schopenhauer, for whom every fulfillment is merely the removal of a negative void.
however, if one views contentment as a positive entity, then the realization of our desires is not solely the exchange of a negative state for a positive one, combined with a sense of joy; instead, the interplay between a wish and its fulfillment is highly intricate, as desires seldom encompass all facets of an object and its impact on us.
reality scarcely aligns with our desires as a potential category for possession aspiration.
it is a common saying that possessing something we desire often leads to disappointment, as we realize that the reality of having it fails to meet our expectations.
this awareness of the disparity between our desires and their fulfillment through possession is often devoid of any emotional content.
however, money stands out in this regard.
on one hand, it amplifies the gap between our wishes and the objects of our desire.
pursuing money alone inevitably leads to a vague and unsatisfying outcome, lacking a tangible relationship or meaningful connection due to its intangible nature.
when our aspirations are solely fixated on monetary wealth without a clear purpose, it inevitably results in profound disillusionment.
this disillusionment occurs when the fervently sought-after financial prosperity, once attained, exposes its true essence: money is a mere tool, incapable of sustaining its elevation to a higher purpose post-acquisition.
the discrepancy between desire and fulfillment is most prominent in situations where money is viewed as the ultimate goal, and greed has become a chronic trait.
in such cases, the pursuit is solely focused on possessing the desired object rather than deriving any satisfaction from it.
this unyielding focus on ownership results in a lack of disappointment when expectations are not met.
unlike other possessions that are anticipated to provide value upon acquisition, money, in the context of greed, is devoid of any inherent purpose beyond ownership.
money is considered a unique object in that its essence is transparent, leaving no hidden qualities, unlike other possessions.
it is an object devoid of distinctive qualities, rendering it incapable of harboring any unexpected or disappointing elements, unlike other more modest possessions.
those solely seeking monetary gain are shielded from such uncertainties.
the common tendency among people to value aspirations differently from their actual achievements culminates in an unparalleled avidity for wealth.
this insatiable desire only superficially fulfills its intended purpose, representing an illusory and unsustainable pursuit.
conversely, once one is truly content with possessing money, this inherent frailty dissipates.
when considering the correlation between desires and their fulfillment, money emerges as an inadequate yet fitting object of pursuit in the overall design of human fate.
the item being consumed is not actually the intended object, but rather a substitute lacking the desired quality of motivation.
the only conceivable reason for its consumption is to, at least, offset the expenditure.
money, in turn, serves another purpose, resulting in a sense of contentment and marking a peak in the teleological sequence.
this shift does not detract from the satisfaction, despite the failure to serve its subjective final purpose as an entity in itself.
this seemingly mundane yet notably peculiar occurrence exposes a unique teleological aspect of the value of money.
while often not evident in valuable items, making it seem bourgeois and insignificant, it represents the extreme manifestation of money's role as an intermediary that surpasses the actual final purpose.
in this scenario, not only is the authentic concept of saving money disregarded, much like in greed, but also the allure of power and the potential benefits of having wealth for the sake of owning it idly are discarded.
the item, which has lost any significance and intention in its consumption, is used in conditions that are uncomfortable and detrimental simply because the money spent has given it an absolute value.
here, not only is the purposeful action halted by money, but it also regresses into something perverse, as the purposeful valuation process is achieved through a method that lacks direct purpose.
in the realm of the money economy, the squanderer pertinent to the philosophy of money is not someone who recklessly gives away money in kind, but rather an individual who wastefully spends it on senseless purchases that do not align with their situation.
the joy derived from squandering is connected to the act of spending money on any item, distinct from the satisfaction gained from briefly enjoying possessions, the snobbery it may represent, or the excitement of obtaining and using goods.
this pleasure is specifically linked to the act of squandering itself, devoid of concern for the value or context of what is being spent.
this forms the core of greed and wastefulness, as both fundamentally disregard the ability to measure value, essential for setting limits and boundaries to goals, ultimately leading to the enjoyment of possessions.
it is essential to differentiate a true spendthrift from an epicurean or someone merely frivolous, as these traits may coexist within a person.
the spendthrift shows apathy towards possessions once acquired, experiencing fleeting and impermanent enjoyment without finding peace.
obtaining an object marks the end of its enjoyment for the spendthrift.
life mirrors a similar pattern for both the spendthrift and the miser: achieving a goal triggers an insatiable desire for more, indicating a perpetual search for satisfaction rooted in an ultimate purpose, which inherently rejects any clear purpose, focusing solely on the means and near-end moments.
the miserly individual embodies a more abstract form in comparison to the spendthrift.
the distinction lies in the individual's awareness of their intention, which diverges significantly from the ultimate goal.
the wasteful individual approaches objectives more closely as their pursuit of a rational aim concludes at a later point to possess it, treating it as the ultimate destination itself.
this parallels the conflicting outcomes despite the identical opposition in visible results and the absence of a specific guiding purpose.
the concurrent irrationality in both tendencies hints at a complex interaction between the two, contributing to why a person may exhibit both thriftiness and extravagance.
these traits may manifest in various areas of their life or in response to shifting emotions.
the ebb and flow of these emotions manifest as parsimony and lavishness, where the driving force remains constant, only varying in intensity each time.
luxury goods will always cater to demand without surpassing it.
for instance, precious metals serve numerous purposes, such as for crafting jewelry, highlighting their limitless utility.
this is due to their inherent extravagance.
the closer a commodity is to our essential needs for survival, the stronger the demand, yet it may be limited in quantity and reach saturation sooner.
conversely, commodities further removed from necessities are less influenced by natural demand and can endure without significant change in availability.
money differs from precious metals used in jewelry as it does not have to strike a balance between the insatiable craving for it and direct necessities.
instead, it now represents the fundamental requirements for human existence.
this intriguing duality of money, in relation to the desire for it, is demonstrated through detachment in the behaviors of greed and extravagance.
in both cases, money transforms into a pure object of desire.
these actions highlight the conflicting aspects of money, where it both fuels our conflicting psychological urges and simultaneously widens the scope in which they operate.
greed showcases a stagnation in material wealth, whereas extravagance displays a sense of fluidity and expansion.
poverty, alongside avarice and greed, manifests in its purest form within a specific stage of a money-driven economy.
in natural settings unaffected by money economies, where agricultural goods are not solely considered commodities or money values, extreme destitution is less prevalent.
historically, russia took pride in areas less influenced by money economies for having minimal personal poverty.
this phenomenon can be attributed to the easier access to essential needs without relying on money and the heightened sense of empathy towards poverty in such settings.
in monetary systems, compassionate sentiments toward poverty endure a more convoluted path before reaching their true target, often diminishing along the way.
when salvation of the soul is envisioned as the ultimate goal, various doctrines often view poverty as a positive and essential means that transcends mere utility to become an intrinsic and valuable concept.
this shift in perspective can occur at different points in the hierarchy of objectives and for various reasons.
initially, a detachment from worldly pleasures and concerns may lead to this view.
the burden of poverty is then effortlessly lifted from the soul without necessitating a deliberate focus on it.
it is plausible that the earliest christians behaved in this manner, not actively rejecting or striving against material wealth, but simply existing without attachment to it, akin to things imperceptible due to lacking the necessary receptivity.
hence, the intermittent communal practices in ancient christianity fundamentally differ from contemporary communist endeavors, as the former springs from indifference towards material possessions while the latter stems from a heightened embrace of them.
thus, in a situation where indifference to external factors is predominant in principle, this disposition, unlike money, can easily evolve into genuine hatred.
furthermore, the alluring nature of money exerts an even more pronounced influence on this disposition.
being readily available for use at any moment, money becomes a dangerous temptation during moments of weakness, as it facilitates all pursuits and presents itself in its most irresistible form to the soul.
this heightened peril stems from the fact that money, while existing solely as currency in our possession, is the most neutral and harmless entity in the world.
however, for ascetic sensibilities, it emerges as a tangible symbol of the deceptive devil concealed beneath an innocent and simplistic veneer.
consequently, the ultimate defense against both the devil and money lies in maintaining a distance from them and rejecting any association, no matter how innocent it may seem.
hence, the act of obtaining things through money, which levels out the process of acquisition without favoring any particular item, ultimately renders the objects more interchangeable.
this effect becomes even more pronounced as wealth accumulates, encompassing a wider variety of objects and diminishing their distinct values.
when items are beyond our purchasing power, they exert a unique fascination on us.
however, once we can easily buy them with money, their allure diminishes.
this loss of allure occurs not only because we possess and enjoy them, but also because acquiring them through a generic means erases their individual worth.
while this impact may be subtle at the level of individual instances, it is nevertheless present.
i have previously noted the importance of distinguishing between greed and avarice, as they often appear together but have distinct conceptual and psychological differences.
there are instances where these traits manifest independently.
the pursuit of money can be separate from the desire to hold onto it, even at levels where these inner drives remain within normal boundaries.
this separation is often due to the improper prioritization of money as a goal, lacking objective standards, which alters its perceived value as it transitions from being pursued to being used for other purposes.
the disparity between the value associated with money and the pursuit of acquiring it diminishes once it is obtained.
this inconsistency is also evident in the fact that, when acting as consumers, many individuals tend to be less frugal compared to when making business-related decisions.
this behavior might be the basis of a regulation in ancient jewish law which implies that people tend to be more cautious and meticulous in acquiring wealth than in using it.
according to this law, the defendant was always required to take an oath in disputes involving money, with only the grocer occasionally permitted, as mentioned in a passage of the talmud, to swear by his account book.
the varying approach to the management of money can be observed in historical figures such as louis xi and others, who were stringent in revenue collection but generous in expenditures.
generally, there is a notable link between the pace of gaining money and the speed of its disposal.
individuals like gamblers, fortune seekers, and individuals in certain social classes spend money more frivolously and freely than others.
i have highlighted this pivotal moment in the transition between the two segments of the teleological series because it unveils a fundamental aspect of money.
when money is viewed as the primary and most immediate goal in our minds, it possesses a certain quality.
it may be challenging to pinpoint this quality precisely, but the intensity of desire, the focus of our thoughts on it, and the intensity of associated hopes and emotions imbue it with a vibrant aura that makes the concept of money significant, regardless of the quantity.
all our practical aspirations progress in a similar manner.
while these goals remain unattained, they captivate us entirely, leading us to believe that even the smallest sum of money, as it symbolizes solely that particular object and idea, would bring us lasting contentment.
our focus is primarily on the quality of the object, with attention to quantity emerging as a secondary consideration once the quality has been experienced to a certain degree.
this shift in interest is especially evident in our perception of money, which becomes a significant factor in a modified way.
money, being a neutral tool with diverse practical uses, is primarily defined by its quantity rather than its other attributes.
when it comes to money, our main concern is not about its nature or purpose but simply the amount.
the true importance of money, and its effectiveness as a tool, is only fully appreciated when it is acquired and converted into tangible value.
it is then that the significance of its quantity in determining its power as a medium becomes apparent.
quantitative variations in the ownership of money lead to significant qualitative distinctions for the owners.
this fact, often overlooked due to its obviousness, becomes critical when individuals misunderstand money's sheer quantitative essence and mistakenly view its impact solely in mechanical terms.
an illustrative example reveals how different concentrations of money can dramatically influence its qualitative effects.
the circulation of small-denomination banknotes, predominantly held by individuals with limited incomes, distinctly differs from that of higher denominations.
those possessing smaller notes encounter difficulties redeeming them promptly compared to holders of larger notes.
in times of crisis, individuals with smaller notes might hastily demand redemption or part with them hastily at lower values.
below a certain limit, it is advised not to take risks, even if there is a possibility of gaining a large sum with minimal chances of loss.
in this scenario, objective factors typically used to assess the reasonableness of risks become irrelevant.
the use of money values can lead individuals to misinterpret this economic principle by breaking down values into smaller units, enticing those with limited resources to take risks that they should actually avoid.
an example of this can be seen in the issuance of gold shares valued at one pound by mining companies in the transvaal and western australia.
despite their low value and high potential for profit, these shares have been purchased by individuals not normally involved in stock market dealings.
a similar situation arises in the italian lottery.
this scenario demonstrates how the nature of money can significantly change based on variations in its quantity, leading to diverse qualitative implications for monetary issues.
the value and significance of a specific amount of money differ based on whether it falls below or above a certain threshold, primarily determined by the individual's overall financial resources.
adjustments in the amount of money in circulation result in the emergence of novel characteristics and implications.
ultimately, this concept aligns with a broad principle governing the behavior of various systems, predominantly evidenced in the field of psychology.
an escalation in the quantity of factors acting as causes does not invariably lead to a commensurate increase in their effects.
in fact, while enhancing a cause may correlatively augment the associated outcome at a certain level, a significantly greater input becomes necessary to achieve a similar impact at a higher level.
for instance, it is common to observe how the initial working capital generating a specific return within an emerging domain of investment necessitates substantial expansion over time to sustain the same level of return.
it is a common and significant everyday occurrence that almost all stimuli that bring pleasure can initially result in an increase in pleasurable sensations, but eventually, they can lead to their cessation or even to a feeling of discomfort.
the discrepancy between external causal stimuli and the internal sensation they provoke is further demonstrated in the following manner.
objects with minimal economic value, though still possessing value, often do not motivate us to act in ways that align with their economic worth.
for instance, certain items like stamps may hold value in terms of money, yet this value is disregarded and does not influence how we interact with them.
we may anticipate responses from distant individuals to whom we wouldn't think of requesting payment, and who themselves might not have any stake in the matter.
if the recipient holds a similar social standing, we might feel hesitant to include a stamp for their reply.
for example, specific colors or color combinations may be vivid but fail to evoke aesthetic pleasure when not displayed in a space of substantial size.
in such cases, they function merely as sensory stimuli rather than eliciting aesthetic appreciation.
similarly, a historical threshold exists, delineating the stark contrast between individual efforts and their broader historical impacts.
numerous indian ascetics shared teachings akin to gotama's, yet only he achieved the status of buddha.
many jewish teachers delivered sermons similar to jesus', yet he uniquely shaped world history.
this disparity in impact is prevalent across various contexts, underscoring the pivotal role of influential personalities who transcend historical significance thresholds, unlike their lesser-known counterparts who fade into obscurity.
beyond this realm, a higher threshold exists - that of philosophical consciousness.
the varying thresholds of awareness for pleasure and pain sensations present here pose challenges that resist analysis.
recent physiological studies have revealed significant differences in pain sensitivity among nerves in different body parts.
some nerves have thresholds that are six hundred times higher than others, further complicated by the lack of a consistent relationship in sensitivity to pressure at the same location.
comparing thresholds for diverse emotional and non-sensory experiences is complicated due to their heterogeneous nature, making quantitative comparisons unlike those of mechanical or electrical stimuli on sensory nerves.
all connections formed based on other aspects of life possess a degree of stability due to their consistent connection to the individual.
these relationships can resist changes until significant personal growth occurs.
in contrast, money, lacking inherent qualities or ties to a specific personality, can easily transition between individuals without internal resistance.
therefore, the circumstances and contexts related to money can readily adapt to any fluctuations.
for our current discussion, the ability to accumulate money, highlighting its purely quantitative nature, allows it to significantly impact the specific experiences of life.
commonly linked with money are pivotal events that elucidate its fundamental nature, including unearned gains, being just one of its defining traits.
the importance of this concept to our understanding can be clarified by referring to a tenet in marginal utility theory.
according to this theory, each unit within a supply of goods is assigned the value of the least valuable unit, typically utilized for the least essential purpose.
this is because in the event of the loss of any unit, the remaining units would naturally cater to more critical needs, leaving only the least essential ones unmet.
therefore, the unit that would need to be foregone is deemed the least critical.
consequently, the value of a supply of goods is not determined by the various potential uses for the goods, but rather by the least valuable unit's use, multiplied by the total number of units within the supply.
one acknowledged exception to this theory is when a collection of goods forms a unified whole, providing a unique utility effect that surpasses the sum of the individual parts.
take, for example, the impact of a forest, believed to influence climate, weather, soil fertility, public health, and the stability of the nation's wealth.
the forest, viewed holistically, holds value that transcends calculating the utility of separate trees.
similarly, the worth of an army is not determined by the marginal utility of each soldier, nor can the value of a river be assessed by the marginal utility of a single drop of water.
this distinction applies to an individual's possessions as well.
possessing one million marks as an individual not only grants a distinctive status and social standing that is vastly different from the owner of a mere thousand marks.
the subjective importance of this sum extends beyond its corresponding value in smaller increments.
the objective worth of one million marks is not simply a calculation based on the marginal utility of its parts at a thousand marks each; rather, it represents a unified entity akin to the value of a living being where its worth as a whole transcends the sum of its individual components.
in a previous discussion, it was emphasized that regardless of the number of coins involved, the monetary value of an object remains a singular entity.
hence, one million marks, though comprising multiple units, essentially function as an interconnected whole.
the inherent formlessness of money itself is at the core of the conflict between artistic inclinations and financial concerns.
aesthetic priorities often emphasize pure form, with design historically regarded as the paramount aesthetic aspect across various art forms due to its ability to remain consistent regardless of the material used.
however, it is now recognized as a fallacy, and it is essential to acknowledge that the physical size of an artwork significantly impacts its aesthetic value.
even the slightest alteration in dimensions can greatly influence its aesthetic impact, although the essence of aesthetic value still resides in the form itself, such as the interplay between its elements.
despite this, it is evident that the realization and materialization of art also play a crucial role in shaping its character and impact.
interestingly, while many proverbs touch on the subject of money, unlike the vast array of folk songs, only a handful seem to address its overwhelming significance.
avoiding unnecessary repetition doesn't add value to the content.
essentially, focusing our assessments on form leads to a disregard for its quantitative aspects, when in fact, its lack of form is what highlights its importance for determining value.
although the connection between low and high denominations of currency is well understood, there are situations where valuable items like boats or houses cannot be purchased using numerous low-denomination pieces, necessitating the use of a specific high-ranking currency.
this requirement for a particular quality of currency is also seen in transactions involving women, where no amount of other types of money can serve as a substitute.
conversely, in certain regions, gold is reserved for acquiring expensive items, not for buying bulk goods of low value.
these phenomena differ from the gold standard, where gold is demanded for payments exceeding a certain threshold, and other metals are acceptable for smaller transactions.
in the realm of historical psychology, money inherently symbolizes a cognitive trend prevalent in modern science: the conversion of qualitative aspects into quantitative ones.
this concept parallels the neutral mediums responsible for our perception of color and sound.
quantitative variations in these mediums determine whether we interpret qualitative differences as green or violet, or identify notes as a contra a or a high c.
in the fragmented and accidental influence of objective reality on our consciousness, everything is organized based on quantity and numerical value, with the qualitative distinctions in our subjective responses aligning quantitatively with their objective equivalents.
it is possible that the vast array of substances, evident in their chemical interactions, are essentially diverse vibrations of the same fundamental material.
whenever mathematical science delves into specific materials, configurations, or causes of movement, it aims to represent structures and progressions through purely quantitative expressions.
when an individual maintains a significant level of prominence and qualitative uniqueness, it is seen as a remarkably fortunate inheritance, representing a culmination of energies and achievements of humanity.
even in a culture that emphasizes individualism, this democratic inclination remains potent and evolves into a broader worldview, albeit at the expense of undervaluing the inner essence of the soul.
this perspective argues that the greatest virtues are interwoven into everyday life and its mundane moments rather than in heroic attitudes or catastrophic events, which are often deemed arbitrary and shallow.
while we may all experience intense emotions and extraordinary flights of imagination, their ultimate worth is determined by their significance during those quiet, unassuming hours when our true selves truly emerge.
in essence, despite initial impressions and valid criticism, modern times exhibit a prevailing shift toward empiricism, thereby revealing a fundamental connection to modern democracy in both structure and attitude.
empiricism supersedes singular visionary or rational concepts with a multitude of observations, prioritizing quantity over quality of individual instances.
this methodological approach aligns with psychological sensualism's view that our highest reasoning capacities are essentially heightened collections of ordinary sensory components.
interest in quantity is only meaningful when considered alongside what and how, as it is merely an abstract concept on its own.
it plays a fundamental role in shaping our intellectual capacity and serves as a vessel for our appreciation of qualities.
while a balance between both types of interests contributes to a rich tapestry, focusing solely on one, though not rational, holds significant psychological implications in defining periods, individuals, and mental states.
nietzsche's divergence from socialist perspectives lies in his belief that the essence of humanity lies in its quality alone, with the value of an era being determined by a singular exemplary standard.
in contrast, socialism places importance on the widespread presence of desirable conditions and values.
the previously mentioned examples of the contemporary quantitative trend clearly delineate two distinct types.
primarily, the objective substances and events that form the foundation for qualitatively unique subjective interpretations are themselves solely distinguished by quantity.
secondly, the accumulation of elements and forces alone gives rise to subjective occurrences that differ qualitatively and with regard to value perspectives from those that stem from quantitative factors.
money serves as a prime example, representation, or emblem of the modern emphasis on the quantitative aspect.
the increasing availability of commodities for monetary exchange, along with money's transformation into a central and ultimate value, results in items being evaluated primarily based on their monetary cost.
the perceived value of objects is merely dependent on their monetary price, with their quality of value being perceived as directly proportional to their price in monetary terms.
the high or low monetary value of these objects yields two distinct outcomes.
in the scenario where a serf generates goods solely to cover their owed payment to the manor's lord, the latter shows no concern for the overall output.
this becomes crucial when dealing with fractional payments, leading to monitoring, coercion, and oppression.
the establishment of fixed payments based on an absolute rather than a relative amount signifies a shift towards monetary transactions.
essentially, at this stage, achieving full freedom and liberation from obligations for individuals may seem plausible, as the focus is on receiving a set payment, regardless of how it is obtained.
however, in practical terms, this payment can only be acquired by the obligated party through their own efforts, forming the basis of their relationship.
due to these reasons, it has been somewhat considered a significant declaration of personal freedom within civil law.
under classical roman law, it was stated that if payment in kind was refused, then the obligation could be settled using money.
this concept essentially granted individuals the option to satisfy personal duties through monetary means, thus affording them the ability to buy themselves out of such obligations.
for instance, when a feudal lord demanded certain goods like beer, poultry, or honey from a serf, it determined the serf's activities.
however, if the lord instead requested a monetary payment, the serf was liberated as they could choose the activities they preferred, like beekeeping or raising cattle.
in the context of personal labor services, a similar principle applied with the right to designate a substitute, whereby the other party had to accept the replacement, unless their capabilities were questioned.
the initial phase in objectifying and depersonalizing this duty occurs when it is precisely outlined.
consequently, even in early times, there are clear specifications detailing the number of knights and attendants to be hosted, the quantity of horses and dogs allowed to join them, and the provisions of bread, wine, fish, tableware, and table linens that must be supplied.
however, when it came to the actual provision of accommodation and meals, the boundaries of the services offered likely became blurred, intertwining with personal connections.
a more advanced stage is evident when payments in kind are made without the need for lodging.
in such instances, quantifying the supplies becomes much more exact compared to situations where hosting and catering to individual preferences are necessary.
schopenhauer believes that the suffering and joy each individual experiences are predetermined by their inherent nature, and this predetermined amount cannot be exceeded or ignored.
he argues that external circumstances merely alter the way we perceive this unchangeable level of happiness and sorrow.
when applying this outlook on a broader scale to humanity, it appears that all efforts for happiness, material progress, and competition for possessions are simply a reshuffling of existing values without altering the total sum of happiness and sorrow.
therefore, any changes in wealth distribution are essentially about one person acquiring what another has relinquished, whether willingly or not.
this conservation of value aligns with a pessimistic and passive view of life, suggesting that the inability to generate wholly new values underscores the importance of preserving existing ones.
there are two ways to improve this situation.
the most immediate one is to shift the focus of the conflict from fighting against other people to battling against nature.
by tapping into additional resources and forces from nature for human benefit, competition for existing resources is decreased.
it's fortunate that the principle of conserving material and energy applies only to the overall sum of nature and not to the specific portion that humans can utilize through intentional actions.
this smaller portion can be expanded indefinitely by converting more materials and forces into forms that serve our needs, essentially by incorporating them.
advancements in technology show us how to extract even more utility from resources, including those that seem fully utilized.
it is indeed profoundly significant that what distinguishes humans from lower animal species at both a factual and psychological level is their ability for objective contemplation.
this involves setting aside ego-driven impulses and biases in favor of pure objectivity.
this capacity plays a crucial role in fostering the most noble and uplifting outcomes in human history: the creation of a world where conflict and oppression are minimized, and where the pursuit and enjoyment of values are not limited to one individual but can be shared by others.
this challenge, addressed effectively in an objective world, is approaching a solution in a more functional manner.
in transactions where services or benefits are traded for money, one participant obtains a desired item while the other acquires something generally sought after.
due to its universal utility and enduring appeal, every transaction is, in essence, mutually beneficial.
the recipient of the item will only accept it if it fulfills a current need, while the receiver of money values its versatility for future use.
money transactions enhance satisfaction for both parties, unlike bartering, where often only one party is genuinely interested in the item being exchanged.
therefore, exchanging goods and services for money represents the most effective solution to the significant cultural issue stemming from the one-sided benefit of trading possessions.
this solution aims to enhance the inherent objective value by transforming it into a greater amount of subjective value through changes in ownership.
this process, in conjunction with the initial value creation, is evidently a crucial aspect of societal benefit within the broader human context - ensuring the maximum release of the latent value ingrained in the way we shape our life's contents.
observing money's role in facilitating this objective underscores how exchange, embodied in money, is pivotal as the primary social mechanism for addressing this cultural challenge.
it can be argued that changes in the distribution of wealth within a group, despite appearing as mere shifts in form, do not alter its overall significance.
this transformation yields a variety of outcomes both economically and in terms of overall wealth.
the distinctions are not solely quantitative but also qualitative, touching upon the core issues at hand and reverting back to the matter of quantity.
when the same commodity is held by different individuals, it usually results in a quantitative discrepancy in monetary returns.
conversely, when an equivalent sum of money is in the hands of different individuals, it signifies a qualitative shift in its impact on objectives.
the prevalence of social expediency in modern society explains why wealth tends to circulate more quickly among families compared to non-money economies.
money naturally gravitates towards more profitable opportunities, which is particularly evident due to the passive and secure nature of owning money.
money ownership allows for tranquil enjoyment compared to other forms of property, with minimal economic risk and maximum profitability potential.
the ease of transferring money ownership results in efficient economic utility and broadens the scope for achieving its utmost importance through distribution.
as technology becomes increasingly complex, people's lives and activities become more reliant on external conditions.
this heightened interdependence leads to a greater reliance on a growing number of individuals who are mostly valued based on their roles as holders of capital and providers of resources.
their personal characteristics beyond these functions are of little significance in this context.
an individual's personality can be a blend of various qualities, even ones that seem contradictory, creating a diverse range of traits in different people.
it is the fusion of multiple characteristics into a coherent whole that forms a unique personality, giving each trait a personal touch.
rather than a single trait defining a person, it is the combination of traits that shapes them.
understanding the complexity of a person's soul involves breaking it into separate aspects, which when reassembled, reveal their distinct personality.
both phenomena stem from a common origin and represent contrasting aspects of a single process: the contemporary specialization of work allows for a rise in interdependencies while simultaneously leading individual personalities to be overshadowed by their roles.
this results in only one aspect of individuals being emphasized, neglecting all other facets that together form a complete personality.
should this trend be fully realized, the resulting societal structure would share striking similarities with socialism, possibly leaning towards an extreme form of state socialism.
hence, human activities would be elevated far beyond an individual's true psychological essence, resembling the realm of platonic ideals high above the tangible world.
evidences of such constructs are not uncommon: at times, a role within the division of labor appears as an independent, fictitious construct, causing those in the role to lose their distinctive qualities and merely fulfill duties without fully engaging their personality in the rigidly defined tasks.
being viewed solely as a function holder strips away individual relevance, akin to a hotel guest passing through a room.
in such a societal framework taken to its extreme, individuals would become perpetually reliant; their roles would be so narrowly defined that they would depend on others' interventions for completion, with personal abilities secondary to an externally organized work system shaped by completely objective criteria.
in earlier times, individuals managed their few dependencies through close personal relationships that were often irreplaceable.
in contrast, the modern compensation for our numerous dependencies is the ability to detach emotionally from others and the freedom to alter those connections at will.
our reliance on society as a whole has increased due to our complex needs and specialized skills, surpassing that of primitive societies who functioned within small, tight-knit groups.
however, we have become remarkably self-sufficient from specific individuals within society.
their importance to us has shifted to the impartial utility of their contributions, which could just as easily be fulfilled by many others who we are connected to solely through transactions based on monetary value.
this signifies a significantly higher level of autonomy for the vassal in comparison with the serf, despite their duties being essentially equivalent.
the crucial distinction lies not in the bond itself, but in being tied to a specific individual master, which truly contradicts freedom.
even contemporary domestic workers' status is distinguished by the employers' ability to select based on references and personal recommendations, while the worker lacks the opportunity and criteria to make similar choices.
it is only in recent times that the shortage of domestic workers in major cities has occasionally allowed individuals to decline a position for unpredictable reasons.
both parties view this as a significant advancement towards the autonomy of domestic workers, even though the actual workload remains as burdensome as before.
examining a different scenario but within the same context, we could argue that if a particular anabaptist sect were to support polygamy and frequent changing of wives by claiming that it disrupts the internal dependency or female role, it would be like a distorted representation of a fundamentally valid observation.
our general state always comprises a combination of duty and freedom, where one aspect is more prevalent in substance within a certain aspect of life, while the other is more apparent in its structure.
the limitations imposed by a specific commitment feel less suffocating when we have the ability to select the objective, ideal, or personal authorities we adhere to without diminishing our level of dependence.
a similar progression can also be observed among wage laborers in a monetary system.
considering the harshness and compelled nature of their work, it may seem as though wage laborers are merely veiled slaves.
afterwards, we will explore how their status as servants to the objective production process could be seen as a transitional phase towards their liberation.
on a personal level, their connection to individual employers has grown more tenuous compared to earlier labor structures.
although workers are still bound to their jobs similar to how peasants are tied to their land, the frequent turnover of employers in a money-driven economy and the option to select and switch employers made possible by wage payments offer a new level of freedom within their reliance.
unlike slaves, industrial laborers have the freedom to change employers at will, without facing the same dire consequences as a slave attempting to escape a master.
by removing the burden of irreversible dependency on a specific master, the worker is gradually moving towards personal freedom despite their current constraints.
the importance of maintaining slaves and serfs in good working condition was a personal concern for both the slave-owner and the lord of the manor, as it served their own interests due to their authority and responsibilities towards them.
in contrast, the relationship between a capitalist and a wage laborer lacks this intrinsic obligation, and even when present, it is often overlooked.
the liberation of the laborer necessitates a corresponding release of the employer from the benefits derived from bonded labor.
the laborer's current hardships or instability reflect the evolving process of liberation that commences with breaking individual dependency.
social freedom, much like its absence, is fundamentally a connection between individuals.
the expansion of a society signifies a shift from a state of stability and constancy to one of variability and interchangeability among individuals.
true freedom begins with emancipation from the authority of specific individuals.
while the solitary pioneer in the wilderness of germany or america is self-reliant, the urban populace today are independent in a more active sense, although they rely on numerous suppliers, workers, and collaborators, without whom they would struggle.
their associations with others are purely transactional, often involving money.
therefore, urban residents are not reliant on particular persons, but rather on their commodified services, which can be provided by any interchangeable individual.
because money serves as a symbolic representation of abstract group forces, the relationship between individuals and the group is tightly bound by monetary transactions.
this connection mirrors how individuals relate to objects due to the pervasive influence of money.
in a money-driven economy, the abundance of commodities leads to devaluation and a loss of significance in individual objects, rendering them almost worthless.
however, the broader category of objects maintains its importance as our dependence on a multitude of goods increases.
while a specific object may have little value on its own, such as a single pin, it becomes indispensable in modern society.
similarly, the importance of money grows in tandem with this trend, reflecting our deepening reliance on material possessions.
the initial emergence of satire, biography, and drama showcased a naturalistic style that emphasized the significance of the individual.
this coincided with the rise of a money-based economy, which revealed its societal impact.
even during the pinnacle of greek civilization, there was an objective perspective on the world that aligned closely with natural laws.
this perspective also included a strong emphasis on personal freedom and self-determination.
the greeks were slightly behind in formalizing the ideas of freedom and self in theory, which reflected in their less stringent theories of nature.
despite the challenges metaphysics faced in reconciling objective reality with individual freedom, the development of these aspects of culture progressed in parallel.
it seemed that emphasizing one necessitated a similar emphasis on the other to maintain a balanced inner life.
the interdependence among individuals becomes apparent only as the economy reaches its maximum capacity, complexity, and internal interactions.
by removing personal elements, individuals are encouraged to rely on their own capabilities and to appreciate their freedom more positively than they would in the absence of relationships.
money symbolizes this state well as it facilitates connections between people while maintaining personal boundaries; it serves as a precise gauge of material progress yet falls short in capturing individual nuances and personal aspects.
for perceptive minds, the limitations of objective dependencies that money represents serve as a backdrop that highlights the emergence of distinct personalities and their freedom.
certainly, epistemology needs to differentiate between the enduring natural law and the transient aggregate of its manifestations.
its purpose in the realm of cognition seems to revolve around discerning each conceivable manifestation.
the essential entity must be delineated from the personal interpretations through which it is mirrored.
yet, its significance mainly lies in unambiguously specifying every potential perception of the entity.
while the ethical standard surpasses specific actions to which it may apply positively or negatively, its primary purpose remains evaluating any such action.
if there were no actions at all to which it pertained, its actual significance would dwindle to nothing.
in essence, the class of these core elements and principles diffuses from each distinct scenario and the cumulative total of these scenarios, irrespective of their scale.
however, its utter sum is precisely equivalent to its absolute value.
ownership, in its subjective sense, can vary based on the nature of the object possessed.
money stands out as an exception as it is less influenced by this factor.
possessing and utilizing items other than money relies on various factors and efforts.
consequently, ownership plays a significant role in determining the behavior and quality of the owner.
for instance, individuals who own property or businesses but delegate responsibilities become less autonomous, shifting their focus to investments like art collections or horse farms.
this shift not only dictates how they spend their time but also implies specific skills and predispositions.
each possession carries a unique form of ownership that extends beyond mere legal ownership.
it is important to acknowledge the distinct role that money plays in specific monetary transactions.
rather than solely serving as a medium of exchange, money can also function as the central focus, the primary object of a transaction unto itself.
in purely bilateral financial operations, money becomes an end in itself, not only setting aside its function as a tool but also establishing itself as the self-sufficient core of interest.
this distinct monetary dynamic gives rise to its unique norms, autonomous qualities, and specific techniques.
in situations where money displays its individual characteristics and qualities, it allows for a more direct expression of personality in its management compared to when it merely serves as a neutral means to achieve different objectives.
the crucial aspect in such instances is that handling money necessitates a precise and sophisticated technique.
this specialized technique is essential for individuals to cultivate their unique style.
it is only when a particular category of phenomena appears in abundance, requiring a distinct technique to contend with them effectively, that the material becomes flexible enough for individuals to articulate their personal style while managing it.
once the individual's ability to enforce exclusive ownership wanes, others can access what was previously their property, leading to its swift transfer to a new owner.
this cycle continues, with ownership passing to whoever can assert authority over the object.
in societies governed by laws, personal strength becomes irrelevant because collective norms ensure the permanence of ownership and the prevention of unauthorized access.
hence, property is defined as the socially endorsed right to enjoy something exclusively.
this definition is further reinforced when property is valued in monetary terms.
