if an individual possesses money, the constitution of the community ensures that not only does he have access to that money, but also to a multitude of other goods and services.
unlike owning a specific object with limited uses dictated by its nature, owning money implies the potential to obtain a wide range of items.
while public order can protect the rights associated with different possessions based on their intrinsic qualities, like land for farming or a forest for logging, the act of minting money ensures that the money owner can exchange it for various commodities such as grain, wood, or game.
these individual differences revolve around inclinations toward spending, whether one prefers making substantial one-time purchases or numerous smaller transactions, how receiving a large sum of money influences their behavior leading to either wastefulness or increased frugality.
additionally, the passage explores tendencies to overspend impulsively, where each purchase acts as a catalyst for the next one, as opposed to experiencing internal resistance from each transaction, making justified purchases reluctantly.
these characteristics are deeply ingrained in individual personalities and are most evident within a monetary framework.
it is emphasized that these financial behaviors represent a spectrum of attitudes, unlike the diverse personalities that exhibit varying connections with objects and individuals.
the practical impact of artists, officials, preachers, teachers, and scholars is evaluated based on an objective standard and can bring personal satisfaction to the individual based on these benchmarks.
however, the economic prosperity tied to these roles can often diverge from their original ideals.
while financial success may sometimes overshadow the fundamental ideals, particularly for those more attuned to sensitivity and idealism, it can serve as a form of solace or compensation, addressing any sense of inadequacy in achieving their primary goals.
alternatively, it may provide a temporary diversion, ultimately rejuvenating efforts towards the main objective.
if their endeavors fail, they lack the solace, no matter how small, of achieving a tangible secondary victory.
this success, usually in the form of earned money, significantly eases their pursuit of significance.
by clearly indicating that the accomplishment holds value for others, even if it falls short of personal or ultimate objectives, money serves as a practical substitute for a major success.
its concrete nature and quantitative measure offer support and mental relief from the uncertainties of subjective life values, especially during times of transition.
moreover, the detachment of money from abstract ideals shields sensitive individuals from disturbing conflicts in their value system.
thus, freedom can be understood as an internal delegation of tasks, involving a mutual separation and diversification of impulses, interests, and capabilities.
a person is considered free when their different individual abilities grow and function independently towards their unique objectives and standards.
this concept encompasses the conventional notion of freedom from external constraints.
upon closer examination, our experience of a lack of freedom essentially signifies that the inner resilience needed to resist it, the realm of the soul dedicated to an imposed purpose, overlaps with other energies and interests that might otherwise have been spent on other pursuits or joys; only when it interferes with our activities or desirable pleasures do we perceive a forced deprivation as a restriction of freedom.
we would not perceive work assigned to us as an infringement on our freedom unless it disrupted or suppressed other normal or sought-after sensual energies.
achieving complete separation of individual psychic sequences is unattainable as there are necessary connections that present man as a unified entity amid his diverse aspects and behaviors.
total differentiation or liberty within an inner series remains a theoretical impossibility.
the most that can be achieved is reducing the entanglements and constraints to affect fewer specific points of the series over time.
when one series inevitably intersects with another psychic realm, it retains the most autonomy by being generally linked to this realm rather than each of its components.
for instance, intelligence and will are closely intertwined, with intelligence's profound insights and accomplishments relying on the vigorous vitality of the will.
however, if the driving will carries distinct characteristics or particular content, the autonomy and consistency of intelligence are compromised.
intelligence thrives when harmonized with a broad vitality of existence.
however, the intensification of emotions to their fullest extent and their ability to endure might face obstacles if attention is narrowly focused on only one aspect of the other person.
instead, it is when the entirety of the beloved's image shapes one's awareness of them, balancing out each specific trait they possess, that a foundation is laid for love to flourish genuinely and robustly, and to flow naturally.
the inevitable merging of mental energies hinders the individual progress of those energies when they are associated not with a particular facet or phase of the other person, but with their fundamental nature.
it is through this approach that a healthy distance can be achieved, allowing both parties to evolve independently.
the case under consideration here falls within the same category.
the intellectual aspects of the psychic process are intertwined with economic interests, making it challenging to entirely separate the two due to their fundamental nature, which applies not just in isolated instances but within the broader scope of individual and societal contexts.
this interconnection may limit the complete autonomy and liberty of intellectual work, particularly when the economic tie is not specific to a particular economic entity.
the extent to which economic interests can be aligned solely with overarching general interests can create a distance from intellectual pursuits that would not be feasible if the economic focus was on a specific object necessitating particular attention.
traditionally, the most favorable form of property ownership has been land, characterized by its management style, direct usefulness of its yields, and consistent marketability, allowing for a certain level of intellectual engagement without disruption.
issues such as tariff policies, labor protection, association rights, promotion of wholesale or retail trade, and trade regulations, including residency requirements and observance of the sabbath, will evoke varied and often conflicting responses within this intricate framework.
the situation also extends to major corporations and vast land holdings, which share a similar economic status but diverge significantly in their political affiliations.
the amalgamation of classes solely based on income levels loses its real political relevance.
as a result, the state increasingly relies on solutions that accommodate the wide array of interests and inclinations.
this evolution may encounter resistance or be obscured by numerous opposing influences.
by fully retracing back to the ego, it would achieve unity, coherence, and tangibility, which provide significance and worth to what we define as objectivity.
just as in this scenario, the subject surpasses its opposition to the object through complete absorption and transcendence, likewise, in the opposite scenario, the opposition is defeated as objective conduct assimilates all subjectivity without any remnants for the opposition to persist.
money, whether obtained through mortgages, agricultural yields, or land itself, facilitates transactions between landowners and their properties.
it fosters independence from the unique qualities of the land, thereby promoting greater equality among the nobility and other social classes.
the concept of equal rights that prevailed in greek democracies further severs the connection between ownership and social status.
in early german history, land ownership was not an isolated possession but rather a reflection of an individual's affiliation with their local community.
the significance and influence of an individual were not determined by land ownership; instead, possessing specific importance led to the acquisition of particular parcels of land.
this shift resulted in the division of land and its integration into the dynamic sphere of economic activities.
as this trend was eventually halted by the inherent stability of the land, money emerged as a replacement, becoming the most impersonal economic medium.
money proved to be the ideal means to symbolize the separation between existence and possession that was already influencing land ownership.
subsequently, a similar pattern emerged from a different perspective and social stratum in the thirteenth century.
during this era, the rural population, especially in the eastern regions of germany colonized by emancipated peasants closely linked to the developed monetary system, enjoyed a significant degree of autonomy.
however, this autonomy was short-lived as a swift backlash ensued: the feudal system expanded, particularly beyond the elbe river, successfully aiming to tether the peasants to the land.
it is likely that the evolution of private property primarily focused on acquiring tools of labor, such as weapons, rather than the actual produce of labor.
tools are considered crucial as they directly extend our natural limbs, and the resistance encountered when using tools is typically felt at the tip of the tool.
the sense of ownership over tools is more profound compared to other possessions because they enhance one's ability to act.
consequently, tools are integrated into one's identity almost as closely as the body itself.
this interpretation of property highlights how the philosophical concepts of idealism and freedom are enriched by the notion that objects become part of the self, just as the self becomes connected to objects.
the awareness of oneself has expanded beyond its initial limitations and has now intertwined with items that are not directly related to it.
this clearly demonstrates that the concept of ownership essentially signifies the expansion of one's identity onto objects and, by controlling them, the broadening of its sphere of control.
this occurrence clarifies the peculiar situation where, at times, an individual's entire possessions seem to equate the entirety of their character.
in medieval france, there existed a particular group of serfs who, by relinquishing all their belongings to the lord, were entitled to attain freedom as per legal rights.
the significance of this quality for the market is not solely internal to the state, brewery, mine, or bank itself, but in its interconnection with all other stocks and their market conditions.
thus, external events such as major insolvencies in argentina causing a drop in the price of chinese bonds do not inherently impact the security of those bonds.
the value of these stocks, despite their external stability, is influenced by the broader market dynamics, where fluctuations can potentially reduce the profitability of their returns.
apart from the fluctuations in the stock market, which involve combining a single object with others and are objectively generated, there is a significant factor originating within speculation itself.
the bets placed on the future quoted price of a stock play a major role in determining that price.
for example, when a prominent financial group shows interest in a stock for reasons unrelated to its quality, the quoted price tends to rise.
conversely, a bearish group can manipulate the price downward.
in this scenario, the true value of the object seems less relevant compared to the influence of market forces, which inflate prices based on associations rather than inherent worth.
the link between the actual and perceived value of an object through trading has become increasingly uncertain.
this demonstrates the remarkable adaptability of the value system, where the objects have become disconnected from their true essence by adopting a monetary form.
now, value is easily swayed by emotional impulses, greed, baseless opinions with little resistance, exacerbated by the absence of objective indicators for accurate assessment.
the monetary value system has liberatingly distanced itself from its origins to yield entirely to subjective forces.
in this realm, where speculation dictates outcomes, the fluidity and responsiveness of money-based values showcase its profound reliance on subjectivity.
i was once told by someone that they had a strong impulse to purchase everything they truly admired, not for their own sake or to own them, but solely to actively express their fondness for these items.
their sole intention was to allow these items to flow through their hands, imprinting them with the stamp of their unique personality.
money served as a distinct means of extending their identity, rather than for the purpose of possessing material goods.
this individual possessed a personality that was disinterested in dominating objects; their contentment stemmed from the transient influence they exerted over these items.
while it might seem that this lack of a deep connection to objects would not add to their sense of fulfillment, the act of purchasing itself brought them satisfaction as the objects displayed total subservience to money.
compared to typical extravagance, limited to acquiring and enjoying possessions and simply wasting money, this man's behavior is notably eccentric due to his strong attraction to material pleasures closely within reach.
the lack of actual ownership and utilization of items contrasts with the gratification he derives from the act of purchasing, considering it a personal connection with the objects and a source of satisfaction.
this unique dynamic can be attributed to how spending money expands his sense of self, creating a bridge between himself and the material world.
this transactional bond allows his mind to delve into the allure of possession, even if it is not physically attained.
the concept of objects opens up effortlessly and harmoniously to aesthetic contemplation, appearing as if they are guided solely by the fundamental laws of the self.
this results in a sense of liberation integral to the aesthetic experience, freeing one from the mundane pressures of material possessions to allow for a joyful and unencumbered connection between the self and objects that typically exert a heavy influence.
this psychological aspect of finding pleasure in mere ownership of money involves a unique fusion, abstraction, and prelude to actual possession.
it grants consciousness the freedom to extend itself through a pliant medium without resistance, embracing all potentialities without distorting reality, characteristics that are essential components of any aesthetic enjoyment.
the idea that beauty is a promise of happiness underscores the resemblance between the psychological allure of aesthetics and the attraction of money.
ultimately, the appeal of money seems to lie in the promise of the pleasures it can facilitate.
the paradox lies in the contrast between the means typically used to generate wealth, which often lack joy, and the unconventional manner in which individuals express their joy.
however, it is important to recognize that the satisfaction derived from possessing money is a cerebral experience removed from immediate sensory pleasure.
this pleasure is akin to the intense elation felt in victory, where the reward itself may not even be a primary consideration for some individuals.
certainly, greed can extend beyond its limits, yet it exposes its folly through the inherent dissatisfaction inherent in its pursuit, as well as the occasional irony when an excessive accumulation of possessions transforms into something contrary to its original purpose.
this can result in situations such as unprofitable ownership when an owner lacks the effort to yield returns, a tyrant who tires of dominating slaves once faced with unchallenged submission, or a property holder too consumed by managing their assets to actually enjoy them due to exhaustion of time and energy.
the difference between objects lies in their capacity to absorb aspects of personality simultaneously, determining the threshold where possession becomes insignificant as the self can only regulate it until a certain extent.
money, in particular, holds a unique status in this aspect.
it can be argued that managing, controlling, and deriving pleasure from money demands less from an individual in comparison to other possessions.
consequently, one can assert that the magnitude of possessions one can oversee and accumulate as part of their economic persona is greater with money than with other types of assets.
an individual's capacity for growth, constrained by their inherent nature, demonstrates more flexibility and liberty concerning money compared to any other possession.
the distinction from our prior discussions lies in this: previously, it was the distinctive nature of objects hindering self-expansion, while now it's the constraints on personal power that decline once a certain amount of possessions is acquired, despite the inherent flexibility of the items.
this phenomenon is delayed when possessions are in the form of money rather than specific objects.
throughout the history of ideas, we witness a development that, though seemingly straightforward, stands as one of the most significant expressions of intellectual life due to its thorough and profound realization.
initially, particular fields are entirely defined by distinct traits.
over time, this unity diversifies into increasingly specialized subsets, with one capturing the essence of the whole in a limited manner and standing in contrast to other parts.
to put it another way, despite a relative contrast between two elements of a whole, each may still embody the essence of one of them, albeit in an absolute form.
for example, the moral-philosophical argument for egoism may rightly argue that individuals inherently act in their self-interest and for personal gratification.
however, distinction must be made between egoism in a narrower versus broader context.
the influence of wealth in facilitating connections allows the owner and their belongings to be geographically distant from each other, granting them the freedom to pursue their individual principles more independently compared to a time when their relationship was more direct.
in the past, economic transactions held a personal aspect, with any shift in personal circumstances automatically affecting one's economic concerns.
for traditional societies worldwide, there was a strong connection between individuals and their possessions, evident in the practice of burying personal acquisitions with the owner.
such rituals highlight how this close association between people and their belongings hindered cultural advancement, which relies on the accumulation of inherited assets.
it is through inheritance that possessions transcend individual boundaries, gaining autonomy and contributing to broader cultural progress.
the influence of money-driven differentiation and resulting individual freedom extends beyond just the rentier to impact labor relationships.
these relationships, although more subtle, echo similar dynamics.
previously, economic structures like crafts and retail relied on personal hierarchies between apprentice and master, employee and employer.
transactions were rooted in personal connections and carried out under the influence of dominant personalities.
however, as technical and objective factors have gained prominence over personal ones, these dynamics have evolved.
in contemporary settings, such as large department stores, the roles of production managers, laborers, directors, and salespeople are all guided by a common objective purpose, with subordination being a technical necessity for the efficient functioning of production processes.
as we have observed, the money economy has set the stage for the evolution of culture in this direction.
the detachment of workers from their means of production, a situation often viewed as the root of social distress, could potentially be seen as a form of liberation in a contrasting light.
if this separation were to result in the personal distinction of the worker as an individual from the strictly objective circumstances imposed on them by the methods of production, it could be interpreted as a form of redemption.
this scenario exemplifies a common phenomenon in which the significance of a particular element transforms into its opposite once it has realized a fundamental, coherent, and all-encompassing impact beyond its initial limited capacity, as facilitated by money.
the kind and gracious treatment of the bondsman has largely vanished as monetary payments took precedence over contributions in kind, and strict officials replaced the local lords who resided near the serfs.
the introduction of officials marked the depersonalization of management.
these officials operated based on technical standards to achieve optimal results, acting as intermediaries between the serfs and the lords, just as money facilitated transactions between them.
this separation highlighted the role of mediators, leading to potential dishonesty by bailiffs in handling monetary payments on behalf of the lords.
despite the benefits of personal relationships for peasants, transitioning to monetary transactions symbolized a shift towards objectification and fraud.
nonetheless, this transformation was deemed essential for ultimately abolishing serfdom altogether.
the significance of money in this series is highlighted not just by the receiver, but also by the giver.
money allows us to evaluate the overall value of an individual worker's efforts compared to the combined contributions of many individuals, whether it's the tickets purchased by concert attendees, books bought by readers, or the taxes paid by citizens that fund government employees.
this connection is especially apparent in how the money economy is linked to the rise of mechanical reproductions.
following the advent of book printing, the cost per sheet of paper remains consistent regardless of the quality of content, be it mediocre or exceptional.
similarly, with the introduction of photography, a reproduction of a renowned painting costs no more than that of an image of a cabaret singer.
as the mechanized manufacturing of household items became widespread, well-designed utensils are just as affordable as those of inferior quality.
any disparity in earnings between creators is solely due to higher demand for one type over another, with all consumers paying the same price irrespective of the item's merit.
this illustrates the egalitarian nature of money in contrast to the hierarchical systems of feudalism or patronage when bestowing gifts upon esteemed individuals.
conversely, the facelessness of monetary transactions fosters the personal autonomy and unrestricted development of the vendor, guaranteeing their subjective independence.
the swift rise of mechanical reproduction methods, especially, leads to a situation where the price of a product becomes disconnected from its quality.
this disconnect severs the link that tied a specific wage to a particular accomplishment, which previously united the buyer and the producer.
as the distinction between an individual and their achievements deepens, money plays a role in fostering the autonomy of the individual, irrespective of whether this separation stems from the increasing autonomy of the person or their accomplishments.
this societal pattern is pervasive and permeates through individuals.
money not only impacts the constituents of a person but also significantly influences societal components, namely individuals.
this facet of the monetary system is frequently underscored since money serves as a conduit to the accomplishments of others.
in contrast to the time preceding the advent of a monetary system when an individual's reliance was direct on their community and service exchange tightly knit everyone with society, nowadays, each person encapsulates within them a latent entitlement to the accomplishments of others.
everyone holds the power to determine when and where they wish to exercise this entitlement, thereby diluting the direct connections of the former barter system.
money has a significant impact on the relationships between individuals and the broader group, leading to greater independence.
it also brings about a new level of differentiation in the nature of associations and the connection of their members to them.
in medieval times, organizations like guilds encompassed individuals entirely, encompassing technical, social, religious, and political aspects beyond just representing a specific trade.
members were fully engaged in these associations based on shared interests.
however, in today's money-centric economy, numerous organizations exist that solely rely on monetary contributions or focus primarily on financial gains.
a prime example is the joint-stock company, where shareholders are united by their pursuit of dividends with little regard to the company's actual output.
the influence of money in society goes beyond being just a unifier; it can also lead to disintegration, depending on the historical context.
for example, the traditional unity and closeness within families have eroded due to the prevalence of a monetary economy.
families are now often viewed primarily as mechanisms for passing down inheritance.
in cases where a particular interest undermines all other aspects that hold a group together, this interest can end up being the sole remaining bond among the group members.
money not only forges connections due to its inherent nature but also by breaking down existing relationships, creating links between individuals who might otherwise have no association with each other.
a rule that can often be broadly applied to social development is that as a social group expands, the individuals within it tend to become more individualized and independent.
typically, societies begin with small, closely connected groups where members share strong bonds, but as they progress, they evolve into larger groups that offer freedom, independence, and differentiation among individuals.
various examples from family structures, religious communities, economic cooperatives, and political parties demonstrate this pattern.
the significance of money in fostering individuality is intricately linked to its role in expanding social groups.
the relationship between the money economy and the scale of economic entities has been explored previously.
each type of honor originates from an estate or a specific social class, and the honor attributed to an individual or humanity at large is collectively defined by the smaller groups within the broader society.
in situations where honor does not require one to be subservient but instead emphasizes individual distinction, there is a need for a certain level of exclusivity and unity within the group.
for example, the winner of the olympics would be celebrated in a closely-knit region of greece with shared interests.
monetary rewards tend to appeal more to individuals within larger groups due to their self-centered nature.
conversely, the selfless nature of honor, reflecting solidarity within smaller groups, is exemplified by traditions such as the golden wreath awarded for good governance being dedicated to a temple.
even today, within specialized communities like sports or industries, the bestowing of honorary awards is still deemed meaningful and appropriate.
expanding the social group necessitates adopting a system of quantifying merit in monetary values as it leads to the inevitable fragmentation of the group.
as it's challenging to evoke the same level of connection and sentiment in a larger group compared to a smaller one, establishing differences within a larger group necessitates a method where individuals are not solely reliant on the approval and collaboration of the entire group.
during the middle ages in germany, commercial law initially pertained to the collaborative regulations of individual merchant groups.
over time, it evolved into a universal common law, driven by the concept that the entire merchant community of the german empire, and possibly beyond, constituted a vast guild.
consequently, this common law governing merchants transitioned into regulating commercial transactions.
this progression exemplifies how the law shifted from being connected to specific individuals to encompassing broader groups and focusing on objective transactions.
this shift in focus was encouraged by and also promoted the expansion of monetary dealings.
according to a twelfth-century irish manuscript, land was divided due to the expansion of families, and in russia, the shift from communal to private property is evident as population growth promotes this transition.
money is identified as the ideal basis for private ownership, enabling the partitioning of property, establishment of ownership rights, and fulfillment of individual interests.
monetary exchange is essential for expanding economic opportunities, serving as the fundamental mechanism for broadening economic spheres.
money, in its abstract form, originates from economic transactions within a large circle.
its primarily quantitative nature allows for precise mechanical representation of specific demands, individual work values, and personal inclinations.
through this, money fulfills in the economic realm the broader sociological connection between group expansion and individuality development.
the link between money and private property, as well as its role in fostering individual development, is greatly influenced by its mobility, a stark contrast to land ownership.
land ownership surpasses individual ties in two ways: horizontally, as it often suits collective ownership by a group, and vertically, as it is ideal for passing down through generations.
if a primordial group owned only land, development would progress in two key directions.
firstly, as the land produces food, it gains more fluidity, eventually leading to the emergence of private property.
typically, nomadic communities consider land as communal property for the tribe but allocate it for individual families' use, whereas livestock is treated as the private property of these families.
historically, nomadic tribes do not share livestock communally as property.
it has been noted that in the nicobar islands, it is a cultural norm to not inherit assets from relatives, except for trees and dwellings which are considered immovable property and can be passed on to others.
there exists a unique duality in our relationship with possessions, whereby people endure while objects change, and vice versa.
when dealing with movable property, the focus is on the individual, emphasizing their importance.
however, with immovable property such as land, individuals take a backseat as these assets hold more permanence and significance.
land is viewed as a stable foundation on which individual life unfolds, similar to a wave rolling in and out.
this perspective explains the strong connection between landed property and aristocracy, where inheritance plays a key role.
during the merovingian period, the value of the solidus changed from 40 denari to 12 denari.
this adjustment was likely made to lower fines that were previously calculated in solidi, leading to the introduction of a new standard where fines were set at 12 denari instead of 40.
over time, this practice of imposing fines in 12 denari evolved and became widely accepted.
interestingly, in the palau islands, all forms of payment are referred to simply as fines.
it is noteworthy that the severity of an offense was not determined by the different types of coins, but rather by the value assigned to the offense, which in turn determined the monetary penalties.
during the middle ages in the vicinity of florence, various categories of serfs such as coloni, sedentes, quilini, inquilini, adscripticii, censiti, and others existed, with their servitude likely being inversely related to their wergild, leading to no wergild at all for those entirely dependent.
even in the thirteenth century, this antiquated and mostly symbolic standard was still used in courts to determine the credibility of testimonies.
viewed from an individualistic perspective, the concept of wergild should have been upheld more firmly for those who were completely under the ownership of others.
the deviation from this and the hierarchical structure serving as a symbol of the significance of personal testimony underscore the transformation of wergild into a representation of a person's inherent value.
the elevation of the value of human beings can be attributed to christianity, as its beliefs influenced various other evaluations.
however, the full implications of this shift were delayed for quite some time.
the church, although not as proactive against slavery as it should have been, did advocate for compensation in cases of homicide to maintain public order and prevent bloodshed.
despite removing human value from relative and purely quantitative measures, this stance aligns with christian principles.
a key aspect that distinguishes advanced cultures from more primitive ones is the complexity and length of their teleological processes.
the needs of early humans were few and could be fulfilled through a short chain of means if met at all.
through their connection to the one god, they found significance, absoluteness, and transcendency reflected upon them.
the powerful authoritative proclamation that espoused an eternal fate and boundless importance of the soul nullified all merely relative or quantitative differences in value.
the concept of a final mission, which christianity associated with the inherent worth of the soul, has evidently undergone a unique evolution.
just as every desire grows more enduring when satisfied, christianity, by continually emphasizing the idea over time, has deeply instilled the longing for a definitive purpose.
consequently, those who now reject this doctrine will carry with them a sense of unfulfilled yearning for a clear purpose in their existence, as the need has persisted beyond its realization.
the new objective is to impact the individual directly, with any punishment being used as a tool to achieve this goal.
monetary fines now have a different purpose compared to previous compensation for injuries or fatalities.
they are not meant to repay for the harm caused but to cause discomfort to the offender.
therefore, in situations of insolvency, modern law substitutes imprisonment, which not only does not generate revenue for the state but also demands significant expenses.
fines are imposed based on the subjective responses they elicit from the perpetrator.
consequently, fines can instill a personal attribute distinct from money itself.
this attribute is supported by certain qualities that make fines more effective than other forms of punishment: they can be tailored, fully waived, and unlike imprisonment or physical harm in the past, fines do not incapacitate or diminish the offender's ability to work but instead motivate them to make amends for their actions.
in primitive conditions, money can exhibit a contrasting quality from its typical attributes, taking on a sacred and prestigious status.
this notion is exemplified by the rigid rules observed in certain societies, where specific forms of currency were reserved solely for significant or ceremonial transactions, as demonstrated in the practices of the caroline islands.
despite the islanders' self-sufficiency, money holds considerable importance as it influences marriage arrangements, local governance structures, and community standing.
unlike in more developed societies where money primarily fulfills basic needs, in such circumstances, it serves higher social functions beyond mere economic transactions.
among californian indians, even after shell money ceased to be in use, it continued to be offered as a gift to the deceased for their journey to the happy hunting grounds.
at this stage of development, the religious practice of atonement or giving payment in its traditional form implied that regular currency was deemed inadequate for the sanctity of such rituals.
this concept resulted in a devaluation of money, similar to the earlier mentioned opposing trend.
eventually, it separated the value of humanity from the value of currency, which significantly influenced the evolution of the importance of money.
an additional illustration of this concept can be found in the medieval prohibitions against charging interest, which were based on the belief that money should not be treated as a commodity.
rather, money was viewed as static and unproductive, making it sinful to seek compensation for its use in the same way one would for a tangible item.
the separation of a person's worth from monetary value, seen in reducing fines for minor offenses, is countered by another trend.
the legal consequences for wrongdoing are increasingly limited to situations where the victim's loss can be quantified monetarily.
across different cultural stages, this trend appears less frequent in lower levels and progresses at higher ones.
in social contexts where money holds more significance, like urban areas compared to rural settings with a lower socioeconomic status, the value of an individual is often equated to a monetary value.
for example, in modern arabia, tribal vengeance is common in rural regions, while urban centers prioritize monetary compensation through wergild.
the purpose of the law is to penalize any fraudulent act that causes harm to personal assets under the assumption that all such assets hold a monetary value.
the ancient concept of wergild comes into play here, albeit in a basic form.
if compensation for the loss of a personal asset can be made through monetary restitution, it implies that the value of that asset can be equated to money.
nonetheless, contemporary criminal law does not accept that monetary compensation is sufficient for fraudulent damages.
however, there is a prevailing idea that the ill-gotten gains from fraud can be quantified in monetary terms based on the nature of the offense.
only a few instances highlighted by legal professionals need attention here: a landlord prohibiting a tenant from using the garden despite contractual permission, a traveler denied accommodation by a hotel owner despite prior written confirmation, and a teacher breaching a contract with a school principal without arranging for a replacement.
even though these individuals have valid claims to compensation, quantifying the damages in monetary terms is challenging due to the subjective nature of the inconveniences and hardships faced.
without a precise monetary demonstration, these damages may be perceived as insignificant by the judge and may not be acknowledged in a legal context.
it is fascinating to note how roman law, during its middle period, held a contrasting perspective on this matter.
unlike contemporary civil suits, where monetary restitution was typically equal to the value of the object, roman law imposed penalties that exceeded this amount.
these penalties were granted to the aggrieved party as a means of compensating them for any deceit or harm inflicted by the defendant.
for instance, if a deposit was wrongfully withheld or funds entrusted to a guardian for a ward were misused, the restitution did not solely involve returning the money.
the judge, and sometimes even the plaintiff, had the authority to determine compensation not just for the direct monetary loss but also for the intentional violation of the individual's legal rights.
this approach indicates that the principles upheld by the law extend beyond the monetary worth of an object, emphasizing that infractions against personal values necessitate penalties that surpass mere restitution.
in one scenario, money plays a minor role, while in the other, it holds a more significant position compared to today.
this current situation illustrates a blend of the contrasting tendencies that modern culture attaches to the role of money.
on one side, money is elevated to a point where it becomes the driving force behind practical interests, overshadowing personal values when it exceeds its appropriate boundaries.
on the flip side, modern culture detaches money from personal values, diminishing its alignment with authentic personal aspects and ultimately quashing the promotion of personal values instead of settling for an insufficient substitute.
analogies can be drawn to past situations where individuals were valued based on monetary compensation, particularly in the context of the historical practice of purchasing women.
the prevalent occurrence of marriage by purchase, both in civilized societies of the past and in present-day less developed regions, along with its diverse forms, is widely acknowledged.
our focus lies on deriving insights on the types of values that were exchanged in such transactions.
criticisms of the perceived degradation associated with buying individuals for money or its equivalents in modern times may not always be applicable when considering historical contexts.
the corporate-like approach undeniably diminishes the uniqueness of individuals and their relationships.
however, the systematization of marital affairs as seen in the practice of arranged marriages represents a significant advancement compared to the more barbaric practices of forced marriages or primitive sexual unions.
while not entirely promiscuous, these primitive arrangements lacked the stabilizing influence provided by the regulated union of marriage.
throughout history, human development has often necessitated the temporary suppression of individuality as a crucial step towards eventual liberation.
during these transitional phases, the external constraints of life tend to foster spiritual growth, leading to the accumulation of inner strength that later manifests as personal integrity.
though such periods may seem brutal and undignified when viewed through the lens of fully realized individuality, they play a pivotal role in the overall evolution of society.
in narinyeri culture, marriage is traditionally sealed through the exchange of sisters between two men.
when a girl decides to elope with a lover instead of following this custom, she is seen as socially inferior and forfeits the protection that her birth clan would typically provide.
this highlights the communal nature of such marriages, where the clan's support is contingent on the exchange being honored.
by running away, the girl essentially loses the backing of her clan due to the imbalance created by not fulfilling the marriage arrangement.
the introduction of a money economy within the sphere of production combines objective technology, extensive social connections, and wealth alongside the division of labor, resulting in a shift from an earlier state of apathy between domestic and acquisition interests to a need for specialized representation for each.
this evolution clarifies the definitive roles of husband and wife.
the traditional bride price paid by the groom to acquire the woman's productive abilities is now substituted by a dowry.
the dowry serves as a form of compensation for the husband's obligation to provide for the wife, aiming to offer her independence and security alongside her economically active spouse.
this dynamic sheds light on the role of a pimp and the commonly observed incidence of lesbianism among prostitutes.
due to feeling a profound void and dissatisfaction in her interactions with men, the prostitute seeks a different kind of connection where certain qualities of the partner are present.
the belief that sexual activity is universal and impersonal, along with the equal participation of men and women, does not alter this relationship.
for the woman, the stakes are far more personal, essential, and intertwined with her sense of self than for the man.
consequently, a transaction involving money is inadequate and inappropriate, symbolizing a severe degradation of the female individual.
the decline of a woman in prostitution cannot be solely attributed to its polyandrous nature or the multiplicity of her sexual partners.
the increasing appreciation for human life and the diminishing importance of money made it impossible to uphold the practice of wergild.
as individuals gain unique significance, making them irreplaceable, money has become a standard measure that struggles to equate the diverse range of values placed on personal attributes.
in less advanced cultures, the sharp contrast between the worth of goods and their prices, which characterizes prostitution in modern society, is less prominent.
reports from travelers observing barbaric tribes note the physical and sometimes mental similarity between men and women in these cultures, attributed to the absence of the complex values that distinguish highly civilized women.
in these cultures, personal values, particularly regarding sexual integrity, hold a weight that cannot be equated solely in monetary terms, even though women may seem less differentiated and more similar to the general population compared to men of similar status.
another perspective on marriage for financial gain equates it to a form of prostitution, albeit with distinctions yet susceptible to similar critiques as traditional prostitution.
this viewpoint suggests that although the concept is fundamentally polyandrous as well as polygamous, societal norms dictate that only the negative repercussions of polygamy, specifically the depreciation of the female partner, manifest in financially-driven unions.
therefore, it is argued that engaging in a transactional marriage, essentially a form of permanent self-sale, can potentially diminish the dignity of either party motivated by monetary considerations, irrespective of gender.
nevertheless, this generalization is often disproven in reality.
typically, the woman in such unions tends to wholeheartedly commit her interests and efforts to the relationship, offering her complete self, both core and periphery, without hesitation.
in contrast, the man in a marriage is traditionally afforded greater autonomy from the start, often retaining a significant portion of his identity linked to professional endeavors.
nevertheless, various reservations and counterbalancing factors can curb the rapid expansion of dominant power, including tradition, respect, laws, and inherent constraints on power growth.
however, money, due to its unparalleled adaptability and lack of ethical considerations, is least effective in halting this trend.
in relationships driven by financial interests, where one side inherently holds superiority and advantage, these inclinations may intensify in a more extreme and pervasive manner.
it appears as though other, more impartial motives underpin this type of relationship.
advertising plays a significant role in shaping culture by enhancing an individual's chances of finding satisfaction compared to relying solely on chance encounters.
the increasing customizing of personal needs underscores the importance of advertising in expanding the choices available.
however, among the more discerning individuals, particularly those less reliant on advertising, seeking a marriage partner through ads is generally dismissed.
the rejection could be attributed to the emphasis on financial status evident in marriage advertisements, which takes precedence over other qualities that are challenging to accurately portray in such ads.
the unique methodological aspect of owning money makes marriage ads unattainable for the social groups that would benefit the most, as it suggests prioritizing financial matters over genuine connections.
for the owner, the transparency of values when expressed in money provides a straightforward understanding of their possessions.
however, for others, money offers a means to hide and obscure their assets and transactions, a level of secrecy unattainable with physical property.
money's concealability epitomizes its connection to private ownership.
unlike tangible goods, money can be veiled from view, akin to intellectual assets.
just as keeping mental possessions private involves secrecy, money's individualistic nature culminates in its potential for covert handling.
this secrecy poses a significant risk for those with stakes in economic management but lack direct control over it.
conversely, within small circles, individuals representing the public interest wielded a kind of mystical authority and maintained a level of secrecy that surpassed that of their counterparts in larger groups.
in larger groups, the expansion of their authority, the objectivity of their methods, and their detachment from individuals enabled them to accept the public visibility of authorities' actions.
consequently, politics, administration, and law progressively shed their secrecy and exclusivity, while individuals gained more opportunities to retreat and exclude outsiders from their personal matters.
by examining english and german history or exploring cultural developments over the past two centuries, one can observe this interconnectedness.
this differentiation process is also evident in the religious realm, particularly during the reformation.
certainly, the necessity of warmth can be just as pressing and critical for survival as the need for food.
however, its application is more indirect compared to that of food.
the path to survival involves several intermediary steps, allowing a person being tempted to have more time for contemplation than they would for more immediate needs.
money is the most removed from direct enjoyments; its allure always lies in what it represents, making the temptation emanating from it less of a primal instinct that could justify yielding to it.
it is remarkable that aristides, with his significant authority, passed away impoverished, a phenomenon considered uncommon.
in the ancient small city-states, the integrity of an individual seldom rocked the core of society as only a fraction operated on a monetary system, fostering transparent and straightforward relationships that could be maintained in equilibrium effortlessly.
consequently, it is accurate to state that athens' destiny was hinged on daily deliberations on the pnyx.
in today's intricate public landscape, with myriad hidden influences of the monetary system permeating every facet, corrupting officials have far more destructive repercussions.
the traditional classification of objective norms into logical, ethical, and aesthetic categories falls short when considering practical judgments.
for instance, we appreciate the uniqueness and individuality of a person, valuing their distinct form and influence.
we find value in the unparalleled representation of a person's own essence, even if it contrasts with ethical or aesthetic standards.
rather than seeking a comprehensive normative system, it is crucial to highlight that a systematic approach is inadequate in this context, akin to the limitations posed by sensory perception or kantian philosophical categories.
human evolution constantly introduces fresh ways to engage with the world both emotionally and intellectually, as well as novel criteria for assessment.
the positive outcome of this transformation stemmed from the fact that one party, who had previously brought personal strength and individual determination to the relationship without receiving a fair equivalent, was met with impersonal offerings from the other party.
the rights gained from the relationship remained impersonal, while the obligations undertaken were highly personal.
by converting these obligations into monetary payments, they became depersonalized, eliminating the imbalance between them.
however, the scenario changes if the obligated party cannot be simply compensated with a tangible return, but has gained rights, influence, and personal significance through the relationship due to their distinct personal contributions.
in such cases, transitioning to monetary payments will result in unfavorable consequences, contrasting with the positive outcome in the initial scenario.
the inherent implications of historical constellations can be organized in a progressive manner, where each connection accommodates both the liberty and the suppression of elements depending on their specific relationships.
it is evident that individual relationships can be characterized by either the oppressive submission to another person or the autonomous collaboration.
these dynamics shift when an impersonal element becomes the determining factor, whether manifested in an external object or a collective entity where individual subjectivity diminishes.
as demonstrated in the preceding section, the shift to an impersonal entity can be seen as a form of liberation, highlighting how some individuals may choose subjugation to an impersonal collective or objective structure over submission to a person.
i would like to point out that historically slaves and serfs under the state's ownership had relatively comfortable lives.
in contrast, modern warehouse employees under distant management tend to have better conditions than those in small businesses where owners may exploit them personally.
transitioning from personal to impersonal structures can be seen as a loss of dignity and freedom when deeply held personal values are involved.
the aristocratic sentiment of voluntary dedication with extreme sacrifices has increasingly been replaced by feelings of humiliation and degradation, shifting from voluntary acts to legal obligations.
in the sixteenth century, rulers in france, germany, scotland, and the netherlands faced resistance when delegating authority to trained deputies or administrative bodies.
people were more inclined to follow personal authority out of devotion, while compliance with impersonal bodies was merely seen as submission.
hence, it is evident that at times these requests were firmly denied.
for instance, when peter iv of aragon appealed to the aragon estates for financial assistance, they responded that it was not their custom to provide credit.
they explained that while his christian subjects were willing to offer personal services, the offering of money was typically associated with jews and moors.
similarly, in anglo-saxon england, the king lacked the authority to enforce direct taxes; instead, the traditional teutonic belief persisted, emphasizing the obligation of providing personal military and court services to the commonwealth.
the imposition of danegeld by the king under the guise of defense against new invasions symbolized the deterioration of the state.
the people would generally agree to transition from personal services to monetary payments only if it did not imply a shift in power dynamics.
it is common for different factions within the same community to have conflicting views based on their perspectives on this matter.
in addition to instances where the release of financial obligations leads to a decrease in the status of the debtor, another aspect supplements the findings discussed in the previous chapter.
the positive implications for a serf able to fulfill obligations through monetary means have been examined.
conversely, a negative outcome emerges when the serf's association with money is controlled by the landlord, such as purchasing the land the serf previously owned with certain rights.
the prohibitions implemented in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries in the former german empire against peasants being bought out were primarily linked to financial or agricultural policies.
nevertheless, there was a sense of injustice towards the peasant if their land was taken, even if compensated fairly in monetary terms.
in instances where freedom is defined solely in negative terms, it is often viewed as inadequate and demeaning.
giordano bruno believed that free will was a flaw specific to humans, highlighting their imperfection compared to god who was bound by necessity.
this abstract concept can be clarified with a concrete example.
the prussian cottagers resided on land separated from the communal farmland, which was divided into mixed strips controlled by shared regulations.
by living on land with independent cultivation rules, the cottagers enjoyed more personal freedom.
however, their exclusion from communal decision-making processes resulted in a limited positive freedom to engage in field-related choices, granting them only the negative freedom of autonomy from communal dictates.
this lack of involvement in community decisions, despite owning significant property, relegated the cottagers to a subordinate position with minimal social standing.
freedom on its own is a hollow structure that only gains meaning, vitality, and worth through the growth of other life elements.
when we scrutinize the processes leading to freedom, we always observe a concrete underlying theme in conjunction with the abstract and pure notion of freedom.
this concrete aspect assigns a positive value to freedom but also establishes specific boundaries, outlining what needs to be achieved through this newfound freedom.
the actions undertaken to attain freedom can be categorized based on the extent to which the material content and benefits exceed the formal and negative aspects of freedom from prior constraints.
for instance, for a young man transitioning from the constraints of school to the free lifestyle of a university student, the latter phase holds greater significance.
when someone trades their rural property for a city house, they escape the challenges of agriculture but face new responsibilities and uncertainties tied to urban real estate.
on the other hand, selling the property for cash offers true freedom, as the relief from previous burdens outweighs the obligations associated with being a money-owner.
this shift results in fewer specific obligations moving forward.
the release from tangible constraints is now minimized, and money becomes the key to achieving freedom by negating constraints.
the prussian redistribution of communal land in the early nineteenth century significantly benefitted a class of day laborers who lacked stability and roots.
access to natural resources like woods and meadows helped maintain the living standards of impoverished peasants, who had no equivalent in theory.
attempts to compensate for the loss of these rights in cash would result in its quick depletion, while land compensation would be inadequate for producing tangible benefits.
as a consequence, these land compensations were turned into monetary payments, inadvertently exacerbating the trend towards proletarianization and the erosion of livelihood.
ethnologists note a similar challenge faced by greek peasant women in purchasing goods from local inhabitants.
with a growing inclination and the expansion of the money economy, there is an increasing impact on objects that are not intended for sale but are seen as permanent possessions closely tied to one's personality.
these include businesses, factories, works of art, collections, landed property, rights, and various positions.
while there is a notable level of freedom in the frequent changing of ownership and conditions of these possessions, the process is hindered by the uncertainty and lack of direction inherent in money.
as a result, despite the liberating aspects of this continuous exchange, there is often a failure to establish new foundations and lasting connections.
it is evident that the value of things goes beyond their monetary worth when selling a service rather than a product, especially when that service is unique not only in its physical execution but also in its essence.
this distinction becomes apparent in various scenarios.
in transactions involving money and services, the buyer typically seeks the specific service or result offered.
conversely, the provider often desires more than just payment.
for example, while a concert attendee may be content if the performance matches expectations, the artist performing seeks not only payment but also the audience's appreciation in the form of applause.
similarly, subjective offenses cannot simply be erased as if they never occurred, unlike tangible external damages.
if the offender believes that undergoing punishment alone leads to complete redemption, it is actually due to an internal transformation that uproots the foundation of the wrongdoing.
the insufficiency of punishment in erasing the offense is evident in the lingering mistrust and degradation faced by the wrongdoer post-punishment.
as previously discussed, there is no direct equivalence between qualitatively different elements, unlike the balanced nature of a financial statement.
this discrepancy is further highlighted by the values intrinsic to an individual, which lose significance when detached from their core, giving way to a tangible object like money as the ultimate measure.
it is deemed acceptable to consider offering valuable items or performances for a high price, and if that isn't feasible, it is preferable to give them as a gift rather than accepting a low price for them.
the latter act would be seen as demeaning, unlike the former.
therefore, in the company of sophisticated and delicate individuals, gifts intended to honor someone should downplay their monetary worth.
the transient nature of flowers and confections that one might consider gifting to a lady of limited acquaintance denotes the absence of significant value.
the value disparity between a specific task and its monetary equivalent may not always be evident or easily quantifiable, as seen in historical examples like the artist, physician, official, and scholar.
when the task is generic and performed by an average individual, such as an unskilled laborer, there is a lack of uniqueness and personal expression in the work.
whether the worker is adequately compensated for any added value typically depends on their social standing and the level of recognition they receive.
in cases where recognition is lacking due to a lower social status, the individual may feel degraded when forced to trade their personal value solely for monetary gain.
hence, the contempt towards medieval minstrels stemmed from their practice of singing both joyful and sorrowful songs for payment, which was seen as a debasement of their genuine emotions in exchange for money instead of esteem.
to preclude any notion of virtuous recompense, it was deemed appropriate to treat them fairly in monetary terms alone, excluding intangible rewards.
despite their overall unfavorable circumstances, minstrels were dealt with equitably, ensuring they were remunerated as justified.
when authentic personal values are commodified solely for financial gain without additional non-monetary recompense, it can lead to a dilution or even a loss of intrinsic value in individual lives.
the sentiment that personal principles are bartered in financial dealings for inadequate renumeration is a key reason why transactions involving money have often been reviled by proud and principled individuals, with agriculture, as its antithesis, extolled as the sole respectable pursuit.
it is a common sociological observation that contrasts between elements are most apparent when they share a common origin.
for instance, sects within the same religion often exhibit more intense animosity towards each other than towards completely different religious groups.
similarly, rivalries between small neighboring city-states are typically more fervent than those between larger countries with distinct spatial and strategic interests.
some argue that the most profound animosity can be found among blood relatives.
this escalation of tension arising from shared interests can peak when those shared interests evolve, potentially leading to a blurring of distinctions.
as lower and higher elements draw closer, the latter tends to accentuate remaining differences and place greater value on them.
nevertheless, its value remains equivalent to the labor spent to obtain it, serving as the benchmark for its exchange value concerning the specific natural product.
if labor is indeed the ultimate arbitrator for all value assessments of the item, employing an external entity like money for measurement seems unfitting and deflective.
instead, the focus should be on finding a way to symbolize the intrinsic unity of labor in a form that can serve both as a medium of exchange and a standard of measurement – a role typically fulfilled by money.
declining to take a stance on the definitive unification of value, i assert that the labor theory of value stands out as the most intriguing theory from a philosophical standpoint.
in the realm of human existence, the material and intellectual facets, comprising intellect and will, coalesce harmoniously through labor, a state unattainable when these aspects are viewed in isolation.
labor functions as the unified conduit where these elements blend akin to converging river sources, erasing their individual complexities and culminating in a unified product.
if labor indeed solely dictates value, it would be submerged within the specific juncture of our practical essence, necessitating the selection of the most fitting representation in the external realm.
however, the third crucial mental factor essential for creating the chair at hand is not subject to potential consumption.
with this chair's design, numerous copies can be manufactured without depreciating the plan itself, requiring restoration, or inflating the cost of production.
despite serving as the defining, material-intellectual blueprint for each chair, the plan remains unaffected.
by accurately discerning between the objective-mental content within a product and the subjective-mental process driving its creation based on the content model, we can appreciate the argument that mental labor carries no monetary expense.
once a thought has been articulated, it is impossible to repossess it with any force in the world.
the concept becomes permanently accessible to anyone who exerts the necessary mental effort to recollect it.
conversely, once a thought is expressed, it cannot be appropriated again by any means.
it remains intricately linked to the individual as a perpetually reproducible entity, distinct from the dynamics of the financial realm.
this indicates that the intellectual process holds significance beyond economic realms, intertwining with the psychological domain.
therefore, our focus lies solely on the latter aspect, exploring how mental exertion contributes to value creation in conjunction with physical labor.
should one decide to take on this challenge, it becomes imperative to somehow condense these interests and attributes into a form that allows for a somewhat even distribution.
i understand that contemporary scientific socialism does not advocate for a mechanical-communist approach to equality, but rather aims to create equal working conditions, fostering a range of positions and contentments based on individual talents, strengths, and efforts.
in the current landscape where factors like inherited wealth, social class distinctions, capital accumulation, and unequal economic opportunities widen disparities more than differences in individual contributions, achieving not only a fundamental leveling in all aspects but also an equalization in ownership and contentment becomes essential.
these, i believe, remain crucial catalysts for mobilizing the masses effectively.
if historical materialism is utilized as the scientific foundation for the socialist doctrine, the central concern arises from the deliberate construction of a pathway that contrasts with the organic flow of creative thinking.
in this context, socialist theory does not simply stem from a deductive application of historical materialism but is instead contingent on the practical establishment of a socialistic-communistic inclination, which underscores economic interests as the primary and unifying factor.
subsequently, this economic inclination must evolve to condense its multifaceted elements into a cohesive unity that transcends individual contributions and upholds the prospect of achieving equality and fairness that can be externally validated.
the argument that the value of all valuable items depends solely on their labor costs is insufficient.
it is conceivable to consolidate the diverse qualitative aspects of labor in a way that a smaller amount of more skilled labor could produce a similar or higher value compared to a significantly larger amount of less skilled labor.
however, in doing so, a completely different system of value would emerge than the one being discussed.
specialization, intellectuality, and complexity would continue to be inherent qualities in labor, but they would be viewed only as attributes of labor rather than as determining factors of value.
ultimately, the basis of value would no longer be rooted in labor itself, but in the hierarchy of qualities structured based on an independent principle.
in this scenario, labor, as the universal component of all labor qualities, would merely play a minor role.
similarly, a coherent labor theory needs to uphold the notion that any unequivocal and undisputed value differences between two accomplishments that may seem equally demanding in terms of labor input ultimately indicate that one involves more labor than the other.
at first glance, these achievements might appear to require the same amount of labor, but upon closer inspection, the underlying basis for their varying values lies in the disparities in the amount of labor involved.
disregarding coincidences stemming from the intricacies of historical events would make it extremely difficult to uphold any fundamental social connections.
in my opinion, it is possible to argue that the varying assessments of performance qualities reflecting the same subjective level of labor nonetheless signify the differing levels of labor inherent in individual accomplishments in an indirect manner.
consequently, this temporarily ensures benefits for the theoretical alignment of economic values on which the labor theory is based.
in this envisioning, mental work would be regarded equally to physical labor, with its outcomes evaluated purely on a quantitative basis alongside those of manual labor.
this represents a scientific ideal that highlights how converting all quantifiable work into manual labor might not inherently entail any fundamental logical inconsistency, even from a non-dogmatic materialistic perspective.
this challenges the perceived dualism between intellect and physicality that is often associated with such efforts.
as this connection exists exclusively within these two labor categories, it results in a never-ending series where mental labor continuously recedes but never disappears entirely.
consequently, the sustenance of the most advanced labor categories also relies on a chain of labor tasks where the cognitive input of each individual is compensated by others with purely physical contributions, gradually approaching almost negligible value.
it is conceivable that all external requirements for mental work can essentially be quantified in terms of manual labor.
if the traditional cost value theory was deemed valid, the worth of mental labor, equating its production costs, would equate to the value of specific manual tasks.
this theory might hold ground in a revised form.
the idea that the value of mental activity should directly correspond to the means of subsistence may seem paradoxical and lacking in meaning.
yet, it is worthwhile to explore a point where reality somewhat aligns with this concept as it delves into the internal and cultural connections between intellectual values and their economic foundations.
it can be speculated that the brain holds a significant amount of stored energy as the main focus of organic development.
this stored energy enables the brain to release a considerable amount of energy, leading to the remarkable efficiency of weaker muscles that can be activated by mental impulses.
the profound exhaustion experienced by the entire body following intellectual exertion or changes further suggests that mental activity, when considered in terms of its physical counterpart, consumes a substantial amount of organic energy.
restoring energy does not solely depend on increasing the basic necessities for manual workers, as the body has limitations on the amount of nourishment it can effectively utilize.
this limitation is even more noticeable for jobs that focus mainly on mental tasks.
therefore, the revival of energy, similar to the essential mental stimulation needed for mental work, often requires a focused, nuanced, and personalized approach to one's lifestyle and overall living conditions.
two pivotal factors of cultural and historical significance play a role here.
our daily lifestyle habits were crafted and honed during a time when the prevalent living conditions drastically varied from today's environment, particularly for intellectual groups where physical labor and exposure to fresh air surpassed the challenges of nervous strain and a sedentary lifestyle.
the abundance of both direct and indirect digestive ailments on one side, and the rush to find concentrated and easily digestible foods on the other, highlight a significant breakdown in the alignment between our physical constitution and dietary habits.
this broad observation underscores the validity of the varying nutritional needs among individuals with diverse professions, emphasizing that dietary requirements are crucial not just for culinary pleasure but for maintaining the well-being of individuals, particularly high-skilled workers who must ensure access to a specialized diet tailored to their specific nutritional needs.
moreover, a more concealed yet crucial aspect is that intellectual work pervades various aspects of life to a greater extent and is embedded in a broader network of interconnected relationships than manual labor.
this fact highlights an inherent discord between the principles of quality and fairness on one hand, and the drive to increase productivity on the other, which is often overlooked.
the unique blend of our physical and mental makeup, the dynamic interplay between enabling and constraining forces, and the interconnection of intellect and will, all contribute to a scenario where personal achievement, influenced by individual traits and circumstances, encounters a significant inconsistency.
this means that any change in one aspect necessitates a corresponding and sometimes substantial adjustment in the other to yield a similar outcome.
moreover, it appears that these innate disparities in realizing one's full potential become more pronounced in advanced, intricate, and intellectual domains of accomplishment.
in contrast, individuals reliant solely on physical strength for a given task would maintain similar dietary and lifestyle requirements for its execution.
there is yet another perspective to consider regarding the reduction of all labor value to that of manual labor, revealing its simplistic and common nature.
the true validation and significance of physical labor as a form of value and effort do not solely stem from physical strength alone.
it is not merely about the fact that physical labor would be pointless for human needs without some level of intellectual direction.
instead, the critical component that imbues physical labor with its value and worth is the incorporation of mental energy.
the complete essence and worth of physical labor are derived from the utilization of mental capacity within it.
despite being perceived as irrelevant and not emotionally connected to us, the possession of an object may prompt us to seek compensation only when it arises from a strong internal dilemma that necessitates a sacrifice.
in considering value, one could argue that physical labor equates to mental labor, except in cases where humans compete directly with machines or animals.
while all forms of work involve internal effort and mental energy, the latter do not strive to enhance their mental accomplishments since their focus lies solely on achieving results through physical means.
in cost-effective production scenarios, the reward is unlikely to increase as long as cheaper alternatives are available.
expanding this concept to our practical consideration of whether to reward the output of non-human forces solely through the effort of human accomplishment, a fundamental distinction emerges between human labor that derives recognition from its cognitive aspect and that which, resembling mechanized labor, seems to disassociate itself from this criterion for remuneration.
in essence, it is possible to argue broadly that, concerning the value to be recompensed, the differentiation between cognitive and physical work is not a distinction between mental and material essence; instead, compensation is essentially sought in the latter instance for the internal components of labor, such as the reluctance to engage, the exercise of willpower.
the intellectual element presumed to underlie work's external manifestation and constitute its intrinsic worth is actually rooted not in intellect but in emotion and volition.
consequently, it is not aligned with cognitive labor but serves as its foundation.
these comments not only illustrate that the concept of work is primarily associated with muscular activity but also dismiss common arguments against this correlation.
i find no insurmountable challenges in this regard.
the objection often raised is that worthless, unnecessary work exists, which questions the belief that only efficient work, justifiable by its outcomes, should be regarded as fundamental value.
however, debunking this idea inadvertently raises a critical flaw in the entire theory.
the admission that both valuable and worthless work coexist implies the existence of intermediate levels of work that may lack distinct purpose or value.
therefore, the value of a product, supposedly dictated by the labor input, fluctuates based on the efficacy of that labor.
this suggests that the value of work is not measured merely by quantity but rather by the usefulness of its outcomes.
despite acknowledging the inclination of labor money to reconnect money with personal values, each outcome underscores the intertwined nature of the opposition to this with its fundamental essence.
moreover, because money inherently possesses a relentless objectivity in measuring all items and the standard of value it establishes defines their connections, a complex network is created intertwining objective and personal elements of existence that mirrors the natural order with its seamless unity and rigorous causation.
this network is unified by the omnipresent value of money, akin to how nature is bound together by life-giving energy.
much like money, energy manifests in myriad forms, but its intrinsic uniformity and the ability to convert one form to another establish connections among them all, each being essential to the others.
just as the interpretation of natural phenomena has eliminated emotional biases in favor of impartial intellect, the entities and associations in our practical world, as they form increasingly intricate chains, eliminate emotional influence.
