each of these inquiries has the potential to spark in-depth discussions.
however, for the purpose of this discussion, the focus will be on presenting a chronological overview of the evolution of humanities computing.
this narrative will spotlight pivotal moments of intellectual advancement within the field and instances where humanities computing has significantly impacted or been adopted by other disciplines.
defining humanities computing is not the purpose of this essay.
the wide array of topics covered in this companion reflects the essence of the field.
in essence, humanities computing focuses on applying computing to research and education in the broad spectrum of subjects known as "the humanities" or "the arts" in british english.
notably, the core of humanities computing has revolved around applications involving textual sources, a defining aspect emphasized in major publications.
consequently, this essay naturally emphasizes this aspect.
while not delving into defining "interdisciplinarity" here, it is evident that humanities computing inherently merges "the two cultures," blending the systematic procedures synonymous with the sciences with the humanities' traditionally more serendipitous approach to problem-solving.
a sign of an emerging discipline is often the establishment of a new academic journal.
computers and the humanities was founded in 1966 and was spearheaded by joseph raben.
raben played a pivotal role in nurturing the journal during its initial years when formal conferences and associations were not yet established.
consequently, computers and the humanities served as a primary platform for sharing information about humanities computing.
the journal's directory of scholars active, curated by raben, soon became a vital resource for individuals contemplating the initiation of new projects in the field.
additionally, other specialized newsletters, such as calculi for computers and classics edited by stephen waite, catered to specific communities within the discipline.
if one word could encapsulate this era, it would undoubtedly be "consolidation." during this time, an increasing number of individuals adopted methodologies that had been established in the earlier period.
the production of electronic texts surged, along with the initiation of numerous projects utilizing the same applications.
awareness of the potential capabilities had disseminated steadily through traditional scholarly communication channels.
as computers became more ubiquitous in everyday life, more people started contemplating the ways in which computers could enhance their research and teaching endeavors.
the personal computer has become an essential tool in academic circles, yet during its inception, it was notably more costly.
early buyers were mainly tech enthusiasts or individuals well-versed in computing.
in the realm of humanities computing, its introduction eliminated the need to rely on computer centers for access.
personal computer users had the freedom to operate independently without necessarily leveraging existing expertise.
while this led to some duplication of work, it also spurred innovation by allowing users to explore new possibilities unconstrained by existing norms.
by the late 1980s, three dos-based text analysis programs - wordcruncher, tact, and microocp - had gained popularity for their advanced features.
users of personal computers found these programs useful for various purposes.
wordcruncher and tact provided quick search results, while microocp employed batch concordance for its mainframe program.
despite these advancements, word processing remained the primary use of personal computers, attracting a broader user base who were largely unfamiliar with other applications and often overlooked the full potential of computers beyond word processing capabilities.
the humanist electronic discussion list has set a high standard among similar platforms, with mccarty ensuring top-notch editing and fostering insightful discussions.
in europe, receiving three to six humanist digests in the early morning has become a cherished part of the daily routine.
the list plays a central role in nurturing a community and has been instrumental in shaping the field of humanities computing.
with archives dating back to 1987, it serves as a valuable resource for tracking developments and issues over the years.
its success has inspired the creators of the linguist list, a prominent online forum in linguistics.
the tei's size, reach, and impact went beyond the expectations set during the vassar meeting.
it marked the inaugural comprehensive effort to classify and delineate all attributes present in humanities texts that could capture scholars' attention.
a total of about 400 encoding tags were outlined in a framework that allowed for seamless expansion into new domains.
the specifications of these tags in the guidelines shed light on some of the encountered challenges, while deeper intellectual complexities surfaced during the project's evolution.
engaging with the tei spurred an exploration of markup theory and the portrayal of humanities knowledge as a standalone field.
the release of the tei guidelines coincided with advancements in full-text digital libraries, prompting digital library initiatives, previously unacquainted with humanities computing, to adopt the tei as the foundation for their projects instead of creating a new markup system from scratch.
a significant amount of the tei project's tasks were conducted via email by utilizing both private and public discussion lists.
additionally, drafts of documents were uploaded to a fileserver for collaborative editing.
following the project's inception, active participation in a tei group necessitated regular use of email, making the project an interesting case study of this communication method.
nonetheless, participants soon recognized the challenges of reaching consensus solely via email discussions.
fortunately, funding allowed for a consistent schedule of in-person technical meetings, ensuring timely decision-making and effective streamlining of markup proposals from various working groups.
in addition to the significant advancements in personal computing, networking, and the text encoding initiative (tei), the activities in humanities computing that originated in the 1970s saw continued growth with an increased number of users and projects.
over time, specific application areas evolved from humanities computing and established their unique culture and pathways for spreading information.
the topic of "computers and writing" quickly faded away, while a notable shift occurred in linguistic computing, especially corpus linguistics, as it began to have its own dedicated conferences and meetings.
despite efforts by don walker within the tei steering committee to bridge humanities computing and computational linguistics, computational linguistics persisted as a distinct discipline with antonio zampolli from the institute for computational linguistics in pisa.
though walker and zampolli endeavored to unite the two communities, their success may have been limited.
the increased accessibility of electronic resources through the web resulted in a growing interest in humanities computing.
scholars began studying electronic resources as subjects of analysis, even if they lacked technical expertise.
among various forms of electronic resources, hypertext garnered significant attention from theorists, expanding the scope of discussions in humanities computing.
however, this shift also led to some misunderstandings about the practical aspects of creating and utilizing these resources.
this situation revived the divide between those actively involved in the process and those who preferred discussing it, highlighting issues between the two cultural perspectives.
the rise of academic programs signifies the growing recognition of a subject area within the academic community.
in the case of humanities computing, this trend began in the late 1990s.
interestingly, only a few programs actually use the term "humanities computing" in their titles.
for instance, king's college london offers a ba minor in applied computing integrating humanities disciplines, along with an ma program named ma in applied computing at the centre for humanities computing.
mcmaster university in canada provides a ba in multimedia, while the upcoming ma program at the university of virginia is named digital humanities and falls under the media studies program.
the university of alberta appears to be the first to incorporate "humanities computing" into the program title, although the university of glasgow has offered an mphil in history and computing for an extended period.
the primary task of an archaeologist involves locating and excavating the material remnants left by past civilizations to extract valuable information from them.
this process of uncovering historical artifacts requires a systematic approach to maximize the insights they offer.
whether through excavation or surface survey, the unveiling of these remains unavoidably involves the destruction of the initial evidence.
sometimes, this destruction is profound and total, such as when digging through one layer to reveal another.
frequently, it involves extracting objects from their original contexts, potentially losing essential information about their physical and chronological placement.
preserving accurate records becomes crucial in mitigating inadvertent data loss due to the intrusive nature of archaeological work.
it can be contended that meticulous documentation stands as the primary task of a field archaeologist.
the significance of context for archaeologists underscores the necessity of maintaining meticulous records.
detailed documentation of not just the archaeological contexts and artifacts but also various other aspects of excavations or surveys is essential for analysis.
these records play a critical role, and the potential benefits of using computers for record-keeping are evident today.
it may not be immediately apparent that if computers are employed to document the fundamental information crucial for constructing archaeological interpretations, all professionals must eventually possess the ability to utilize computers to access this data.
in essence, proficiency in computers and computer skills will become imperative for all archaeologists if a significant portion of the archaeological record is preserved in digital format.
the potential of computers for record-keeping has become evident over time.
however, during the late 1950s when archaeologists initially adopted computers, they were considered complex and unfamiliar tools.
due to high costs and limited accessibility, academics couldn't fully harness their record-keeping capabilities as affordable microcomputers were not yet available.
data input involved punch cards or tape, with outcomes being produced solely on paper.
consequently, computers were primarily utilized for demanding processing tasks rather than routine data storage.
early applications focused on statistical processing, leveraging the computers' capacity to perform more intricate statistical procedures than previously achievable manually in archaeology, where statistics had been employed for years.
the challenges stemming from the differences in terminology and data structures have been magnified by the distinct requirements of the archaeological community and museum specialists.
when archaeologists document excavated artifacts, they typically start with excavation context, whereas museum curators tend to classify based on cultural or object-oriented systems.
consequently, the databases used by these two groups are structured in divergent ways, hindering seamless collaboration on a broader scale.
although it may not be feasible to merge different datasets in the short term, it is crucial to prioritize the preservation of datasets for future retrieval.
archaeologists now have access to digital repositories that actively support the long-term safeguarding of their data files, highlighting the critical duty of preserving digital data.
the recovered artifacts and their associated data serve as the primary remaining evidence of fieldwork, with neither component holding complete significance without the other.
furthermore, it can be suggested that ongoing economic progress may limit opportunities for excavations and field surveys, potentially leading to future archaeology revolving around excavations in museum archives and historical records.
initially, archaeologists commonly utilized cad programs primarily for drafting assistance, regarding the computerized drawings as the end result.
this allowed them to create plans and elevations at different scales with varying focuses without the need for laborious redrawing.
nevertheless, precise dimensional data could still be obtained from the cad file in its original accuracy, irrespective of the drawing scale.
additionally, the computer data could be segmented to incorporate or exclude specific phases or elements from the overall digital file into any given drawing.
consequently, over time, cad data became acknowledged as more comprehensive and intricate than individual drawings.
the significance of cad extended to its capacity to document in three dimensions and produce drawings based on the complete 3-d geometry of a site or structure.
with advancements in database technology during the 1960s and 1970s, archaeologists could effectively record the additional information they were discovering with precision, using cad to capture 3-d data effortlessly while maintaining the accuracy of original field measurements.
the accessibility of sophisticated surveying tools, such as the total station and desktop photogrammetry, simplified the collection of 3-d data.
the combined 3-d capabilities of cad and advanced surveying equipment have facilitated the creation of intricate 3-d models as archaeological records.
these models encompass the entire geometry, allowing for the retrieval of all dimensions with surveyed precision.
moreover, the 3-d models can be segmented to customize on-screen views or paper drawings by including or excluding specific sections based on immediate requirements.
archaeologists predominantly use cad models for reconstructing, illustrating, or envisioning the past, prioritizing appearances over precise dimensions.
by utilizing simpler, idealized dimensions in the computer-aided designs of buildings or larger ensembles, they can create visually appealing and cost-effective representations.
to illustrate reconstructed realities effectively, archaeologists often depend on supplementary technologies like rendering programs or virtual reality programs that build upon the cad models as their foundation.
challenges specific to archaeology arise that pose complexities in utilizing various technologies.
one such challenge is the disparity in terminology, which hinders the seamless sharing of data across these technologies, as previously discussed in relation to databases.
moreover, the application of cad and gis technologies in recording data by archaeologists differs significantly from what software developers envisioned.
the standards set by developers are often inadequate for scholarly users, and the progress in establishing scholarly standards has been sluggish and lacking direction.
the archaeology data service in england has been instrumental in addressing these issues, offering guidelines on best practices for scholars.
in the past, early archaeological research involved scholars writing their own programs for computing, but this practice is no longer essential.
nowadays, most scholars rely on commercial software for their work.
however, specific archaeological challenges such as certain statistical methods and seriation procedures still motivate archaeologists to develop their own programs.
simulation remains a critical area that necessitates programming skills.
in the 1960s, using computers for simulating the development of simpler societies showed great potential, but as interest in the "new archaeology" declined, so did the attraction towards simulation.
presently, those interested in simulation are more inclined to use gis, cad, or statistics to compare different predefined scenarios for testing potential developmental explanations, rather than utilizing simulation or artificial intelligence algorithms, which have been scarcely used in archaeology.
it is not guaranteed that future archaeologists will have the capability to effectively utilize the digital data generated during fieldwork today.
unfortunately, individuals proficient in such technologies often have to teach themselves, whereas it would be more beneficial for them to learn from experts who are familiar with the potential challenges.
the issue of inexperienced or self-taught users of computer technology is not widely acknowledged within the field of archaeology, perhaps because archaeologists have not realized the importance of all professionals being able to access digital data from computer databases, cad models, or gis datasets.
the lack of formal training poses a significant barrier to both the efficient utilization of computer technology and the reuse of existing digital data.
in this context, the discipline encompasses not only educators and students involved in sharing and acquiring knowledge, as well as curators responsible for managing resources like slides, but also personnel at museums and galleries entrusted with the preservation and curation of extensive collections, often exceeding display capacity.
it is crucial to acknowledge that various historians rely on and utilize historical images, a point evident in the diverse array of participants attending conferences.
particularly in sizable collections, computers were swiftly acknowledged as indispensable for organizing frequently insufficient paper records, benefiting curators, conservators, registrars, and eventually, the wider public.
could the emergence of the web signal a shift towards a diminished role for campus-based universities and physical museums and galleries?
given the limitation of gallery space that allows only a fraction of their collections to be showcased, perhaps directing funding towards web-based image databases would be more beneficial.
while there is widespread recognition of the value of in-person seminars and tutorials, the traditional fixed-location lectures may fade away due to the allure of web-based, visually rich alternatives and the financial constraints that prevent some students from physically attending.
the key challenge lies in ensuring that online "lectures" match or surpass the quality of traditional ones.
by leveraging digital imagery, which owes its development in part to photography, art history's reach and cultural significance could potentially be amplified globally, especially in a digitally interconnected age.
although there might be a desire to downplay classical computing's role in future history as a distinct entity, classicists have had to establish their own historical narrative.
even in optimistic scenarios where classicists adapt existing tools and collaborate extensively with other disciplines, they will still face significant challenges in ensuring their perspectives are acknowledged and that upcoming technologies and norms cater to their requirements.
this section aims to elucidate the rationale behind classicists shaping their unique historical trajectory and connecting present patterns with a broader historical backdrop.
while critiquing the past is straightforward, this chapter not only scrutinizes historical events but also uses them to support projections for the future, thereby justifying any biases in hindsight by revealing its predictions for upcoming developments.
our lack of technical expertise became apparent when harvard initiated its computing project in the summer of 1982.
this inexperience turned out to be advantageous, as a more knowledgeable approach may have deterred the department from proceeding, waiting for technology to advance.
instead, the department committed significant resources that made it difficult to halt the project.
ultimately, our focus on addressing specific challenges in classical typesetting led to cost reductions for publications like harvard studies in classical philology and the loeb classical library.
this success justified the initial investment, but the process itself was flawed.
despite the satisfactory outcomes, our achievements were tempered by our good fortune, considering the common challenges encountered by similar projects in the field of classics and academia at large.
initially, our access to email was confined to our individual computer; it wasn't until we connected to a network named uucp that we could exchange emails between computers.
however, this came with challenges as our computer would significantly slow down each time it handled mail.
additionally, email wasn't particularly useful back then as very few individuals outside our circle had email accounts.
we also struggled with basic file transfers as the concept of the present-day internet would have appeared far-fetched to us.
being on the forefront of technological advancements elicited contradictory feelings, vacillating between optimism and skepticism.
during the late 1960s and early 1970s, historians perceived a significant impending shift within their profession, the field of history itself.
this transformation was evident through a series of unmistakable signs.
it sparked a culture clash within the discipline, leading to a wave of intense conference discussions, public debates, and roundtables featuring titles like "the muse and her doctors" and "the new and the old history." this clash pitted the "new" history, heavily influenced by social science theories and methodologies, against the traditional narrative approaches of historians.
the "new" historians employed computers to conduct analyses and draw connections never before explored, yielding occasionally astounding outcomes.
fueled by success and exuberance, and perhaps bordering on overconfidence, these historians were reluctant to entertain opposition to their findings or methods.
encountering challenges at conferences, some historians simply responded with mathematical equations.
prominent british social historian lawrence stone criticized the efforts and expenses associated with the emerging field of new history, stating that the most generously financed projects that involved extensive data collection, dedicated teams of researchers, advanced computer technology for analysis, and sophisticated mathematical presentations have been the most underwhelming.
these views continue to resonate within the discipline, reflecting profound disagreements regarding the practical approach and methodology in historical studies.
looking back, historians have utilized computing technologies in three distinct phases.
the first phase, dating back to the 1940s, featured pioneers like owsley, curti, and aydelotte who were instrumental in the initial adoption of quantitative history.
these historians employed mathematical techniques and constructed extensive datasets.
the second phase emerged in the early 1960s within the realm of social science history, focusing on the "new" social, economic, and political history with an emphasis on themes such as mobility, political alignment, urbanization, assimilation patterns, and legislative behavior.
notable figures during this phase included lee benson and allan bogue from the "iowa school" of quantification, alongside historians like olivier zunz, michael f.
morgan kousser, and others who employed various statistical methods.
the emergence of the pc revolution and the internet, combined with the continuous growth in speed and disk capacity of computing technology following moore's law, ushered in the third phase.
in this present era, the networking capabilities of the internet present historians with significant opportunities as well as challenges.
simultaneously, the internet has established an extensive network of systems and data, while personal computers and software have progressed to the extent that almost every historian now integrates information technologies into their daily workflow.
throughout the 1980s, historians in europe advanced the utilization of databases for historical computing.
during this period, they raised questions about the impact of these tools on their interpretations and whether relational database models were capable of accommodating non-tabular data like lengthy texts, sound, images, and maps.
manfred thaller introduced a system that aimed to distinguish the "knowledge environment" from the software or system environment, ensuring that the meaning of database records remained detached from their source information.
the development of databases for historical computing prompted thaller and other quantitative historians to differentiate between designs based on the method of analysis/model and those built around the data sources.
the former involved historians extracting information from sources and organizing it into tables conducive to anticipated queries.
conversely, the latter method focused on preserving the original textual or data content along with its complete source context, deferring decisions on data analysis and organization until later stages.
as historians debated the merits of quantitative methods and embraced cultural studies, computer scientists were concurrently developing a standardized language for sharing files online.
the emergence of the world wide web in 1993, marked by the introduction of html and web browsers, provided historians with a novel platform to showcase their research.
among the early scholars to recognize the potential of the web for academic purposes was edward l.
ayers from the university of virginia.
ayers, while studying two american communities during the civil war, transitioned his research from traditional distribution methods to online publication upon encountering the emerging possibilities offered by the mosaic institute for advanced technology in the humanities at his university.
the valley of the shadow project was initially perceived as simply a collection of civil war letters, records, and accounts by the general public.
however, students and teachers appreciated its role in providing them access to the past and allowing them to become their own historians.
while scholars were initially skeptical about the value of an electronic archive, gradually historians, including prominent figures like james m.
mcpherson, started to take notice of the project.
some historians viewed it as a disruptive innovation that had the potential to alter established historical narratives.
in a notable conference panel on the valley project, mcpherson, a renowned civil war historian, expressed concerns about the project's narrow focus and argued that the selected communities did not adequately represent the north and south.
edward ayers made a crucial decision early on to develop the valley of the shadow project for the world wide web, which played a vital role in its ongoing success.
although the team at the university of virginia, in collaboration with ayers, also created cd-roms and ayers is preparing a narrative book based on the electronic archive, the website stands out as the centerpiece with millions of users and is the focal point for all other scholarly materials.
the cd-rom versions of the valley of the shadow and who built america?
contained valuable content, but their closed systems and offline nature limited their impact, especially as technology rapidly progressed in the late 1990s.
in contrast, the world wide web provided the connectivity and hypertext capabilities that appealed to the growing public demand and scholars, who recognized its significant advantages.
ayers noted that historians could harness these new media possibilities by exploring innovative ways to craft narrative forms on paper that capture the intricate nature depicted in digital archives.
in his discussion, darnton highlighted middle east studies as a prime example of a marginalized area of academic research that garnered little public interest.
mere years following darnton's analysis, the pivotal events of september 11, 2001, propelled middle east studies into the forefront of american consciousness.
he astutely noted that the uncertain market dynamics, coupled with mounting pressures on academic publishers, tenure processes, and scholars, posed significant challenges to the longevity of scholarly books.
ayers and the author are collaborating on an electronic article for the american historical review titled "the differences slavery made: a close analysis of two american communities." this digital scholarly piece serves multiple purposes by bridging form and analysis.
one key feature is its ability to guide readers through the evolutionary process of our argument, enabling them to trace the rationale behind our insights, akin to the envisioned "trails" by vannevar bush for historians utilizing technology.
additionally, this innovative scholarship incorporates spatial analysis and presentation to situate both its subjects and audience within the historical backdrop and interpretation.
moreover, it is designed to foster unexpected linkages with forthcoming research, enhancing its enduring relevance and impact on the scholarly community.
the work combines interpretative argument with the digital resources available through the valley of the shadow project, envisioning a forthcoming era of interconnected scholarly practices where interpretation, narrative, evidence, commentary, and other academic endeavors are intertwined.
the resulting work aims to meld structure and argument within the digital landscape.
the authors advocate for a prismatic model as a departure from darnton's traditional pyramid framework, enabling readers to explore multiple facets of interpretation based on shared evidence and historiographical context.
this article's prismatic approach invites readers to engage with historical interpretation through sequential and interlinked analyses, evidence, and their connections to prior scholarship.
equally significant, the article leverages its structure to elucidate its argument and subject matter.
the narrative underscores that slavery is not defined by a singular determinant but possesses multifaceted effects that permeate all aspects of society.
the thresor was initially made available online in 1994 as an interactive database through the artfl project at the university of chicago.
the ascii data files were later adapted to operate within the philologic program.
by the year 2000, the dictionnaires d'autrefois from artfl were integrated into a server located at the inalf in nancy, utilizing the stella interactive database software.
simultaneously, in 2000, the thresor was also launched as an interactive database on a windows server housed at the university of toronto.
this system operated under tactweb, with the data files initially undergoing indexing by tact within an ibm-compatible environment.
the idea of thorough testing, free from personal biases and interpretations, hinges on the belief that computerized methods can pinpoint and extract textual characteristics accurately.
when automation is not feasible, rigorous steps must be taken to prepare texts accordingly.
a significant advantage of many electronic literary studies is their foundation on a theoretical framework of textuality that scrutinizes the critic's role and the text's unique features, ensuring the criteria employed in analysis are well-grounded.
the distinction of these textual characteristics often requires them to be separated from the rest of the text, with markup serving as the most evident form of "external intervention." the role of markup is crucial in literary examination of electronic texts, as the interpretative process by the critic is essential due to the inherent ambiguity of meaning in literature even before the actual analysis begins.
words presented as distinct sets of characters, sentences, lines, and paragraphs represent "natural" textual elements but are not without value.
the utilization of thematic markup for disambiguation stems directly from a critic’s interpretation of the text, thereby shaping the analysis.
numerous computer-based studies have emphasized that transparently disclosing the criteria used to encode specific textual attributes is vital for any method striving to yield measurable outcomes.
despite the hesitancy of most literary critics to adopt electronic media for scholarly analysis, literary computing has not significantly influenced mainstream scholarship.
in contrast, electronic scholarly editions have been widely embraced in the academic community and are recognized as essential resources for teaching and research.
despite the abundance of electronic texts with advanced markup, their availability has not resulted in a notable uptick in computer-based studies.
considering these technical challenges, it appeared that with the removal of hardware limitations and the readiness of computing systems to handle scholarly computing requirements, the electronic analysis of literature would emerge as a significant research area.
issues related to research methodologies in studies that aimed to undertake more complex tasks but were hindered by technical constraints, such as the need for extensive datasets, access to diverse texts, and sufficient computing capacity to analyze lengthy texts for specific patterns, primarily stemmed from technological limitations.
emphasizing the importance of computer-assisted studies aligning themselves with current scholarly trends, exploring theoretical aspects related to text and textuality, and illustrating to non-specialists that the outcomes warrant further investigation is crucial.
utilizing computers goes beyond mere novel tools, as they can enhance a critic's work by providing insights inaccessible to human readers.
the electronic tool's strengths lie in its speed, accuracy, vast memory capacity, and instant access to all textual elements.
by leveraging expanding knowledge resources and establishing connections between texts to create extensive repositories of material, traditional literary criticism stands to greatly benefit from the insights and expertise gained through computer-based investigations towards a more rigorous analysis of literature.
since its inception, humanities computing has consistently displayed a multifaceted nature concerning literary genres, socio-cultural contexts, and the historiogeographical origins of literary works.
research has delved into various forms of literature such as poetry, drama, and narratives spanning from ancient times to contemporary pieces.
while there is a notable focus on english literature, texts in other languages have also been scrutinized.
the strength of these studies lies in the diverse methodologies employed to analyze varied textual materials, drawing from a wide range of theoretical frameworks and literary models.
rather than adhering to a specific technique or school of thought, these studies share a common tool, fostering a rich and inclusive research environment.
contemporary investigations often delve into literary theory, text analysis, and the interdisciplinary aspects of computer-aided literary studies.
mainstream literary criticism has embraced contributions from this field, which maintains a keen awareness of its theoretical underpinnings.
over the past two decades of the 20th century, music notation software has advanced significantly.
composers can now create their own music without relying on professional copyists.
previously, individual parts had to be copied manually from the score.
with this technology, complex ensemble pieces requiring a conductor's score and individual musicians' parts can now be created quickly and cost-effectively.
once the main score is inputted into the computer, the software can automatically generate the parts with minimal manual intervention.
this software is extensively used in the music publishing field and enables musicologists to produce precise, efficient, and cost-effective scholarly editions of works.
the term "multimedia" initially denoted artworks integrating various traditional art media, such as in multimedia art installations.
however, when defining multimedia as "computer-based," it purposefully eliminates such mixed-media creations.
essentially, a multimedia piece is a digital creation accessed through a computer, even if some components were initially crafted in analog form and then digitized for computer integration.
this classification also rules out pieces generated on a computer, like a desktop publishing file, but indirectly experienced by audiences through an analog medium such as print.
these examples serve as illustrations of different types of multimedia.
establishing a suitable taxonomy would revolve around specific criteria.
for instance, one approach could involve categorizing multimedia content based on its intended purpose, distinguishing between entertainment and educational content.
another aspect to consider could be the methods of distribution and consumption contexts, ranging from freely accessible websites demanding a high-speed internet connection to high-end cd-rom games necessitating cutting-edge video cards for optimal performance.
additionally, multimedia could be classified based on the blend of different media elements, such as remixes combining music with synchronized textual annotations or immersive virtual environments for exploration.
furthermore, other classification criteria may include the production technologies employed, the sensory modes activated, the originating organization, or the level of interactivity provided.
the practice of digitization leads to the creation of multimedia, which involves combining various media to form rhetorically persuasive works.
computer-based media are characterized by their interactive potential, notably seen in the elaborate systems designed by interactive game developers.
consequently, the emerging field of digital game criticism plays a crucial role in examining computer games as significant elements of popular culture and rhetoric within multimedia.
this discipline delves into questions such as what defines a game, how games can be viewed as art forms, what defines an effective and engaging game, and what opportunities exist for interactive engagement through digital platforms.
interactive gaming stands out as a quintessential form of multimedia and a primary mode of expression in the contemporary digital era.
there are two approaches to understanding multimedia.
the first involves examining it through definitions, histories, examples, and theoretical challenges.
the second approach entails using multimedia for thinking and communication.
the academic analysis of multimedia typically involves a critical examination of the subject, conveyed through academic mediums such as textbooks, articles, and lectures.
"thinking-with" multimedia involves applying multimedia to ponder concepts and convey them effectively.
working with multimedia involves its distinct conventions of dialogue, organizational methods, tools, and results.
engaging with multimedia aids in exploring ideas and expressing them.
in a dynamic field like multimedia, where novel ideas are prevalent, thinking with multimedia is crucial.
scholars in the multimedia field must embrace the task of utilizing multimedia to contemplate multimedia and endeavor to produce outstanding multimedia creations within the traditions of the humanities.
the performing arts go beyond text and are fundamentally experiential, engaging sight, sound, and physicality.
it wasn't until the 1980s, with the rise of affordable personal computers capable of processing images, sounds, and videos, that computers started to enable a meaningful representation of live performances.
larry friedlander's groundbreaking shakespeare project, initiated in 1984 on an ibm infowindow system and later switching to hypercard in 1987 during its apple development stage, anticipated the use of digital technology in performance education.
due to the rudimentary graphics and lack of video capabilities in personal computers at the time, friedlander devised a solution using a dual-screen setup that accessed media from a laserdisc.
this laserdisc stored various images and six pivotal video segments, such as contrasting scenes from hamlet, macbeth, and king lear.
friedlander ingeniously used this video content in three distinct ways within the framework of the shakespeare project.
in the performance section, students had the opportunity to engage with shakespearean text while watching videos, switch between different film versions seamlessly, navigate to specific parts of the text, and switch between the original audio of the film and a recording where friedlander offers insights into the actors' "subtext." the study section provided interactive tutorials for students to explore various aspects of shakespearean performance like character portrayal and verse.
additionally, in the notebook section, students could extract digital video clips to include in their essays.
through each of these sections, the computer enabled students to closely and flexibly analyze performances almost as thoroughly as they would with a printed text.
in the 1990s, these cd-roms utilized the video display capabilities of personal computers, eliminating the necessity for a laserdisk player and an additional monitor.
although this method was more sophisticated, space-saving, and economical compared to laserdisk systems, the video quality of early cd-rom titles was inferior and smaller in size.
however, by 2000, advancements in computer processors, video cards, efficient video compression technologies, and the widespread adoption of dvd technology bridged the gap between personal computers and laserdisk players.
even the most elaborate theater models and scenery, regardless of how detailed, immersive, or interactive they are, only replicate the performance environment.
efforts have also been made to utilize computer animation methods to replicate the essence of theatrical performances for educational and academic purposes.
one early pioneer in this field was larry friedlander, who developed theatergame in collaboration with the shakespeare project.
this groundbreaking software garnered significant media attention for its time.
theatergame enabled students to explore staging techniques by selecting basic two-dimensional human figures, dressing them in various costumes, arranging set pieces on a virtual stage, and manipulating the actors to depict simple gestures.
the primary aim was to provide inexperienced students or those without access to live actors an opportunity to examine the impact of fundamental staging decisions.
during the same period when friedlander was developing theatergame, tom calvert set out to create a more advanced application aimed at choreographers.
starting in the 1970s, he initiated a project known as compose, which initially functioned as a dance notation system on a mainframe computer, producing output on a line printer.
by the 1980s, calvert enhanced compose by integrating 3-d human animations in lieu of abstract symbols for movements, resulting in a new program named lifeforms.
despite its featureless wireframe human models, lifeforms boasted impeccable, adaptable, and anatomically precise movements.
positioned as a dance composition tool, lifeforms operated akin to a word processor for dance enthusiasts and professionals.
this software gained global recognition when the esteemed choreographer merce cunningham embraced it in 1990.
subsequently, lifeforms transformed into a commercial product in the early 1990s.
virtual vaudeville aims to create an immersive experience where viewers are enveloped by the lively atmosphere of a theatrical production both on stage and behind the scenes.
upon entering the virtual theater, audiences can observe animated performances from various vantage points within the audience, with the ability to engage with other animated spectators.
skilled actors are reenacting live stage shows, with their movements and facial expressions captured through advanced technology and applied to 3-d models resembling performers from the nineteenth century.
the platform is under development using a cutting-edge gaming engine typically employed for designing high-performance commercial 3-d action games.
throughout a succession of shows beginning with invisible site: a virtual sho in 1991, coates honed a method for creating a striking deception of live actors seamlessly embedded in a dynamic 3-d virtual setting.
audience members are equipped with polarized glasses to witness expansive, high-definition stereoscopic displays of digital graphics.
these projections envelop the rotating stage, encompassing not only the rear wall but also the stage floor and translucent black scrims in front of the actors.
the digital visuals are dynamically altered during the shows to ensure precise coordination between the live actors and the media.
the integration of computers in the realm of performing arts goes beyond being just a new tool within a traditional field; it fundamentally questions core beliefs about performance.
initially, it blurs the lines separating various performance disciplines.
for instance, can we definitively categorize a performance where a performer triggers pre-recorded dialogues while moving on stage as music, dance, or theater?
secondly, it challenges the distinction between academic research and artistic expression.
for instance, is a person who reconstructs a full stage design, script, and performance based on historical fragments to create a virtual performance simulation to be considered an artist or a scholar?
is someone who invents new artificial intelligence algorithms to enable a dramatic interplay between a digital character and a live actor functioning as a computer scientist or an artist who employs computers as a creative tool?
ultimately, digital technology blurs the line between live performance and media.
for instance, when a live performer engages with a computer-generated animation, is the animation considered "live"?
this trend is in line with findings from other studies demonstrating the displacement of early grassroots attempts to harness the internet and the web for political activism as established power structures also adapt to leverage these technologies, eventually reclaiming their dominance online.
similarly, advocates of online religion envision a global internet facilitating a diverse, dialogical culture promoting multiple voices from various religious backgrounds in a new pluralistic environment.
however, current internet usage patterns, while slightly favoring previously marginalized beliefs, predominantly mirror and uphold the existing religious landscape characterized by loyalty to one's own faith and efforts to promote it.
in the beginning of an email, there isn't a direct match between von neumann's logical elements and the hardware parts found in contemporary computers.
therefore, i will allocate a segment to each logical part, offering a fundamental overview of its function, and delve deeper into how specific hardware components execute the tasks associated with that logical element.
the selection of components and the order of discussion will be influenced by the contextual framework - the process of typing and sending an email containing the message "hi!".
throughout, i may include supplementary remarks rather than exclude a crucial element.
keyboards operate with simple microprocessors that continually scan the circuit board for closed circuits representing key presses and releases.
upon detecting a completed circuit, the microprocessor cross-references it with a programmed character map, akin to a seating chart of characters.
in cases where multiple circuits are closed simultaneously, the microprocessor verifies if the key combination is defined in the character map.
the character map then leads to a designated scan code for the completed circuit, which is transmitted to the computer for conversion into the appropriate ascii bit string.
while the scan codes are standardized, the character map is specific to each keyboard model.
the key role of the character map is to distinguish the keyboard's functionality from the actual characters visible on the keys.
returning to the realm of inactive keys, we find scan codes patiently residing in the bios, a crucial component tasked with facilitating seamless coordination among different computer parts.
despite being a form of software code, the bios is housed within the chipset.
generally, computer systems operate with three tiers of software: the operating system (os), specific device drivers equipped with instructions for operating individual peripherals, and the bios responsible for deciphering and relaying instructions and data between the os and drivers.
notably, the bios facilitates the transmission of electrical signals exchanged among various peripherals.
in essence, the bios intercepts the scan code, converts it into the corresponding ascii code, and forwards it to the os for processing.
subsequently, the video adapter undergoes a check, and if everything is in order, content will display on the monitor.
the system ram is then tested, with the machine appearing to meticulously count each byte of memory.
following this, the post process progresses through various system components, verifying their functionality and, when necessary, loading a device driver into the bios to ensure swift and proper operation upon the os's request.
typically, the bios subsequently provides a brief summary of the system configuration on the screen, briefly flashing before the os commences.
afterward, the post revisits the cmos to identify designated boot devices, hardware components that could harbor an os.
finally, the bios inspects the boot sector of these devices for a master boot record, seizing command of the pc for the startup's remainder.
a ram chip consists of numerous pairs of transistors and capacitors interconnected to form memory cells, each capable of storing a single data bit.
the capacitors retain a charge while the transistors function as switches, enabling the control circuitry to alter the capacitor's state.
these components are organized in a grid layout, with columns linked by bitlines and rows by wordlines.
these "lines" refer to minuscule electrically conductive strands etched on the ram chip.
when an electrical impulse passes through a bitline, active transistors charge their capacitors.
the unique combination of bitlines and wordlines assigns an address to each transistor and capacitor, hence the term "random access" as any memory cell can be directly accessed with its specific address.
most ram is deemed volatile or dynamic due to the constant leakage of charge from the capacitors, necessitating frequent refreshing.
after the introduction of bells, municipal authorities innovated various timekeeping mechanisms to regulate various aspects of daily life such as commerce and communication.
commencing in the 13th century, marketplace activities were overseen by clocks, dictating trading hours for different vendors and shopping schedules for the local residents.
before the 15th century, universities structured their lectures flexibly based on subject matter.
however, by the 15th century, especially in secondary education, the day was divided into specific time blocks for teaching various subjects, marked by the use of bells and hourglasses.
apart from organizing the daily schedule, these timekeeping tools played a role in standardizing spatial rationalization.
from the 15th to the 18th centuries, postal and courier services transitioned from measuring distance to quantifying it in terms of time intervals.
despite the qwerty arrangement not being the most efficient layout of keys regardless of the printing mechanism used, it proved to be the most practical among sholes's designs.
sholes encountered a design challenge involving overlapping rods, which led to potential jamming if consecutive keys were pressed by a typist.
this would require the operator to pause and fix the issue, causing a waste of time.
to minimize jamming, sholes strategically placed keys for letters that often appear side by side in commonly used words.
the purpose of this arrangement was to enhance speed by ensuring better coordination between the operator and the machine.
while it is commonly believed that sholes intended to slow down typists, his actual goal was to foster improved synchronization between man and machine, creating a manageable rhythm and sequence beneficial to both.
it wasn't until about fifteen years after the invention of the typewriter that the idea of using all fingers for typing was commonly accepted.
initially, there was skepticism about teaching this technique, with many typists successfully using the "hunt and peck" method.
longley introduced a pamphlet advocating for a ten-finger typing method.
despite facing significant opposition in the trade press, she persisted in promoting her concept.
five years later, frank mcgurrin, a court stenographer from st.
louis, also proposed a similar ten-finger typing approach, including the innovation of "touch typing." mcgurrin faced resistance as well, but he demonstrated the effectiveness of his method by winning a typing competition in 1888.
the chord keyset was envisioned by engelbart to enable users to operate a keyset and a mouse simultaneously without needing to look at their hands.
he envisaged a modernized version of the remington typist who could change paper seamlessly without interrupting her work.
according to his vision, the input devices would serve as natural extensions of the human hands, allowing users to manipulate them without relying on other senses.
however, mastering this seamless interaction would necessitate acquiring a new language, a fresh code, and an additional symbol set that closely mirrored the binary system utilized by computers.
the line dividing humans and machines appeared blurred, with humans seeming to embrace the characteristics of machines rather than vice versa.
engelbart's pursuit of developing input devices to enhance human intellect, despite encountering apparent contradictions, serves as a significant source of inspiration alongside licklider for envisioning the future potential of computers.
in his 1961 report titled "program on human effectiveness", engelbart outlines his vision for empowering individuals to become more effective problem solvers.
his ultimate goal is to optimize human problem-solving capabilities by integrating computers into various facets of our problem-solving processes.
he emphasizes the importance of training humans not only in utilizing these input devices but also understanding the underlying logical operations of computers.
although engelbart aspires for humans to teach computers, he currently focuses on creating tools and machines that can aid in training humans.
in contemporary times, the early exposure of children to computers has normalized tasks like using a mouse and programming languages to the point where they appear intuitive and natural.
to illustrate, a historian conducting an analysis on demographic information extracted from census books, parish records, and city directories may categorize individuals based on their gender, age, occupation, and birthplace.
birthplaces, in turn, could be categorized into large or small cities, towns, villages, or rural parishes.
meanwhile, a linguist examining a text might categorize every word by its part of speech or each sentence by its structure.
additionally, linguists, literary experts, and social scientists may sort words found in a text by semantic categories and organize them into semantic networks.
the act of classification serves a dual purpose, each profoundly significant: it groups similar objects together under a class while also segregating dissimilar objects into distinct classes, thus highlighting the differences that are relevant to the classification's objective.
moreover, the classification system itself, through pinpointing properties crucial for determining similarities and differences, can illuminate a specific perspective regarding the essence of the objects under classification.
classification hinges on identifying the characteristics of the object under classification, thus achieving perfect classification necessitates a comprehensive understanding of the object.
a flawless classification system would reflect impeccable knowledge of the object.
for example, in subject classification, positioning each topic within a field in a multi-dimensional space close to related topics and distant from unrelated ones results in a precise depiction of the intellectual landscape relevant to the area being categorized.
consequently, classification systems not only serve practical purposes but also carry considerable theoretical significance.
such systems inherently presuppose some theoretical framework regarding the objects being classified, even if it is merely positing certain attributes of the objects.
essentially, any ontology can be viewed as laying the groundwork for classifying the entities it defines.
similarly, any classification system can, with varying degrees of ease, be seen as a manifestation of a specific ontology.
most classification systems designed for broad application often settle for depicting an imperfect picture of the intellectual framework within their subject area.
they strive, with differing degrees of achievement, to confine their theoretical suppositions to ones that the majority of anticipated users would likely accept.
in extreme cases, these underlying assumptions in a classification system can become virtually imperceptible, making them unchallengeable or open to reassessment.
for scholarly endeavors, such opacity poses risks and should be averted.
every scenario mentioned up to this point categorizes objects according to a singular attribute assigned to the object.
ideally, this attribute can be easily and consistently assessed, and its possible values are distinct.
as the instances become more ambiguous, the classification procedure is expected to be more challenging to implement, potentially resulting in a loss of information when using the classified data instead of the raw data for analyses.
in more complex classification systems, multiple characteristics are taken into account, often creating a hierarchy of increasingly detailed distinctions.
for instance, the dewey decimal classification system designates class numbers in the 800s for literary works.
within this range, the 820s are reserved for english literature, the 830s for german literature, the 840s for french literature, and so forth.
under the 820s, the number 821 represents english poetry, 822 english drama, 823 english fiction, and so forth.
additional digits beyond the third digit provide even more specific categorizations.
consequently, the classification system presents both the classifier and the user with a structured hierarchy of classes and subclasses, resembling a tree-like structure where smaller classes branch out from larger ones.
in many instances, the concept of classification depicting an n-dimensional cartesian space can be a significant oversimplification.
despite this, it remains practical to portray each attribute or feature used in a classification as defining a point along an axis, regardless of whether that axis is relevant for all categories within the system.
for those who find this metaphorical approximation bothersome, they may find it entertaining to envision the logical space established by such a classification not as cartesian or newtonian, but as a relativistic space with non-euclidean geometry.
a pre-coordinate system involves pre-specifying combinations of terms from different axes for classification or indexing objects.
on the other hand, a post-coordinate system involves identifying values along various axes, allowing for flexible combinations during searches.
printed indices in a fixed order of descriptors represent a pre-coordinate scheme, while online indices enable searches with arbitrary axis combinations, defining a post-coordinate system.
although printed indices can allow free term combinations, post-coordinate indexing is more user-friendly for computer systems.
an a priori system is characterized by predefined axes and values, where items are categorized accordingly.
on the other hand, in an a posteriori or data-driven system, the axes and values are formulated based on encountered items post-analysis.
data-driven classification methods, such as author-specified keywords and free-text searching, serve as straightforward examples.
citation analysis, especially examining co-citation patterns in academic literature as outlined by garfield, is another illustration of a data-driven approach.
in certain cases, determining axes in a data-driven system may require complex and costly statistical analysis of data.
latent semantic analysis exemplifies this process: it starts by considering the presence or absence of every word in the vocabulary across all indexed documents as an axis.
through statistical analysis, efforts are made to consolidate as many axes as feasible and pinpoint a valuable set of axes that are as close to perpendicular as the data permits.
in a standard scenario, latent-semantic analysis will categorize documents within a space of approximately 200 dimensions.
while it is occasionally feasible to explore the dimensions and attribute individual meanings to them, data-driven statistical techniques typically do not aim to interpret each axis of their space separately.
let's assign numbers from 1 to n to label the classes, where n represents the total number of classes.
assuming that the objects to be classified can be arranged in a specific order, the method used for this ordering is not of current relevance.
subsequently, let's organize the descriptions of potential classifications into a particular sequence.
although the descriptions may be practically limitless, we can still arrange them systematically.
assuming the descriptions are presented in english or any other natural language, we can consider categorizing them first based on their length and then alphabetically.
while distinguishing whether a given english text qualifies as a description of a classification may pose challenges, for the purposes of this exercise, we can meticulously outline all english texts and any sequences of letters, spaces, and punctuation.
in situations requiring systematic classification, researchers have the option of utilizing an existing classification scheme or creating a new one based on their specific needs.
established schemes are typically well-documented and widely recognized, potentially offering a more in-depth exploration of technical aspects compared to a hastily devised scheme.
these established schemes draw from extensive data sets, likely offering a more comprehensive coverage—including unique cases—than a researcher could achieve independently.
additionally, they are more conducive to facilitating direct comparisons with materials organized by others.
these relationships offer more than just improved information storage and retrieval capabilities; they also promote heightened critical and methodological self-awareness.
a database not only facilitates quick access to specific facts but also allows unexpected connections to emerge serendipitously.
therefore, in the context of humanistic studies, relational databases serve as para-interpretative structures rather than purely pre-interpretative tools.
similarly, in digital humanities, the process of creation often holds as much significance for the experiential value of scholarly work as the ultimate utilization of the end product.
regrettably, there are additional instances of redundancy persisting in the database.
notably, each publisher entry in our database lists new york as its location, resulting in repetitive data across all six publisher records.
this duplication could have been prevented by adhering strictly to a precise definition of "types of information that vary independently of one another" during the creation of our initial er diagram.
in reality, identifying such redundancies can be challenging during the initial domain analysis.
in some cases, these duplications may only become apparent after substantial data has been input into a prototype system.
in this instance, we must include a foreign key value that corresponds to a primary key in the authors table.
there are three approaches to achieve this.
the first method involves identifying the relevant record in the authors table, noting its primary key, and incorporating it into the insert statement for the work entry.
the second method suggests performing an update statement post the record creation to append the author's primary key to the foreign key field author_id in the work record.
the third and potentially most efficient method is to integrate the primary key lookup statement within the insert statement for adding a work record.
all these methods necessitate proficiency in querying the database; hence, we will briefly defer this discussion to delve into sql query commands.
the limitations of a derivative model like tei in accurately representing the structures and functions of traditional textual documents become evident upon observation.
traditional documents, embedded with their own markup codes, provide simulations not just of language but also of various semeiotic processes as described by peirce.
these texturized documents serve to narrow and alter the broader semeiotic context in which they exist, often for self-reflective intentions.
however, the operational confines imposed by traditional textual forms on the encompassing semeiotic context they imitate and replicate are notably more practical, in a comprehensive peircean sense, than the current electronic models being utilized.
alongside the progression of the ivanhoe project, a related initiative known as time modelling was undertaken by bethany nowviskie and johanna drucker.
the purpose of this project was to incorporate visualization and interface design at the outset of projects like ivanhoe, which focus on interpretation through transformative and sometimes disruptive interactions with primary data.
while ivanhoe's computer is configured to record and algorithmically analyze players' interpretative actions for post-game evaluation, the primary critical function occurs retrospectively as humans reflect on the varied patterns revealed by the computerized analyses.
in contrast, the time modelling device seamlessly intertwines performative and critical actions, with users actively participating in deliberate digital transformations.
this device provides users with a range of design tools to restructure a chronological timeline of events subjectively and speculatively.
originally, our idea revolved around creating "ultimate ivanhoe," a playspace guided by emergent consciousness software.
in this setup, the computer would play an active role during ivanhoe sessions, allowing players to assess and compare their interpretations of their actions with computer-generated perspectives.
while the potential for realizing this vision of ivanhoe still exists, the concept of time modelling highlighted an alternative approach to positioning the human observer within an autopoietic system.
a different perspective on these concepts can be achieved by reimagining textspace as topological, providing unique benefits.
while this space operates as an autopoietic system, it doesn't conform to conventional dimensional standards in mathematics.
instead, the model we suggest autonomously defines and evaluates its dimensions as part of its self-organizing mechanisms.
moreover, a space characterized by interdependent relationships implies that any specified dimension within the system can be systematically linked to others.
this transformative capability is what shifts the notion of a dimension to that of a dementian.
this text-processing model is characterized by its open-ended, discontinuous, and non-hierarchical nature.
it unfolds within a fieldspace that becomes apparent through the act of "reading." a digital processing software needs to be conceptualized and developed to enable the marking and storing of these textual field maps.
subsequently, the program would facilitate the examination of their growth, evolution, and comparison with other textual mappings and interactions.
by framing textualities as spaces within these contexts, it bypasses various critical biases that limit our conventional understanding of texts.
it circumvents binary interpretations such as text versus reader or subjective versus objective textual perspectives.
reader-response criticism attempted to address these issues but inadvertently reinforced the existing distinctions.
this perspective highlights that these distinctions are essentially tools for understanding.
from this standpoint, the "text" we engage with is considered an autopoietic occurrence that we actively engage with and contribute to.
a natural enhancement to the aforementioned method was to substitute extensive strings of intricate formatting codes with more straightforward abbreviations that could be automatically enlarged into the formatting commands they represented.
instead of inputting the entire command sequence, the typesetter would simply enter the abbreviation.
during the 1960s and 1970s, these abbreviated commands were commonly referred to as "macros." this term was borrowed from assembly language programming, where it denoted symbolic instructions at a higher level, which would be expanded into lower-level primitive instructions before program execution.
enhancing portability and interoperability is key.
documents that employ clear descriptive markup instead of complex, application-specific formatting directives make it significantly simpler to transfer them to different text processing systems.
oftentimes, minimal adjustments like changing delimiter conventions, replacing specific labels with others, and converting formatting guidelines to align with the new platform are all that's required.
as mentioned earlier, the purpose of this chapter is not to teach the reader about text encoding but to offer a brief historical and theoretical context to enhance comprehension.
here, we discuss key themes in sgml and xml and address various topics we consider beneficial.
however, for a comprehensive understanding, we recommend referring to the "gentle introduction" and the additional readings listed in the references below.
despite the complexity that may make the sgml standard challenging to comprehend, its fundamental concept is straightforward.
sgml serves as a metalanguage, a language for creating machine-readable definitions of descriptive markup languages.
by defining the parameters such as markup tag delimiters, permitted arrangements of identified components, asserted characteristics, and abbreviations, sgml facilitates the creation of structured documents.
another perspective describes sgml as a metagrammar—a grammar for outlining other grammars, using the term "grammar" in the specialized sense within linguistics and computer science.
one of the significant issues was the lack of diversity in the html element set.
to fulfill its potential, web publishing needed to support advanced and specialized markup languages.
this required enhancing the software for handling dtds to allow for the use of various markup vocabularies without prior coordination.
moreover, there was a clear need to establish a method for more dependable processing of document instances even in the absence of dtds.
the text encoding initiative (tei) was born in november 1987 during a gathering at vassar college, organized by the association for computers in the humanities and sponsored by the national endowment for the humanities.
thirty-two experts from various fields, including professional organizations, libraries, archives, and projects across europe, north america, and asia, participated in this meeting.
the participants shared a common concern about the growing problem of numerous incompatible and inadequately structured encoding systems, which posed a serious hindrance to the utilization of computers for advancing research in the humanities.
the association for computers in the humanities, the association for literary and linguistic computing, and the association for computational linguistics collaborated to establish a steering linguist committee and create an advisory board comprising delegates from different professional societies.
michael sperberg-mcqueen from the university of illinois at chicago and lou burnard from oxford university were appointed as editors.
additionally, four working committees were established.
by the conclusion of 1989, more than fifty scholars were actively engaged in the initiative, with its scope expanding rapidly.
the history behind the creation of the tei guidelines highlighted in this brief account underscores a crucial aspect.
the guidelines emerged and persist as a result of a vast collaborative effort among scholars worldwide spanning various disciplines and countries, each bringing diverse perspectives and interests.
this comprehensive endeavor included active involvement from professionals in different fields and institutions and unfolded over numerous years through a structured process of development, assessment, and synchronization, featuring thorough testing across diverse projects.
the culmination of these efforts is manifested in a text encoding system distinguished by its exceptional robustness and intricacy.
arguments about the prevalence of electronic text, like the one presented in 1971, may appear overstated considering it was a time precluding personal computers, character standards, and the internet as we know it today.
yet, remarkably, these early writings on electronic texts in the humanities before 1995 astoundingly foresaw the utility of electronic text even when the concept was unfamiliar to many.
it's crucial to acknowledge the emergence of the world wide web in the 1990s when assessing the insights of computational humanists.
before this digital milestone, despite significant discussion about the applications and readership of electronic text, few anticipated its potential as a potent tool for widespread dissemination or its subsequent popularity as a means of sharing textual content with a broad audience.
however, in 1971, the environment described by wisbey, characterized by computing centers that accommodated humanists' needs, was present at only a few universities and research centers.
these centers were more likely to attract scientists and social scientists than literary scholars or historians.
typically, universities only had a small number of humanities professors with an interest in electronic texts, leading to a sense of isolation for computing humanists.
therefore, annual conferences and specialized journals became crucial platforms for like-minded colleagues to engage in discussions about various issues, ideas, and advancements.
most of these studies were written before the widespread popularity of the world wide web.
although the web does not completely resolve all issues related to creating, storing, delivering, and displaying electronic texts, it does simplify many of these tasks, particularly when compared to older technologies like ftp, listserv, and gopher.
initially, early adopters, enthusiasts, and critics considered electronic texts primarily for scholars and researchers to aid in traditional humanistic work, as described in the aforementioned table of contents.
they did not anticipate the world wide web's potential to reach a broader audience of readers.
some individuals, particularly those affiliated with project gutenberg, are wary of encoding methods, arguing that avoiding encoding could enhance the longevity of e-texts amidst evolving hardware, operating systems, and applications.
project gutenberg embraces simplicity by not necessitating special software or extensive training for contributors, fostering a culture of volunteerism.
despite potentially surpassing 10,000 titles by the close of 2003, the accuracy of transcriptions may be questionable due to the absence of centralized editorial oversight.
the absence of encoding presents challenges such as the inability to distinguish notes from the main text, identify chapter boundaries swiftly, or denote text formatting like highlighting and font changes.
nevertheless, the founder of project gutenberg, michael hart, has successfully harnessed a volunteer-driven ethos akin to many open-source initiatives.
numerous individuals have explored the concept of establishing a repository housing manuscripts and alternative editions tailored for both scholarly researchers and casual readers.
within this publication model, scholars would be able to examine all manuscript variations to track the evolution of a piece through its different versions, while the general public could engage with a curated reading experience provided by the editors and sourced directly from the original materials.
this proposed archival approach for renowned authors like yeats and hardy has the potential to benefit a wide audience, yet implementation has proven to be highly challenging.
apart from a few prominent initiatives like the canterbury tales project, this vision has seldom materialized, underscoring the immense dedication and labor involved.
various individuals including scholars, students, librarians, computing professionals, and enthusiasts across diverse fields engage in the creation and dissemination of electronic texts.
notably, commercial publishers, originally recognized for their microfilm collections, are now transitioning to digitize and offer access to significantly extensive collections comprising tens of thousands of volumes.
collaborative efforts between institutions and publishers, exemplified by initiatives like the university of virginia's joint venture with chadwyck-healey for early american fiction, and the text creation partnerships established for early english books online and the evans early american imprints, highlight the partnerships forged in the realm of electronic text publication.
how do scholars and students in the humanities go about creating electronic texts?
one approach involves a continuum ranging from a traditional method where considerable time and attention are devoted to producing carefully considered, well-documented, and meticulously edited electronic works.
examples of this approach include the women writers online project at brown university, the archive of henrik ibsen's writings supported by the national library of norway and managed by the universities of oslo and bergen, and the collection of sir isaac newton's manuscripts at imperial college, london.
on the other end of the spectrum are less structured efforts that rely on volunteers and enthusiasts, with well-known instances like project gutenberg and distributed proofreaders.
this diversity in approaches reflects the range of editorial practices seen in the last century, akin to the distinctions between scholarly editions and reading editions, which cater to different objectives and readerships.
