while some scholars find the latter category adequate for classroom instruction or quick reference, others prioritize the thorough documentation and editorial standards typical of the former.
there is a growing interest in enhancing this situation as libraries are now incorporating electronic text records into their online catalogs.
innovations like the open archives initiative have the potential to streamline the discovery process of electronic texts.
efforts are being made to create search methods that can access diverse collections across various institutions.
this advancement would enable individuals, such as those intrigued by nineteenth-century american history, to conduct a single comprehensive search across multiple sites holding collections from that era, with the results conveniently gathered and displayed in a unified interface.
there is an additional type of division that is emerging.
there is a growing gap between individuals who have access to an expanding array of collections offered by commercial publishers and those who do not.
this gap was evident at a recent conference focusing on nineteenth-century american literature, where it was observed that graduate students at prestigious research universities had access to diverse commercially published digital text collections, while many of their counterparts who had recently started jobs at smaller institutions did not.
despite the fact that these early-career academics may no longer need to physically visit institutions to view original documents, they still rely on resources to travel to institutions with licensed electronic text collections.
however, there is optimism for these scholars as more libraries and museums are digitizing larger segments of their collections and making them accessible to the public.
one major issue is the restricted variety of electronic texts accessible.
researchers or readers using electronic texts face a chaotic assortment, with little consideration given to choosing suitable editions, as noted by mcgann.
it parallels a race for territory as publishers, libraries, and individuals endeavor to release substantial collections.
the quantity of freely obtainable texts, including initiatives like making of america, the wright american fiction project, the university of virginia e-text center, and the library of congress's american memory, is expanding rapidly.
the aforementioned commercial publishers initially commenced their journey as microfilm publishers, where their collections were built based on the same concept.
copyright law significantly influences most electronic text collections.
with very few electronic text collections containing copyrighted material, even those offered by commercial publishers, two primary effects are observed.
firstly, digital collections primarily feature works by authors who lived and published before the twentieth century, as works by newer authors are likely still under copyright protection and harder to reproduce.
secondly, new editions of pre-twentieth-century writers are usually favored, as projects and publishers opt for works in the public domain.
consequently, contemporary literary criticism, biographies, and theories, which could offer essential context and analysis of primary literature, are mostly absent.
the full potential of the medium to provide a comprehensive context for studying primary literary texts and historical documents has not been fully realized to date.
in a way, the world wide web has revolutionized the creation and dissemination of electronic texts on a scale previously unimaginable.
however, the tools currently used for accessing these texts often fall short in comparison to the functionalities provided by traditional publishing methods like cd-roms.
this shortfall may stem from the lack of consensus on how electronic texts should be utilized, as well as the challenges of developing comprehensive text analysis tools that cater to a wide array of text collections.
the adoption of more advanced automated analysis will likely remain constrained until more sophisticated tools become more universally accessible.
in the interim, common activities will mainly revolve around basic keyword searches and text retrieval techniques.
while these practices hold significance for many academics, they only scratch the surface of the potential offered by humanities computing.
on the field, your plans were like a sacred scripture to you, always by your side, becoming dog-eared, yellowed, and stained with mud, bearing witness to your dedication.
despite their revered status, the plans only marked the beginning.
once you set foot on the site, everything changed.
no amount of meticulous preparation could anticipate the variables.
it was a fascinating moment when you encountered the real site, a departure from the idealized sketches.
for instance, let's consider the familiarity one may have with a specific theme in a well-known piece of literature.
when creating a model, one starts by giving importance to this knowledge, regardless of its accuracy, and then constructs a digital representation of it using tools like text analysis to specify a structured vocabulary of word forms.
initially, this model is likely to expose minor mistakes or oversights.
however, with continuous refinement, these minor errors are gradually replaced by insightful discoveries.
models can surprise us by either revealing unexpected success, such as finding a word where it shouldn't be, or by puzzling failures, like missing a word that should be present.
these surprises challenge the modeling process.
as a research instrument, modeling proves its worth when it leads to failures, either by exposing shortcomings within the model itself or by highlighting flawed concepts indirectly.
the term "diagram" functions both as a noun and a verb, with a wide range of verb forms.
just like the word "represent," its action is defined more by concepts than by visual representation, even when that representation is highly detailed.
in physics, as maxwell points out, diagrams frequently portray force or motion, even if implicitly, despite their static nature.
in the context of communication, such as during a lecture or a collaborative discussion, the act of diagramming takes precedence over the fixed result.
this end product might actually be incomprehensible without the dynamic discussion it originated from.
the reason why answering this question is essential is that our work involves an experimental approach that requires specific equipment and established methods.
to proficiently apply these methods, we must have a comprehensive understanding of our actions.
i have termed the essence of this approach as "modeling" and proposed that when grasped correctly, modeling can lead to a form of computing that is integrated with the humanities, enabling a continual process of gaining knowledge through manipulating representations.
despite being on solid epistemological ground, the challenge lies in articulating the intellectual justification for the techniques involved in this process.
consequently, the lack of a structured discourse on modeling results in its significance being overshadowed.
while the explicit methods and concrete actions are evident, the inability to effectively explain the intellectual rationale behind the outcomes has relegated computing to being viewed merely as a tool and not as a respected discipline, often marginalized within academic circles.
however, the practical utility of this approach is undisputed.
stanley fish has posed a comprehensive challenge to the field of stylistics by questioning its fundamental principles.
he argues that the conventional approach of identifying formal structures in a text and interpreting them in isolation from the reader's perception renders stylistics fruitless.
fish contends that meaning is not inherent within the text but is constructed during the act of reading.
therefore, he dismisses the notion that the formal elements scrutinized by stylisticians hold significance independently from the reader's engagement with them.
according to fish, analyzing these features outside the reader's context results in a futile exercise as they only refer back to themselves and do not contribute to a deeper understanding of the text's meaning or its comparison with other texts.
fish aims to go beyond merely criticizing certain stylistic excesses; his objective is to completely dismantle stylistics.
the sense of urgency in his analysis arises from his skepticism towards the notion that stylistics possesses a unique "scientific" legitimacy and what he perceives as its anti-humanist inclination, which neglects the human element in reading and interpretation.
nonetheless, there is room to suggest an alternative rationale for stylistics: revealing hidden language usage patterns that might go unnoticed due to their subtle nature or widespread occurrence on a vast scale; and putting forth and validating hypotheses about language use where empirical confirmation appears feasible and fitting.
for instance, an exploration of a playwright's utilization of "thou" and "you" forms exemplifies the former, while investigating differences in writing styles between genders showcases the latter.
in computational stylistics, working with tendencies instead of rigid rules is essential due to the variability in the semantic function of language, making the relationship between features and meanings constantly shifting.
every element and combination thereof can take on novel meanings in different contexts.
despite this fluidity, there are discernible patterns and consistencies that call for a comprehensive theory of semantics.
while a textual unit like the pronoun "i" may hold a specific individual meaning within a given context, it also carries significance as part of a broader collection.
for instance, the use of "i" not only signals a speaker's identity but also contributes to the overall distribution of this pronoun in the text, indicating varying levels of first-person discourse throughout.
this aligns with a conventional, hypothesis-driven design approach.
an alternative method involves exploratory data analysis, where researchers alter various parameters to uncover significant insights.
when conducted cautiously, this method can unveil discoveries that could have been overlooked in a rigidly structured study.
with the decrease in time and costs associated with collecting, manipulating, and visually presenting data, the appeal of exploratory analysis has grown.
the concept of assigning authorship hinges on a specific concept of the author.
since the 1970s, the conventional academic practice of determining authorship has been carried out with a degree of uncertainty, influenced by the theories of french post-structuralists including roland barthes, michel foucault, and jacques derrida.
these thinkers challenged the notion of the bourgeois individual subject, diminishing the author's role as the primary source of meaning in texts.
in the realm of literature, this idea of the individual author had peaked during the romantic era's notion of the heroic author.
following the rise of structuralism, there has been a growing focus on the significance of discourse, culture, and language itself in shaping texts.
during the 1980s, there was a significant surge in the speed and capacity of computers.
as more texts were being generated in digital formats, it became feasible to compile corpora that surpassed the sizes of the brown and lob corpora, reaching millions of words.
the abundance of such large-scale language resources enabled the extraction of valuable statistical insights regarding language usage patterns.
these statistics played a vital role in enhancing language processing tools like syntactic parsers, igniting a fresh wave of interest in corpus compilation within the computational linguistics community.
additionally, parallel corpora, featuring identical texts in multiple languages, began to emerge during this period.
among these, the most renowned is the canadian hansard corpus, which encompasses parliamentary debates in both english and french.
corpora serve as a repository of samples crucial for developing numerical language models, making the utilization of corpora closely linked to empirical methodologies.
with the surge in electronic text volume in the late 1980s, the door opened for extensive implementation of data-driven approaches in tackling fundamental issues in computational linguistics, like part-of-speech recognition, prepositional phrase matching, parallel text alignment, and word sense disambiguation.
the triumph in addressing some of these challenges using statistical techniques paved the way for their extension to other areas, leading to the integration of statistical methods as a fundamental aspect of computational linguistics research by the mid-1990s.
probabilistic parsing is a modern use of statistical techniques in processing language.
to determine the likelihood that a specific syntactic structure is accurate within its context, vast amounts of data that have been previously annotated and checked for syntax are necessary.
since syntactic structures can be highly ambiguous, traditional parsers commonly generated multiple potential structural interpretations for a sentence.
in contrast, a probabilistic parser relies on existing statistical data to select the most probable analysis.
challenges in collecting corpus-based statistics involve ensuring that the corpus is truly representative of the entire language.
this requires including samples from a wide range of texts that capture different syntactic and semantic aspects of the language.
it is crucial for the corpus to be large enough to prevent issues of data sparseness commonly encountered in statistical analysis.
for instance, in tasks like word sense disambiguation, the data needs to be comprehensive to cover all meanings of a word with multiple senses and do so with enough frequency to derive meaningful statistical insights.
while classics like the brown corpus have been extensively utilized in natural language processing, their one million-word size falls short for contemporary large-scale applications.
many word senses remain unrepresented, syntactic patterns are too rare to be significant, and the corpus lacks the size required for computing bi-gram and tri-gram probabilities essential for training language models like those used in speech recognition.
regrettably, the main freely accessible corpora used for research are comprised of texts that are easily obtainable and can be redistributed without copyright restrictions.
as a consequence, corpora utilized for statistical analysis in language processing tend to be predominantly representative of certain genres, particularly newspaper articles, which make up the majority of texts available through sources like the ldc.
these texts also heavily influence the training datasets for speech recognition technology.
additionally, other accessible corpora mainly consist of technical documents, transcripts of legislative proceedings, brief phone conversations, and similar content.
consequently, corpus-based natural language processing primarily relies on language data from a limited range of specialized fields, resulting in potential biases.
for instance, in newspaper data, there is an overabundance of complex noun phrase complements for certain verbs, commonly found in newspaper-style sentences like "the price increased by two percent to $102 per share from $100 per share." collecting genuine language data from corpora allows for a description of language that is grounded in evidence rather than being based on a specific theoretical framework.
since language users produce texts with actual communicative intentions, collections of texts from native speakers serve as authentic examples of language use.
this is why one of the primary applications of corpora is in compiling dictionaries, especially "learners' dictionaries" aimed at individuals acquiring a foreign language.
the compilation of the cobuild corpus commenced in the early 1980s, comprising approximately 7 million words at that time.
it served as the foundation for developing the collins cobuild english dictionary, marking the pioneering dictionary to solely depend on corpora for its development.
subsequently, within the following decade, the majority of british dictionary publishers adopted corpora as their main source for dictionary content.
interestingly, it is only recently that american dictionary publishers have started turning to corpora for lexicographical guidance.
typically, there has been a lack of collaboration between researchers in the humanities and those in computational linguistics, despite sharing common issues and objectives.
however, this pattern is expected to shift with the rise of the world wide web.
humanists now have greater access to information on computational linguistics research and the tools developed by that field.
conversely, computational linguists may encounter fresh challenges in language processing as they navigate a wider range of web-accessible content, such as literary texts and historical records.
ultimately, the anticipated cooperation between these two disciplines promises to significantly enhance the capabilities of both.
faith is indispensable when it comes to trusting any printed version, whether crafted by franklin or by another editor, myself included.
readers are often unable to fully examine the documentary evidence that influences decisions on anything from genre classification to the appropriateness of content in an academic publication.
these considerations are not only crucial to the humanities field but also form the core of knowledge creation in humanities.
the ability to scrutinize the creators and intents behind the academic materials we analyze, as well as to assess which components are fundamental and deserving of examination, is directly linked to the accessibility of essential documentary evidence facilitated by the medium of presentation.
compared to the limited visibility offered by printed book versions, electronic editions provide easier access to discussions on editorial accuracy, granting insight into the editorial procedures.
by including images of all edited documents along with their typographic translations, electronic editions enable a closer examination.
in this digital environment, it is not feasible to remove 74 words without explanation or to translate marks uniformly without attracting scrutiny.
readers can refer to digital document images to evaluate and compare with editors' interpretations.
the presentation of original documents as digital facsimiles alters the way scholars engage with foundational materials in scholarly editions, impacting notions of expertise and setting new standards.
the concept of a "poem" involves structuring and shaping perspectives and interpretations of dickinson's works to align with societal norms and literary conventions, regardless of the actual content.
following this guideline, the physical evidence, such as manuscripts, embodies the essence of a "poem", and it is the editor's duty to present this essence in a format that enables easy extraction of the poetic elements.
in this context, there are distinct textual boundaries defined by established genre conventions.
the challenge in deciphering textual annotations lies in resisting the urge to confine the text within prescribed categories of prose or poetry, as it often transcends such classifications, blending elements of both and necessitating creative adaptations of existing tei markup structures.
the lack of clear textual boundaries is evident in our submission form for co-editors, where we use quotation marks around the term "genre" to emphasize its imposition by the encoding system.
this highlights that while the categorization of texts into "poem" or "letter" is necessitated for bibliographical purposes, electronic editing allows for a more adaptable interpretation of emily dickinson's works and her genre manipulations.
this flexibility prompts readers to question the nature of the texts and the intentions behind them, leading to inquiries such as "what is this?" and "what is this writer aiming to express?" just as editors must consider the intentions of the authors, and readers should also take into account the intentions of both the writer and any subsequent editors, multiple editors collaborating on different sections of the same text must also consider the intentions of their fellow editors and collaborators.
readers who invest time and effort in adhering to the principles established for the scholarly production of texts are important participants in this process.
engaging with the various intentions that shape textual productions offers valuable insights for creating editorial environments that are not only reliable but also contribute to advancing critical comprehension.
this approach encourages scholars to explore new and previously unimagined questions.
as previously mentioned in another essay, lucy suchman offers perceptive insights into the conditions necessary for maximizing knowledge production.
when examining the concept of "objective knowledge" presented in a critical edition, it is suggested to move away from perceiving it as a singular, fixed standpoint that claims objectivity by silencing debate.
instead, in the context of creating a dynamic critical edition online, "objective knowledge" can be understood as a collection of diverse, situated viewpoints that achieve objectivity through continuous discussions.
as critical insight is multi-dimensional, it is crucial to engage in the processes of comparing and assessing these various perspectives akin to appreciating different viewpoints of an image.
the source of objectivity is not a static body of knowledge dictated by one entity but rather a continuously evolving pool of knowledge that we all contribute to and are accountable for.
a fitting comparison could be drawn to handwoven rugs that vary between those predominantly featuring russet tones and those where greens and blues take precedence.
in this context, the focus lies not on any individual stitch, thread, or color, but on the combined impact.
these effects are most noticeable when contrasting pieces are viewed together.
this will be the scenario i aim to illustrate.
the data being analyzed consists of word-counts for 150 common words in each of the forty specimens.
these words are among the most frequently used in seventeenth-century verse.
this comprehensive list provides more reliable results compared to a list generated from a smaller, more selective text sample being examined.
the texts were processed using the same protocols as the primary database, ensuring consistency.
modifications were made to modernize the texts by standardizing spelling variations prevalent in seventeenth-century texts.
contractions like "don't" and "i've" were expanded to count their full forms, while certain words like "so" and "that" were tagged to indicate their primary grammatical functions.
after these preparations, the texts were analyzed using sorting and counting programs.
raw word counts were adjusted to percentages relative to the total word count in each text to account for variations in text lengths and to ensure a fair comparison across texts.
this normalization helps prevent bias towards longer texts during analysis.
analyzing a large group of texts reveals intricate patterns of similarity and dissimilarity through concurrent variations.
these patterns are further complicated yet understandable due to the presence of numerous exceptions, some attributed to unique author characteristics.
the potential combinations across various genres, time periods, authors, and texts are virtually limitless.
these effects likely influence the perceptions of adept readers but can be challenging to express verbally.
on the contrary, statistical analysis provides a straightforward albeit less nuanced means of illustrating these patterns.
the collection features a total of sixteen plays, with the first ten being verse dramas followed by four prose dramas.
the last two plays, from southerne's the fatal marriage, offer a mix of both verse and prose.
each subset, including works by dryden, rochester, stapylton, congreve, and southerne, presents authorial pairs.
sedley and shadwell provide an opportunity to compare authorship styles between verse and prose.
although the sample size is limited, consisting of only 16 plays, they can be analyzed alongside the poetry and personal letters of the same period for informative insights.
an argument can be put forward to justify the exclusion of personal pronouns due to their inconsistent frequency, making them unreliable as measures.
if they are removed, then the issue of inflected verbs becomes significant.
it would seem reasonable to also eliminate them.
however, the growing loss of information at this point should be a cause for concern.
these three removals would result in 81 words being taken out of the original 150 on the list.
while achieving a desirable level of strictness, this action would come at a significant expense.
category d writing is characterized by the absence of first and second-person pronouns, with third-person pronouns such as "it" and "they" being prevalent.
articles mainly serve as referential markers, with a notable lack of feminine pronouns.
notably, historical texts, although sometimes more personalized than scholarly works, often do not prominently feature feminine pronouns.
an interesting case study could be examining whether feminine pronouns are used extensively in sections of gibbon's historical work, particularly in the chapter that discusses empress theodora's achievements.
the empress is one of the rare women mentioned in the titles of his 71 chapters.
contemporary feminist scholars are actively working to rebalance historical biases by revising the use of pronouns in scholarly discourse.
drawing inspiration from novels by henry fielding, dear reader, i am reminded that various literary forms, including the novel, can draw from multiple categories i have discussed.
naturally, when this happens, the usage of pronouns, articles, and auxiliary verbs is likely to undergo some modifications.
the limited list of identifiable literary forms i have presented only scratches the surface of the more obvious classifications.
i acknowledge that the term genre has expanded its scope in recent times and lost some of its former precision.
its broadened application becomes apparent when it is used to describe personal letters, which belong to a diverse group of loosely connected literary forms.
if a significant disparity in writing styles between male and female writers can diminish entirely within a generation or two, as indicated by these findings, the cause might not stem from biological distinctions between the genders.
however, if the discrepancies in "gender," as evidenced in the subtle nuances of male and female societal roles mentioned previously, were the primary rationale, it seems improbable that the shift would be almost complete.
regardless of individual perspectives, it is challenging to argue that the social distinctions in roles between men and women in english-speaking communities are no longer discernible.
the traditional form of textual analysis involves tasks such as separating, distinguishing, and focusing on individual works.
this method of literary analysis typically relies on what may appear to be intuitive observations and distinctions, which may seem different from the data collection and classification processes of computational stylistics that i have been emphasizing.
however, these insights and distinctions are not purely intuitive as they are rooted in a wealth of knowledge accumulated over a lifetime of reading, stored in the subconscious, and utilized through comparison and classification processes, whether explicitly or implicitly, as samuel johnson pointed out.
both traditional and computational methods of textual analysis possess unique advantages.
while the intricate connections in the plots of king lear or the refined interpretations made by coleridge in the initial lines of hamlet may elude digital analysis, the subtle ironies in jane austen's works or the nuanced ambiguities identified by william empson remain beyond reach as well.
however, computers excel in handling extensive textual datasets, identifying distinct patterns, and compiling occurrences of recurring elements more efficiently than human capabilities alone.
libraries, archives, and museums are actively collaborating on thematic research collections to complement their ongoing collection development efforts.
historically, these institutions have been vital for humanities research, gathering a wide array of materials across various subjects to support scholarly exploration.
despite the existence of numerous specialized research collections, their physical distance from scholars and students has been a challenge.
to address this, many organizations are now converting selected collections into digital formats, enhancing their accessibility on the internet for researchers, students, and the public.
the materials are organized thematically or centered around a specific research topic.
an illustration of this can be found in various collections at iath, such as the complete writings and pictures of dante gabriel rossetti: a hypermedia research archive, the dickinson electronic archives, and the walt whitman archive, which are all focused on the works of specific authors.
alternatively, collections can revolve around a particular literary or artistic creation, like uncle tom's cabin and american culture.
for instance, the hamlet on the ramparts collection, managed by the mit shakespeare project, is a prime example of a collection honing in on a narrowly defined literary subject.
this project endeavors to compile texts, artwork, photographs, films, sound recordings, and analyses related to a specific part of hamlet - his initial encounter with the ghost.
themes of a collection may pertain to an event, place, phenomenon, or any other subject of scholarly interest.
noteworthy examples beyond literature studies include projects focusing on the salem witch trials, pompeii forum, and the waters of rome.
some thematic collections are integrated within larger digital repositories.
using a contextual mass model, collections are formed to connect various sources, merging different materials and subjects to facilitate in-depth and comprehensive analysis within a particular field of study.
while numerous resources featured in this chapter encompass extensive primary material cores, such complexity is not obligatory for achieving contextual mass.
for instance, the decameron web project, focusing on the literary, historical, and cultural backdrop of boccaccio's renowned work, includes a critical edition alongside translations and supplementary materials like annotations, commentaries, critical essays, maps, and bibliographies.
the website's design and content clearly reflect its educational purpose, yet also serve as a robust research platform.
several established thematic collections demonstrate the concept of contextual depth and complexity, along with explicit objectives.
the primary focus of the rossetti archive is to encompass all of rossetti's textual and visual creations, supported by a range of contextual materials including contemporaneous works, personal correspondence, biographical information, and modern secondary sources.
the blake archive similarly places a strong emphasis on contextual information as a cornerstone of its scholarly mission.
the project's website underscores the idea that artworks derive meaning from their context, necessitating the presentation of texts alongside illustrations, illuminated books with other similar works, and combining them with additional drawings and paintings.
all these components are then situated within the broader scope of pertinent historical background.
the advent of hypertext has revolutionized the organization of collections, with current endeavors focused on establishing extensive links between aggregated materials.
for instance, the walt whitman hypertext archive aims to connect sources to illustrate the intricate and numerous revisions whitman made to his poems.
each poem's associated materials may include initial notes in a notebook, trial lines, published versions from periodicals, publisher's page proofs, and various printed book editions.
similarly, the bolles collection on the history of london, housed within the vast perseus digital library, leverages hypertext to provide complete historical texts on london.
this approach incorporates hyperlinks linked to names of towns, buildings, and individuals, enabling the correlation of items such as photographs, maps of locations, drawings, and biographies of people.
themed collections that emphasize providing support for contextual mass and activities are approaching the creation of a laboratory-like environment suitable for scholars' daily work.
similar to scientific labs, the ideal spaces should include necessary materials for study and reference, as well as tools to conduct research effectively.
for scholars in the humanities, a well-equipped workspace would offer access to sources found in libraries and archives relevant to their research area, enabling activities such as reading, analysis, interpretation, and writing that typically occur in their offices.
the most effective environments will expand beyond mere thematic focus by offering support for contextual mass and activities tailored not only to existing scholarly practices but also to the inquiries scholars wish to explore and the tasks they aim to accomplish.
in the past, scholars had to sift through numerous catalogues and indexes and visit multiple libraries to access a significant amount of material related to a specific author or subject.
they would painstakingly copy and gather information during their visits, facing restrictions when dealing with delicate items that could not be physically handled or reproduced through photocopying or microfilming.
nowadays, scholars are leveraging the capabilities of virtual collocation to assemble comprehensive collections.
by aggregating content dispersed across various repositories, they can create extensive and intricate compilations of sources that are easily accessible at any time and location.
for instance, the rossetti archive directory showcases a wide array of materials, such as images, poems, prose, illustrated texts, manuscripts, books, biographical information, bibliographies, timelines, and historical contexts, demonstrating the diverse and abundant resources that can be organized through the merging of digital materials.
copyright concerns have limited the full potential of digital collocation.
due to the ease of digitizing and sharing sources without copyright restrictions, older materials in the public domain are more commonly featured in digital collections.
with the aim of creating systematic and purposeful collections, curators are now navigating copyright regulations for published works and integrating new digital sources.
projects such as the william blake archive serve as a notable example by successfully collaborating with institutions and private collectors to address copyright issues and include valuable materials in their collections.
as an illustration, the profile of william blake includes references to 20 collections, with two of them being part of the william blake archive initiative.
collaborative efforts among various institutions commonly result in subject collections that encompass wide academic or geographic subjects.
some instances include the urban studies collection at the center for research libraries, an association focused on collective collection initiatives, and the cooperative development of east asian collections at the university of north carolina and duke university.
special collections departments curate specialized collections based on specific subjects and themes, primarily focusing on primary source materials.
these departments safeguard and provide restricted access to rare and delicate items like manuscripts and papers.
with the advent of online accessibility by research libraries, special collections often became the priority for digitization.
this move aimed to broaden access to the valuable treasures held within these collections, offering digital alternatives to physical viewing that helps reduce damage and preservation issues.
the library of congress launched its pioneering digitization efforts in 1994 through the american memory project, starting with photographic collections.
this initiative has expanded to include over 100 digital collections, many of which feature multimedia and thematic content.
while most collections are digitized versions of existing library of congress materials, thematic collections like band music from the civil war era and the american variety stage bring together items for online presentation for the first time.
currently, various types of resources, such as journal article pre-print servers and lists of links on web pages, are now being labeled as digital or electronic archives.
despite this shift, the conventional professional archive continues to play a crucial role in research collections, with efforts underway to digitally convert some of these archives while preserving their original purposes and structures.
concurrently, informal interpretations of the term are on the rise, and fresh scholarly interpretations of the concept are emerging.
a thematic collection differs from a traditional library as it is curated specifically for inclusion in a digital library or can stand alone without being part of any formal library or institution.
unlike libraries, which house various collections and are dedicated to providing access and maintaining the resources, thematic collections typically do not possess the same cohesive structure or specialized features due to their more focused scope and audience demographics.
the library holds a wide range of primary and secondary materials focusing on the early modern period.
an outstanding thematic collection within perseus is the pre-twentieth-century london segment, drawing from the bolles collection on the history of london.
this section digitally recreates a specialized collection known for its thematic cohesion and diverse content.
as mentioned before, it connects london maps, pertinent texts, and historical and modern illustrations of the city.
it is evident that there is a significant intersection between digital libraries and thematic collection initiatives, with the terminology evolving alongside variations and hybrids.
digital research libraries are expected to persist in acquiring collections created by scholars, collaborative groups, and institutions, as scholars' endeavors expand to incorporate and expand digital special collections.
a noteworthy result of this development is that the proficient arrangement of research materials by scholars is introducing a valuable new resource layer to humanities research collections.
in the past, scholars primarily utilized collections for their research and also authored contributions to collections.
however, their involvement in constructing collections was restricted.
they curated personal collections for individual use and organized materials by editing and publishing collected works.
conversely, the establishment of collections has consistently been a crucial aspect of the responsibilities of library professionals, archivists, and curators.
the connection between scholars and collection experts has significantly influenced the evolution of research library collections.
scholars, as the primary group served by research libraries, have shaped collection strategies at research institutions through their inquiries, demands, and ongoing academic activities.
scholars have notably contributed as creators of intellectual works, forming a substantial portion of research collections.
presently, scholars are also actively involved in building research collections, fostering a pivotal transformation in the future formation of expansive research materials.
libraries have not yet established a systematic approach to gathering collections created by scholars.
this is partly due to the novelty of this type of content and also because meta-collecting is an unfamiliar concept.
currently, most research libraries do not acquire or index non-commercial digital content available on the web.
for instance, as of now, worldcat, a significant database of library resources, shows that 263 libraries have acquired and catalogued a recent critical book on william blake by william vaughan.
in contrast, only 26 libraries have included the william blake archive in their collections.
by way of illustration, 34 libraries have listed voice of the shuttle in their catalogues.
this humanities gateway, while widely accessed, differs from the scholarly works typically amassed by libraries and thematic collections.
to overcome the gap, research libraries should establish mid-range collection services that group thematic collections into relevant aggregations.
a mid-level research collection should differ from the existing digital research library, focusing less on top scholarly journals, major indexes, general references, or disciplinary canons.
instead, it should offer access to clusters of top-quality thematic research collections that match the institution's scholarly pursuits.
as the legitimacy of scholar-created research collections continues to gain acceptance, their numbers are expected to rise.
research libraries are still adjusting to how this trend will influence their operations, and there may be a delay before we see a convergence of scholar and institution-generated collections.
a broader appreciation for thematic collections as a valuable scholarly activity is essential before this can happen.
scholars and scientists are increasingly creating numerous digital products, many of which are high-quality compilations, supported by funding agencies.
research libraries will need to adapt their collection development strategies to accommodate this trend.
furthermore, universities must allocate resources to support this type of research as collection building becomes a more prominent scholarly endeavor.
currently, the necessary materials and expertise for collection building are scattered across various departments, libraries, and computing centers.
scholars are increasingly adept at digital collocation and are creating revolutionary research environments, reshaping the concept of collection development.
thematic collections are not just tools for supporting scholarship but are actively shaping it.
they offer curated groupings of research materials that effectively highlight the connections between various sources and subject areas.
by utilizing contextual mass, interdisciplinary platforms, and activity support, thematic collections enhance the depth, adaptability, and engagement of formerly fragmented and stagnant content repositories.
not only do they facilitate the generation of new research, but they also have the capacity to significantly enhance the scholarly research process.
thematic collections play a crucial role by integrating research materials into the inquiry process, thus making the scholarly landscape more apparent within the collection.
through this integration, the collection reflects the questions and methodologies driving scholarly investigations, highlighting a visible representation of scholarship.
furthermore, as scholars collaborate to develop these collections, the networks of researchers and institutions contributing to a specific research field are illuminated.
in today's digital age, thematic collections significantly enhance research resources, enriching the existing materials and creating novel prospects for the field of humanities scholarship.
in this chapter, i will explore the connection and assert that grasping the intricacies of this relationship necessitates an examination of scholarly practices and the utilization of resources.
this investigation extends to how information is applied, whether through computational means or traditional print, within the broader landscape of scholarly pursuits.
it is essential to contemplate our approach to interpreting texts and visual materials to appreciate the ongoing significance of print, and its interplay with digital counterparts and reproductions.
i am currently at the byzantine museum, where i am being presented with some of the treasures from this northern greek city that boasts the longest period under continuous byzantine rule.
the museum is brimming with icons, mosaics, marble carvings, and elaborately painted tombs.
while admiring these artifacts, my guide inquires about my opinion, emphasizing that their interpretation is crucial.
i come across a tomb featuring a painted tree providing shelter to a plump bird resembling a turkey, though it is, in fact, an olive tree symbolizing eternity and peace, with the bird representing a peacock, a symbol of paradise.
it becomes evident that these pieces are not merely decorative but carry profound symbolic meanings.
the icons radiate vibrant colors that captivate me, with each hue bearing significance: the golden backdrop signifies heaven and eternity, a red cloak symbolizes love, and a green band adorning the madonna's head represents hope.
the painted wrinkles on her face serve as a symbol that true beauty originates internally and remains unaffected by the passage of time.
as my mentor challenges me to identify what lies before me, i find myself struggling to recall the unfamiliar visual language being introduced to me.
it dawns on me that my dependency on written text and the absence of these evocative visuals have hindered my ability to understand this form of communication.
this symbolic imagery represents a distinct tradition deeply rooted in ancient greek culture, which has endured alongside the prevalence of written language yet has not been entirely replaced by it.
i serve on the advisory board for the portsmouth record office.
over the course of many years, they have diligently created nine edited printed volumes that document some of the contents of their archives.
these volumes are organized thematically, covering topics such as dockyards, historic houses, and legal documents.
each volume is elegantly presented in hardback format with its unique design.
despite having a sizeable number of volumes still being prepared, the increasing cost of printing has led the office to opt for electronic publication.
our discussions often revolve around forthcoming volumes, and we are all pleased to learn that the next volume, after three decades in the making, will soon be available.
there is a mutual culture shock experienced from both perspectives.
i am surprised to learn about the extensive duration that editing and publishing processes require.
while thirty years appears lengthy, an average of a decade seems common.
i contemplate the historical significance of the papers, which persist in archives, ready to be unearthed even without specific scheduling.
transitioning back from the fast-paced technological advancements i am accustomed to, it's challenging to adjust to the slower pace and lesser sense of urgency in this context.
i maintain the view that the concept of distinct volumes is unnecessary in digital publications.
unlike print volumes, there is no requirement to establish a publication schedule.
instead, we can release data on various themes simultaneously in multiple installments as soon as it is prepared.
this approach allows the digital records to expand according to the pace of the editing process, thus preventing any unnecessary delays.
while these suggestions are met with enthusiasm, the series editor cautions us about the human aspects involved in this process.
editors of individual volumes may desire recognition for their work as a distinct entity, crucial for acknowledgment from funding bodies or review panels.
moreover, it is noted that these collections would feel incomplete without an introduction, typically crafted at the end.
this task is a significant intellectual endeavor and could potentially have contributed to publication delays, given its requirement to synthesize a broad array of sources and convey their historical significance.
the author privately ponders if releasing the data without an introduction temporarily is an option worth considering.
exploring various approaches to presenting the data from different perspectives may help address these challenges, with both parties making intellectual adjustments that are perceptible.
as the use of digital resources began gaining prominence, there was a belief that these resources could and should replace the traditional practice of interpreting printed materials through reading.
advocates supported digital resources and criticized those hesitant to embrace them as misinformed or resistant to technology.
in the 1990s, initiatives were launched to educate scholars on digital resources.
universities established learning media units to assist in resource production and offered technical support to academics, although this support remains insufficient in the british academic system.
the availability and quality of digital resources in the humanities improved over time.
despite this progress, printed scholarship remains relevant.
scholars in the humanities continue to emphasize reading books and writing articles, alongside using or creating digital resources.
i observed during my time in portsmouth that cultural norms in academia evolve slowly.
print publications still hold considerable authority.
this prompts the question: why is this collection published in book format?
consequently, there is a risk that enthusiasts of humanities computing may be perceived by their more traditional peers as overzealous technophiles who simply dabble in computers and digital resources because they can.
they might be viewed as indulging in technological gadgets while their peers engage in the challenging task of interpreting texts without the aid of technology.
since reading holds a high value and remains a common practice, it is essential for humanities computing practitioners to also take reading seriously to be regarded as serious scholars.
the incident at my portsmouth meeting illustrates that both sides of the argument tend to hold specific assumptions about scholarly practices, highlighting the necessity for mutual understanding and appreciation of these assumptions to progress collaboratively.
given that reading remains a persistent activity among academics, even after the adoption of digital resources, it is crucial to consider what reading signifies and the nature of the materials being read.
moreover, a challenging aspect lies in the interpretation of the analysis results.
a key principle in developing automated information retrieval systems is the prerequisite for a researcher to have a predetermined search objective.
this ensures that they can configure the system to identify and recognize the sought-after criteria and fully grasp the efficiency of recall.
in contrast to social scientists or linguists, scholars in the humanities often delve into texts without a predefined search target, making it challenging to ascertain the significance of their findings.
computer systems excel at locating specific features, presenting a dilemma since researchers can only gain this insight by extensively studying the text and potentially others.
otherwise, it becomes arduous to decipher the outcomes of computer analyses or pinpoint the right inquiries to pose regarding the text.
having a digitized version of a transcribed manuscript enables us to access its contents.
it is often through viewing a digital image that scholars recognize the additional possibilities for interpretation that exist, which seem to be best explored through the physical artifact.
the complexity of this process means that we have not yet comprehensively grasped its full significance.
it is crucial to consider the type of resources utilized by humanities scholars.
this consideration helps in understanding the ongoing intricate relationship between print and digital resources.
the suitability of digital resources may not always align with the requirements of humanities scholars or the tasks they wish to accomplish.
despite this, printed materials still serve various purposes, potentially motivating scholars to disseminate their research through traditional publishing methods.
however, it could be contended that leveraging computational techniques could offer more advanced and nuanced approaches to analyzing such content.
despite its seemingly straightforward nature, reading remains a fundamental aspect to be explored.
the art of pattern making in language is such that the significance of a word can be influenced by its placement in a text and the response it triggers in the reader.
for instance, dramatic irony succeeds in communicating unacknowledged meanings in a character's dialogue.
our ability to grasp this hinges on the mental associations and resonances it stirs.
language gains depth and richness through its connections and the contexts in which it is employed.
however, the intricate patterns produced by human readers pose a challenge to replicate through computational analysis.
text analysis software typically isolates the specific phenomenon being studied from its broader context, focusing only on the immediate surrounding words.
for example, a linguist might compile instances of a particular phenomenon and organize the findings in a concordance sorted alphabetically, regardless of their original sequence in the text or their authorship.
yet, for a literary critic, recognizing these patterns is essential to interpreting the text and deriving meaning from it.
consequently, the fragmented nature of computer analysis tools falls short in capturing the depth of meaning that comes from interpreting a word within the context of a narrative structure.
hence, the reason for the continued coexistence of print resources alongside digital ones should be evident.
the primary task of a humanities scholar is to comprehend and analyze texts, and attempting to mimic the nuanced and intricate process of human interpretation using computational tools seems rather redundant.
engaging with a physical text involves a refined and intricate analytical approach.
thus, it is not unexpected that scholars tend to view digital resources and computational methods that merely imitate the act of reading as a feeble replication of an already effective technique.
for digital resources to be beneficial to humanities scholars, they need to offer a distinct dimension that has the potential to transform our perception of the source materials.
the impact of this development and the increasing popularity of graphical user interfaces has reminded us of the significance of images, not just for organizing information, but also for effectively communicating it.
similar to the artworks displayed in the museum in thessaloniki prompting a different perspective on interpreting and conveying ideas, we have needed to rediscover how to analyze an image, whether it portrays a painted masterpiece or a digitally created icon.
the decision on the significance of such movement and its implications for the play is left to the critic, but the program has effectively brought about a useful sense of defamiliarization, a concept challenging to envision in print media.
a comparable method of visually representing textual information is evident in the interactive 3-d model of dante's inferno, also contributing to a defamiliarizing effect.
this fresh perspective on the text motivates readers to revisit the printed version with a renewed outlook.
the digital resource does not render reading obsolete but instead opens up new avenues for interpretation.
notably, this project is in progress at iath, the research center associated with mcgann and ramsay, bridging the gap between digital resources and conventional scholarly practices.
some other historians argue that in order to fully grasp the complexity of the subject area, anecdotal sources and printed texts should be utilized in conjunction with research findings.
they suggest that problems arose due to excessive dependence on numerical data analysis, which implies that it alone could provide a definitive explanation of slavery and resolve controversies stemming from subjective human interpretation.
projects like valley of the shadow mark a significant advancement not only in computational methods but also in scholarly approaches.
by integrating numerical data with textual and spatial information, these projects offer interpretive tools that supplement the historian's analysis rather than replace it.
humanities scholars work with intricate materials that contain nuanced meanings which can be challenging to decipher.
the processes of interpretation involved are intricate and multifaceted, and we are just starting to grasp their complexity.
despite the apparent simplicity of reading a text, it is actually a highly complex task that current computer analysis struggles to emulate.
this insight helps us appreciate why many scholars will likely continue to rely on reading printed materials as a fundamental aspect of their research endeavors.
digital resources, although not intended to supplant the cognitive abilities of scholars, can significantly enhance their work.
instead of serving as a replacement for the human mind's analytical capabilities, computer-assisted delivery of resources can function as a valuable support tool.
the utilization of visual aids to preserve memory and convey information was well-understood in ancient times, evident during my exploration of the icons in thessaloniki.
while much of this expertise got overshadowed by the text-centric nature of print culture, the graphical interface of computer screens has facilitated a reconnection with the visual realm.
this has allowed us to rediscover a forgotten language of interpretation.
by offering a fresh perspective, digital resources enable us to discern the intricacies of interpreting humanities materials in a new light.
this novel approach to examining texts can liberate readers from the confines of physical print, even if it ultimately guides them back to the pages of traditional books.
a remarkable paradox unfolded as many european directors absorbed valuable lessons from watching american films.
despite not understanding english, they keenly observed the visual storytelling techniques employed in these movies, uncovering a dynamic visual vitality often overlooked by american audiences and critics fixated on plot.
these filmmakers not only embraced the american cinematic style but also offered a distinctive counterpoint, skillfully evading the commercial pressures prevalent in the american studio system that viewed films merely as products for consumption.
the influence of the french new wave's innovative writing and filmmaking technique gradually made its way to britain and eventually the usa, triggering a compelling reverse effect that prompted emerging american film scholars to reevaluate their own cinema, which had been largely dismissed and forgotten.
in the early days, the focus was on what was taught and studied.
the auteur theory presented the film director as the pivotal creative force behind a movie rather than just someone to worship.
this theory proved to be a valuable tool for analysis.
by identifying specific stylistic and thematic characteristics associated with a filmmaker, one could delve into understanding and dissecting their work.
alternatively, adopting a foucauldian perspective, the auteur concept could emerge from a body of films.
by scrutinizing a director's oeuvre, patterns and methods of cinematic storytelling recognizable across different films could be revealed.
since the 1990s, numerous academics have ventured into exploring different forms of computer depictions.
i personally credit stephen mamber for sparking my interest and that of many others in utilizing computers to analyze movies.
mamber's pioneering work led to the most captivating and intricate computer-assisted cinematic analysis known as the "digital hitchcock" project focused on hitchcock's the birds.
this project began with mamber gaining access to the film's script, storyboards, and other related materials through the academy of motion picture arts and sciences.
creating software from the ground up, mamber crafted an impressive display: he initially showcased the first frame of each shot from the film all on a single screen.
essentially, the entire movie is visually represented by a still image of every shot, each of which can be interacted with.
clicking on a still image reveals the complete shot for further exploration.
the program featured interactive elements that enabled users to create a montage cell from eisenstein's potemkin, visualize classical hollywood three-point lighting by adjusting key, fill, and backlighting on a figure, and navigate through a sequence in vertigo to understand how camera movements and framing convey a narrative distinct from the character's perspective in the film.
additionally, it included a glossary function where users could click on hotwords within the text to access definitions of terms.
i would like to emphasize that concerns related to intellectual property should not be the primary barrier to incorporating moving images into educational or academic projects.
there are various avenues available to obtain necessary materials, even if they may not always align with preferences.
fair use principles should be upheld for in-class educational purposes, inclusion of digital images in books, and, following the enactment of the teach act, for broader educational dissemination.
there has been a shift towards increased flexibility from studios, possibly influenced by the rise of dvd formats and the unexpected popularity of their "supplementary material." dvds present a new realm for advancing digitized media in film studies, offering potential relief for copyright issues.
the introduction of the search function in film analysis presents a unique challenge.
it essentially transfers some essential analysis tasks to the program user.
this shift raises complex critical and practical queries, with a fundamental one being: what will the user seek in their search?
should we anticipate user needs when building the database, setting up a predefined list of keywords for users to search, and ensuring their presence in relevant database fields?
could we include such a list within the program, possibly as part of the introductory materials, to guide users on potential search queries?
unlike using a web search engine like google, where we generally have a clear idea of our search intent despite potential mismatches in results, using a film database interface and speculating on user search intentions presents a distinctly different challenge.
to fully enhance our capabilities, we require a program that can directly scan images.
this would involve categorizing images in the database and conducting searches based on these tags.
essentially, we could specify details regarding the image's content, color, arrangement, and thematic significance and permit users to select these criteria to pull up related images or scenes.
the emerging mp7 codec offers a promising feature of tagging the image itself, rather than relying solely on text annotations.
however, the current methods are still reliant on textual descriptions appended to the images for search purposes.
while there exist tools to retrieve still images by similarity, such as selecting an image to find others with comparable colors or shapes, these are sophisticated tools not readily accessible to film researchers.
exploring moving images through search functions presents a unique challenge.
for instance, being able to browse through a database of short cuts to locate specific zoom shots by simply clicking on a similar example could revolutionize the analysis of a film's narrative, a filmmaker's signature style, and, significantly, help us grasp the fundamental principles of cinematic representation.
while software for searching moving images is gradually advancing, a kodak researcher once remarked to me, "it won't happen in our lifetime." however, this conversation took place six years ago.
by transforming thoughts into visible written sentences, writers alleviate the burden of having to remember their creations.
by externalizing words, phrases, and sentences, they can freely delete, rearrange, alter grammatically, and substitute elements as needed.
this process requires dedicated focus to execute these tasks effectively.
through converting inner speech into visible text instantaneously, writers feel acutely aware of the mental process of composition, even though it remains opaque, particularly to experienced writers.
beginners, mastering linguistics, may painstakingly construct utterances in their memory before verbalizing them.
novices conscientiously engage in this task, potentially able to articulate the conscious steps they take, delve into their memory, and mentally refine their composition before speaking.
this preparatory approach, understandable to any native speaker, demonstrates a methodical process in formulating sentences in one's own language.
writers who reflect on their inner thought processes while crafting and vocalizing sentences are accurate in describing the "voice" they hear as formless.
when we listen to someone else speaking, we are not truly hearing their voice but rather our brain's own interpretation of it.
it's clear that various brains could interpret the same speech sounds in divergent ways, resulting in different perceptions of the words being spoken.
in this way, the mind serves as an interpreter of creations produced through a mental procedure, taking on an ethereal and occasionally peculiar voice.
cognitive sciences support authors' impressions of the language-making process as being elusive and inaccessible.
the inner voice articulates sentences that seem to materialize out of thin air.
the fact that we perceive this voice implies that we are eavesdropping on another rather than ourselves; an anonymous, unidentifiable figure who remains somewhat removed and beyond analysis, akin to listening to a voice on a radio.
these mental images serve as a kind of recollection of the process of performing a task, constructing verbal expressions from natural language, where we are unable to link this recollection process to our own identity.
this process is a paradigm of the expert mind failing to pay attention to its own actions.
when we are engaged in composing, we are unable to rectify this disregard, unlike when we are driving a car and suddenly snap back to awareness, realizing we have been on autopilot for a distance.
we cannot voluntarily summon an awareness of how our minds generate verbal expressions.
why is it so elusive for us to remember the process of constructing a sentence?
what causes the mind to be hindered by implicit memory when trying to grasp this fundamental aspect of human communication?
the explanation may be rooted in the nature of our mnemonic capabilities.
our hippocampus, the center for long-term memory formation, can retain information such as language, visuals, sounds, emotions, and thoughts, but not neural processes.
suggestively, we do not rely on recalling the specific activities within the language-processing regions explicitly.
during our cognitive development, these centers lack designated names for the entities and operations taking place.
while not entirely inaccessible, this knowledge might be deemed nonessential and potentially obstructive to our survival instincts.
louis milic, a few decades ago, proposed that stylistics should move away from impressionism towards using quantitative measures.
since then, researchers have gathered numerical data on style and attempted to explain how it sheds light on literary works and their authors.
cognitive stylistics argues that individual minds, not literary texts, possess style when expressing themselves.
it suggests that personal styles are heavily influenced by the neural limitations that govern mental language processes.
because analyzing minds directly is challenging, stylistics needs to conduct research at the intersection of cognitive sciences and corpus linguistics.
cognitive psychology and neuroscience provide insights into what to anticipate.
corpus linguistics identifies quantitative text features for analysis based on human sciences predictions.
several trial literary analyses were conducted to investigate if characteristics in the works of two english poets, geoffrey chaucer and shakespeare, could be explained using the standard cognitive model of language processing.
the studies involved using texts with standardized spelling, not phonetically transcribed due to the incomplete understanding of middle and early modern english pronunciation.
the software utilized, collgen, was only able to capture recurrent fixed phrases and node-collocate pairs, while groups of three or more collocates were not included.
despite these constraints, the published findings of the analyses generally supported the idea that the writing styles of both poets could potentially be linked to cognitive processes and partially deciphered.
various examples demonstrate the practical applications of cognitive stylistics.
in one study, chaucer's repeated phrases in the general prologue were compared with those in the other tales.
interestingly, despite different lengths, it was observed that the general prologue had more repeated phrases in common with an apparently unrelated tale, by the manciple, which always preceded the last tale by the parson.
this finding led to the speculation that chaucer may have written these works in the same year.
another example involved analyzing the 107 repeated phrases in agamemnon's speech in shakespeare's troilus and cressida, which shed light on the rationale behind an unusual sequence of images.
by examining passages from earlier poems and plays, researchers were able to uncover hidden associative connections that were previously unrecognized.
the introduction of the printing press extended the narrative length, rejuvenated the episodic structure characteristic of epic poetry to suit the expansive format of books, made traditional mnemonic aids redundant, and paved the way for the emergence of the novel.
this new literary form allowed for intricate plot developments, including framing, embedding, branching, digressions, disruptions of chronological order, and the incorporation of multiple storylines.
leveraging the spatial layout of the page, illustrations began to complement textual content, and visual elements were progressively acknowledged and utilized as a means of expression.
given these advancements across historical stages, one may ponder: what novel innovations remain for digital media to explore within the realm of storytelling?
the digital platform provides a more robust tool for constructing multivariant narratives compared to random combinations or unconditional forks, as the transition between text segments can be carefully dictated through programming.
in a hypertextual environment, clicking on buttons triggers the execution of specific machine-language commands, such as a "goto" command directing to a particular memory location and instructing to display corresponding data.
this "goto" command can be integrated within an "if .
else" statement to enable conditional branching.
for example, from the node "hero arrives at castle," the system could be programmed to present either the nodes "hero marries princess" or "king assigns hero a mission to rescue princess," contingent on whether the reader has previously explored "hero defeats villain." reconstructing a coherent narrative world from a jumbled discourse could easily become monotonous if the reader were merely seen as a metaphorical piece in a jigsaw puzzle.
any image can be fragmented, boxed, and marketed as a puzzle.
if hypertext were strictly compared to puzzles, it would imply that the reader's participation is detached from the narrative message of the text.
in literature, the most effective hypertexts are those that succeed in presenting the reader's navigation through the network and reconstruction of the narrative as a symbolic act imbued with a specific meaning tailored to the text, a significance not pre-determined by viewing the medium as a preconceived statement.
the presence of hypertext in a text does not inherently make it groundbreaking or meaningful; the responsibility lies on the author to employ it in shaping a distinct textual concept or metaphor that assigns purpose to the reader's engagement.
in "victory garden," this engagement is depicted as an exploration of space.
in interactive fiction, players take on the role of a character in the story world and direct their actions by typing commands in a simplified form of natural language on a traditional command-line interface.
a parser interprets the input and the system reacts with suitable, and occasionally humorously mismatched, actions.
typically structured as adventure games, most interactive fictions involve the player's character undertaking a specific task, with the full plot unfolding as the player solves various challenges to succeed in their mission.
while interactive fiction (if) permits users to input any text but restricts acceptable commands, first-person shooter (fps) games incorporate all user actions within the game mechanics, limited to activities like movement, collecting ammunition, weapon selection, and aiming and shooting.
each playthrough can be likened to crafting a new "life story" for the character, generating a fresh narrative with every session.
this narrative unfolds dynamically through player actions rather than being purely narrated.
due to the complexity of game mechanics and processing speed, the player experiences partially unpredictable reactions from the system, resulting in a vast array of potential life stories for the character in fps games.
these narratives persist as virtual experiences until mentally revisited by the player, who typically recounts them using a conventional "diegetic" storytelling approach.
unlike the fast-paced lives of fps players, the sims offers narratives that can be enjoyed both in the moment and looking back.
through the game's system, users can create and share stories by capturing screenshots and adding text.
these player-created stories, often presented in a cartoon-style format, are frequently shared on the game's website.
while the subjective appeal of these narratives may vary, the fact that players feel compelled to share them underscores the narrative depth that computer games can evoke in their virtual realms.
the chapter discusses two contrasting aspects of textual phenomena on the cultural spectrum.
on one end, computer games have immensely impacted popular culture, thriving as a billion-dollar industry comparable to hollywood and disneyland.
on the other end, hypertext remains a niche academic genre primarily explored by theorists and aspiring writers.
bridging the gap in digital textuality involves navigating between the conventional narrative structures of mainstream culture and the anti-narrative stance of experimental texts.
this uncharted territory recognizes narrative as a dynamic source of knowledge and aesthetic experiences, avoiding stagnation or exclusion.
in the early 1990s, theorists championed hypertext as the future of digital literature, prioritizing non-linearity and spatiality in aesthetics.
however, it is crucial to acknowledge that narrative inherently relies on temporal and linear storytelling mechanisms.
nonetheless, our venture into digital humanities was a deliberate one.
while engaging in digital humanities has caused some who held relativistic views to adopt a more pragmatic stance due to the demands of technology, it has also reignited our shared focus on the core of our scholarly pursuits.
with the practical application of digital humanities advancing within libraries and archives to enhance collection management and dissemination systems, the realm of theory is being prompted to facilitate novel introspective initiatives.
the utilization of digital tools not only serves to expand research in the humanities but also prompts contemplation on the methodologies and foundations that inform our knowledge-seeking practices and our comprehension of how interpretation is constructed.
digital humanities initiatives transcend mere technical applications by fostering occasions for critical self-awareness.
can we prove that humanities computing transcends being merely a technical advancement, by positioning it as a pivotal turning point akin to deconstruction, cultural studies, and feminist ideologies?
this requires demonstrating that digital methods not only repackage subjects of analysis in new forms but also alter the foundational philosophies guiding our work.
the task at hand is to devise tools that actively involve and empower such examinations, rather than just facilitating superficial discussions about them.
despite digital humanities' current appearance of automation, viewed from a practical standpoint, much of its activities appear automated.
differing from augmentation, as articulated by douglas engelbart, a key figure in graphical interface development, automation implies the rigid application of technical knowledge guided by fixed principles.
once initiated, an automated system functions based on its set design, and its efficacy hinges on this initial setup.
before immersing oneself in the dizzying realm of speculative and 'pataphysical pursuits, it is beneficial to initially explore some conventional aesthetics frameworks.
these frameworks serve as valuable starting points for comprehending the challenges involved in incorporating visual methods of knowledge representation within digital humanities contexts.
key themes within descriptive aesthetics that significantly influence digital images include truthfulness, the inherent qualities or capacities of a particular medium, the cognitive aspects of aesthetics, and the purported moral enrichment derived from aesthetic experiences.
discussions around beauty will be set aside for now, unless they intersect with considerations of practicality and the frequently made differentiation between applied and artistic practices.
the concept that exposure to high-quality art and culture leads to individual and cultural betterment has persisted, whether viewed as personal development or improvement through appreciation of the "best" in art forms.
figures like samuel taylor coleridge, matthew arnold, and walter pater advocated this belief in the 19th century.
today, the humanities and fine arts are still frequently defended based on their presumed influence on moral enhancement.
the integration of "digital" technology into the humanities is at times hindered by persistent ideas of progress and improvement.
