examining text on social media provides three clear benefits compared to traditional methods.
one benefit is based on economic theory, which relies on revealed preference to understand behavior.
actions taken by individuals better reflect their preferences than opinions provided in surveys or hypothetical scenarios.
similarly, social media discussions also reveal emotions and attitudes of individuals in a more direct way.
secondly, it can be conducted instantly instead of the delays associated with traditional survey methods.
significant effort has been dedicated to using traditional survey methods to make sure the sample mirrors the socio-economic diversity of the population.
however, this is currently not the situation with twitter.
despite their perceived complexity, survey methods may not always be successful in achieving their goals.
one common issue is the underestimation of support for right-wing parties in election polls, prompting survey companies to work on correcting this bias.
additionally, over time, social media platforms like twitter might become more reflective of the overall socio-economic diversity of the population.
evidence indicates that emotions and attitudes expressed on twitter may serve as an impartial reflection of the general population.
conventional socio-economic categorizations of samples may not be applicable in this context.

we distributed the document to 11 staff members from a consulting firm in london and requested them to indicate if the tweets were positive or negative by assigning a 1 or 0 to each tweet based solely on the text.
everyone in the group works in london and is well-versed in the city's social and cultural landscape.
with the exception of one individual, all members have backgrounds in economics or psychology.
the majority of the group are in their twenties and are therefore proficient in using online media platforms.
it is likely that this specific group would excel at evaluating the emotional tone of a tweet compared to a randomly selected sample from the uk population.

it would be more challenging to categorize a random sample of tweets from the entire population, rather than those with emojis.
we compiled the responses of 11 individuals for the 100 tweets.
tweets scoring 0, 1, or 2 were considered negative, while those scoring 9, 10, or 11 were considered positive.
we found 82 tweets falling into these clear categories, while the remaining 18 fell in the mid-range scores of 3 to 8, evenly distributed.
this indicates that in 18% of the tweets, there was disagreement among humans on the emotional tone being positive or negative.

in this part, we discuss the algorithms to be utilized for categorizing tweets into either positive or negative groups.
to train a model based on an ensemble of decision trees, multiple trees are generated during training by selecting random subsets of data points with replacement.
each tree is created by randomly choosing a small set of features to split on at each node and determining the best split based on these features in the training data.
the predictions from the individual trees are then averaged.
this approach aims to strike a balance between bias and variance by combining many trees trained on different subsets of data, each with high variance but low bias.
this ensemble method helps reduce overall variance without significantly increasing bias.
a way to determine the confidence of a specific classification is to calculate the percentage of trees that classify the observation as the most frequent class.
the machine learning community values out-of-sample performance, which is similar to what econometricians call predicting results outside of the data used for training.
in section 2, the algorithms were trained using 10,000 tweets randomly chosen from those with positive emojis and another 10,000 tweets randomly chosen from those with negative emojis.
the outcomes described below are all derived from the performance of the models when tested outside of the original sample.
there is a vast array of options to consider when deciding on a model for the validation step discussed in the previous paragraph.
these include selecting the algorithm, choosing the hyperparameters for the algorithm, deciding between glove and word2vec word vector representations, and determining the dimension of the word vectors.
at first, we compared the effectiveness of the glove and word2vec methods and explored the optimal size of the word vectors for future analysis.
we evaluate the performance of different machine learning models, such as random forest, linear support vector machine (svm), and radial basis function svm, in python using default hyperparameter values.
we utilize the appropriate functions from the scikit-learn python package, specifically linearsvc for training and evaluating linear svm, svc for svm with rbf kernel, and randomforestclassifier for random forests.
we provide the accuracy rate of correctly classified tweets by averaging the out-of-sample performance in 10 separate data folds and calculating the variance of this value across the folds.
the average accuracy calculates the percentage of accurately classified tweets by computing the results from each fold of the 10-fold process.
the standard deviation of accuracy measures the variation in accuracy across the 10 different folds.
next, we proceeded to analyze how varying the values of the hyperparameters of the algorithms would impact the word2vec dataset containing 200 dimensions.
the initial stage involved analyzing the outcomes utilizing random forests and linear svms.
the findings from this analysis are presented in tables 2a and 2b.
these findings indicate that the sampling method has minimal impact on the results, whereas increasing the number of trees and depth enhances the accuracy of classification.
the outcomes achieved using the linear svm method appear to be somewhat superior to those produced by the random forest.
in the left table, we have the support vector machine (svm), while the right table displays the random forest model.
the svm shows a slightly higher accuracy in terms of correct classifications.
additionally, error distribution is more evenly spread in the svm results, whereas the random forest tends to misclassify positive tweets as negative more frequently.
as a result, the svm model was selected for the validation phase.

internet finance is a modern financial concept that has experienced rapid growth compared to other financial innovations in recent times.
unlike traditional finance, internet finance is not just a combination of traditional financial institutions and the internet, but is predominantly led by internet companies.
this type of financial innovation focuses on technology firms utilizing information technology to enhance the effectiveness and structure of financial services like financing, investment, and payment systems.
the entire internet industry uses this distinctive approach to bolster its position through ongoing funding and acquiring companies.
this model emphasizes that value is generated not just by creators, but also by customers and others in their value creation network.
by strategically investing and acquiring diverse businesses, a company in the internet sector can gain customers, expand its reach, and enhance its services, reinforcing its presence in the digital economy.
from this point of view, competitive advantages can be gained through various means, including resource availability and user engagement.
this idea has resulted in a high number of acquisitions and investments within the internet sector.
currently, there is limited literature available on the model, risks, or features of internet finance in significant economic systems.
this article aims to explore fluctuations in risks by analyzing disruptions in corporate value.
we recognize that certain internet companies possess strong risk management abilities, allowing them to effectively manage and navigate through risks as they establish their presence in the digital economy.
however, when attempting to assess risk using a risk mass perspective, there is a likelihood of distortion.
to address these issues, we have established several new comparative tests.
these include comparing internet financial companies with other internet firms, comparing internet technology companies with diverse operations, and evaluating overall market performance and corporate stock values.
we consider the local connection of risks, understand the transition from scale modification to extracting characteristics, and identify features with overlapping risk cycles.
it has been discovered that the quantity of risk does not always provide an accurate measure of risk for internet technology firms.
while a high risk volume may indicate a crisis within the company, some firms with elevated risk indicators continue to lead in terms of longevity, market value, and user base within the internet technology sector.
this showcases the interplay between ecological value and risk.
our findings indicate that companies with high-risk values may not experience the most significant fluctuations in risk.
while risk value merely communicates the extent of risk, fluctuations in risk can indicate shifts in investor sentiment over a specific timeframe, particularly useful for internet companies.
this data offers internet technology firms insights into their risk standing within the sector, while regulators can use it to monitor industry-wide risk trends promptly to address potential issues effectively.
based on our analysis of the correlation test, we observed that market factors significantly impact the correlation of risks.
we noted that companies operating in the us market exhibit a level of risk fluctuation similarity, while those in the chinese market demonstrate different types of similarities.
overall, the findings underline the challenge of separating the interrelated risk volatility within the internet industry, which displays periodic overlaps.
in practical market scenarios, there are instances where a single company specializes in a specific sector, while others engage in multiple sectors.
internet companies are expanding into financial services, and traditional financial institutions are utilizing online technology to stay competitive.
while official financial entities operate with licenses, there are also unregulated "shadow banks" in the market.
internet financial institutions employ a marketing tactic called two-way subsidies to encourage offline merchants to adopt mobile payment features.
additionally, online financial institutions have introduced the feature of making payments in multiple currencies across countries and have launched mobile payment services in both domestic and international consumer markets.
furthermore, the integration of online financial institutions and individual credit assessment is crucial in establishing a credit consumption mechanism.
by leveraging artificial intelligence and extensive data analysis, the aim is to enhance the online payment infrastructure through the credit system.
this will offer a technical foundation for microfinance and credit transactions.
p2p lending is an online financial platform established by internet companies that offers services for matching users who need financing or investment opportunities.
another trend is the integration of traditional microfinance with the internet, a move led by traditional financial institutions.
this enables them to reach a wider customer base with the help of online technology, resulting in increased operational efficiency.
the business model of internet lending incorporates innovation through point-to-point matchmaking, where investors transfer funds to the platform for lending to borrowers.
however, this model also introduces capital risks.
these risks are primarily associated with user funds being held by the online platform, the importance of the platform's credibility, the impact on the platform if borrowers default, and the potential effects of stock market volatility leading to withdrawal by users.
weak capital reserves and risk management by the platform can further exacerbate the negative outcomes, potentially causing a run due to negative news.
small businesses, individuals, and other groups not typically served by traditional financial institutions are the primary users of internet lending services.
companies providing these services focus on building their user base by offering subsidies and have minimal entry barriers for customers.
as a result, the quality of customers in internet lending carries certain risk characteristics.
in the realm of online lending, companies that are purely internet-based operate without licenses, a practice known as regulatory arbitrage.
some of these businesses lack proper risk management practices and do not meet technical standards.
as regulations become stricter over time, these companies face challenges in the market.
this has led to the closure of some platforms, disruptions in their funding sources, and harm to the customers' interests.
websites such as angellist, fundable, crowdfunder, and equitynet can also enhance information dissemination, discussions, and capital generation.
internet funds allow investment clients to directly communicate with third-party financial institutions through the internet, eliminating the need for banks as intermediaries.
this approach, known as "financial disintermediation," enhances traditional financial services by reducing the involvement of banks in connecting clients with financial management institutions.
this online financial management model enhances efficiency, lowers costs, and diminishes the intermediary role traditionally played by banks.
compared to traditional trust business, internet trust offers several advantages.
this includes utilizing internet technology to promptly share information on trust products, enhancing transparency and suiting user preferences.
it also involves improving services through the internet platform based on customer needs.
additionally, internet trust leverages technology to provide comprehensive services for customers, like net value management and coupon reminders.
this involves offering financial services digitally at every stage of a transaction using internet technology and platforms, which can include payment, financing, and settlement services among others.
the consumer finance model on the internet is categorized into two types: a vertical installment purchase platform and an e-commerce consumer finance platform.
consumers can seek instalment credit from instalment purchase platforms when making purchases.
once approved, merchants can quickly provide the requested products or services.
this approach targets areas with limited traditional consumer finance use, offering installment or consumer loan options, but it faces challenges due to stringent risk management requirements.
in the absence of leveraging e-commerce data, these platforms often resort to online credit checks resulting in higher default rates.
business risks encompass various elements such as capital flow, market cycle, interest rates, user preferences, and investor relations.
these risks are interconnected and can result in contagion between the different risk segments.
for instance, internet financial companies may face challenges in obtaining adequate funding at reasonable rates to support asset growth or meet debt obligations, leading to the risk of a capital chain breakdown.
this risk can be influenced by investor relations, as well as factors like interest rates and market cycles.
furthermore, business risks can have an external impact by interacting with other risk categories, particularly credit and operational risks.
for instance, the performance of internet finance platforms can impact the stability of their capital flows, as these platforms heavily rely on attracting users through financing and subsidies.
thus, maintaining a healthy capital flow is crucial for platform sustainability.
the payment and settlement services in internet finance are considered fundamental banking services and play a crucial role in generating significant non-interest revenue for banks.
the emergence of new payment channels in internet finance has had an impact on the traditional financial industry's intermediary operations.
there is a risk transmission mechanism that links internet finance and traditional finance.
the influence of internet lending, fund, and payment businesses on traditional banks has led to a situation where the assets, liabilities, and intermediary operations of commercial banks are being squeezed.
this has resulted in increased operational costs, reduced profitability, loss of deposits, and higher leverage ratios.
the services offered by internet finance have altered the dynamics of money supply, demand, and interest rates, impacting the macroeconomic intermediary variables.
as a consequence, bank credit has expanded, the demand for money has decreased, macroeconomic controls have weakened, and ultimately, banking crises have ensued.
as internet technology continues to eliminate industry boundaries, reduce entry barriers, and increase competition, internet companies are increasingly opting to secure technology or businesses through investments and acquisitions.
this shift has spawned a conducive environment for investment and mergers within the internet industry.
we think that investing in and acquiring companies in the internet industry can improve an individual's competitiveness in the field, but it also raises the uncertainty and risk level for the industry as a whole.
when one company faces risks, the entire industry can be impacted, leading to an increase in overall risk volatility across businesses in the industry.
in analyzing alibaba's financial report, it is evident that expenses related to research, development, and sales have been consistently rising, while interest and investment income as well as operational income have decreased.
this suggests that the company may not be seeing fruitful returns on its investments.
nevertheless, there is a faster growth in revenue, indicating a relatively positive outlook on the overall revenue and expenditure balance.
the notion of a business model in the internet sector may disrupt the traditional ideas of how value is created and acquired.
unlike conventional models, internet-based models emphasize that value can be generated not just by producers, but also by customers and other stakeholders in the value-creation process.
this perspective suggests that competitive advantage can be achieved through various means, such as having access to resources and engaging users actively.
hence, alibaba's active investments and acquisitions across various sectors are seen as enhancing its position as a leader in the digital economy in china.
the company's focus is not solely on generating profits but rather on considering whether the industry aligns with its core business or offers vital resources such as technology, services, or products to support its growth.
these ventures are aimed at driving user engagement and fostering growth within the ecosystem to create ongoing value.
nevertheless, the strategic investments and acquisitions made by alibaba continue to negatively affect its financial performance.
for instance, acquiring companies with lower profit margins or losses, like gaining control of businesses such as lazada and cainiao network, may not yield profitability in the future.
furthermore, investing in the expansion of its operations, infrastructure, and staff may expose alibaba to additional unforeseen costs, such as labor disputes, compliance expenses, and other risks.
when assessing risks, it is crucial to take into account the potential ecological significance associated with those risks.
hence, understanding how to effectively evaluate the balance between the value and risk of internet companies is a critical area of research.
the risks, whether they have happened or are anticipated, will be communicated to the market through different channels, like negative news, leading investors to adjust their expectations for the company.
consequently, these risks will manifest in fluctuations in stock prices.
we gathered stock price information for technology firms to create a model assessing risk.
fourteen chinese and american technology companies were chosen based on their primary operations and market significance.
these include alibaba, jd, facebook, paypal, ebay, google, apple, twitter, amazon, bidu, tencent, yrd, ppdf, and dnjr.
several internet finance companies that have significant market share and influence have chosen not to go public.

as a result, most of them opt for the adr method to list in the united states.
the opening section highlighted that internet finance combines internet technology and financial technology.
an essential aspect is to thoroughly assess risks by considering the enterprise's value and the internet ecosystem supporting it.
this is crucial because the internet industry's value is not solely generated by producers, but also by customers and other participants in their value creation network.
therefore, when examining risk formation, it is vital to account for the potential ecological value associated with the risk.
hence, previous risk studies have not sufficiently illustrated the risks within the internet industry, particularly in the realm of internet finance.
it is acknowledged that certain internet firms possess strong risk management skills, enabling them to navigate risk fluctuations effectively and establish stronger footing in the digital economy.
using a risk quantity-focused approach can often lead to distortions when measuring risks.
to mitigate this, the study emphasizes investigating risk fluctuations over time to analyze risk concerns without the influence of risk volume.
we think that levels of risk vary for internet companies, leading to different strategic approaches and expectations for future value.
even if the companies or business models acquired at present are not profitable and entail risks, they can contribute to building a future ecosystem and infrastructure.
therefore, it is necessary to assess risk fluctuations across different enterprises from a comparable standpoint by eliminating the impact of risk levels.
the bmm model utilizes various statistical techniques to analyze the highest or lowest values in a set of independent and identically distributed observational data.
as a result, it requires a significant amount of data for simulation.
in internet finance, constraints such as limited numbers of listed companies and constrained market entry times can hinder the acquisition of a substantial dataset due to abbreviated development timelines.
these research findings offer valuable insights for our own study and demonstrate the versatility of using the generalized pareto distribution in time series risk assessment across different sectors.
building upon this, the paper employs the generalized pareto distribution model to assess risks associated with businesses.
the threshold plays a crucial role in the pot model.
by predefining a threshold, all data points that surpass this threshold are grouped together and analyzed using the generalized pareto distribution to determine the risk value.
in this section, we examine four prominent internet technology firms - facebook, paypal, alibaba, and jd - to present a set of comparative data that illustrates our analysis approach.

following this, we utilized the accumulation area chart to illustrate the distribution of risks across each company and the overall risk trends within the dataset.

by examining the ordinate data on the chart, we can make comparisons of risk levels among the four companies at various points in time.
furthermore, the cyclical correlation among these enterprises will be elaborated on in subsequent discussions.
if individual companies do not exhibit significant risk growth, each company still experiences some level of risk increase.
in such cases, the graph on the right will indicate a large risk area, suggesting that overall enterprise risk in the industry is collectively rising, leading to an increase in industry-wide risk.
following a risk event in one company, the extent of risk contagion and its success rate within the industry are reflected in the risk metrics of other firms.
a single company facing risk can effectively spread that risk to other firms, causing overall industry risk to escalate during a specific period.
if effective risk control mechanisms prevent the spread of risk contagion in the industry, only the individual company faces increased risk, while the industry's total risk tends to remain stable.
one benefit of this approach is that it integrates both macro- and microanalysis, while also taking into account the impact of risk on the infection process.
furthermore, by selecting different threshold values, measurements can be conducted using different time units such as day, week, or month, allowing for flexibility in transforming observation index details as needed.

this research examines the accuracy of rent estimates available for different cities by analyzing craigslist listings.
the study finds that existing data sources often underestimate the true cost of renting a property, impacting individuals looking to relocate between cities or those using vouchers.
the paper discusses various rental data sources, summarizes past research on rising rental costs, details the methods used to compare data across 25 metropolitan areas, and proposes ways to improve the availability of spot market data for planners.
many official and private data sources on rental prices provide information on the terms of existing leases, helping decision-makers analyze affordability, set fair market rents, and understand how much current tenants are paying relative to their income and other factors.
however, this data may not capture the dynamic nature of the rental market where landlords and prospective tenants negotiate new rent amounts.
asking rents might significantly differ from reported transacted rents due to delays in data publication, market fluctuations, government subsidies, and rent regulations.
data on transacted rents mostly overlook the real-time changes in rental rates, especially in areas with rapidly increasing rents or a high number of rent-controlled properties.
these are the areas of primary interest to housing experts, professionals, and advocates for fair and inclusive housing practices.
the authors express their gratitude to paul waddell for kindly permitting the use of data that was originally gathered in his laboratory at uc berkeley.
blockchain technology is a connected chain of blocks storing transaction data and user information, operating through a decentralized digital ledger system.
it facilitates secure and confidential financial transactions among network users, with validation and approval by all participants in a transparent manner.
its popularity has grown due to the use of digital currencies, presenting a promising future for online transactions, despite facing security challenges and vulnerabilities.
this paper explores blockchain methodology, applications, and security concerns, providing insights for enthusiasts and researchers in this field.
blockchain is the underlying technology of the digital currency bitcoin and has become highly significant in the digital realm due to its key characteristics like decentralization, immutability, anonymity, and suitability for electronic transactions.
there are four main types of blockchains that are worth noting.
the sender has enough bitcoin in their account for transfer, and the specific amount they want to transfer has not been sent to anyone else.
for instance, when someone is attempting to transfer digital currency like bitcoin to you, the private key stored in your wallet must correspond with the important public address assigned to your wallet.
only if these two keys align will the digital currency be successfully sent to the public address of your wallet during the transaction processing.
primary information: information related to transactions will be stored in blocks.
the type of transaction data stored will be determined by the specific services for which the blockchain is being utilized.
for financial institutions such as banks, the stored data will primarily consist of financial transaction information.
the timestamp will be found in the blocks as well.
in this context, the timestamp indicates the specific date and time when a block is created.
modifying the input even slightly causes the hash output to differ significantly.
the variations seem to happen arbitrarily without any predictable pattern.
despite this randomness, no one has been able to decipher how the alterations in the input affect the hash output.
the hash algorithm is designed to be irreversible, making it challenging to crack.
proof of work involves validating the hash value of a block against a set range.
if the hash value falls within the range, the block is accepted; otherwise, it is rejected.
miners participate in a competitive process to find the correct hash value for a block within the specified range in the pow system.
miners receive the information and attempt to solve a mathematical problem known as hashing.
currently, the attacker can work out the math problem independently and generate a new block without sharing it with the rest of the network.
the unauthorized blockchain grows by the attacker adding more blocks, which are then shared with the network.

similar to the broad scope of feminism, feminist media theory and research also vary and encompass a wide range of perspectives.
with the increasing influence of media in our lives and the acknowledgment that gender is influenced by media, feminist scholars have focused on analyzing media content since the 1970s.
although feminist analysis of media is extensive and multifaceted, initially, the main emphasis was on examining how gender is portrayed and the underlying ideologies in media content.
scholars have highlighted the significance of representation in media, asserting that various media forms, whether factual or fictional, shape perceptions and convey messages about diverse groups to the audience.
advocating for social change does not weaken feminist scholarship; on the contrary, it is highlighted as a key strength in the chapters of this book's third section.
this area has seen significant progress in recent years and presents new challenges to be addressed.
feminist theory is a comprehensive theoretical framework that links empirical data and observations with critical analysis of gender-related issues and identities.
it seeks to elucidate the dynamics of gender inequality, power structures, and patriarchal systems, examining how gender and power impact various aspects of society.
while older feminist perspectives were criticized for being limited in scope and focusing predominantly on white experiences, modern feminist theory now addresses broader forms of subordination and dominance that extend beyond gender, taking into account intersectional identities.
feminist scholars have criticized the mass media for symbolically erasing women.
these scholars have published numerous articles in mainstream communication journals, as well as authored and edited countless books on this topic.
my work has evolved to be more reliant on data, as i have taken on larger and more complex projects that involve managing information through spreadsheets and data analysis.

instead, we chose to examine state policies and cultural values within the context of the society itself.
our success was measured by the detailed analysis we conducted on qatar's policies and cultural practices.

this stands in contrast to societies where gender equality in media is expected and shapes material reality.

war rugs are popular among military personnel and carpet collectors, who are among the primary purchasers of these items.
in war literature in the united states, the house is often portrayed as a place of military defense, contrasting with oriental carpets symbolizing peaceful gardens untouched by war.
the concept of the home has shifted with the introduction of war carpets, blurring the line between defense and offense.
this dynamic forces consumers to withdraw and isolate themselves.
as labor remains confined in war zones or refugee camps, war carpets become mobile, offering a sense of being at home while also being detached from the war, within the everyday realms of empire.
war, as well as the unrestricted movement of goods, allows for the implementation of neoliberal strategies such as restricting access to credit, disregarding infrastructure development, ignoring technical education, feminizing the workforce, and relocating goods to conflict zones and refugee camps.
additionally, neoliberal governance promotes a type of consumerism that masks the harsh realities of war and militarism in regions where goods can be manufactured at lower costs, often at the expense of smaller producers.
war carpets transform the sorrowful experience of war into a pleasurable act of consumption.
the process of beautifying and idolizing war carpets signifies the remembrance of war intertwined with feminized labor, its denial, and its continuation in daily life within various locations like war zones, refugee camps, and remote settlements.
the beauty associated with acquiring, displaying, trading, and owning these carpets is, in my opinion, rather lacking in sensitivity, as it overlooks the harsh reality and emotional impact of war by making it seem more domesticated and guilt-inducing.
in fact, since the 1980s, war carpets have evolved into a subtle means of culturally suppressing the memories of war.

the file monitoring agent is a specialized tool connected to an ia module, operating similarly to a process monitoring agent and operating on all host machines to gather various statistics related to files.
in order to focus monitoring efforts, a list of critical files is maintained to detect suspicious activity.
criteria for flagging files as suspicious include new files generated or modified by new processes, large files obtained from the internet, or files copied from external storage devices.
details sent to the ccs module consist of which process modified the file, its size, creation method, and other file attributes.
developed in python utilizing the watchdog observer library, the file monitor agent allows real-time monitoring of all file actions in specified directories.
like the process monitoring agent, it translates file operation data into rdf format and transmits the information to the ccs module.

one important difference between regulatory markets and self-regulation is that in regulatory markets, the government is responsible for determining the desired outcomes of regulation, rather than leaving it to the regulated entities.
in this system, governments create and manage the regulatory market structure and supervise the entities operating within it.
our proposal for regulatory markets aims to establish a system of supervision and transparency for private regulation.
we suggest utilizing market mechanisms to create efficient and advanced forms of regulation without solely relying on self-regulation.
instead, we advocate for the introduction of an additional market layer comprising independent private regulators who are accountable to government oversight and adaptable to the rapid advancements and complexities of ai technologies on a global scale.
policy labs in the government involve civil servants learning and using human-centered design and data analytics to create new ways to regulate and deliver public services.
certification bodies may be seen as competitors to some extent, as they vie to be embraced voluntarily by a significant portion of a specific industry to establish themselves as the global standard.
however, this competition is more about achieving widespread acceptance rather than a traditional market competition.
once a dominant standard is established, there is a risk of stagnation without ongoing competitive pressure, which is crucial for fostering continued innovation.
enhancing the capacity to develop creative regulatory strategies may involve shifting regulatory responsibilities from the public sector to markets.
by establishing regulatory markets that encourage investments in regulatory innovation, such as human and financial resources, we suggest a framework that draws on non-governmental regulators and redefined roles for private entities in regulatory governance.
private regulators have the flexibility to use more than just traditional regulatory methods.
they could create technologies that influence the decisions made by the businesses they regulate.
their authority to enforce regulations comes from a contract with the target company and approval from governments to issue fines or impose regulations on companies that are subject to their oversight.
private regulators have created various regulatory methods which could encompass tools for assessing risk, software for processing information, procedures for managing conflicts or complaints, and more.
in relation to autonomous vehicles, governments could define limits for accident rates and levels of traffic congestion.
they could also create guidelines focusing on upholding public trust in road safety.
in the banking sector, governments have the authority to determine criteria for customers to access credit.

in terms of the application of facial recognition technology in drones, governments may set limits on the probability of unauthorized users accessing the software.

regulatory mechanisms are necessary to uphold the safety and benefits of ai systems.

one advantage of the regulatory markets model is that it supports the growth of a strong and autonomous regulatory sector.
this can provide a counterbalance to the increasing influence of major tech corporations involved in ai advancement.
it offers a compromise between government-imposed regulations and self-regulation by tech companies, which is typically seen as inadequate.
private regulators have the potential to regulate data more efficiently compared to government regulators due to certain constraints that government regulation faces.
governments sharing data may lead to concerns regarding data misuse, whereas commercial entities can establish more secure data-sharing processes through contracts and intellectual property rights.
as a result, private regulators can directly monitor data in companies and explore innovative technological collaboration between regulators and businesses.
in regulatory markets, there are concerns about the need to maintain competitiveness and independence among private regulators who oversee the entities they regulate.

the model simplifies by not accounting for the timing of household investment behavior.

the common clinical situation that illustrates acute myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury is when a patient presents with an acute st-segment elevation myocardial infarction, and is treated with either thrombolytic therapy or percutaneous coronary intervention.
a treatment that safeguards the heart from acute ischemia-reperfusion injury (iri) could potentially offer broader protection to other essential organs like the brain, kidney, and liver.
however, there is a lack of clinical studies exploring new heart-protective approaches in the context of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (cpr).
it is crucial to consider the results of prior preclinical and clinical studies when designing the clinical cardioprotection study.
there is currently no effective treatment to protect heart muscle cells from damage caused by restricted blood flow or reperfusion injury in patients experiencing acute myocardial infarction (mi).
numerous therapies have been investigated over the past few decades as additional treatments alongside reperfusion therapy, but most have yielded disappointing results in terms of reducing injury and improving outcomes in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention for st-segment elevation mi.
table 1 summarizes several significant clinical studies that failed to show any benefit for reperfused mi patients and highlights various reasons for these failures, such as not considering factors that could affect cardioprotection.
frequently, these studies are dismissed as negative, which means the chance to find new treatments for patients with acute myocardial infarction is overlooked.
in clinical trials focused on protecting the heart, it is crucial to evaluate the key factors that influence the size of heart attacks in patients with st-elevated myocardial infarction undergoing treatments to restore blood flow to the heart.
the diversity of patients receiving cardiopulmonary bypass surgery and the many variables that could affect cardioprotection complicate the selection process for clinical studies in cabg patients.
it is crucial to consider the specific type of surgery, as patients undergoing cabg differ from those undergoing valve surgery.
factors such as hypertrophy in patients with aortic conditions may influence the effectiveness of cardioprotective interventions.
the possibility of direct myocardial injury during cabg surgery affecting results also needs to be acknowledged.
therefore, focusing on patients undergoing either cabg or valve surgery alone may be more advisable for cardioprotection studies.

the constitution of south africa mandates that local areas are responsible for promoting community and economic development.

to understand crm, it is essential to first understand its origins.
crm stands for customer relationship management, which encompasses any technology, method, strategy, or process that helps businesses organize and access customer information effectively.
starting from handwritten notes and rolodexes, the concept has evolved rapidly with the rise of digital technology.
with databases stored on computers, crm has transformed into a more complex system.
it now involves managing various client interactions, making it essential in today's competitive market to have a robust crm software system in place.
a customer relationship management (crm) system acts as a unifying platform for various departments like marketing, sales, and customer support by consolidating their information, activities, and metrics into a single framework.
this allows easy access to real-time customer data for all users, promoting collaboration and enabling personalized customer experiences.
compared to older systems, crm systems have the potential to revolutionize customer communication.

with the evolution of cloud-based crm programming, businesses of any size can now easily expand and scale their crm systems to suit their needs.

many experts suggest that zippers may be one of the initial mechanical devices individuals become adept at handling during childhood, a skill that continues to be utilized throughout their lifetime.
while some may not consider a zipper to be a machine, it does meet the necessary criteria as it involves interconnected metal or plastic components that work together to move and require force for proper operation.
additionally, zippers have a fascinating history.
multiple attempts were made to introduce zippers as a common feature in adult clothing, which finally succeeded in 1937 with the inclusion of zippers in men's attire.
this breakthrough came about when the duke of windsor expressed his desire for trousers with zippers, leading to widespread acceptance by tailors worldwide.
the zipper rapidly became a well-known and favored fastening device, quickly expanding its use to various items such as hunting jackets, trousers, and overshoes.
the public embraced zippers for their discreet, reliable, and convenient functionality, leading to a significant rise in their popularity, with over 20 percent of men's clothing incorporating zippers by 1938.
eventually, only a minority resisted the trend of wearing clothing with zippers.
in 1939, the annual production of zippers had reached over 300 million, which was twice the amount from the preceding two years.
by 1950, the yearly sales of zippers exceeded one billion dollars.
initially, zippers were crafted by the first manufacturers from durable metals like brass, aluminum, and nickel, making them ideal for heavy fabrics.
however, as their popularity grew, the production shifted towards plastic zippers which were more flexible, gentle, and simple to care for.
today, zippers are available in a wide range of materials including colored metallic options, coils, and others.

diamond is a crystalline form of carbon with a diamond cubic structure, while another form, graphite, is more stable at standard temperature and pressure.
despite being metastable, diamond is known for its exceptional hardness and thermal conductivity, making it useful in various industrial applications like cutting tools.
due to these properties, diamond anvil cells can replicate high pressures similar to those found deep within the earth.
diamond's exceptional hardness in specific directions is valuable for materials science applications, such as the use of a pyramidal diamond in the surface of a vickers hardness tester.
diamonds remain unchanged when exposed to various chemicals such as strong acids and bases at room temperature.

what to steer clear of: relying solely on a proofreader.
while proofreading is valuable, addressing higher-level concerns during the editing process is crucial.
issues like character development, plot coherence, and other macroscopic elements should take priority.
shifting a comma on one page won't resolve fundamental problems such as inconsistent characters or unresolved plotlines.
therefore, it's advisable to save proofreading for later stages of the process.
if you have a proofreader available, consider involving them in the later rounds of manuscript review.

utilizing various research and development methods related to the efl score threshold, our initial focus is on assessing the impact of the efl tool on enhancing credit accessibility.
if the absence of credit data does not hinder small and medium enterprises (smes) seeking loans, those with efl scores below the threshold might secure funding from alternative sources, potentially resulting in no substantial variation in loan utilization near the efl score threshold.
additionally, in a subsequent analysis, we investigate whether smes granted loans through the efl tool demonstrate poorer repayment patterns compared to those receiving loans through traditional screening methods.
because loan applicants without credit history may find technologies like the efl tool more useful, we divide our loan applicants into two categories: those with little credit history and those with substantial credit history.
the equifax scores for applicants with substantial credit history are influenced by their past credit behavior, while scores for those with little credit history are determined by alternative sources given their lack of credit history.
to assess repayment behavior, the study examined the percentage of individuals with loan arrears exceeding 60 days in the two-year period after applying for the loan.
there was no significant difference in arrears rates between thin file applicants evaluated through the efl tool versus those assessed through traditional methods.
however, for applicants with thicker credit histories, the likelihood of facing arrears was higher when screened with the efl tool.
in general, it seems that using psychometric credit scoring is an effective means of evaluating loan applicants who lack a credit history.
these individuals have an increased likelihood of receiving loans compared to the traditional screening process, and their repayment behavior does not appear to be worse.
additionally, the study emphasizes the importance of credit bureau data, as it suggests that applicants with poor credit histories are more likely to face repayment difficulties in the future, regardless of their psychometric score.
the upcoming overview course of financial sector issues by the world bank will cover the application of psychometric tools in sme finance and related subjects.
visit the link for course details and registration information.

one side is characterized by urban areas that are lively, connected with the european union, and economically prosperous.
for instance, bucharest stands out as a vibrant city with flourishing modern amenities and a higher income per person compared to the eu average.
on the flip side, the rural parts of romania tend to be less developed, impoverished, and socially disconnected.
in order to continue progressing and reach similar standards of living as those in the eu, romania will need to undertake certain adjustments.
the workforce's skills have not evolved at the same rate as the economy, which is becoming more sophisticated.
romania's export focus has shifted from labor-intensive, low-technology industries to advanced sectors like automotive, machinery, electronic equipment, and information and communication technology (ict).
romania's infrastructure is in poor condition, with the country ranking 102nd out of 137 countries in terms of transport infrastructure quality.
due to inadequate planning and ineffective public administration, romania has been unable to effectively utilize the structural funds it has received from the eu since joining.
20% of the population do not have access to clean drinking water, while 33% lack access to a flushing toilet.
the situations are even more dire for the roma community, where only 28% are employed and 70% live in poverty.
the mix of extensive maternity benefits and scarcity of part-time work opportunities has unintentionally discouraged women from joining the workforce.
gender stereotypes persist in assigning majority of child and elderly care responsibilities to women, whether they are employed or not.
a large number of workers are stuck in unproductive agriculture and informal work, resulting in inefficient use and distribution of labor.
consequently, the shift to higher-productivity jobs has been slow.
considering the many conflicting aspects, can romania still take pride in its past accomplishments?
looking back, the answer is definitely affirmative.
in just a short period, romania has established an inclusive society, strengthened its democracy, and achieved unprecedented prosperity.
in the future, romanians should be worried if the country does not fix its governance issues.
this could lead to unstable economic growth and reduced prosperity for all.
a successful and fair romania should ensure that no one is left out.

in the united states, there is a continuous decline in the number of black teachers.
in california, over 78,000 black students attend schools where there are no black teachers.
what is causing black educators to exit the profession?
based on the results of the study and the comments from the survey, the following are five suggestions for school administrators and policymakers trying to encourage black educators to stay.
a culturally affirming school administrator would acknowledge the presence of racism and anti-blackness within their school environment, affecting both students and faculty.
they may analyze student performance data to offer targeted assistance to specific groups based on academic requirements, and work towards ensuring equitable treatment of staff regardless of race or gender.
participants recommended promoting inclusivity by deliberately incorporating elements of black culture into different aspects of the school environment.
for instance, instead of limiting the teaching of historical black figures to black history month, actively incorporate black history lessons throughout the entire academic year.
one illustration of affinity spaces for black students is the black student union framework.
educational institutions that have black student unions facilitate relationships among black students and provide them with chances to investigate colleges and careers that resonate with their identities.
some participants underscored the importance of providing educational opportunities, such as training on implicit bias, anti-black racism, and professional development, for all employees.
they stressed the significance of improving the expertise and capabilities of educators to promote inclusivity in the environment.
simultaneously, along with providing professional development opportunities, it is essential to ensure accountability at the school level.
if teachers are mandated to undergo training in culturally responsive teaching methods, how can we determine its impact on the overall classroom and school environment?
one way to enhance accountability could involve incorporating additional questions in staff satisfaction surveys to evaluate the presence of cultural responsiveness and inclusivity at the school site.
another accountability measure could entail developing a rubric to assess how professional development values are implemented and reflected in the overall school environment and culture.
teachers emphasized the significance of listening to and backing black educators, creating opportunities for them to take on leadership roles, and acknowledging their valuable input.
a number of black educators stated they were not being utilized as leaders within their schools or were frequently passed over for roles such as instructional coaching or leading their department.
this overlooking of black educators is seen as a display of bias and it is recommended that schools and districts actively work towards empowering black educators to take on leadership responsibilities.
for instance, schools can establish mentorship or training programs for black teachers to explore and take on responsibilities beyond their classroom duties.
this approach provides teachers with a platform to understand various positions within their school or school district.
individuals who reported being the sole black educators in their school expressed feeling pressured to represent the entire black community.
this leads to a negative school atmosphere where microaggressions are prevalent among both students and staff.
to address this issue, school districts can actively seek to hire black educators by collaborating with teaching programs that have diverse participants or providing support for black educators as they start their careers.

arndt and jonsson displayed moral courage by rescuing miller and preventing her attacker from causing further harm.
moral courage is required in situations where we witness our values being compromised, societal expectations being disregarded, or laws being violated.
by taking action to prevent these injustices, even in the face of potential negative consequences, we demonstrate moral courage.
in different contexts, individuals demonstrate moral courage by facing bullies, challenging discriminatory actions, or exposing cheating.
this bravery can also be shown in the workplace through actions like exposing corporate fraud.
despite potential consequences like physical harm or social rejection, those who bravely defend their ethics can serve as protectors, drivers of social progress, and sources of inspiration for others, ultimately making a significant positive impact.
given this situation, the aspiration is for a society where a large number of individuals exhibit moral courage.
unfortunately, the occurrence of moral courage is quite scarce.
instances of violent altercations, sexual misconduct, or racist incidents often go unaddressed, with bystanders choosing not to intervene.
many of us may have witnessed or experienced such situations and opted to stay on the sidelines.
witnesses must observe an event and then perceive it as an act of misconduct.
afterwards, witnesses must take on accountability and have confidence in their ability to intervene effectively.
in the end, observers must determine whether to take action despite possible dangers.
in a recent research project, researchers studied moral courage using an experience-sampling method.
participants were asked to report instances of wrongdoing they witnessed in their daily lives over a week through their mobile phones.
upon reporting a wrongdoing, participants answered questions related to various aspects of the moral courage model.
the results supported the model, indicating that moral courage was more prevalent when participants felt accountable and competent, but decreased when they viewed the situation as being potentially risky.
in summary, it is important to recognize that moral courage is a multifaceted process that is influenced, in part, by both our individual characteristics and the circumstances we find ourselves in.
when faced with a situation that demands moral courage, it can be difficult to recognize the positive impacts it can have for the broader community, as certain acts of moral courage may not always feel comfortable.
think about the concept of moral courage in relation to bullying situations.
it can be challenging to speak up against classmates or inform a teacher about the issue, especially when we feel a strong bond of loyalty with them.
this loyalty to our peers may clash with our desire to advocate for what is right, hindering us from taking action.
in combination, demonstrating moral courage is frequently difficult.
however, understanding these challenges should not dishearten us.
instead, we can utilize this understanding to create specific strategies for fostering moral courage.
each individual has the opportunity to cultivate greater moral courage, but it doesn't have to be a task undertaken alone.
various institutions like educational institutions, workplaces, and online platforms also have a vital part to play in this endeavor.
what specific suggestions can be offered to promote moral courage in these settings?
develop and reinforce social and ethical standards: by having a clear grasp of our ethical principles, it is simpler to identify unethical behaviors.
organizations can aid in this effort by recognizing and exemplifying core values.
for instance, the moral standards and principles exemplified by educators can serve as significant guiding principles for children and adolescents.
in situations where wrongdoing occurs, it is important not to suppress anger as it can drive action and intervention.
it is also crucial to understand that when individuals express anger, it should not be dismissed as unreasonable but viewed as a reaction to injustice.
offer and promote reporting mechanisms: institutions can offer reporting systems to help witnesses report incidents more easily and without the need for direct confrontation, lessening the burden on individuals to choose the best intervention method.
displaying social support: if individuals confront a perpetrator, it is important for others to be encouraged to assist them in order to minimize potential dangers.
practicing self-compassion involves treating oneself with the same kindness one would show a friend during difficult times.
by soothing ourselves when facing challenges and encouraging ourselves with kindness, we can reduce anxiety and depression.
adolescents who cultivate self-compassion tend to experience lower levels of anxiety and depression.
this practice also helps children effectively deal with obstacles, leading to increased well-being and self-esteem.
how can we support children in cultivating a compassionate inner voice?
here are three strategies to achieve this goal.
the manner in which we communicate with children significantly influences their internal dialogue.
consistent validation and nurturing from caregivers can lead to the development of an inner voice that is compassionate.
studies indicate that children who receive supportive and empathetic parenting are more likely to treat themselves with kindness.
conversely, children of parents who are critical tend to be more self-critical.

happiness scores are derived from a survey that assesses life satisfaction by asking respondents to envision a ladder representing their life, with 0 being the worst possible life and 10 being the best.
participants are then asked to rank themselves on this ladder, encouraging reflection on their own well-being, achievements, resources, and social status.
in the research, a culturally appropriate method was created to assess well-being, revealing that the current happiness rankings may not fully capture the scores in some nations.

our views on happiness are influenced by our cultural background.
for instance, in cultures that prioritize individualism, happiness is often measured by personal satisfaction and self-experience.
in such cultures, happiness is often associated with feelings of excitement and enjoyment.
in some countries, the emphasis on happiness is rooted in connections and maintaining positive relationships, prioritizing social harmony and reliance on others.
unlike individualistic cultures, where happiness is seen as an individual pursuit, in collectivist cultures, people attribute their happiness to communal experiences and the well-being of those around them.
consequently, individuals in these cultures tend to perceive happiness as contentment, and their own happiness levels are often influenced by the happiness of those in their social circle.

according to our research, individuals with high levels of intellectual humility tend to be more discerning when evaluating the evidence presented in an article regarding the benefits of dental flossing.
their ability to differentiate between reliable and unreliable information on the topic stems from their awareness that their beliefs could potentially be inaccurate.
thus, intellectually humble individuals prioritize scrutinizing the quality of evidence supporting their beliefs.
intellectual humility is closely linked with a willingness to acquire new knowledge.
those who exhibit high levels of intellectual humility show greater interest in seeking out new information, as evident in their strong desire for intellectual curiosity.
this curiosity appears to stem from both their enjoyment of acquiring knowledge and their discomfort when faced with gaps in knowledge or understanding.
additionally, individuals with high intellectual humility tend to display a greater enjoyment in engaging in critical thinking, pondering complex issues, and solving intellectual challenges compared to those with lower levels of intellectual humility.
research suggests that individuals high in intellectual humility tend to refrain from criticizing those with differing opinions, while those low in this trait tend to react emotionally to disagreement and may belittle those with differing views.
this essay marks the beginning of a three-year project by the ggsc to promote awareness of research on intellectual humility and its significance.
aside from exacerbating disputes and generating resentment, a lack of intellectual humility can lead to real-world challenges.
those who are closed-minded towards differing opinions can hinder open and sincere conversations.
for instance, leaders who do not welcome diverse perspectives may prevent group members from sharing their thoughts, potentially impeding innovative and beneficial ideas.
conversely, leaders who are humble and open to alternative viewpoints can encourage others to participate more actively in discussions.
intellectual humility offers individuals personal, practical, and societal advantages.
however, the factors that influence why some individuals exhibit more intellectual humility than others remain mostly unexplored due to limited research on the topic.
nonetheless, findings from related fields can offer some insights for speculation on this matter.
because most personal traits have some genetic component, it is not unexpected that intellectual humility may also be partially influenced by genetics.
this is supported by the correlation between intellectual humility, overconfidence, and openness, all of which have genetic factors at play.
certain ideologies may not encourage people to exhibit intellectual humility.
for instance, many religions assert that they are the sole possessors of the truth and discourage individuals from questioning the validity of their beliefs.
it should be noted that individuals who do not adhere to any religious beliefs may also lack intellectual humility; atheists, for example, may be just as resolute in their convictions as religious extremists.
regrettably, many of us tend to overestimate the correctness of our beliefs and viewpoints, often without considering the potential for error.
however, individuals can develop greater intellectual humility by choosing to be more open-minded and through interventions that challenge their overconfidence, leading them to become more humble intellectually.

in the book the semisovereign people published in 1960, elmer e.
schattschneider, a political scientist, contended that economic inequality acted as a means of disenfranchising voters.
he believed that this occurred as the wealthy and affluent could influence the discussion and manipulate outcomes to favor their own interests due to their economic advantage.
this perception that the political system primarily prioritized their needs could discourage lower-income and working-class individuals from engaging in the political process.
the main point is that inequality significantly reduces voting rates among low-income individuals, as demonstrated by recent studies.
a fresh examination of polling data for the 2020 election by fivethirtyeight further supports this finding, showing a correlation between lower incomes and lower voter turnout.
researchers at harvard university conducted a study in 2001, analyzing the data from the current population survey for the years 1990, 1992, 1994, and 1996.
their findings revealed a correlation between high voting inequality among different socioeconomic groups in states and the likelihood of individuals reporting fair or poor health.
this connection between inequality, health status, and voting patterns was also observed in various other countries.
to validate the connection between disparities in health and political engagement, aaron reeves and johan mackenbach analyzed voter registration and health information from 17 european nations.

a recent study by steven o.
roberts, an assistant professor of psychology at stanford university, revealed that discussions about race are lacking in leading psychological publications.
the study, published in perspectives on psychological science, found that only a small number of prominent psychological publications focus on race, and when race is addressed, it is predominantly written and edited by white scholars.
the researchers examined photos of editors and authors online, mainly from faculty webpages, to identify their race.
they emailed the individuals to confirm their self-reported racial identity and validate the researchers' initial assessments.
the racial composition of editors-in-chief differed across different areas of psychology.
in cognitive psychology, which focuses on mental processes such as perception, memory, thinking, attention, and language, there has never been an editor of color in either of the journals.
roberts suggests that cognitive psychologists might steer clear of studying race because they focus on examining universal, race-neutral phenomena.
the researchers also considered if the difference could be accounted for by the number of white authors.
if there are more white authors, they should be more prevalent in all journals.
however, roberts discovered that in less prestigious specialized journals, white authors were actually not as prevalent as expected.
roberts suggests that journals should first communicate a strong commitment to diversity from the top down.
this includes clearly indicating if the journal showcases research that embraces diversity and values the involvement of diverse scientists in editing, writing, and contributing to the journal.
additional suggestions include involving a wide range of individuals at various stages of the publication process, examining the diversity of research subjects during reviews, publishing yearly reports on diversity, and creating a team dedicated to promoting diversity.
roberts suggests that authors have the power to influence change by including a thorough explanation and rationale for the racial composition of their research subjects, a practice that is not widely seen in traditional psychology publications.
roberts wants this project to acknowledge the hard work of numerous psychologists over the years who have often been overlooked when it comes to having their research published in prestigious journals.

during the survey, some participants were randomly asked to choose true or false within 11 seconds, while others were told to delay their response for at least 11 seconds.
a third group received no specific time instructions and completed the survey at their own pace.
the study at ucsb revealed that individuals who answered questions in less than 11 seconds tended to have higher scores in social desirability.
essentially, when given a short amount of time to respond, they portrayed themselves as more kind and helpful.
conversely, when provided with more time, participants tended to depict themselves in a more selfish manner.

previous research has presented conflicting findings on the frequency of bystander intervention in public conflicts.
for example, one study from 1983 found that bystanders attempted to intervene in just 11 percent of cases.
however, other studies have shown higher rates of bystander assistance, such as observations of barroom attacks where bystanders intervened around one-third of the time.
another recent review of police case files revealed that bystanders stepped in to help in nearly 75 percent of public attack incidents.

in october, an israeli tank crew fired two shells at a clearly marked group of journalists in lebanon, resulting in the death of a reuters reporter.
the crew then likely continued to shoot at them with a heavy machine gun for almost two minutes, according to a report released on thursday.
reuters was unable to confirm whether the israeli tank crew was aware that they were targeting journalists, or if they additionally used a machine gun to shoot at them, and if so, the reason behind it remains unknown.
both of the remaining reuters journalists and another afp reporter present did not recall hearing the sound of the machine gun.
they all mentioned being in a state of shock during that moment.
according to international humanitarian law, journalists are protected as civilians and cannot be targeted during attacks because they are not considered military objectives.
"we strongly denounce the assault on a group of journalists who were clearly identifiable and working openly.
our colleague issam abdallah lost his life in the attack, and several others were injured.
we urge israel to provide an explanation for this tragic event and to ensure that those accountable are held responsible," stated reuters editor-in-chief alessandra galloni.
afp global news director, phil chetwynd, emphatically repeated his request for a comprehensive and open investigation to be carried out by the israeli military.
he stated that if the reports of continuous machine gun fire are verified, it would further support the idea that this was a purposeful and planned assault.
ihtisham hibatullah, who is in charge of international communications at al jazeera, called on the israeli government to reveal the results of its own inquiry.
"this incident clearly suggests a deliberate act of targeting, as substantiated by various investigations, including those conducted by tno," he stated.
tno observed that the seven journalists were clad in blue protective gear, with "press" marked on their vests in white letters.
they were capturing footage of cross-border shelling from a vantage point on a hill close to the lebanese village of alma al-chaab for almost an hour prior to the incident.
video recordings of the incident aftermath also displayed a black vehicle owned by reuters, with the word "tv" prominently displayed in large yellow tape letters on both the hood and the roof.
tno mentioned that there was a direct visual connection between the location of the tank rounds being fired and the area where the attack occurred.
in the video footage broadcasted before the attack, there were sounds of drones possibly present, and an israeli helicopter could be seen flying above in certain clips.
the institute pinpointed the origin of the two tank rounds by utilizing video footage capturing the second round's muzzle blast and trajectory, along with audio recordings gathered at the scene of the event.
nonetheless, the rapid succession of gunfire following the tank rounds, combined with the examination, convinced tno that it was probable both originated from the same source.
the institute did not present any alternative explanations for the origin of the machine gun shots.
approximately half a minute after the second tank round, a machine gun fired around 25 shots, followed by bursts of nine and 12 shots.
after another 30 seconds, three shots were heard, followed by a single shot and a metallic ping sound, possibly caused by a bullet hitting a nearby low wall according to tno.
the attack also caused injuries to reuters photographer thaier al-sudani, aged 47, cameraman maher nazeh, aged 53, and two journalists from al jazeera, along with another journalist from afp.
some of the experts who examined the tno report for reuters had differing opinions on whether the tank crew intentionally aimed at journalists.
jessica dorsey, an expert in international humanitarian law at utrecht university, stated that the tno report suggests that machine gun fire from the same location likely accompanied the two tank rounds, indicating a deliberate targeting of the victims.
she believed that from a legal standpoint, if the matter ended up in court, it would further strengthen the argument that the incident constituted a war crime.
yet, nick kaufman, a lawyer from britain and israel who has a background serving in the idf military advocate general's corps and has defended prominent clients accused of war crimes at international criminal courts, stated that the reason for the tank firing at the journalists remained uncertain.
israel's military announced that they have footage of the attack and are currently conducting an investigation, but no findings have been shared with the public yet.

in his works like the meditations, descartes argued that the presence of consciousness conflicts with materialistic beliefs, leading to the assertion of a form of dualism.
fellow philosophers of his time, such as thomas hobbes, antoine arnauld, and princess elisabeth of bohemia, raised objections to descartes' arguments in different manners.
naturally, these are just two examples, but they are fundamental ones.
it's difficult to find two problems in philosophy more significant than descartes' mind-body problem and hume's induction problem.
additionally, the instances provided serve as a clear demonstration of a widespread approach often used to resolve philosophical issues.
these issues are resolved by broadening the scope of what constitutes truth or a justifiable belief.
in essence, resolution occurs when we recognize the necessity of altering or abandoning a previously convincing boundary thesis.
how could someone challenge this proposal?
just like any philosophical topic, the concepts involved are intricate and offer various paths for exploration.
however, due to limitations in space, i will focus on three primary critiques.
although the issue of successor problems may arise, it should not be seen as a valid argument against holding a reasonable sense of optimism.
it is important to understand that progress in philosophy does not mean that no new problems can emerge.
this belief is unreasonable and would suggest that progress is unattainable in any field if followed consistently.
if the problem at hand remains identical between the original issue and its successor, it can challenge a sense of reasonable optimism.
however, in numerous instances, the successor problem differs from its predecessor.
for instance, the current problem regarding materialism and consciousness is separate from descartes' query.
descartes focused on equating matter with extension, whereas today's philosophers do not center their discussions around that concept.
however, despite the common objection to negativity in addressing boundary problems, there are two clear rebuttals to this view, particularly in the context of the argument being discussed.
firstly, the objection fails to recognize the nature of boundary problems, which often involve conflicting elements that necessitate trade-offs for resolution.
these dilemmas inherently demand relinquishing certain aspects.
hence, deeming the act of rejecting elements as merely negative overlooks the intricacies of these issues.
this is a fundamental aspect of addressing any paradoxical situation.
when faced with a set of credible premises leading to an implausible outcome, it is evident that all premises and the negation of the conclusion cannot simultaneously hold true.
therefore, to untangle the paradox, it is essential to make negative assertions.
an insistence on avoiding negativity while attempting to resolve the issue effectively hinders any progress in tackling the problem.
i believe we should acknowledge that philosophers frequently seek theories or explanations for phenomena that interest them.
upon further consideration, it becomes apparent that philosophers have also achieved success in this regard.
while philosophers may not focus on causal explanations, they are keenly interested in constitutive explanations.
when pondering concepts like consciousness, morality, or knowledge, the aim is to gain insight into the underlying structure of these elements in the world.
have we advanced in addressing such philosophical queries?
with the perspective influenced by lewis's idea of explanation, the crucial consideration becomes whether the current information offered on these constitutive structures surpasses past insights.
however, if the question is posed in this manner, it is hard to argue against answering it positively.
the information presented in areas such as philosophy of mind regarding the essence of conscious states appears to align well with the criteria lewis outlines in his assessment of effective or ineffective explanations.
for instance, the concept that conscious states involve the awareness of properties, as opposed to merely the presence of properties, is a prevalent idea in modern attempts at elucidating consciousness.
this proposition is widely accepted and integrated into various philosophical approaches to the mind.
even those philosophers who oppose it usually do so on the grounds that it may not be applicable to all conscious states, rather than dismissing its relevance altogether.
thus, this perspective on mental states offers more insightful knowledge on the fundamental structures linked to consciousness compared to previous understandings.
it illustrates a step forward in tackling a non-boundary problem.
to the degree that it mirrors typical progress in the field, there is cause for cautious optimism.
