ancient egyptian deities refer to the gods and goddesses honored in ancient egypt, whose worship was central to the ancient egyptian religion that originated in ancient times.
these deities represented natural elements and were revered through offerings and ceremonies to maintain harmony and order in accordance with maat, or divine principles.
following the establishment of the egyptian state circa 3100 bc, the responsibility of overseeing these rituals fell to the pharaoh, who asserted divine authority as the gods' intermediary and oversaw the temples where these practices took place.
gods were believed to be universally present and capable of impacting both natural occurrences and human destinies.
individuals engaged with them at both formal temples and informal shrines, seeking their guidance for personal matters and also for broader state ceremonies.
egyptians commonly prayed to their gods for assistance, performed rituals to impel their intervention, and sought their counsel.
the interaction between humans and deities played a key role in the fabric of egyptian civilization.
the origins of predynastic egypt can be traced back to autonomous villages.
some scholars believe that the egyptian pantheon developed as different communities merged into larger states, leading to the spread and blending of worship of local deities associated with specific areas.
conversely, others contend that the main predynastic gods were widespread throughout the nation, transcending political boundaries, similar to how various aspects of egyptian culture were uniformly present throughout the country.
the last stage in the development of egyptian religion occurred with the unification of egypt.
rulers from upper egypt became pharaohs of the entire country, establishing themselves and their officials as the only ones allowed to communicate with the gods.
as a result, kingship became the central theme of the religion.
a great deal of what is known about egyptian beliefs about the gods comes from religious writings created by the country's scribes and priests, who were the privileged class in society.
the majority of the population at the time were unable to read or write.
the extent to which the common people understood the complex ideas developed by the elite remains uncertain.
it is possible that there were differences in how the general population and the priests perceived the divine, with the commoners potentially interpreting symbolic religious explanations as literal truths.
however, the limited information available suggests that popular religious beliefs align relatively closely with those upheld by the elite.
overall, there seems to be coherence in the portrayal of the gods and their characteristics between the two groups.
it was believed that divine conduct controlled all aspects of nature.
with the exception of a few gods who caused disorder, the actions of the gods upheld harmony and nurtured all living creatures by utilizing a force known as heka, which is often interpreted as "magic" in english.
heka was viewed as an essential force that the creator god utilized to shape the world and the deities.
the initial divine act involves the creation of the cosmos as depicted in various creation myths.
these myths highlight different gods who perform as creator deities.
for example, the ogdoad's eight gods, symbolizing chaos before creation, give birth to the sun god who establishes order in the newly shaped world.
ptah, representing thought and creativity, shapes all things by imagining and naming them.
atum generates all things as extensions of himself, while amun, according to his priesthood's beliefs, precedes and gives rise to the other creator gods.
these diverse accounts of creation were not viewed as conflicting but rather as providing various perspectives on the intricate process through which the structured universe and its numerous deities emerged from an initial state of chaos.
following creation, a series of gods govern as kings over the divine realm in most myths.
they combat chaos and contend among themselves before ultimately stepping back from the human world and placing historical kings of egypt in charge.
gods were associated with specific parts of the universe in ancient egyptian beliefs.
the universe was believed to consist of the earth, the sky, and the duat, with the surrounding dark formlessness representing the time before creation.
while most gods were thought to reside in the sky, those with specific roles were associated with different parts of the universe.
mythological events, occurring before the gods retreated from the human realm, took place on earth, with occasional interactions between earth-bound deities and sky deities.
the duat, on the other hand, was considered a distant and isolated realm where communication between its resident gods and those in the living world was challenging.
additionally, the space beyond the cosmos was believed to be inhabited by deities, some of which were regarded as hostile while others were supportive of the ordered world of gods.
in egyptian belief, names are seen as reflective of the true nature of the entities they represent.
thus, the names of deities often correlate with their characteristics or origins.
for instance, the name sekhmet, associated with a powerful goddess, means "powerful one", while amun's name, linked to a god of mystery, signifies "hidden one".
similarly, nekhbet's name relates to her city of worshippers, nekheb.
however, some names lack clear meanings despite their association with specific roles.
for example, the names of sky goddess nut and earth god geb do not directly translate to "sky" or "earth" in egyptian.
the egyptians came up with incorrect explanations for divine names, attributing additional meanings to them.
for instance, in the coffin texts, the name of the god sokar was interpreted as "cleaning of the mouth" to associate it with his role in a specific ritual.
in the pyramid texts, it is suggested that the name sokar derived from words spoken by osiris, aligning sokar with the key funerary deity.
the gods were thought to have various names, including secret ones that revealed their true essence more deeply.
knowing a deity's true name gave one control over it.
this significance of names is illustrated in a tale where isis poisons ra and demands his secret name as payment for the antidote.
once she learns the name, she shares it with her son horus, granting them increased knowledge and authority.
the egyptian gods were linked in intricate and ever-changing relationships.
these connections with other deities played a crucial role in shaping each god's identity.
for instance, isis, known as a healer and the guardian of horus, was also revered as the special deity of kings.
these divine relationships served as the foundation for the myths that were developed.
many gods in egyptian mythology are connected through familial relationships, often depicted as male and female pairs to emphasize the importance of procreation.
triads of deities, consisting of a father, mother, and child, symbolize the creation of new life and the passing of power from one generation to the next.
this pattern, exemplified by deities like osiris, isis, and horus, became widespread over time, with various divine families such as ptah, sekhmet, and nefertum at memphis, and amun, mut, and khonsu at thebes.
these genealogical relationships are fluid in egyptian belief, with figures like hathor embodying different roles in different contexts.
nine, arising from the multiplication of three by three, symbolized a large collection for the egyptians.
they referred to various significant groups as " enneads ", groups of nine, irrespective of the actual number of members.
the most renowned ennead was the ennead of heliopolis, a divine family lineage originating from the god atum, encompassing numerous essential gods.
this terminology was commonly broadened to encompass all of egypt's deities.
this divine gathering had a somewhat unclear and changeable hierarchy, where gods with significant influence or age in mythology were considered to have higher positions.
at the top of this hierarchy was the king of the gods, typically associated with the creator deity.
throughout different eras in egyptian history, various gods held this esteemed position.
for example, horus was most significant in the early dynastic period, ra in the old kingdom, amun in the new kingdom, and isis in the later ptolemaic and roman periods.
when new gods rose to prominence, they often inherited characteristics from their predecessors.
isis, for instance, incorporated attributes from several goddesses as she gained importance, and when amun took over as the leader of the pantheon, he fused with ra to become a solar deity.
in 1971, erik hornung published a study challenging the notion that egyptian religion was monotheistic or pantheistic.
he argues that many deities, including lesser-known ones, were frequently depicted as superior to all others.
hornung suggests that the term "god" in ancient texts was generic and could refer to any deity chosen by the reader to worship.
he highlights that while the characteristics and representations of gods varied, they were never portrayed as completely interchangeable in a monotheistic or pantheistic manner.
instead, he proposes that henotheism, the worship of one god without denying the existence of others, better describes egyptian religious practices.
according to hornung, the gods in egyptian mythology were united only in myth and before creation, and emerged as a multitude from a uniform nonexistence thereafter.
egyptian texts provide detailed descriptions of the gods' bodies, attributing qualities such as flesh made of gold, bones of silver, and hair of lapis lazuli.
the gods are said to emit a fragrance resembling incense, and some texts specify details like height and eye color.
however, these features are not fixed, as gods are known to alter their appearances.
egyptian writings often refer to the deities' true forms as "mysterious," and visual depictions of the gods symbolize specific traits rather than being literal representations.
for example, the depiction of anubis as a dog or jackal in egyptian art serves to counter the threat of scavengers to buried mummies and to symbolize resurrection through his black coloring.
even though the egyptians thought their gods were among them, direct interactions between humans and the divine realm were generally restricted to specific situations.
while literature may depict gods appearing to humans physically, in reality, communication between egyptians and the gods was often through indirect channels.
to safeguard the sanctity of the temple sanctuaries and protect them from outside impurities, the egyptians encased them and limited access primarily to kings and high priests.
except during festive processions when the cult statues were briefly brought out in portable shrines, common people were prohibited from direct interaction.
however, individuals had alternative ways to engage with the divine, as public temple areas included designated areas for prayer, such as doorways or stand-alone chapels nearby.
communities constructed and oversaw their own chapels, and some households had personal shrines.
despite the perceived distance between humans and the gods, the egyptians were continually surrounded by various means to connect and communicate with their deities.
the egyptian gods interacted with both human lives and the natural order.
while their influence was primarily felt in egypt, foreigners were seen as outside this divine order.
however, in the new kingdom period when egypt controlled other nations, foreigners were believed to be under the rule of the sun god just like egyptians.
humans had the choice to disregard divine guidance and the principles of maat, but in doing so, they risked facing divine retribution.
this punishment was delivered by deities wielding their ba, a power that was believed to carry out the will of the gods in the human realm.
the ancients attributed natural calamities and diseases to the wrath of the deities' bas.
on the other hand, the gods were also thought to be capable of healing the virtuous and prolonging their lives.
over time, specific deities embodying these concepts emerged, such as shed, who symbolized protection from harm during the new kingdom, and petbe, an apotropaic deity from later periods in egyptian history who was thought to mete out justice for wrongdoing.
egyptian texts offer varied perspectives on whether the gods bear responsibility for human suffering.
some texts attribute misfortune to the cosmic disorder, isfet, contrasting it with maat, absolving the gods of blame for evil occurrences.
certain deities linked with isfet, like set, are sometimes implicated for worldly chaos without incriminating other gods.
conversely, some texts do place blame on the gods for causing human suffering, while others present justifications defending the gods.
in the middle kingdom, narratives began linking evil in the world to a myth in which the creator god combats a human revolt against his authority and then distances himself from the earth due to human disobedience, leading to the existence of suffering.
during the new kingdom, texts show less questioning of the gods' just nature compared to the earlier middle kingdom writings.
the focus shifts to emphasizing personal relationships with deities and their capacity to intervene in human affairs.
in this period, individuals placed trust in specific gods for personal protection, diminishing the significance of upholding maat ideals in favor of seeking favor from the gods for a prosperous life.
even the pharaohs were perceived as reliant on divine assistance, and post-new kingdom governance increasingly heeded oracles conveying divine will.
official religious rituals in egypt were concerned with upholding maat for the greater good of society, while the common people's religious practices were more personal in nature, focused on seeking divine assistance for their individual challenges.
as the roman economy declined in the third century ad, temples and cults in egypt diminished.
by the fourth century, christians began to suppress the worship of egyptian deities, leading to the extinction of formal cults, such as at philae in the fifth or sixth century.
beliefs surrounding the gods faded away over time, though some persisted in magical texts until the seventh and eighth centuries.
practices like processions and oracles from the worship of the deities were modified to align with christian beliefs and were integrated into the coptic church.
the extent to which modern coptic practices are directly descended from those of ancient egyptian religion is a topic of debate among scholars due to the significant changes in egyptian culture over time.
however, many festivals and traditions observed by present-day egyptians, regardless of their religious affiliation, bear similarities to the worship practices of their ancestors.

private flying can be categorized into recreational purposes and personal transport, with individuals either owning aircraft themselves, sharing ownership collectively, or renting from flying clubs.
a survey conducted among pilots in 2001-2002 revealed that common recreational flight activities included local trips near the base aerodrome, visits to other aerodromes, and day outings.
additionally, around half of the flights returned to the departure aerodrome, with only a small percentage involving overnight stays away from home.
in 2007, there were 27 deadly incidents involving general aviation aircraft which led to the deaths of 48 people.
this stands in contrast to the previous year, where 16 accidents resulted in 19 fatalities.
while the figures for 2007 were above the norm, they were not considered unusually high.
airspace is used by various users, including commercial, military, and general aviation.
it is categorized into controlled and uncontrolled airspace, where controlled airspace requires aircraft to be under the guidance of air traffic controllers, while uncontrolled airspace allows for autonomous operation.
general aviation flights mostly operate outside of controlled airspace, with some exceptions permitting entry under specific circumstances.
in recent years, regional airports like edinburgh airport have seen a significant rise in commercial air transport (cat) operations, creating challenges for general aviation (ga).
while there may not be intentional discrimination, the practices have inadvertently deterred or excluded ga.
charges for ga aircraft have increased, including the introduction of handling fees at some airports.
there are restrictions on ga parking and activities at certain airports, leading to a decline in light ga aircraft presence at major international airports such as heathrow, stansted, gatwick, and manchester.
the planning system plays a crucial role in the functionality of general aviation (ga) aerodromes.
as many cities lack direct air transport services and access to commercial airports for ga is increasingly challenging and costly, having a well-supported network of aerodromes is seen as a significant national concern.
however, there is no unified national planning policy for ga aerodromes, leading to decisions being made at a local level without considering broader national implications.
aircraft noise, as the main concern in many planning decisions related to ga land use, is the subject in which planning restrictions are often based.
local planning authorities, not always familiar with ga, tend to either reject planning requests or approve them with strict conditions.
this lack of clear planning guidelines can hinder the growth and safety of ga operations, as seen in examples like little gransden airfield, which must adhere to limitations on movements, potentially impeding further development.
the idea of a gold dollar was suggested multiple times in the 1830s and 1840s but was not immediately approved.
however, following the california gold rush, which significantly increased the availability of gold, congress was motivated to take action and authorized the creation of a gold dollar in 1849.
initially, the gold dollar quickly gained popularity in commerce as silver coins were being hoarded or exported.
eventually, when congress mandated lighter silver coins in 1853, silver coins started circulating once again, leading to the gold dollar becoming less common in transactions.
furthermore, due to the economic turmoil brought about by the american civil war, federal coins disappeared from circulation, further diminishing the use of the gold dollar in commerce.

the process has been employed in several important complete syntheses such as the danishefsky taxol synthesis, which creates the anticancer drug taxol, and the kuehne strychnine synthesis that generates the pesticide strychnine.
besides the reactions documented by johnson, corey, and chaykovsky, other homologation reactions utilizing sulfur ylides have been employed and categorized collectively under the same label.
aggarwal has created a new technique that uses the sulfide mentioned earlier along with a unique alkylation process that involves a rhodium carbenoid produced on-site.
however, this method also has restrictions as it is only effective for a specific range of substrates and cannot be used with electrophiles containing basic substituents because the carbenoid is used up in competition with them.

many reviewers praised the feast of the goat, appreciating its portrayal of the connection between sex and authority, as well as the vivid descriptions of violent scenes.
trujillo held the title of dictator from 1930 to 1938, and again from 1942 to 1952, but he exerted control over the country during the whole time.
despite his regime being largely nationalist, daniel chirot notes that trujillo did not follow a specific ideology, and his economic and social policies were generally considered progressive.
the novel's story is separated into three main parts.
one part follows urania cabral, a fictional character from the dominican republic, while another delves into the group of conspirators planning to assassinate trujillo.
the third part centers around trujillo himself.
the narrative shifts between these three plotlines and moves back and forth between 1961 and 1996, often including flashbacks to earlier times in trujillo's rule.
as the novel reaches its conclusion, the three narratives start to converge more frequently.
the tone of these final chapters becomes notably bleak, focusing on the brutal torture and demise of the assassins by the sim, the unsuccessful coup, urania's traumatic experience, and the compromises made to appease trujillo's most ruthless followers, who carry out their savage retribution on the plotters before fleeing the country.
the story closes with urania gearing up to go back home, committed this time to staying connected with her family on the island.
the main themes of the feast of the goat involve political corruption, masculinity, memory, and the interplay between writing and power.
olga lorenzo, who reviewed the book for the melbourne age, proposes that vargas llosa's main objective is to expose the illogical influences of latin tradition that lead to authoritarian rule.
memory plays a significant role in the parts of the novel that focus on the assassins, as each of them recalls the events that led to their participation in the assassination of trujillo.
these events include the galindez kidnapping and murder in 1956, the murder of the mirabal sisters in 1960, and the split with the catholic church in 1961.
vargas llosa uses these historical incidents to show how the assassins are linked to specific moments that reveal the brutality of trujillo's regime.
moreover, trujillo himself is depicted reflecting on his own past, particularly his training under the us marines.
primarily, mario vargas llosa employs the character urania within the narrative to aid in the novel's exploration of remembering the regime.
urania's story both opens and concludes the novel, providing a framework for examining the past and its impact on the present.
furthermore, her expertise in studying the history of the trujillo regime allows her to grapple with the collective memory of the regime for the nation.
this aligns with the novel's goal of ensuring that future generations remember the brutalities of the dictatorship and the perils of unchecked authority.
ruiz suggests that writing has the ability to alter reality by immersing readers in the past and helping them grasp the true essence of myths and inaccuracies found in historical accounts.
understanding the past is deemed essential for comprehending the present from a postmodern perspective.
ruiz asserts that "the feast of the goat" serves as a postmodern narrative that empowers the recreation of history.
some reviewers have noted that the feast of the goat stands out for its realist style compared to the allegorical approach often seen in dictator novels.
the novel has generally been well-received, with many reviewers appreciating its compelling storytelling even if it may take some liberties with historical accuracy.

the caves' rock architecture, carved from solid basalt rock, is believed to have been constructed between the 5th and 8th centuries.
there is ongoing debate about the identity of the individuals who originally built the caves.
while the caves were once adorned with paint, only faint remnants of the original artwork can be seen today.
even though the primary cave was renovated in the 1970s, several other caves, including three with significant sculptures, remain in poor condition.
these caves were recognized as a unesco world heritage site in 1987 due to their cultural significance and as they embody a remarkable example of human creativity and provide exceptional evidence of a culture that is either still existing or has vanished.
located on the eastern side of the island, there is a cluster of caves on stupa hill that hold buddhist relics.
the hill draws its name from the stupa monument it features.
one of the caves remains unfinished, while the second one houses a brick-built stupa.
the primary cave combines elements of chalukyan architecture, such as large sculptures of deities and guardians, and square pillars with unique capitals, with gupta artistic features like representations of mountains, clouds, and female hairstyles.
one tale about the depicted panels involves a quarrel between parvati and shiva.
ravana happened to come across mount kailash, and in frustration at the obstacle, he shook it.
this action startled parvati, causing her to seek comfort in shiva's embrace.
shiva, angered by ravana's behavior, subdued him until ravana praised shiva and asked for forgiveness, becoming a devoted follower.
alternatively, another account suggests that shiva was pleased with ravana for calming parvati and granted him a blessing.
located on the eastern hill north of sitabai's cave is a hindu excavation structure with a veranda.
originally intended to have three cells, this construction was halted due to a defect in the rock.
on the east side of the hill lies a desolate pond surrounded by artificial boulders and buddhist cisterns.
at the tip of the northern spur of the main hill stands a mound reminiscent of a buddhist stupa.

during world war ii, the occupying forces of nazi germany and the soviet union suppressed polish culture, targeting scholars, artists, and cultural artifacts.
this resulted in widespread deaths and destruction that aimed to erase poland's cultural heritage.
niall ferguson, a british historian, noted that the mistreatment of poles was just one of the many similarities between the oppressive regimes of the nazis and soviets.
the invaders plundered and ruined a significant part of poland's cultural and historical treasures, in addition to targeting and killing leaders in the polish cultural community.
the majority of polish educational institutions were shut down, and the ones that stayed open had their educational programs drastically changed.
the german forces in poland were heavily involved in eradicating jewish culture, particularly through the destruction of wooden synagogues.
additionally, they prohibited the sale of jewish literature across the country.
educational and training programs focus heavily on the world war ii era and the occupation.
war-related events and figures are prevalent in various forms of media such as tv, radio, and print.
the impact of world war ii is also evident in literature, education, film, theater, and the arts.
politicians frequently reference this historical period.
this country stands out for frequently and ceremoniously acknowledging anniversaries associated with world war ii.
following germany's defeat and the armistice in november 1918, the royal navy held markgraf and the main warships of the high seas fleet in scapa flow.
these vessels were disarmed and operated with only a bare minimum crew while the allied nations finalized the treaty of versailles.
just before the treaty was officially signed on 21 june 1919, rear admiral ludwig von reuter, in charge of the interned fleet, gave the order to sink the ships to prevent the british from taking control of them.
unlike other ships that were scuttled, markgraf was never salvaged and remains on the seabed to this day.
after being commissioned on 1 october 1914, markgraf underwent sea trials until 12 december.
by 10 january 1915, the ship had become part of the iii battle squadron of the high seas fleet along with her three sister ships.
on 22 january 1915, the squadron was separated from the fleet to practice maneuvers, gunnery, and torpedo drills in the baltic sea.
the ships sailed back to the north sea on 11 february, missing the opportunity to support the i scouting group during the battle of dogger bank.
archaeologists have determined that the coldrum stones were constructed by pastoralist communities shortly after agriculture was introduced to britain from continental europe.
while part of a broader tradition of long barrow building in neolithic europe, these stones are considered a local variant of barrows found near the river medway, known as the medway megaliths.
the coldrum stones are in the best state of preservation among the medway megaliths and are situated close to other barrows like addington long barrow and chestnuts long barrow on the river's western side.
on the eastern side of the river, three other well-preserved long barrows, kit's coty house, the little kit's coty house, and the coffin stone, can be found.
the stones in the area can be classified into two main groups: one located to the west of the river medway and another on blue bell hill to the east, with a distance of around 8 to 10 km between them.
the cluster in the west includes coldrum long barrow, addington long barrow, and the chestnuts long barrow, while the eastern group comprises kit's coty house, little kit's coty house, the coffin stone, and other stones possibly from chambered tombs.
it is unclear whether these structures were all built simultaneously or one after the other, and there is uncertainty regarding their intended purposes and whether they were used in a hierarchical manner.
all the medway long barrows were built following a similar blueprint, with each one oriented in an east-west direction.
they featured a stone chamber located at the eastern part of the mound, most likely with a stone facade beside the entrance.
these chambers were made of sarsen, which is a tough and long-lasting type of stone found in abundance in kent, created from hardened sand during the eocene period.
during the early neolithic era, builders would have sourced these stones locally and then transported them to the monuments' locations for construction.
there might have been a front structure in front of the tomb, similar to those seen at other tombs in britain like west kennet long barrow and wayland's smithy.
there could have also been a stone at the entrance, as seen at kit's coty house and lower kit's coty house.
some of the large fallen stones on the eastern end of the site might have been components of this front structure.
keith suggested that the skulls he studied shared common characteristics, theorizing that they could belong to either one large family or multiple families with shared ancestry.
similarly, other researchers observed comparable features in skulls from different long barrows in britain, but smith and brickley cautioned that this did not necessarily indicate a family connection.
they suggested that the findings could also be attributed to a small, closely related population that lived in scattered groups.
the presence of occupational remains on top of the bones was not exclusive to this site but was a typical feature in chambered tombs from southern england.
by examining a similar case found at kit's coty house, ashbee believed that the coldrum chamber would have been divided into sections by internal slabs, which acted similarly to the side chambers found in west kennet and wayland's smithy.
the megalithic tombs dating back to the early neolithic period have been neglected and impacted by agriculture.
even though the coldrum stones are considered one of the least damaged long barrows in kent, they too have experienced significant deterioration over the past six thousand years.
one notable issue is the collapse of the eastern side, with the stones that supported it now lying at the base of the slope.
it is suggested that some of the sarsens at the bottom of the slope may not have been part of the original structure but were added later, potentially by farmers who found them in nearby fields.

china has long been the top manufacturer of antimony and its derivatives, mainly sourced from the xikuangshan mine in hunan.
industrial techniques like roasting and reduction with carbon, as well as direct reduction of stibnite with iron, are commonly employed to produce antimony.
in his work natural history, the ancient roman scholar pliny the elder outlined various methods for preparing antimony sulfide for medicinal use.
additionally, pliny distinguished between two forms of antimony - "male" and "female." it is believed that the male form refers to the sulfide, while the female form, described as superior, heavier, and less prone to breaking, is thought to be natural metallic antimony.
pedanius dioscorides, a roman naturalist, indicated that antimony sulfide could be transformed into metallic antimony by roasting it with the help of a current of air.
in 1615, german chemist andreas libavius discovered the metal antimony by combining iron with a hot mixture of antimony sulfide, salt, and potassium tartrate.
this method resulted in antimony with a distinctive crystalline or starred appearance.
when challenges arose against the phlogiston theory, scientists acknowledged that antimony, like other metals, can form sulfides, oxides, and other compounds as it is recognized as an element.
the primary meaning of the ancient terms for antimony often refers to kohl, which is the sulfide compound of antimony.
in a report published in 2011, antimony was recognized as one of the 12 crucial raw materials for the eu, mainly because of the limited availability of supply from sources other than china.
the roskill report indicates that antimony production decreased in china in 2010 and is not expected to rise in the near future.
china has not developed any major antimony deposits in approximately a decade, and the existing economically viable reserves are being exhausted quickly.
based on data from the usgs, the existing worldwide stores of antimony are projected to run out in 13 years.
nonetheless, the usgs anticipates the discovery of additional resources.
antimony is utilized in the production of bullets, including bullet tracers, as well as in the creation of paint and glass art projects, and as an opacifier in enamel.
wheeler is acknowledged as a significant british archaeologist from the 20th century who played a key role in promoting public interest in archaeology in britain and improving excavation and recording techniques.
additionally, he is known for his contributions to south asian archaeology.
despite his achievements, some of his theories about archaeological sites have been disproved or reevaluated, and he faced criticism for mistreating colleagues and engaging in sexual harassment of young women.
in 1899, wheeler enrolled at bradford grammar school when he was almost nine years old, starting in the second form.
in 1902, his parents had a second daughter named betty, but wheeler didn't show much interest in his younger sister.
in 1905, his father took on a new position at the yorkshire daily observer in london and the family moved to a house called carlton lodge in west dulwich.
after relocating to herne hill in 1908, wheeler, at the age of 15, was encouraged to pursue his education independently.
he spent his time in london visiting art galleries like the national gallery and the victoria and albert museum.
in october 1917, wheeler joined the 76th army field artillery brigade, part of the royal field artillery units led by the general officer commanding, third army.
the brigade was stationed in belgium at the time, involved in the battle of passchendaele on the western front against german forces.
wheeler assumed command of an artillery battery upon arrival, stepping in for a major incapacitated by mustard gas.
his role as acting major placed him in the left group of artillery supporting advancing allied infantry in the battle.
he stayed in touch with his family through letters during this time.
following the allies' success in the battle, the brigade was relocated to italy.
shortly after starting at the museum, wheeler was chosen to serve on the council of the society of antiquaries.
he became part of discussions on financing archaeological oversight of construction projects in greater london, advocating for the city of london corporation to provide funding.
however, it was ultimately decided in 1926 that the society would appoint its own excavation director based at lancaster house.
wheeler was also involved in the royal archaeological institute and played a role in moving it to lancaster house.
he began an unpaid teaching position at university college london in 1927, where he established a graduate program in archaeology, with one of the first students being stuart piggott.
wheeler curated an exhibit at ucl in 1928 titled "recent work in british archaeology," which garnered significant media coverage.
focusing on southern india, wheeler found remnants of a roman amphora in a museum and conducted excavations at arikamedu, uncovering a first-century ce port that traded goods with the roman empire.
despite facing challenges like heavy rains and heat during the dig, wheeler rewarded workers with an extra rupee when world war ii ended.
some claim wheeler took undue credit for the discovery, suggesting it was previously recognized by a.
wheeler later excavated six megalithic tombs in brahmagiri, mysore, allowing him to establish a chronology for much of southern indian archaeology.
as his marriage deteriorated and his wife returned to england, he wanted to end his stay in india early but worried about his financial future, so he urgently sought a new job.
with the help of colleagues in british archaeology, he was offered a position as the secretary of the royal commission on ancient monuments for wales.
although he was disappointed by the lower professional status and income, he declined the offer and instead accepted a role as a professor in roman provinces archaeology at the institute of archaeology.
moreover, he was invited to serve as the archaeological adviser to the pakistani government by the minister of education.
he agreed on the condition that he would only be required to spend a few months in the country each year for the next three years.
the species can be found all over the world, excluding very cold regions.
it is abundant in temperate and tropical areas and has been observed in various continents including africa, asia, australia, europe, north america, and south america.
in traditional chinese medicine, earthstar has been utilized as a hemostatic agent, where the spore dust is applied externally to stop bleeding wounds and alleviate chilblains.
the baiga and bharia tribes from the forests of madhya pradesh in india have also been known to use the fruit bodies of this fungus for medicinal purposes.
they mix the spore mass with mustard seed oil to create a salve that helps treat burns.
similarly, the blackfoot tribe in north america referred to the fungus as "fallen stars," viewing them as stars that had descended to the earth during mystical occurrences.

jim spigelman, the chairman of abc, strongly criticized the federal government's proposed anti-discrimination law, contending that it could jeopardize freedom of speech.
spigelman, a former chief justice of new south wales, argued that the inclusion of the term "offending" in the definition of discrimination lacked justification.
the legislation aims to streamline various anti-discrimination laws, notably in areas such as racial discrimination, which prohibits offensive treatment.
the new law broadens the concept of "offending" to encompass all forms of discrimination.
during an address on human rights day, spigelman highlighted that existing commonwealth acts on sex, disability, and age discrimination did not address conduct that was solely offensive.
he emphasized the vital role of the freedom to offend in safeguarding freedom of speech, stating, "there is no inherent right to not be offended." spigelman underscored that neither international human rights agreements nor anti-discrimination laws in other democratic nations extended to actions that were merely deemed offensive.

historian james holland delves into the harrowing tale of the battle for malta, a pivotal and exceedingly brutal chapter of the second world war.
malta, a diminutive mediterranean island smaller than the isle of wight, bore the brunt of relentless bombings between 1940 and 1942, surpassing the blitz on britain.
enduring incessant airstrikes and dire living conditions, the maltese people teetered on the brink of starvation amidst axis forces' relentless assault.
king george vi's personal acknowledgment of their resilience led to the awarding of the george cross to the entire island.
however, holland posits in his documentary that malta's offensive significance has been overshadowed.
positioned at the heart of a fierce british-german struggle for dominance in the mediterranean's shipping lanes, by 1942, malta had earned the dubious honor of being the most heavily bombed place on the planet.
despite its small size, the intensity of attacks underscored the island's strategic importance, as it held the key to the entire mediterranean and north african theater of war.
recent migrants in australia often face high levels of ethnic or religious discrimination, as indicated by a comprehensive new survey.
despite the prevailing stereotype of australians being caring and hospitable, the reality for many migrants is quite different according to the research conducted by monash university.
this study comes at a crucial time as the abbott government plans to amend aspects of the racial discrimination law.
the findings of the survey, set to be published on monday, shed light on the fears of many migrants about personal safety, with concerns such as walking alone at night or becoming victims of crime being prevalent.
the survey, part of the ongoing series "mapping social cohesion" supported by the scanlon foundation and the federal government, marks a significant step in understanding the experiences of recent migrants in comparison to the broader australian population.
it reveals that migrants who have arrived in the past two decades often feel targeted due to their skin color or religious beliefs, leading to a notable lack of trust in both fellow individuals and governmental institutions unlike the wider population.
the incessant barking of the neighbors' dog persists even as they leave the house, as if they have a routine to switch him on.
despite my attempt to drown out the noise by closing all windows and playing a beethoven symphony at full volume, his barking remains audible underneath the music.
it's as if he has now become a part of the orchestra, confidently barking throughout the piece.
even when the symphony ends, the dog continues to bark from his spot in the oboe section, capturing the attention of the conductor and the rest of the musicians, turning his persistent barking into a legendary, avant-garde solo that defines beethoven's innovative genius.

the chick evans caddie scholarship is an esteemed program that offers a full tuition and housing college scholarship for golf caddies, which can be renewed for up to four years.
annually, over 960 deserving caddies nationwide are granted a four-year scholarship by the evans scholars foundation.
successful candidates are required to showcase a solid caddie background, exceptional academic performance, remarkable character, and verifiable financial need.
since its inception in 1930 with the enrollment of the first two evans scholars at northwestern university, over 10,830 exceptional individuals have been honored with evans scholarships.
the majority of scholars attend one of the 16 universities housing an evans scholars foundation scholarship house.
these scholarship houses provide a unique environment where scholars reside and collaborate, electing officers, organizing social and service events, and engaging in campus activities.
the chapters are recognized for their academic excellence and community involvement, facilitating the development of leadership skills and effective communication among evans scholars.
the success of the 16 evans scholarship chapters is credited largely to the camaraderie and empowerment fostered through chapter living.
compared to other campus organizations, the scholarship houses consistently excel in academics and community service.
additionally, evans scholars reside in designated residence halls at five additional universities.

multiple research studies have highlighted the potential antibacterial properties of melaleuca alternifolia, commonly known as tea tree essential oil.
the study discussed here aimed to replicate a 2004 in vitro experiment in humans by using a dressing model over petri dishes to evaluate the antimicrobial effects of tea tree essential oil vapors.
for this current study, the same dressing model was applied to patients with wounds infected by staphylococcus aureus.
ten individuals participated in this quasi-experimental research, with four of them paired up to compare healing times when receiving conventional treatment alone or supplemented with tea tree oil vapors.
the findings revealed quicker healing times in most participants treated with tea tree oil, showing significant differences between the matched pairs.
these initial results suggest the need for further investigation through larger-scale studies.

the tail anatomy of unenlagiid theropods is not well understood, with the most comprehensive and informative specimen being buitreraptor gonzalezorum from the upper cretaceous of rio negro province, argentina.
this study aims to analyze the tail anatomy of buitreraptor using both the holotype and a newly discovered specimen.
shared characteristics between buitreraptor, rahonavis, anchiornis, and archaeopteryx include mid-caudal vertebrae with postzygapophyses longer than prezygapophyses, as well as mid-caudal centra with a system of lateral laminae and concavities.
examination of paravian skeletons and muscular reconstruction reveals the presence of two distinct functional sections in the tail.
this research illuminates the evolution of paravian tails and offers new insights into the tail modifications that occurred along the theropod lineage leading to modern birds.

a recent gallup poll shows that a significant portion of the population in states like illinois and connecticut express the desire to relocate, with around half of the residents considering a move.
conversely, states such as hawaii, montana, and maine show much lower percentages of residents inclined to leave.
in alabama, the sentiment is notably different with only 31 percent indicating a desire to move, tied with florida for the lowest in the southern region.
when looking at the preference to stay, 69 percent of alabamians and 67 percent of floridians expressed their commitment to remaining in their states.
states like kentucky, tennessee, and arkansas displayed slightly more favorable responses compared to the national average, while mississippi and georgia had higher percentages of residents contemplating a move.
the overall trend in the southern states aligns closely with the national average, where approximately one-third of the population entertains the idea of relocating.
on the contrary, states like maine, montana, and hawaii have lower percentages of residents willing to move if given the opportunity.
additional states like oregon, texas, and new hampshire also exhibited similar reluctance to relocate.
in contrast, states such as louisiana, massachusetts, new york, new jersey, rhode island, nevada, and maryland have more than 40 percent of residents interested in moving away.
states like connecticut and illinois are on the lower end of the spectrum, with less than half of their residents indicating they would remain if the option to move presented itself.

windows 10 home users do not have the option to disable automatic updates for the operating system.
however, users of windows 10 professional can choose to defer updates, allowing them to postpone updates for approximately four months.
microsoft has introduced a tool that permits users to hide certain updates and drivers from windows update if they are causing installation problems.
this tool guides users through the process of concealing updates to prevent them from being automatically reinstalled.
users can also use the same tool to reveal the hidden patches once they have been updated by microsoft.
it is unclear from the download information how long the updates can remain hidden, but it is likely not a permanent solution.
the tool is designed to address temporary issues, and users are advised to unhide updates once microsoft resolves the associated problems.
it is unlikely that this troubleshooter allows users to block every windows 10 patch, as this would contradict microsoft's policy of automatic updates for windows 10 home users.
overall, this tool is intended to assist with temporary issues and should be used accordingly.

melvyn bragg and his guests delve into the timeless tale of tristan and iseult, which originated in the 12th century through the works of thomas of britain, beroul, gottfried of strasbourg, and wagner.
tristan and iseult's story, deeply rooted in celtic mythology, gained immense popularity during the middle ages.
originating in british literature shortly after the norman conquest, the narrative quickly transcended borders across northern europe.
the legend follows the fateful encounter of tristan, a cornish knight, and iseult, an irish queen, who accidentally consume a love potion while journeying together to cornwall on the same vessel.
despite being betrothed to tristan's king, mark, tristan and iseult's love is deemed heroic yet poses moral dilemmas regarding their adultery, particularly amidst the strict teachings of the medieval church.
guests discussing this captivating story include laura ashe, associate professor of english at worcester college, university of oxford; juliette wood, associate lecturer in the school of welsh at cardiff university; and mark chinca, reader in medieval german literature at the university of cambridge.
the segment is produced by simon tillotson.
pope francis has given his approval for the establishment of a new vatican department dedicated to addressing cases involving bishops who neglect to safeguard children from abusive priests.
this historic decision represents a significant advancement in the vatican's efforts to hold bishops responsible for concealing or failing to prevent instances of child sexual abuse within the catholic church.
the vatican announced that pope francis endorsed the recommendations put forth by his advisory board on sexual abuse.
comprising nine men and eight women, including clerics and lay individuals, the international commission's mandate is to aid dioceses in implementing preventative measures and supporting victims, ensuring the adoption of "best practices." advocacy groups for victims have persistently called for the vatican to introduce transparent protocols that promote bishops' accountability for abuse within their dioceses, irrespective of their direct involvement.
although no bishop has been forcibly removed for shielding offending clergy before, pope francis accepted the resignation of a us bishop in april following his conviction for negligence in reporting a suspected child abuser.

we extend our gratitude for dan dodge's significant contributions to both qnx and blackberry, guiding a startup to become a prominent figure in embedded software.
following dan's retirement, john wall, who played a crucial role in qnx's success as chief operating officer, will assume the position of senior vice president and head of qnx.

in a statement to the publication, dodge remarked, "my decision to depart was personal." he added, "i organized a farewell gathering, inviting all my colleagues from qnx over the past 35 years, and we celebrated together." the roots of qnx date back to 1980 when dan dodge and gordon bell initiated the project as students at the university of waterloo.
by 1982, the inaugural version of qnx was unveiled.
in 2004, qnx software systems was acquired by harman international industries, with a strong presence in the automotive sector for telematics systems.
eventually, on april 9, 2010, research in motion acquired qnx and utilized it to power blackberry's playbook, blackberry 10, the blackberry iot platform, and expanded its reach into diverse fields like medical devices, industrial automation, network routers, critical applications, and notably, the automotive industry, with its integration into over 50 million vehicles.

during a summer internship focusing on astrophysics, monash undergraduate amelia fraser-mckelvie made a remarkable breakthrough by contributing to the resolution of a longstanding scientific enigma.
the mystery revolved around the discrepancy in mass of the visible universe compared to what was thought to be present based on celestial bodies like planets and stars.
scientists believed that a significant portion of the universe's mass was undetectable, leading to the conjecture that approximately half of the necessary mass was unaccounted for.
this missing mass conundrum prompted amelia's investigation, which eventually led to a groundbreaking discovery that has implications for enhancing telescopic advancements in australia.
collaborating with monash astrophysicists kevin pimbblet and jasmina lazendic-galloway, the 22-year-old aerospace engineering student, amelia fraser-mckelvie, successfully pinpointed some of this elusive mass, offering a crucial insight into the workings of the universe.
my neighborhood food basics grocery store carries spanish chorizo, which i have been enjoying incorporating into various dishes lately.
chorizo has gained significant popularity, with countless recipes featuring this sausage available online and on television.
there are two primary varieties of chorizo, each with distinct characteristics that are essential to understand when cooking with it.
spanish and portuguese chorizo are typically crafted with chunks of pork and are cured.
throughout europe, various sausages are cured, with each region boasting its own unique type such as german salami, italian capicola, and spanish chorizo.
spanish chorizo can be diced or sliced and utilized in cooking similarly to ham.
on the other hand, mexican chorizo is raw and consists of ground or minced pork.
when working with mexican chorizo, it is crucial to ensure thorough cooking.
one can cook the chorizo first, then proceed to slice and dice it for use in the dish being prepared.
alternatively, one can extract the raw chorizo meat from the casings and incorporate it into dishes akin to how italian sausage is used.
the following recipe highlights a popular method of enjoying chorizo: paired with eggs.
chorizo and scrambled eggs complement each other perfectly, making a delightful combo for a special breakfast taco that will undoubtedly elevate your morning meal.
in 1884, near tantanoola in south australia's southeast, there was a purported escape of a bengal tiger from a passing circus.
despite a search effort, the tiger remained elusive.
following the incident, a series of sheep disappearances occurred in the vicinity, leading to speculations that they might have fallen prey to the missing tiger.
it wasn't until eleven years later that a local resident, tom donovan, mistook an animal he encountered in a paddock as the bengal tiger attacking a sheep and fired his gun, only to discover it was actually a eurasian wolf—an unexpected presence in the australian setting.
believed to have been a stowaway on a shipwrecked vessel, the wolf made its way ashore.
the wolf, posthumously identified, was preserved and is currently exhibited at the tantanoola hotel.
surprisingly, sheep continued to vanish from the area for a long period afterward.
a law enforcement officer from adelaide eventually intervened, investigating and apprehending a local individual for sheep theft.

given the opportunity presented by 'car sos' from the national geographic channel, we were entrusted with the task of restoring two cars for the third season of this highly acclaimed tv series.
one of the vehicles we worked on during this season was a 1963 alfa romeo giulia spider.
initially, the car seemed to be in decent condition, but upon closer inspection, we were surprised by the amount of underseal and filler present underneath.
to address this, we took the precaution of stripping the shell and arranging for it to undergo a chemical dipping process.
upon the shell's return, we discovered extensive repair work that had been performed on the car throughout its years on the road, with numerous patches and subpar welds evident.
working with the bare metal enabled us to efficiently carry out the necessary fabrication work, compensating for the time lost during the chemical treatment.
we ensured a comprehensive restoration by solidly welding the body and installing a new front panel before meticulously preparing the surfaces for the bianco pininfarina paint application.

the finishing touches with the trim were expertly executed by aldridge in walsall.
exploring the challenges faced by individuals surviving in extreme altitudes, where nature's harshness is at its peak, from dense cloud forests to barren summits.
as elevation increases on the mountain, life becomes more demanding.
the documentary human planet delves into the remarkable strategies employed by people to endure these unforgiving environments.
for instance, in the altai mountains of western mongolia, the vast terrain makes hunting difficult, leading locals to form a remarkable alliance with golden eagles, enlisting them for assistance in hunting.
meanwhile, in the rugged cliffs of ethiopia's simien mountains, we witness a young boy engaged in a fierce confrontation with intimidating gelada monkeys intent on pillaging his family's scarce grain reserves.
additionally, in nepal's himalayan region, a rare and unique sky burial ritual is observed.
as timber for cremation is scarce and traditional burial methods unfeasible, the deceased are consigned to vultures as a profound tribute to nature's cycle.

imagine trying to operate a computer without a monitor.
how would you navigate where to click, type, or visualize the images on your screen?
these are genuine struggles faced by individuals who are blind or visually impaired.
for many of us, contemplating using a computer or accessing the internet without sight may be unfamiliar territory.
despite being somewhat disconnected from the conventional internet experience, visually impaired individuals find ways to utilize it just like everyone else.
although using computers without sight presents difficulties, the innovative solutions that have been developed are impressive and continuously improving.
recent technological advancements such as smartphones, wearables, and smart devices offer great potential to benefit the visually impaired community even more than the sighted.
however, without assistance from sighted individuals, many online functions that we take for granted may remain inaccessible to those who are visually impaired.
the first essential step towards change is to understand these challenges.
embark on a journey through an unseen aspect of the web, led by those who possess the most insightful perspectives.

according to a team of european researchers, the belief that cyclists doping with epo gain a performance advantage is unfounded.
despite the health risks involved, there is no concrete evidence supporting the idea that epo enhances cyclists' performance.
following lance armstrong's disqualification from his tour de france titles due to doping, including epo use, it has been highlighted that using this drug illicitly can lead to severe health issues like blood clots resulting in strokes and heart attacks.
adam cohen, a professor at the centre for human drug research in the netherlands, emphasizes the lack of scientific experiments proving epo's performance benefits in elite cyclists, cautioning against the widespread misconception in the field.

this number has increased by approximately 3,000 compared to the august statistics, though there has been a decline in the waiting list for gastrointestinal assessments.

additionally, 438,267 people were on the list to be seen at outpatient clinics, a rise of more than 3,000 from august.

he acknowledged that waiting lists continue to pose a significant challenge, emphasizing the importance of prioritizing those with the longest wait times.

human beings are dual in nature, possessing both physical and psychological aspects, each revealing distinct implications in the realm of business.
the basic demands of individuals have driven the establishment of large corporations in contemporary society.
these extensive multinational entities have thrived by catering to our essential necessities such as clothing, food, shelter, communication, and transportation.
conversely, the psychological facets of human beings, albeit significant, have not significantly impacted the business world.
unlike the extensive corporations meeting material needs, there are limited commercial ventures dedicated to guiding individuals towards the essence of life, fostering benevolence, or ushering them through various life stages.
professionals such as therapists, poets, artists, and intellectuals who delve into the psychological realm often work independently and harbor skepticism towards organizational structures, rendering them akin to small-scale operations.
experts predict that fixed prices for consumer goods and services will become increasingly rare within the next five years, due to a pricing revolution inspired by uber's dynamic pricing model spreading throughout the uk.
this shift towards "peak time" pricing, where costs fluctuate based on demand, is expected to be widely adopted in supermarkets, petrol stations, and on energy bills.
replacing traditional paper price tags, these "e-prices" are directly linked to retailers' computer systems, allowing for adjustments of up to 90% in a single day.
this technology enables stores to swiftly respond to market changes by adjusting prices, such as removing discounts on popular items like ice creams and chilled drinks during heatwaves, or sandwiches during lunchtime.
though this practice is already established in europe and the us, its potential introduction in the uk may provoke a reaction from cost-conscious consumers who are becoming increasingly mindful of their expenditures.

extensive research has focused on investigating the relationship between a specific polymorphism in the promoter region of the maoa gene and antisocial behavior patterns.
these studies consistently indicate that males exposed to childhood maltreatment with low-activity maoa alleles are more likely to exhibit antisocial tendencies.
recently, new evidence has surfaced suggesting that the rare 2-repeat allele of the maoa gene may influence violent behaviors regardless of environmental factors.
the latest study further explores this concept by examining how the 2-repeat allele is linked to shooting and stabbing behaviors in a cohort of males sourced from the national longitudinal study of adolescent health.
findings demonstrate a notable association between african-american males carrying the 2-repeat allele and the increased likelihood of engaging in shooting and stabbing behaviors, as well as reporting multiple victims.
the study's constraints are deliberated, and recommendations for future investigations are proposed.

this paper, written on april 22, 2016, delves into the institutional factors influencing persecution by examining the severity of black death pogroms in the holy roman empire.
the authors assert that political fragmentation worsened rent-seeking behavior in the empire, resulting in heightened persecutions endured by jewish communities during the black death.
their hypothesis is tested using data on pogrom intensity, historical trade routes, and political and ecclesiastical boundaries.
consistent with their thesis, the study reveals that areas in close proximity to archbishoprics, bishoprics, and imperial free cities witnessed more severe and violent persecutions compared to regions under imperial governance.
the paper also deliberates on the implications of these findings for upholding the rule of law in vulnerable states.

this design was actually inspired by a reddit suggestion.
the concept involved creating a unique greatsword capable of launching a shuriken by swinging the blade.
in its sword form, it appears as a typical greatsword-style weapon.
however, it transforms in its secondary form by separating the blades, enabling a shuriken stored at the base to be propelled out with the momentum of the swing.
the intriguing aspect of this weapon is the shuriken itself, which is connected to the sword through a cable that extends up to 20m upon release.
initially compacted, the shuriken expands into a weaponized form once ejected from the blade.
the retractable cable allows the shuriken to be pulled back into the sword after use, with the option to extend its reach by stopping the retraction just before it fully returns.
this extended shuriken can enhance the swing reach of the sword and can be utilized to catch opponents, enabling the user to manipulate the retracting force to either draw in the enemy or reposition themselves.
additionally, the shuriken can serve as a grappling hook by adjusting the blade angles for optimal ledge-catching abilities.
the sword is equipped to store 2 spare shurikens and can disengage the cable from the loaded shuriken in critical situations, where the spares act as emergency backups should the primary shuriken be incapacitated or unretrievable.

new hope academy, to be housed in an office building at 3250 n.
arlington heights road, just south of dundee road, will make the move before the commencement of the 2017-18 school year in august.
brandy larrance, the school's executive director, confirmed the move.
established in 2000, the school serves students with special needs from 35 suburban school districts, encompassing northwest suburban high school district 214, palatine-schaumburg high school district 211, as well as districts in gurnee, naperville, and yorkville.
currently, there are 65 students enrolled at the school's current location at 6289 howard st.
in niles, with plans to increase enrollment to 80 with the relocation to arlington heights.
new hope academy is set to occupy 18,000 square feet within the 73,000-square-foot, multi-tenant office building, which is predominantly vacant.
the school's facilities in the new location will consist of 12 classrooms, an art studio, gym, cafeteria, staff lounge, and offices.
recently, the village board granted approval for a land use variation to facilitate the move.
new hope academy intends to enhance the landscaping surrounding the property prior to moving in.

it was during this trip that i was introduced to horchata- a delightful blend of creaminess, sweetness, and refreshment, particularly welcome in the scorching summer climate.
ever since that memorable experience, i have attempted to recreate it using various powders and boxed rice milks without success, until i chanced upon a recipe that instantly transported me back to juarez.
this recipe is believed to be highly authentic, incorporating evaporated milk for an indulgently creamy texture.
i assure you, your loved ones will be astounded by the results!
the ingredients required for this recipe are readily available and cost-effective.
one essential item you will need is a cheesecloth, typically found in the baking section of most supermarkets.
for those avoiding dairy, the horchata can still be enjoyed without the evaporated milk; simply adjust the sugar content to approximately 1 cup, or to suit your preference.

this marks the completion of the initial phase of the resettlement program initiated by the liberal government shortly after assuming office.
the event was not widely celebrated at the time, but immigration minister john mccallum is set to provide an update on the program in toronto on monday, detailing the future steps of the program.
government officials from citizenship and immigration canada had been expecting to reach this milestone over the weekend, despite the uncertainty of the exact timing due to varying refugee numbers per flight.
achieving the 25,000-refugee target is a significant accomplishment for the liberal government, fulfilling an election promise to resettle individuals fleeing the syrian civil war.
initially aiming to achieve this goal by the end of 2015, the deadline was extended to the end of february after the government came into power.
of the 25,000 newcomers, over half will have their expenses covered by the government in the first year, while the rest will receive support from private organizations or a combination of both.
in the following days, the new arrivals will disperse across eight provinces, joining those who have been resettled in canada since the launch of the syrian refugee plan in november.

achieving a consistent 90 fps in vr poses a considerable challenge, but this presentation introduces a novel approach to dynamically adjusting graphics quality to ensure vr framerate remains stable without resorting to reprojection techniques.
this method is effective even on low-end gpus, while still offering the flexibility to enhance rendering quality on high-end gpus and multi-gpu setups.
for instance, valve's aperture robot repair vr demo at gdc 2015 necessitated an nvidia 980 for consistent framerate, whereas this discussion will showcase how the same experience can now maintain 90 fps on an nvidia 680, an aging gpu model.
the outcome is an engine that sustains a heightened level of fidelity, a reduced gpu minimum specification, expanded capabilities for art assets, and a framework that empowers developers to shift their focus from fps optimization to enhancing renderer quality and performance, all the while ensuring framerate stability.

teifi, a vegetarian, unpasteurized cheese hailing from wales, is organically crafted by the caws teifi cheese company founded by john and patrice savage-ontswedder.
reminiscent of gouda, this semi-hard cheese boasts a vibrant sunshine-yellow interior.
teifi comes in various iterations, distinguished by its aging process.
in its youth, it offers a gentle, slightly sweet taste with a velvety, creamy consistency.
with age, teifi transforms into a robust, flaky cheese akin to parmesan, maturing over a span of two to nine months.
infused with ingredients like nettles, seaweed, garlic, onion, sweet pepper, and cumin, each variety imparts a unique flavor profile.
a smoked version of teifi is also available.
when melted, teifi takes on a stringy texture, making it a delectable addition when used for heating, toasting, or topping pizzas.

friedrich nietzsche, the renowned philosopher of the 19th century, stood out as a brilliant yet controversial figure.
his unyielding and often harsh concepts shattered the conventional beliefs in religion, morality, and science.
in his world, devoid not only of god but also of much of what defines humanity, the starkness and innovation of his post-religious views were striking.
bettany hughes delves into the convictions of a man whose philosophical work has been widely misconstrued and manipulated.
nietzche's aversion to structured systems and a quest for absolute truths rendered his ideas enigmatic and at times inconsistent.
this ambiguity made room for varying interpretations, allowing his ideologies, which cautioned against totalitarian political systems, to be distorted to serve such ends.
despite his vocal stance against anti-semitism, his efforts were tarnished by the actions of his anti-semitic sister, who portrayed him as a champion of hitler's aryan agenda.
opposing nationalism, he unwittingly became associated with a regime he would have detested.
while nietzsche's philosophical journey led him to isolation and ultimately madness, his concepts significantly influenced the modern intellectual paradigm.
the first high-resolution climate modelling for the future predicts that sydney and the wider region of nsw will experience more hot days, changing rainfall patterns, and heightened fire risks due to global warming.
collaborative efforts between the nsw and act governments and researchers at the university of nsw's climate change research centre have developed scenarios for grids measuring 100 square kilometers up to 2030 and 2070 across eastern australia, spanning from south-east queensland to the eastern half of south australia.
the updated models show an increase in extreme fire weather days during spring and summer throughout most parts of the state.
previous models erroneously equated sydney's climate with more inland towns like bathurst, but the new findings confirm that temperatures will rise across nsw.
as stated by matthew riley, director of climate and atmospheric science at the office of environment and heritage, there will be a decrease in cold days, particularly along the great dividing range.

the compact grill is designed to accommodate charcoal briquettes, with a recommended placement approximately a quarter inch below the underside of the grill to account for the briquettes' thickness.
assembly begins by attaching the legs.
insert all four screws through the designated holes, securing them in place with nuts.
only fully thread one nut initially, leaving it slightly loose.
proceed by positioning the grill on the legs and loosely threading another nut halfway down.
for the remaining legs, partially screw the nuts in, align them with the grill's holes, then push them through and secure them with an end nut.

whether your goal is weight loss or toning up, incorporating weight training into your exercise regimen is highly beneficial.
however, for beginners, it can be intimidating not knowing where to begin.
fortunately, anna renderer, a popsugar fitness host and personal trainer, has devised a beginner-friendly dumbbell circuit workout to alleviate any apprehensions.
anna recommends performing two consecutive moves to really feel the workout's intensity.
the circuit consists of completing the first move 10 times to finish one set, then repeating the second move 10 times to complete another set.

in the first step, use a food processor to chop the onions, then add the garlic and ginger and process until finely chopped.
moving on to step 2, heat vegetable oil in a medium, enameled cast-iron casserole.
add coriander, cumin, cayenne, cinnamon, cloves, and cardamom, and cook over low heat until fragrant, approximately 1 minute.
stir in the onion mixture and cook over high heat, stirring occasionally until golden brown, around 6 minutes.
next, add turmeric and tomato sauce, and simmer over moderately high heat, stirring occasionally until slightly thickened, about 3 minutes.
finally, season the chicken breasts with salt, then add them to the casserole.
coat the chicken with the sauce, pour in water, cover, and bring to a boil.
let it simmer over low heat, turning occasionally, until the chicken is fully cooked and white throughout, approximately 10 minutes.
season the chicken curry with salt as needed.

it has been a widely held belief that human brain evolution led to the enlargement of the frontal lobes; however, our research challenges this assumption.
by analyzing five distinct data sets using correctly scaled measures and phylogenetic methods, we have found that the size of human frontal lobes and specific frontal regions is in line with the size of other brain structures.
claims of relative enlargement of human frontal white matter volume and similarities across all great apes appear to be inaccurate.
our study also indicates that the rate of change in relative frontal cortex volume in the human evolutionary branch was not exceptional, with other branches exhibiting significantly faster rates of change.
while absolute and proportional frontal region size did increase rapidly in humans, this growth was closely linked to corresponding size increases in other brain areas and whole brain size, alongside decreases in frontal neuron densities.
therefore, investigations into the neural basis of human cognitive distinctiveness should shift focus from the frontal lobes in isolation to consider distributed neural networks.

new images obtained from nasa's earth observatory have revealed the ongoing decline of the aral sea, marking the devastating aftermath of the soviet-era decision to redirect the lake's tributaries for agricultural purposes.
this catastrophe has resulted in the escalation of salinity levels and chemical pollution, exacerbating the environmental crisis.
once recognized as the world's fourth-largest lake, the aral sea now stands as a colossal toxic wasteland straddling kazakhstan and uzbekistan, former soviet territories in central asia.
these recent satellite images exhibit the alarming retreat of the lake's waters over the past 14 years, culminating in the complete desiccation of the eastern portion of the south aral sea, formerly the lake's central body.
prior to the 1960s, the aral sea thrived due to inflows from the amu darya and syr darya rivers, sourced from mountain snowmelt and local precipitation.
however, the soviet union's diversion of these vital water sources for agricultural irrigation initiated the lake's demise, triggering a decline in water levels and an uptick in salinity.
additionally, the use of fertilizers and chemicals only intensified the environmental degradation, contaminating the exposed lakebed and leading to soil dispersion onto nearby farmlands.
consequently, this escalation in water depletion caused drastic shifts in the local climate, as evidenced by harsher winters and sweltering summers attributed to the absence of the moderating influence of the once-massive body of water, as outlined in a recent report from the earth observatory.
